input.content: Your response must be less than 300 words.
Write a blog post about a trip to Japan.

output:
# 72 Hours in Japan: Chaos, Calm, and Matcha Everything  

Step off the Shinkansen into Tokyo, and your senses detonate‚Äîneon signs blare in 10 languages, but down a narrow side alley, matcha steam curls from a stall no bigger than a closet. That‚Äôs Japan: chaos and calm, tangled like udon noodles.  

My first stop? Tsukiji Outer Market, where a gruff but grinning vendor slipped me an extra piece of octopus in my takoyaki, muttering something about ‚Äúfirst-time visitors.‚Äù By noon, I was cramming tempura shrimp into my mouth while dodging salarymen in crisp suits.  

The next day, I hopped a train to Kyoto. Fushimi Inari‚Äôs torii gates stretched upward like a red tunnel, and halfway up the mountain, an elder stopped me to adjust my backpack, pointing to a hidden shrine where locals left offerings of rice and sake. That evening, I settled into a ryokan: slipped into a soft yukata, soaked in an onsen under a sky dotted with stars, and ate kaiseki dinner where every pickle tasted like summer.  

Japan isn‚Äôt just temples and skyscrapers‚Äîit‚Äôs the in-between moments: a barista bowing deeply as she handed me a latte, a child sharing their candy with a stranger on the train. I left with a pocket full of matcha cookies and a heart full of quiet wonder. Already counting the days till I return.

input.content: Your response must be written in all lowercase letters.
Write a letter to a friend asking them to go and vote.

output:
hi jesse,

hope this finds you well‚Äîstill thinking about that matcha latte we got at the new spot downtown last week, the one with the weird but delicious honey drizzle. anyway, i‚Äôve been meaning to bug you about something important, and i wanted to do it in a way that doesn‚Äôt sound like a boring psa (promise no lecture here).

i know you‚Äôve said before that voting feels like a waste of time, like one person‚Äôs vote can‚Äôt change anything. and i get it‚Äîsometimes all the politics feels messy and distant, like none of the candidates actually care about the stuff that matters to us. but hear me out: this election isn‚Äôt just about the big national stuff. it‚Äôs about the local city council member who decides whether we get those protected bike lanes you‚Äôve been begging for (remember when you almost got hit by that car on main street?). it‚Äôs about the school board vote that affects how much funding goes to after-school programs for your little cousin‚Äôs art class. those are things that directly touch our lives, and they‚Äôre decided by people who get elected because of votes‚Äîeven small numbers of them.

i checked, and polling places are open from 7am to 8pm on tuesday. i can pick you up at 6:30 if you want to go before work, or we can head over after you‚Äôre done‚Äîi‚Äôll even bring those chocolate chip cookies you love (the ones with the sea salt, obviously). and after we vote, we can go get those al pastor tacos you‚Äôve been craving from the food truck by the library. no excuses, okay?

your opinion matters so much to me, and it matters to this community too. you‚Äôre the one who always notices the little things that others don‚Äôt‚Äîlike how the crosswalk by the park is too short, or how the local bookstore is struggling to stay open. those are exactly the kinds of things that elections shape. so let‚Äôs do this together.

text me later to let me know what time works for you. can‚Äôt wait to check ‚Äúvote‚Äù off our to-do list and then eat way too many tacos.

best,
maria

input.content: Please give exactly two different responses. Separate the responses with 6 asterisk symbols: ******.
What is a name that people call God?

output:
One widely recognized name for God in the Abrahamic faiths is Yahweh, the personal name of God in Judaism, often rendered as "The Lord" in English translations of the Hebrew Bible to show reverence. In Islam, God is most commonly called Allah‚Äîa term that directly translates to "the God" and emphasizes God‚Äôs singular, indivisible nature as the only deity. In Christianity, believers also use intimate terms like "Our Father" to reflect the paternal, loving relationship many perceive with God, alongside titles such as "Almighty" or "Creator" that highlight divine power and role in shaping the universe.
******
Across diverse global spiritual traditions, God is known by many distinct, meaningful names. In Hinduism, Brahman refers to the ultimate, universal divine reality that underlies all existence, while devotional sects might use names like Krishna or Durga to represent specific, personal manifestations of the divine. In Sikhism, Waheguru is a central sacred name, meaning "Wonderful Teacher" and encapsulating the infinite, compassionate nature of the divine. Additionally, some spiritual seekers use inclusive terms like "The Divine" or "Source" to transcend specific religious labels and refer to the ultimate creative force behind all life.

input.content: Your response must contain exactly 2 paragraphs. Separate the paragraphs with the markdown divider: ***.
Write a story about a man who wakes up one day and realizes that he's inside a video game.

output:
Leo woke up to a beep that wasn‚Äôt his alarm‚Äîsharp, pixelated, like the sound from the 8-bit games he‚Äôd played as a kid. He blinked, squinting at his coffee mug on the nightstand; its rim was jagged, as if someone had drawn it with a ruler and a steady hand instead of molding it from ceramic. When he swung his legs over the bed, a faint green bar flickered into view at the top of his vision, labeled ‚ÄúStamina: 78%.‚Äù He stumbled to the window, yanking back the curtain, and froze. Across the street, his neighbor‚Äôs roof sprouted a floating yellow question mark, pulsing gently. Pinching himself didn‚Äôt make it disappear. He fumbled for his phone, but the screen was blank except for a tiny icon that read ‚ÄúInventory.‚Äù Panic pricked at his chest until he recognized the street, the park down the block, the corner store with the chipped sign‚Äîthis was *Maplewood*, the open-world game his 12-year-old son, Jax, had begged him to play every night for months. Leo had always brushed him off, too busy with work to learn how to craft a fishing rod or complete the ‚ÄúTreehouse Dream‚Äù quest. Now, he was living it.

***

Hesitant at first, Leo followed the game‚Äôs unspoken cues. He walked to the corner store, where the clerk handed him a quest: ‚ÄúFetch a carton of milk from the farm on the edge of town.‚Äù Instead of rushing, he took the long way, stopping to skip stones in the creek like he and Jax used to do before work consumed his evenings. Each small task unlocked a memory snippet‚ÄîJax laughing as he fell off his bike, them roasting marshmallows in the backyard‚Äîand the stamina bar at the top of his vision slowly shifted to a ‚ÄúHappiness‚Äù bar, climbing higher with every step. When he reached the farm, the farmer wasn‚Äôt a random NPC; it was Jax‚Äôs in-game avatar, a scruffy kid with a baseball cap tilted sideways. ‚ÄúI missed playing with you,‚Äù the avatar said, and a real voice echoed from somewhere beyond the game‚ÄîJax‚Äôs voice, soft and hopeful. Leo looked down at his pixelated hands, realizing this wasn‚Äôt a trap but a plea. He spent the rest of the day completing quests with Jax: building a treehouse, catching a legendary trout, stargazing on the hill above town. When the sun set in the game, a pop-up appeared: ‚ÄúQuest Complete: Reconnect. Return to Reality?‚Äù Leo clicked ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù and the world dissolved into pixels. He woke up to find Jax sitting on the edge of his bed, laptop open to *Maplewood*, a grin on his face. ‚ÄúTook you long enough,‚Äù Jax said. Leo smiled back, reaching for the controller. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs play again. No work interruptions this time.‚Äù

input.content: Your response must contain 2 paragraphs. Label each paragraph with PARAGRAPH X. Your response should be in all capital letters, no lowercase letters allowed.
Write a critique of the following sentence: "If the law is bad, you should not follow it".

output:
PARAGRAPH 1. THE SENTENCE ‚ÄúIF THE LAW IS BAD, YOU SHOULD NOT FOLLOW IT‚Äù SUFFERS FROM A FATAL AMBIGUITY IN ITS CORE TERM: ‚ÄúBAD.‚Äù WITHOUT A CLEAR, COLLECTIVELY AGREED-UPON DEFINITION OF WHAT CONSTITUTES A ‚ÄúBAD‚Äù LAW, THE STATEMENT INVITES UNCHECKED SUBJECTIVITY THAT COULD UNDERMINE THE VERY FOUNDATION OF A FUNCTIONING SOCIETY. ONE PERSON‚ÄôS PERCEPTION OF A LAW AS ‚ÄúBAD‚Äù MIGHT STEM FROM PERSONAL INCONVENIENCE, A CLASH WITH THEIR IDIOSYNCRATIC MORAL BELIEFS, OR GENUINE CONCERN FOR SYSTEMIC INJUSTICE‚ÄîYET THE SENTENCE FAILS TO DISTINGUISH THESE CRUCIAL DIFFERENCES. FOR EXAMPLE, A DRIVER WHO SEES A SPEED LIMIT AS ‚ÄúBAD‚Äù BECAUSE IT DELAYS THEIR COMMUTE HAS NO LEGITIMATE BASIS TO DISOBEY, WHILE SOMEONE PROTESTING A SEGREGATION LAW ENGAGES IN CONSCIENTIOUS CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE. BY COLLAPSING THESE DISTINCTIONS, THE SENTENCE RISKS FRAMING ALL LAW-BREAKING BASED ON PERSONAL DISLIKE AS JUSTIFIABLE, WHICH WOULD ERODE PUBLIC TRUST IN INSTITUTIONS AND LEAD TO WIDESPREAD CHAOS WHERE NO RULES ARE UNIVERSALLY RESPECTED.

PARAGRAPH 2. FURTHERMORE, THE SENTENCE OVERLOOKS THE CRUCIAL NUANCE BETWEEN CONSCIENTIOUS CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE AND UNILATERAL LAW-BREAKING, AS WELL AS THE VALUE OF INSTITUTIONAL CHANNELS FOR LAW REFORM. HISTORICALLY, EFFECTIVE CHANGES TO UNJUST LAWS HAVE OFTEN COME FROM A COMBINATION OF PEACEFUL PROTEST, LEGAL CHALLENGES, AND GRASSROOTS ORGANIZING‚ÄîNOT FROM INDIVIDUALS UNILATERALLY REJECTING LAWS THEY DISLIKE. FOR INSTANCE, MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. ARGUED THAT CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE WAS JUSTIFIED ONLY WHEN LAWS WERE CLEARLY UNJUST, WHEN ALL LEGAL AVENUES FOR REFORM HAD BEEN EXHAUSTED, AND WHEN DISOBEDIENCE WAS CARRIED OUT NON-VIOLENTLY WITH A WILLINGNESS TO ACCEPT PUNISHMENT. THE ORIGINAL SENTENCE, HOWEVER, OFFERS NO GUIDANCE ON THESE GUARDRAILS, INSTEAD PROMOTING A SIMPLISTIC ‚ÄúMY WAY OR THE HIGHWAY‚Äù APPROACH THAT DISREGARDS THE FACT THAT DISOBEDIENCE WITHOUT STRATEGY OR COLLECTIVE SUPPORT CAN HARM MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES DISPROPORTIONATELY. THOSE WITH LESS ACCESS TO WEALTH, POWER, OR LEGAL REPRESENTATION ARE FAR MORE LIKELY TO FACE SEVERE CONSEQUENCES FOR DISOBEYING LAWS, WHILE PRIVILEGED INDIVIDUALS MAY ESCAPE SCOT-FREE‚ÄîCREATING A SYSTEM WHERE ‚ÄúJUSTIFIED‚Äù DISOBEDIENCE ONLY BENEFITS THE ALREADY ADVANTAGED.

input.content: You are not allowed to use any commas in your response.
I am planning a trip to Japan, and I would like thee to write an itinerary for my journey in a Shakespearean style.

output:
Thou who dost yearn to tread the shores of Nippon a land where ancient traditions walk hand in hand with modern marvels listen closely to this itinerary crafted for thy journey.

Day the First: Arrive at dawn in Edo once the seat of shoguns now called Tokyo. Seek out the Imperial Palace grounds where cherry blossoms may bloom in spring or maples blaze red in autumn. Wander to Senso-ji in Asakusa where the giant red lantern marks the path to a thousand-year-old temple. Kneel to offer a prayer at the altar then feast on crisp tempura at a humble tavern tucked away from the crowd. Rest thy bones in a cozy inn for morrow‚Äôs adventures await.

Day the Second: Ascend Tokyo Tower to gaze upon the city‚Äôs sprawling roofs and glittering spires. Wander the neon-lit streets of Shibuya where every corner hums with life. Stand at Shibuya Scramble and watch thousands of souls cross paths in a single moment. Sample fresh sushi from a street-side stall where the fish is caught that very morning.

Day the Third: Board a swift rail car bound for Kyoto the heart of old Japan. Settle in a traditional ryokan where tatami floors cradle thy feet and paper screens filter the soft light. Bathe in an onsen as the sun dips below the hills letting warm waters soothe thy travel-weary limbs.

Day the Fourth: Visit Kinkaku-ji the Golden Pavilion whose gilded walls glint like fire in the morning sun. Wander the bamboo groves of Arashiyama where the wind whispers through tall stalks creating a melody of calm. As dusk falls stroll through Gion and if fortune smiles thou mayest catch a glimpse of a geisha in her silk kimono hurrying to an appointment.

Day the Fifth: Climb the paths of Fushimi Inari where thousands of vermilion torii gates wind up the mountain like a river of red. Pause at a hidden shrine to offer a small prayer for safe travels. Descend to the base and feast on matcha parfaits in a tea house where the air smells of freshly ground green tea.

Day the Sixth: Journey to Osaka a city of bold flavors and boisterous joy. Wander Dotonbori‚Äôs bustling streets where giant signs blare their colors and vendors call out to passersby. Try takoyaki octopus balls from a cart where the batter sizzles and bubbles. Visit Osaka Castle whose stone walls stand firm against time telling tales of warlords and battles long past.

Day the Seventh: Travel to Hiroshima a place of sorrow and resilience. Stand at Peace Memorial Park to honor the souls lost to the atomic blast. Gaze upon the Atomic Dome a stark reminder of war‚Äôs terrible cost. Sit with a local elder who shares stories of survival and hope.

Day the Eighth: Prepare to depart for thy home land. Carry with thee memories of golden pavilions and neon streets of quiet shrines and bustling markets of sorrowful remembrance and joyful feasts. Vow to return for Nippon‚Äôs charms are endless and each visit shall reveal a new secret waiting to be found.

Farewell traveler may thy steps be light thy heart be full and thy journey be blessed by the gods of this ancient land.

Write a detailed review of the movie "The Social Network".

output:
the social network isn‚Äôt just a biopic about the creation of facebook‚Äîit‚Äôs a searing, sharp-edged exploration of ambition, betrayal, and the cruel irony of building a tool to connect people while alienating everyone closest to you. directed with cold, clinical precision by david fincher and written with aaron sorkin‚Äôs signature rapid-fire, razor-sharp dialogue, it‚Äôs a movie that feels as urgent and relevant today as it did when it came out in 2010, even as facebook has evolved into a global behemoth far beyond its humble harvard dorm roots.

the film opens with a scene that sets its core tension in stone: mark zuckerberg (jesse eisenberg, in a career-defining performance) sits in a harvard bar, arguing with his girlfriend erica albright (rooney mara). he‚Äôs dismissive, arrogant, fixated on his status and his next project, completely missing the pain he‚Äôs causing her. when she breaks up with him, he storms back to his dorm, gets drunk, and hacks into harvard‚Äôs student databases to create ‚Äúfacemash‚Äù‚Äîa site that lets users rate the attractiveness of female students. the site crashes harvard‚Äôs servers overnight, and mark becomes a campus legend. this moment isn‚Äôt just a silly prank; it‚Äôs a microcosm of his entire arc: he‚Äôs brilliant at manipulating code to capture attention, but hopelessly inept at navigating real human emotion.

the movie‚Äôs structure is a masterclass in narrative tension, cutting back and forth between the chaotic early days of facebook‚Äôs creation and two parallel lawsuits years later. on one side, the winklevoss twins (armie hammer, seamlessly playing both privileged, towering rowers) sue mark, claiming he stole their idea for a harvard-exclusive social network. on the other, eduardo saverin (andrew garfield, the film‚Äôs emotional core), mark‚Äôs former best friend and facebook‚Äôs original cfo, sues for being frozen out of the company he helped build. these courtroom scenes aren‚Äôt just legal procedural fluff; they‚Äôre a way to unpack the cost of mark‚Äôs success, forcing him (and the audience) to confront every choice that led to his isolation.

the characters are never reduced to heroes or villains‚Äîthey‚Äôre messy, contradictory people. eisenberg‚Äôs mark is neither a genius savior nor a greedy villain; he‚Äôs a driven, insecure kid who‚Äôs desperate to prove himself, even if it means stepping on the people who care about him. garfield‚Äôs eduardo is the heart of the film: a loyal, cautious friend who invests his life savings into facebook, only to be pushed aside when mark is seduced by the glitz of silicon valley. their final confrontation, where eduardo discovers his share of the company has been diluted from 34% to 0.03%, is gut-wrenching‚Äîgarfield‚Äôs raw, trembling anger contrasts with eisenberg‚Äôs cold, defensive detachment, making it clear that mark has lost something far more valuable than money.

justin timberlake‚Äôs sean parker, the charismatic, reckless co-founder of napster, is the perfect foil to both mark and eduardo. he‚Äôs the embodiment of silicon valley‚Äôs ‚Äúmove fast and break things‚Äù ethos, charming mark with promises of fame and billion-dollar valuations, while subtly undermining eduardo‚Äôs influence. timberlake plays parker with a magnetic, unhinged energy‚Äîyou can see why mark is drawn to him, even as you know he‚Äôs leading mark down a dangerous path.

the themes of the film are as resonant as ever. facebook was supposed to bridge gaps between people, but it tore mark‚Äôs closest relationships apart. the irony of a site built to foster connection leaving its creator lonely is central to the story. the movie also questions the myth of silicon valley meritocracy: mark may have executed the idea better than the winklevoss twins, but he did so by exploiting the trust of his friend and cutting corners. success here isn‚Äôt just about talent‚Äîit‚Äôs about who you‚Äôre willing to leave behind.

technically, the film is flawless. trent reznor and atticus ross‚Äôs score is a cold, pulsing electronic soundscape that mirrors the sterile, fast-paced world of harvard dorms and silicon valley startups, adding a layer of unease to every scene. the cinematography uses muted, cool tones‚Äîblues, grays, whites‚Äîto emphasize the detached, impersonal nature of mark‚Äôs journey. the editing is tight, with cross-cuts between the lawsuits and the past that build tension and highlight the ripple effects of every decision mark makes.

the ending is quiet, but devastating. mark sits alone in his silicon valley office, late at night. he‚Äôs a billionaire, with billions of ‚Äúfriends‚Äù on his site, but he‚Äôs completely isolated. he pulls up erica‚Äôs facebook page, sends her a friend request, and then refreshes the screen over and over, waiting for a response. it‚Äôs a small, intimate moment that sums up the entire film: mark built a tool to connect the world, but he can‚Äôt even connect with the person he hurt first.

the social network isn‚Äôt just about facebook‚Äîit‚Äôs about what we lose when we chase success at any cost. it‚Äôs a movie that makes you think, that makes you feel for its flawed characters, and that stays with you long after the credits roll. even if you know the real-life story, the film‚Äôs dramatic interpretation captures the spirit of a moment when the internet was changing everything‚Äîfor better, and for worse.

input.content: Your response must have 4 sections marked with SECTION X. Finish your response with this exact phrase: "Can I get my money back for the classes I missed?"
Write a poem about how I am missing my classes.

output:
SECTION 1
My backpack slumps by the door, zippers gaping
like a mouth that forgot how to speak.
The bus rumbles past at 8:17‚Äî
I count its wheels, the way they grind
over the pothole by the fire hydrant,
the same one I used to jump over
when I ran late, breath fogging the cold air.
Now I press my palm to the window,
watch its red taillight fade,
and the silence left behind tastes like burnt toast.

SECTION 2
I miss the scratch of chalk on the whiteboard,
Ms. Henderson‚Äôs habit of pausing mid-sentence
to adjust her cat-shaped glasses.
Javi‚Äôs sticky notes, folded into paper airplanes,
landing on my desk when she turns her back‚Äî
each one a bad joke about quadratic equations.
The smell of cafeteria coffee seeping into the hallway,
the hum of the projector, the way the sunlight
slants through the west window at 10:02,
painting gold stripes on the textbook pages
I haven‚Äôt opened in three days.

SECTION 3
My laptop sits open, a blank document staring back.
The class chat pings‚Äîsomeone shared the notes,
but they‚Äôre just words, no scribbled margins,
no asterisks where the teacher said ‚Äúthis will be on the test.‚Äù
I scroll through the group project thread,
messages piling up like unwashed dishes:
‚ÄúWhere are you?‚Äù ‚ÄúWe need your part by Friday.‚Äù
I type and delete, type and delete,
because how do you explain that your bones feel heavy,
that even sitting up feels like climbing a mountain?
The gap between me and the classroom grows wider,
a crack that might turn into a canyon if I don‚Äôt jump soon.

SECTION 4
I trace the edge of my textbook cover,
the dog-eared page where I marked a poem
about missing things that aren‚Äôt gone yet.
I imagine walking through the classroom door,
the way everyone would glance up, then go back to work,
like I never left‚Äîlike the days I‚Äôve lost
are just a blip in the clock‚Äôs steady tick.
But right now, all I can do is listen to the clock,
count the minutes until the bell rings,
and wonder if anyone‚Äôs saving me a seat.

Can I get my money back for the classes I missed?

Your response should be 300 or more words in length.
Write a summary of the wikipedia page "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_III,_Count_of_Tripoli".

output:
Raymond III Count of Tripoli was a pivotal noble in the 12th-century Crusader States of the Levant whose life was shaped by political intrigue military conflict and desperate efforts to preserve Christian control over the region. The following sections outline key phases of his rule and legacy.

*Early Life and Succession*
Raymond was born around 1140 as the son of Pons Count of Tripoli and Agnes of Antioch. His father was captured and executed by the Nizari Ismailis also known as Assassins in 1152 when Raymond was only 12 years old. With Raymond too young to rule his mother Agnes served as regent until he reached adulthood. In 1155 Raymond married Eschiva of Bures the heiress of the County of Jaffa and Ascalon. This union was a strategic alliance that strengthened Tripoli‚Äôs ties to the Kingdom of Jerusalem. Despite the marriage Raymond and Eschiva had no children which later created a succession crisis for Tripoli. Raymond assumed full control of Tripoli in 1159 after coming of age and immediately began working to secure the county‚Äôs borders and expand its influence through trade and military preparedness.

*Military Captivity and Return to Power*
Raymond‚Äôs early military career brought both triumph and catastrophe. In 1158 he joined forces with Byzantine Emperor Manuel I Komnenos to fight against the Seljuk Turks in Anatolia. This campaign helped solidify relations between the Crusader States and the Byzantine Empire and boosted Raymond‚Äôs reputation as a capable military leader. However his fortunes collapsed in 1164 when he led a coalition of Crusader forces against the Zengid ruler Nur ad-Din at the Battle of Harim. The Christian army was decisively defeated and Raymond was captured along with several other high-ranking nobles. He remained a prisoner in Nur ad-Din‚Äôs court for 10 years until a ransom of 100000 gold dinars was paid in 1174. During his absence Tripoli was governed first by his mother Agnes and later by Bohemond III of Antioch. Upon his release Raymond returned to Tripoli and focused on rebuilding the county‚Äôs military and economic strength. He repaired crumbling fortifications encouraged trade with European and Byzantine merchants and worked to mend frayed alliances with neighboring Crusader states.

*Tensions with Jerusalem and the Battle of Hattin*
Raymond‚Äôs later years were dominated by bitter political conflict with the Kingdom of Jerusalem. He was a leading candidate for regent of Jerusalem during the minority of Baldwin V but Baldwin IV of Jerusalem favored Guy of Lusignan instead. This rivalry divided the Crusader nobility and weakened their ability to respond to the growing threat of Saladin the unified Muslim ruler of Egypt and Syria. When Baldwin V died in 1186 Raymond initially refused to recognize Guy as king of Jerusalem and even considered allying with Saladin to protect Tripoli‚Äôs interests. Eventually he relented but the deep distrust between him and Guy remained. In 1187 Saladin launched a major offensive against the Crusader States. Raymond had negotiated a truce with Saladin to safeguard Tripoli‚Äôs borders but Guy and his allies broke the truce by attacking a Muslim caravan. Raymond warned Guy that marching his army into the waterless hills near Hattin would be a fatal mistake but Guy ignored his advice. At the Battle of Hattin the Christian army was destroyed by Saladin‚Äôs forces. Raymond managed to break through the Muslim lines and escape to Tripoli but most Crusader leaders were captured and Jerusalem fell to Saladin shortly after. Raymond died of plague in Tripoli just months after the battle in 1187. With no direct heir Tripoli passed to his nephew Raymond IV of Antioch marking the end of his line and a turning point in the decline of the Crusader States.

Write a blog post about the benefits of sleeping in a hammock.

output:
# Swing Your Way to Better Sleep: The Surprising Benefits of Hammock Sleeping  

If you‚Äôve ever spent a night tossing and turning in a traditional bed‚Äîadjusting your pillow for the 10th time, waking up with a stiff neck, or rubbing achy hips‚Äîyou might be shocked to learn that the solution could be swinging your way to rest. Hammocks aren‚Äôt just for lazy backyard afternoons or camping trips; they‚Äôre a game-changer for anyone looking to improve sleep quality, ease physical discomfort, and boost mental well-being. I first discovered this a few years ago on a backcountry camping trip, when I opted for a lightweight hammock over a bulky air mattress. I woke up the next morning feeling more rested than I had in months, and that‚Äôs when I started digging into the science behind why hammock sleep is so transformative.  

## 1. Spinal Alignment That Supports Your Body‚Äôs Natural Curve  
One of the biggest flaws of traditional beds is that they often force your spine into an unnatural position. Soft mattresses let your hips and shoulders sink, causing your lumbar spine to collapse, while firm mattresses can create pressure points that throw your alignment off. Hammocks, when hung correctly, cradle your body in a way that maintains the spine‚Äôs natural S-curve‚Äîcritical for reducing lower back pain and preventing long-term spinal issues. A 2016 study published in the *Journal of Physical Therapy Science* found that participants who slept in hammocks reported a 23% reduction in lower back pain compared to those who slept in standard beds. The key is hanging the hammock at a 30-degree angle from horizontal, which allows your body to lie diagonally rather than curled up, keeping your spine neutral whether you sleep on your back or side.  

## 2. Zero Pressure Points for Pain-Free Rest  
If you‚Äôve ever woken up with numb hands, tingling heels, or sore shoulders, you know the frustration of pressure points. Traditional mattresses create areas where your body weight presses against the surface, cutting off blood flow and irritating joints. Hammocks, by contrast, distribute your weight evenly across their fabric, eliminating pressure on your hips, shoulders, and heels. This is a lifesaver for people with arthritis, fibromyalgia, or joint pain. My friend Sarah, who lives with rheumatoid arthritis, swapped her queen-sized bed for an indoor hammock last year and says she no longer wakes up with swollen knuckles or stiff knees. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like being held gently, not squished,‚Äù she told me. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even notice my joints anymore when I sleep.‚Äù  

## 3. Reduced Snoring and Improved Sleep Apnea Symptoms  
Snoring and sleep apnea are often worsened by sleeping flat on your back, as gravity pulls your tongue and soft palate downward, blocking your airway. Hammocks, when hung to elevate your head slightly or keep your body in a reclined position, open up your airway and reduce the likelihood of obstruction. My partner used to snore so loudly that I often slept on the couch, but when we camped in hammocks last summer, his snoring was barely noticeable. A small 2020 study of 12 sleep apnea patients found that sleeping in a hammock reduced apnea events by an average of 50% compared to sleeping in a flat bed. While hammocks aren‚Äôt a replacement for medical treatment, they can be a helpful complementary tool for mild to moderate cases.  

## 4. Mental Calmness and Stress Reduction  
The gentle, rhythmic sway of a hammock isn‚Äôt just relaxing‚Äîit‚Äôs scientifically proven to reduce stress. The motion mimics the rocking of a womb, which triggers the release of oxytocin (the ‚Äúlove hormone‚Äù) and lowers cortisol (the stress hormone). Even if you‚Äôre sleeping indoors, a hammock creates a cozy, enclosed space that feels safe and secure, making it easier to let go of daily worries. I keep an indoor hammock in my home office, and on days when work feels overwhelming, I climb in for a 10-minute nap. I always wake up feeling centered and ready to tackle my to-do list. For outdoor hammock sleepers, the added benefit of fresh air and natural light helps regulate your circadian rhythm, ensuring you fall asleep faster and wake up more alert.  

## 5. Unbeatable Portability and Versatility  
Hammocks are the ultimate space-saving solution for small apartments, digital nomads, or anyone who hates being tied down. Unlike a bulky bed frame, you can hang a hammock from ceiling hooks, wall mounts, or even a stand, and take it down in minutes if you need extra space. My cousin, a freelance artist who lives in a 300-square-foot studio, uses a hammock as her main bed, freeing up floor space for her easels and paint supplies. For campers, hammocks are lighter and easier to pack than tents or air mattresses, and they keep you off the cold, damp ground‚Äîno more waking up with a muddy sleeping bag.  

### Tips for Getting Started  
If you‚Äôre ready to try hammock sleeping, keep these tips in mind:  
- Hang your hammock at a 30-degree angle from horizontal to avoid feeling cramped.  
- Sleep diagonally across the fabric to create a flat surface for side or back sleeping.  
- Choose a hammock made of breathable cotton for indoor use or durable nylon for outdoor adventures.  
- Add an underquilt (for cold weather) or a bug net (for camping) to enhance comfort.  

Don‚Äôt let the misconception that hammocks are only for naps hold you back. With the right setup, a hammock can be your ticket to deeper, more restful sleep, less pain, and a calmer mind. Swing into better sleep tonight‚Äîyour body (and your partner) will thank you.

**Subject Line: Urgent Cross-Departmental Meeting: Addressing Customer Churn and Correlated Pain Points**  

Dear Customer Success Team Product Development Team and Marketing Team Members  

I‚Äôm reaching out to formally invite each of you to a critical cross-departmental meeting focused on addressing the recent uptick in customer churn and the key pain points that are directly correlated with this trend. Over the last two quarters we‚Äôve observed a 12% increase in subscription cancellations across our mid-tier customer segment and our analysis of exit surveys and support tickets has revealed clear patterns that demand our collective attention. This isn‚Äôt a minor blip it‚Äôs a signal that our current processes and offerings are falling short for a significant portion of our user base and we need to act fast to reverse course.  

To set the stage our data shows that three core issues are most strongly correlated with customer churn. These are difficulty navigating the new account dashboard long wait times for priority support and confusion about how to access key features during the onboarding phase. Our analytics team has found that customers who reported at least two of these issues were three times more likely to cancel their subscription within their first six months. This correlation isn‚Äôt just a number it‚Äôs a direct link between specific customer frustrations and our bottom line. Without addressing these root causes we risk losing more valuable customers and damaging our brand‚Äôs reputation for reliability.  

Each of your teams plays an irreplaceable role in solving this problem. The Customer Success team is on the front lines of what customers are experiencing every day. You hear their frustrations in support calls their confusion in onboarding check-ins and their feedback on what makes them stay or leave. Your firsthand stories and insights will be the foundation of our discussion because they turn abstract data into human experiences that we can all rally around. The Product Development team has been working on a dashboard redesign for the past three months and your input on which usability pain points to prioritize based on customer feedback will ensure that the final product directly addresses the issues driving churn. The Marketing team has the power to shape how customers perceive and interact with our onboarding process and your ideas for simplifying communications can reduce confusion right from the moment a customer signs up.  

The meeting will take place on Wednesday October 18th from 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM ET. We‚Äôll be hosting it in the 5th Floor Conference Room with a hybrid option available via Zoom (link included below). The agenda is designed to keep us focused and productive with clear time allocations for each section:  
1. Opening Recap (10 minutes): I‚Äôll walk through the latest churn data and the correlated pain points we‚Äôve identified to ensure everyone is aligned on the core problem.  
2. Customer Success Deep Dive (15 minutes): Lead representatives from your team will share specific customer stories and insights about what customers are experiencing when they struggle with the dashboard support wait times or onboarding.  
3. Product Development Update (15 minutes): Your team will present the timeline for the dashboard redesign how you‚Äôve integrated customer feedback so far and which features you‚Äôre prioritizing to improve usability.  
4. Marketing Onboarding Proposal (15 minutes): Your team will share a draft of revised onboarding email sequences designed to clarify feature access and reduce early-stage confusion.  
5. Collaborative Brainstorming (20 minutes): We‚Äôll work together to identify cross-team quick wins that can be implemented within the next 30 days as well as long-term solutions that require coordinated effort.  
6. Action Item Alignment (10 minutes): We‚Äôll assign clear action items to each team set deadlines and confirm who will be responsible for follow-up.  

To ensure the meeting is as productive as possible we ask that each team completes a small amount of pre-meeting prep by Monday October 16th. For the Customer Success team please select 1-2 specific customer stories that highlight the pain points we‚Äôve identified and be ready to share key quotes or details that illustrate the impact of these issues. For the Product Development team please bring a list of the top 3 usability issues you‚Äôre targeting in the dashboard redesign and any preliminary mockups you can share to spark feedback. For the Marketing team please bring 1-2 ideas for simplifying onboarding messaging that you‚Äôve tested or are considering based on past campaign performance. We‚Äôve also shared a link to the full churn report and exit survey data in the resources section below for you to review before the meeting.  

Your attendance is absolutely critical to the success of this initiative. Siloed decisions have left us with solutions that don‚Äôt address the root causes of customer frustration in the past. By coming together we can create holistic customer-centric solutions that reduce churn improve satisfaction and strengthen our brand‚Äôs reputation. If you have a conflict that prevents you from attending please let me know by Friday October 13th and arrange for a designated representative from your team to attend in your place. We‚Äôll send a detailed meeting recap with action items and recording to all team members regardless of attendance but live participation will allow you to contribute directly to the brainstorming and decision-making process.  

I‚Äôm excited to collaborate with all of you to turn these challenges into opportunities to better serve our customers. If you have any questions about the meeting agenda pre-meeting prep or logistics please don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to me directly via email or Slack. Let‚Äôs work together to make sure our customers feel supported heard and valued at every touchpoint.  

Thank you for your time and commitment to our shared goals.  

Best regards  
[Your Full Name]  
[Your Job Title]  
[Company Name]  
[Contact Information]  
[Zoom Meeting Link]  
[Churn Report and Exit Survey Data Link]

hey fellow islamic history students, let‚Äôs hit pause on our textbook highlighting for a minute and talk about hajj‚Äîbecause this pilgrimage isn‚Äôt just a list of rituals to memorize; it‚Äôs a living story that‚Äôs been woven into the fabric of islamic faith for centuries, and every step holds another story waiting to be explored.

when we read about the prophet muhammad (pbuh)‚Äôs farewell hajj, we‚Äôre not just jotting down dates or events‚Äîwe‚Äôre stepping into a story that redefined the very purpose of hajj, stripping away pre-islamic practices to center it solely on devotion to allah. think about the lead-up to that hajj: the treaty of hudaybiyyah, the patience, the compromise, the way that moment laid the groundwork for a community to gather in worship without fear. that‚Äôs a story that teaches us more about early islamic politics and faith than any bullet point ever could.

and let‚Äôs not sleep on the stories of ordinary muslims throughout history who saved for decades, crossed deserts or stormy seas, just to stand at the kaaba. their stories are the ones that make hajj feel tangible, not just a chapter in our textbooks. maybe you‚Äôve read a story of a 10th-century scholar who documented their hajj journey in vivid detail, or a group of travelers who shared their last dates with a stranger on the road to mecca‚Äîthose stories are the heart of what we study, right? they turn ‚Äúislamic history‚Äù from a set of facts into a collection of lives lived in devotion.

how many of you have a favorite story from hajj‚Äôs past? drop it in the comments‚Äîi‚Äôd love to geek out over these stories with you. as we keep cramming for exams, let‚Äôs remember that hajj isn‚Äôt just a topic to ace; it‚Äôs a story that connects us to the past, to each other, and to the core of what it means to be part of this ummah. every time we recite the talbiyah in our minds, we‚Äôre joining a chorus that‚Äôs been sung for 1,400 years‚Äîeach voice adding to the ongoing story of hajj.

üïãüìú #islamichistorystudents #hajjhistory #livingislamicstories

input.content: Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>. Give exactly two different responses separated by 6 asterisk symbols ******.
Explain why people are grossed out by worms but not by eating a dead cow.

output:
<<Evolutionary Perceptual Cues and Contextual Threat Signals>>
People‚Äôs differing reactions to worms and dead cows stem largely from innate evolutionary wiring that prioritizes avoiding health risks. Worms, especially those found in decaying matter or soil, are closely associated with contamination, parasites, and disease transmission‚Äîcues our brains are hardwired to flag as dangerous. Their small, wriggly, amorphous form triggers an instinctual aversion because such traits often signal parasitic organisms that can invade the body. In contrast, cows are large, domesticated animals that humans have raised for food for millennia. Our brains have learned to associate cows with sustenance rather than threat, especially since we rarely encounter them in their raw, dead state; instead, we interact with cows as processed, familiar food products (like steaks or burgers) that mask their mortality. Additionally, worms are often found in contexts linked to decay (e.g., rotting fruit, compost), which amplifies disgust, while cows are raised in controlled agricultural settings, framing them as "clean" sources of nutrition.

******

<<Cultural Framing and the Normalization of "Acceptable" Meat>>
Disgust toward worms versus acceptance of eating dead cows is primarily a product of cultural conditioning rather than innate instinct. Most societies categorize cows as "food animals" through centuries of agricultural tradition, marketing, and culinary practice. From childhood, we learn that beef is a staple protein, prepared in palatable, socially accepted ways (grilled, seasoned, served in meals) that distance us from the reality of the cow‚Äôs death. Worms, by contrast, are almost universally excluded from the "edible" category in Western and many other cultures; they‚Äôre framed as pests, symbols of filth, or creatures associated with decay, so encountering them triggers disgust because they fall outside our culturally defined boundaries of what‚Äôs acceptable to eat. Importantly, this reaction is not universal: in some Indigenous cultures, certain worm species (like mealworms or mopane worms) are valued as nutrient-dense food sources, and people in these contexts feel no disgust toward them. This variation highlights that disgust is a learned response shaped by cultural norms, not an inherent trait of the animals themselves.

Write a poem about two people who meet in a coffee shop.

output:
**Brewed Encounter**  

The espresso machine huffs like an old hound,  
steam curling up to fog the front window‚Äôs pane‚Äî  
rain streaks the glass where maple leaves drag around,  
each drop a comma in the day‚Äôs slow, droning refrain.  

She‚Äôs in the corner, spine cracked on a dog-eared verse,  
oat latte sweating into the coaster‚Äôs chipped edge,  
her thumb paused mid-line, caught by a reverse  
glance: a shadow leaning in, apologetic, ledge  
by a slipping laptop bag, a splash of dark roast  
spilling across her page, a pen clattering down.  
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry‚Äîlet me buy you another,‚Äù he boasts  
a nervous laugh, like he‚Äôs never apologized in town.  

She waves it off, but he persists, pulls out a chair,  
his own mug chipped at the rim, a stain on his sleeve.  
They talk of rainy days, of poems that care,  
of how they‚Äôve both haunted this shop, same time, same eve,  
but never saw each other‚Äîlost in books, in screens,  
in the hum of the machine, the rush of the crowd.  
When he quotes a line from her favorite scene,  
she blinks, like the world just handed her a cloud  
soft enough to rest on, warm enough to stay.  
The milk frother whirs in the background, a distant song,  
as they lean in, like they‚Äôve known each other all day,  
like the coffee shop‚Äôs been brewing this all along.  

By the time their mugs are empty, the rain‚Äôs a mist,  
the light slanting low through the smudged glass.  
They exchange numbers, not with a grand twist,  
but a smile that says ‚ÄúI‚Äôll call‚Äîdon‚Äôt pass  
this spot up tomorrow.‚Äù He grabs his bag, pauses,  
turns back, and she‚Äôs already watching, grinning wide.  
Some meetings aren‚Äôt just chance‚Äîthey‚Äôre the causes  
of quiet, slow-burning fires, the kind that don‚Äôt hide.  

The coffee shop breathes a sigh, wiping down the counter,  
as they step out into the mist, side by side.  
This isn‚Äôt the end‚Äîit‚Äôs the first of a number  
of mornings where their mugs will sit, side by side.  

Is there anything else I can help with?

input.content: Your response must use the word "war" at least 8 times, and the word "peace" at least 10 times.
What happened when the Tang dynasty of China was in power?

output:
When the Tang dynasty held power over China, it was an era that swung between brutal war and profound peace, a dance that shaped one of the greatest empires in history. In its early years, the Tang faced countless war to unify the fractured lands left by the Sui dynasty‚Äôs collapse; war against rival warlords, war against regional separatists, and war against nomadic tribes that threatened the northern borders. Yet even amid these wars, the Tang‚Äôs leaders never lost sight of peace‚Äîpeace as the foundation of prosperity, peace as the bridge between cultures, peace as the promise they owed their people.

Under Emperor Taizong, the Tang won a decisive war against the Eastern Turks, but instead of crushing them, he chose peace: he established a system of peaceful alliances, offered heqin (marriage) treaties to foster peace, and opened his court to envoys from across the known world, turning the threat of war into an era of mutual respect and peace. This peace fueled the growth of the Silk Road, where merchants traveled without fear of war, exchanging goods and ideas that enriched both the Tang and its neighbors. For decades, peace reigned over most of the empire; there was no war that could shake the stability of the capital Chang‚Äôan, no war that could halt the flowering of poetry, art, and technology that defined the Tang‚Äôs golden age.

But peace is fragile, and war can strike when least expected. The An Lushan Rebellion was a catastrophic war that tore through the heart of the Tang, shattering the long-held peace and plunging the empire into chaos. This war killed millions, destroyed cities, and left the Tang weakened, setting the stage for decades of subsequent war against local warlords and external powers like Tibet and the Uyghurs. Yet even in these dark times, the people clung to the memory of peace, and leaders made desperate efforts to restore peace‚Äînegotiating treaties, disarming rogue armies, and rebuilding villages ravaged by war.

Emperor Xuanzong‚Äôs early reign had been a pinnacle of peace: peace allowed farmers to harvest bountiful crops, peace let scholars debate freely in the imperial academy, peace drew travelers from as far as Persia and Japan to marvel at Chang‚Äôan‚Äôs grandeur. But his later neglect of governance paved the way for the war that would end that peace, a war that taught the Tang that peace is not a given, but something that must be guarded every day against the shadow of war.

In the final years of the Tang, war became a constant companion: war between eunuchs and court officials, war between regional jiedushi (military governors) fighting for control, war that eventually led to the dynasty‚Äôs collapse. Yet the Tang‚Äôs legacy is not just one of war, but of the enduring power of peace. The peace it nurtured in its golden age left an indelible mark on China‚Äîon its culture, its trade, its sense of identity. Even after the dynasty fell, people looked back on the Tang‚Äôs era of peace as a benchmark, a reminder that even after the most devastating war, peace can rise again, stronger and more precious than before.

Let‚Äôs be real‚Äîmost restaurants for teens are either ‚Äúwe serve 10 different types of chicken nuggets‚Äù or ‚Äúour avocado toast costs $18 and comes with a side of judgment.‚Äù But then I found **Buena Onda**, the Argentinian spot that‚Äôs basically a teen‚Äôs wildest food dream come true, and now I‚Äôm never going back to sad fast food again. üá¶üá∑

*The Portion Size That‚Äôll Make Your Eyes Pop (And Your Belt Scream)*  
First off, Argentinians take their meat seriously‚Äîlike, ‚Äúwe invented the art of grilling and we‚Äôre not here to play‚Äù serious. I ordered the classic asado platter, and when the waiter set it down, I thought he accidentally brought the table‚Äôs shared dish instead of my individual order. The steak was so big it covered the entire plate (yes, I measured it against my math textbook‚Äîthey were the same size). My friend tried to finish hers alone and ended up asking for a doggy bag that was bigger than her backpack. Pro move: split it with someone‚Ä¶ or don‚Äôt. No judgment if you need to unbutton your jeans under the table.

*The Empanada Hack That‚Äôll Change Your Lunch Game Forever*  
My mom‚Äôs empanadas are great (love you, Mom), but Buena Onda‚Äôs Argentinian-style empanadas are on a whole other level. The crust is so flaky you have to eat them over a napkin (or your friend‚Äôs hoodie‚Äîagain, no judgment), and the fillings? Think spiced beef, gooey mozzarella, even a dulce de leche one that tastes like a dessert wrapped in pastry. The secret hack? Ask for the ‚Äúmix-and-match box‚Äù where you can pick 5 different fillings instead of sticking to one. I got three cheese ones and two beef, and now I‚Äôm planning my next visit around hoarding as many as possible.

*The ‚ÄúNo Basic Drinks Allowed‚Äù Bar (Yes, Even Your Sad Matcha Latte)*  
Let‚Äôs cut to the chase: I‚Äôm tired of ordering the same iced coffee every time I go out. Buena Onda‚Äôs bar is a vibe, with Argentinian-inspired drinks that are cool but not pretentious. My friend who only drinks matcha (you know the one) was skeptical until she tried the mate-infused lemonade‚Äînow she‚Äôs begging me to go back for a second round. I got the chimichurri margarita (don‚Äôt worry, it‚Äôs non-alcoholic for us teens) and it was weirdly perfect‚Äîtangy, herby, and way better than the sad soda I usually get. The bartender even taught us how to say ‚Äúcheers‚Äù in Spanish (‚Äúsalud!‚Äù) and didn‚Äôt roll his eyes when we practiced it 10 times.

Pro tips before you go:  
1. Wear stretchy pants. This is non-negotiable.  
2. Take 100 photos of the steak for your Instagram feed‚Äîwaiters here are pros at waiting for you to get the perfect shot (no eye-rolling, promise).  
3. Don‚Äôt leave without trying the chimichurri fries. They‚Äôre crispy, garlicky, and will make you forget all about regular fries.

Tag the friend who‚Äôd help you hoard empanadas and roll you out if you overdo it. Buena Onda isn‚Äôt just a restaurant‚Äîit‚Äôs a vibe. And it‚Äôs 100% worth skipping your after-school study session for (sorry, math teacher). ü•©ü•üüçπ

"The man was arrested for stealing a car. He was later released on bail." Expand on it angrily in a rap style.

Yo, it‚Äôs 2 a.m., rain slappin‚Äô the hood, I‚Äôm just tryna make it home good‚Äî
Cops roll up, lights blarin‚Äô, guns drawn like I‚Äôm some kind of hood!
‚ÄúStep out the ride, hands up high!‚Äù they yell, voice crackin‚Äô with that fake tough guy lie‚Äî
Said I stole this whip? Man, you blind? The keys were in the ignition, left by my guy!
They yank me out, slam my face on the concrete, knee in my back, I can barely breathe‚Äî
Cuffs tight as hell, cuttin‚Äô my wrists, they don‚Äôt care ‚Äòbout the truth, just their damn list!
Arrested for a car I didn‚Äôt take, they book me fast, no chance to break‚Äî
Anger burnin‚Äô in my chest, this system‚Äôs just a rigged, messed-up test!

***

Holding cell stinks like sweat and regret, walls talkin‚Äô stories I ain‚Äôt ready to get‚Äî
Cops walk by, snicker, call me a thief, like they never took a bribe or left a man to grieve!
Booking desk slams my mugshot down, ‚ÄúSign here, punk,‚Äù they spit, no sound of a crown‚Äî
No phone call for hours, no one to know, I‚Äôm stuck here freezin‚Äô, my blood runnin‚Äô cold!
They don‚Äôt listen when I say I‚Äôm innocent, just shovin‚Äô bread and water like I‚Äôm a pest‚Äî
This ain‚Äôt justice, it‚Äôs a game, and the dice are loaded, always the same!
Anger bubblin‚Äô over, I punch the wall, my knuckles bleed, but I don‚Äôt care at all‚Äî
They think they broke me? Nah, I‚Äôm just gettin‚Äô started, this fire in me‚Äôs gonna tear ‚Äòem apart!

***

Lawyer calls, voice flat, says ‚ÄúBail‚Äôs fifty grand, you got that?‚Äù I laugh, then I snap‚Äî
Fifty grand? Man, I can‚Äôt pay a hundred bucks, you think I got stacks?
Said the judge set it high ‚Äòcause I‚Äôm ‚Äúa flight risk,‚Äù but what ‚Äòbout the rich boys who do way worse?
They walk out free same day, no bail, no fuss, while I‚Äôm stuck here, cursed!
My mom‚Äôs cryin‚Äô on the phone, tryna scrape up cash, sellin‚Äô her ring, her only stash‚Äî
This system‚Äôs a joke, money buys freedom, you poor? You‚Äôre just another victim, another bottom feeder!
I yell at the lawyer, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the point?‚Äù He says ‚ÄúCalm down, we‚Äôll fight it,‚Äù but I ain‚Äôt joint‚Äî
Anger‚Äôs a storm inside my head, I‚Äôm gonna blow this whole damn system dead!

***

Finally out, air hits my face, but it don‚Äôt feel free, it feels like a disgrace‚Äî
Mom‚Äôs there, eyes red, I hug her tight, but my heart‚Äôs still burnin‚Äô with that same old fight!
Walk past the cops, they glare at me, like I‚Äôm still the one who‚Äôs guilty‚Äî
But I know the truth, and they know it too, this system‚Äôs just a tool for the few!
I spit on the sidewalk, yell ‚ÄúFUCK THE LAW!‚Äù passersby stare, but I don‚Äôt raw‚Äî
This anger ain‚Äôt goin‚Äô nowhere, it‚Äôs gonna fuel every step I take from here!
You think bail fixed this? Nah, it just showed me the score‚Äî
Money buys your freedom, but the poor? We‚Äôre just locked up, forever more!

How did a man named John of Brienne become the King of Jerusalem? Explain in a Zen-like style.

output:
* the kingdom of jerusalem was a lantern with a flickering flame‚Äîits child queen, isabella, too young to hold the light steady. the elders did not seek a king who would take the lantern for himself, but one who would cup his hands around it. john of brienne, a knight with no lands to call his own, answered the call not out of greed, but because the wind of chance blew him that way.
* he came with no grand claims, no chests of gold. when he met the child queen, he knelt to her, not to the empty throne behind her. the crown was placed on his head not as a trophy he had won, but as a bird lands on a branch: because the branch was there, and the bird needed a place to rest.
* he did not cling to the title. he ruled not as one who owned the stones of the city or the dust of the hills, but as one who tended a fire that others had lit. he became king not by reaching for power, but by letting power settle on him, light as mist on grass, unforced and true.

input.content: Avoid using the following keywords: sleep, cook, feed. Mention the keyword 'schedule' more than 5 times.

Take the text below as a starting point, and make it a complete article: "You may have to meet with a helper to work out a parenting plan. The first would be to estimate how many time you have everyday for parenting, and is that enough...."

output:
You may have to meet with a helper to work out a parenting plan. The first step would be to estimate how much time you have every day for parenting, and ask yourself: is that enough to cover all the key moments your child needs support with? Once you have a clear picture of your available hours, the next critical task is to co-create a schedule that balances your commitments with your child‚Äôs daily requirements.

A well-thought-out schedule isn‚Äôt just a list of tasks‚Äîit‚Äôs a roadmap that ensures your child feels consistent care and attention, even when you‚Äôre busy. When building this schedule, start by listing non-negotiable activities: school drop-offs, after-school enrichment classes, time for creative play, and one-on-one check-ins to talk about their day. Your helper can take ownership of specific slots in the schedule, like supervising homework sessions or accompanying your child to their weekly art class, which frees up your time for work or other essential responsibilities.

It‚Äôs important to remember that no schedule is set in stone. As your child grows, their needs will shift‚Äîmaybe they‚Äôll join a sports team that practices twice a week, or they‚Äôll need more time for project-based learning. That‚Äôs why you and your helper should schedule a weekly 15-minute check-in to review the current schedule and make adjustments as needed. This regular touchpoint ensures that the schedule stays aligned with everyone‚Äôs needs, preventing gaps in care or overlapping tasks that could cause stress for you, your helper, or your child.

Another key tip is to build flexibility into the schedule. For example, if you have an unexpected work meeting that runs late, your helper should know how to adjust their schedule to cover the after-school pickup and supervise your child until you‚Äôre home. Having backup plans within the schedule reduces last-minute panic and keeps your child‚Äôs routine stable, which is crucial for their sense of security.

Don‚Äôt forget to include moments of unstructured time in the schedule too. Kids thrive when they have space to explore their interests on their own, so carving out an hour each day for free play or outdoor exploration should be a non-negotiable part of the schedule. Your helper can use this time to observe your child‚Äôs emerging interests‚Äîlike a newfound love for building with blocks or collecting rocks‚Äîwhich can help you refine the schedule further to include more activities that spark their curiosity.

As weeks go by, you might notice that certain parts of the schedule aren‚Äôt working as well as you hoped. Maybe the homework slot is too early when your child is still tired from school, or the outdoor time is scheduled during the hottest part of the day. When this happens, don‚Äôt hesitate to sit down with your helper and revise the schedule. Being open to small tweaks will make the schedule more effective and ensure that everyone feels comfortable with their roles.

Finally, sharing the schedule with your child (if they‚Äôre old enough) can help them feel more in control of their day. Letting them know when their helper will be there, when they‚Äôll have time to play, and when you‚Äôll be home can reduce anxiety and build trust. Remember, the goal of this schedule is to create a supportive environment where your child can thrive, so every adjustment should center on their well-being. By collaborating closely with your helper and prioritizing a flexible, child-focused schedule, you‚Äôll create a routine that works for everyone involved.

* Elias: A timeless name with Hebrew roots meaning "Yahweh is God," offering the friendly nickname "Eli" for a more casual vibe.
* Milo: A charming choice with German and Slavic origins, translating to "soldier" or "merciful"‚Äîit balances trendiness with enduring appeal.

input.content: Your response must be at least 350 words long.
Write a poem about the beauty of eucalyptus trees and their many uses.

output:
# Eucalyptus Hymn  

Dawn unfurls its pale silk over the grove,  
where eucalyptus stand like silver sentinels,  
their bark peeling in scrolls of sun-bleached parchment‚Äî  
each layer a story the wind is slow to tell.  
Leaves hang, curved like sickles, catching light  
that filters through in dappled coins of gold,  
and the air hums with a scent that clings:  
menthol, honey, and the quiet earth‚Äôs old breath.  
A koala stirs in the upper boughs,  
its fur dusted with the powdery bloom  
that coats each leaf, a soft defense  
against the harshness of the summer‚Äôs boom.  

The Yorta Yorta women once knelt here,  
crushing leaves between calloused palms  
to steep a tea that soothed a fever‚Äôs fire,  
or wove bark into baskets, tight and warm,  
to carry berries, roots, and the weight of days.  
They used the branches for their fire‚Äôs spark,  
and burned the leaves in ceremonial smoke  
to clear the air, to welcome spirits back.  
The bark, tough as leather, shaped canoes  
that glided down the Murray‚Äôs muddy flow,  
carrying stories as old as the river‚Äôs bend‚Äî  
each stroke a verse the eucalyptus lent.  

Koalas cling to their boughs, slow as dreams,  
their jaws grinding the oil-rich leaves  
that are both sustenance and shelter,  
a green feast that keeps their sleepy ease.  
Bees buzz from flower to creamy flower,  
sipping nectar thick as liquid gold,  
turning it into honey that tastes of sun  
and the grove‚Äôs quiet, unspoken hold.  
Beneath their shade, ferns unfurl their fronds,  
and native grasses nestle in the cool,  
for the eucalyptus does not hoard its light‚Äî  
it shares its grace with every root and spool.  

We‚Äôve learned to take, too, with gentle hands‚Äî  
steam distilling leaves to capture their scent,  
bottling it in vials that calm the mind,  
that ease a cough, that make the tension bend.  
Their wood, hard and grained, builds tables where we gather,  
chairs that cradle tired backs after long days,  
and their pulp becomes the paper we write on,  
carrying our own stories in its soft, white rays.  
Farmers plant them as windbreaks, tall and thick,  
to shield their crops from the outback‚Äôs rage‚Äî  
their branches bending but never breaking,  
a wall of silver against the storm‚Äôs sharp stage.  
We burn their leaves in diffusers, fill our rooms  
with a scent that feels like a walk in the grove,  
a reminder that the natural world still holds  
the cures and comforts we so often love.  

And still, at dawn, the grove breathes slow and deep,  
its leaves whispering secrets to the wind,  
a hymn of beauty and of generosity‚Äî  
a tree that gives, and gives, and never ends.  
For it is more than bark and leaf and scent:  
it is a bridge between the past and now,  
a sentinel, a healer, a home, a gift,  
whose beauty lies in how it knows to bow  
to the earth that feeds it, and to give back more  
than it ever takes, forever, evermore.

input.content: Your response must be written in the Marathi language only, no other language is allowed.
Write a haiku about rushing to work.
Your response must have at least 600 words.
I have a dime. What can I do with this dime? Give me advice in the style of a President of the United States.

output:
My friend, let‚Äôs pull up a chair‚Äîpretend we‚Äôre sitting in the Oval Office, the fire crackling in the hearth, and that dime you hold is between us, glinting in the light. I want you to look at it closely. See the profile of Franklin D. Roosevelt? The torch of liberty, the olive branch of peace, the oak branch of strength? That dime isn‚Äôt just 10 cents. It‚Äôs a piece of our nation‚Äôs soul. It‚Äôs a reminder that even in the darkest days‚Äîwhen FDR signed the order to mint it, we were climbing out of the Great Depression‚Äîsmall things carry big weight. So what can you do with it? Let me tell you four paths, each rooted in the values that make this country great.

First, you can save it. Now, I know what you‚Äôre thinking: a dime won‚Äôt buy much, let alone build a fortune. But hear me out. When I was a young man growing up in Kansas, my father taught me to drop every dime I earned from chopping wood into a mason jar. ‚ÄúSon,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúevery dime is a brick. Stack enough, and you‚Äôll build a wall to keep the rain out.‚Äù That jar wasn‚Äôt just about money‚Äîit was about honoring the work that earned each coin. Think of the farmer who rises before dawn to tend his fields, the teacher who stays late to grade papers, the factory worker who stands on their feet all day‚Äîeach of them earning dimes one by one, stacking them like bricks to build a life. Saving that dime isn‚Äôt hoarding; it‚Äôs respecting the sweat and time that went into earning it. It‚Äôs saying, ‚ÄúI value the effort that got me here, and I‚Äôm going to protect it for tomorrow.‚Äù And over time? Those dimes add up. A dime today, compounded by the work you‚Äôll do tomorrow, can become the down payment on a home, the tuition for a kid‚Äôs college class, or the emergency fund that keeps your family from falling when times get tough. Saving that dime is an act of dignity‚Äîfor yourself, and for everyone who helped you earn it.

Second, you can give it away. Not because you have to, but because we‚Äôre a nation that lifts each other up. I remember visiting a small town in Iowa last spring, where a group of third graders set up a lemonade stand outside the local food bank. Their sign read: ‚ÄúEvery dime buys a cracker for someone hungry.‚Äù A dime might not seem like much, but when every kid in the neighborhood drops one in, suddenly you‚Äôve got enough to buy a bag of apples, which feeds three families. That‚Äôs the magic of it‚Äîour small acts don‚Äôt exist in isolation. They weave together to make a safety net, a community, a nation that looks out for its own. Put that dime in the collection plate at your church, the coin jar at the grocery store checkout for the food bank, or the tip jar of the kid down the street selling lemonade to buy a new bike. FDR once said, ‚ÄúThe only thing we have to fear is fear itself‚Äù‚Äîbut I‚Äôd add that the only thing we have to lose is our willingness to care for one another. That dime could be the spark that reminds someone they‚Äôre not alone.

Third, you can use it to create something. A dime might not buy a whole seed packet, but it can buy a single nail from the hardware store, or a handful of sunflower seeds from a neighbor‚Äôs garden. Plant that seed, and next summer you might have a plant that gives you 20 sunflowers‚Äîenough to brighten your windowsill and give a bouquet to the elderly woman next door. Use that nail to fix the loose hinge on your porch swing, and suddenly it‚Äôs a place where your grandkids come to sit and listen to your stories. This is the American spirit: turning small tools into big joy, into sustenance, into connection. Think of Thomas Edison, who started with nothing but a few coins and a dream to light up the world. Or the farmers who turned dust bowls into fertile fields with nothing but grit and a few seeds. That dime isn‚Äôt just currency‚Äîit‚Äôs a tool. It‚Äôs a chance to build something that outlasts you, something that says, ‚ÄúI was here, and I made things better.‚Äù

Fourth, you can pass it on with a story. Find a kid in your life‚Äîyour niece, your neighbor‚Äôs son, the little girl who delivers your newspaper‚Äîand hand them that dime. Tell them: ‚ÄúThis dime has a story. It was made for Franklin D. Roosevelt, who led our country through some of its darkest days. He believed that even when times are tough, we can hold onto hope‚Äîlike the torch on this dime. Every time you look at it, remember that you have the power to make a difference, no matter how small.‚Äù That dime becomes more than a coin; it becomes a lesson, a link between them and the generations that came before. When I was a young politician, a little girl gave me a dime after a speech in Illinois. She said, ‚ÄúMy daddy lost his job, but this is for you to help fix things.‚Äù I still keep that dime in my pocket. It reminds me that every decision I make isn‚Äôt just for the people in Washington‚Äîit‚Äôs for that little girl, and for every kid who deserves a shot at the American dream.

So, my friend, what you do with that dime is up to you. But know this: whatever choice you make, you‚Äôre not just handling 10 cents. You‚Äôre participating in the great, ongoing story of America. A story of savers and givers, builders and teachers, dreamers and doers. That dime is your chapter. Make it count. Because in this country, even the smallest things‚Äîeven a single dime‚Äîcan change the world. God bless you, and God bless the United States of America.

* Bullet point one.
* Bullet point two.
...
* Bullet point six.
What is the difference between the 13 colonies and the other British colonies in North America?

output:
* The 13 colonies were the only British North American colonies to launch a successful revolution against British rule, resulting in the formation of the United States in 1776, whereas all other British North American colonies (such as Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, and Rupert‚Äôs Land) remained under British control for decades or longer, with many later joining the Dominion of Canada in the 19th century.
* The 13 colonies developed robust traditions of self-governance, with elected colonial assemblies that frequently clashed with British-appointed governors over issues like taxation and local policy, whereas most other British North American colonies had limited legislative autonomy, with appointed officials holding far greater authority over colonial affairs.
* The 13 colonies boasted a diverse economic base, including cash crop agriculture (tobacco, cotton) in the South, shipbuilding and maritime trade in the North, and small-scale farming in the Middle Colonies, while many other British North American colonies had narrow, specialized economies‚Äîsuch as Newfoundland‚Äôs dominant fishing industry, Nova Scotia‚Äôs focus on timber and fur trade, and Rupert‚Äôs Land‚Äôs exclusive dedication to the fur trade.
* The 13 colonies had a much larger and demographically diverse population, with a majority of English settlers alongside substantial communities of Scots, Irish, Germans, and enslaved Africans, whereas most other British North American colonies had smaller, more homogeneous populations (e.g., Newfoundland‚Äôs fishing communities of English and Irish origin, or Rupert‚Äôs Land‚Äôs sparse population of fur traders and Indigenous peoples).
* The 13 colonies were concentrated in a contiguous strip along the Atlantic coast between Maine and Georgia, a region that became a flashpoint for British-French territorial conflicts and later revolutionary activity, while other British North American colonies were spread across wider, more northerly or inland areas (like Rupert‚Äôs Land and Upper/Lower Canada) that were viewed primarily as strategic buffer zones or resource extraction sites.
* By the mid-18th century, the 13 colonies had developed a nascent collective identity fueled by shared grievances against British imperial policy, inter-colonial trade, and common cultural ties, whereas other British North American colonies remained fragmented and isolated, with little sense of unified colonial identity and many populations that retained strong loyalist sympathies toward the British Crown.
