Write a blog post about the history of the internet and how it has impacted our lives. Aim the blog post at teenagers.

output:
"# From 'LO' to TikTok: How the Internet Went From a Cold War Experiment to Your Daily Lifeline

Raise your hand if your morning goes something like this: You jolt awake to the blare of your phone alarm, roll over, and spend 20 minutes scrolling TikTok instead of getting ready. You shoot a quick text to your bestie begging for last night‚Äôs math homework answers, then order a breakfast burrito via app because you forgot to make something. By the time you walk out the door, you‚Äôve already used the internet five times‚Äîand you haven‚Äôt even turned on your laptop for class.

But 60 years ago, none of this existed. The internet didn‚Äôt start as a way to watch cat videos or join viral dance challenges. It began as a top-secret Cold War experiment, and its journey from a clunky network of giant computers to the pocket-sized lifeline you can‚Äôt live without is wilder than a sound that goes viral for no reason. Let‚Äôs rewind and unpack how we got from a failed first message to the world of endless scrolling we know today.

## The Internet‚Äôs Humble (and Failed) Beginnings
Back in 1969, the U.S. government was paranoid about nuclear attacks. They wanted a communication network that wouldn‚Äôt collapse if one part was destroyed (think: if an enemy bombed one city, the rest could still talk). So they funded ARPANET, a project by the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA) to connect four universities across the country.

On October 29, 1969, researchers at UCLA tried to send the first message to Stanford: ‚ÄúLOGIN.‚Äù But halfway through, the system crashed. The only thing that made it through? ‚ÄúLO.‚Äù Yep, the internet‚Äôs first ever message was a fail. Talk about a humble beginning.

## From Labs to Bedrooms: The Internet Goes Mainstream
By the 1980s, ARPANET had grown beyond the military. The National Science Foundation built a network that connected universities and research labs, so scientists could share data without flying across the country. Now, the internet was no longer just for spies and nerds‚Äîit was for anyone with access to a giant, room-sized computer (which, let‚Äôs be real, was still mostly nerds).

Then came 1989, a year that changed everything. A British computer scientist named Tim Berners-Lee was tired of struggling to share research papers with colleagues, so he invented the World Wide Web. Quick reality check: The internet is the network of computers, and the web is the part with websites, links, and URLs. Think of the internet as the highway, and the web as all the stores and houses along it. Berners-Lee made the web free for everyone (no paywalls, no patents‚Äîlegend status). Suddenly, anyone could explore the world from their desk.

The 90s brought the internet to regular people‚Äîsort of. Dial-up internet used your phone line to connect, and it made that iconic screechy sound that‚Äôs now a nostalgic meme. Imagine waiting 10 minutes for a single low-quality image to load, only to have your mom pick up the phone and disconnect you mid-download. If you‚Äôve ever complained about slow Wi-Fi, just be glad you didn‚Äôt live through dial-up. This was also the era of AOL Instant Messenger, where you‚Äôd use screen names like ‚ÄúCoolGirl123‚Äù and send your first online flirts. MySpace launched in 2003, and suddenly everyone was customizing their profiles with glittery backgrounds and terrible pop music. The internet was finally becoming social.

## Pocket-Sized Power: The Internet in Your Hand
By the 2000s, broadband killed dial-up (thank goodness), and smartphones hit the scene (hello, iPhone in 2007). Now the internet wasn‚Äôt tied to your desk‚Äîit was in your pocket. Social media evolved from MySpace to Facebook to Instagram to TikTok, and suddenly anyone could be a creator. You could post a dance video at 2 a.m. and wake up to 100k likes. You could learn to bake sourdough from a YouTube tutorial, or organize a climate strike with friends across the globe.

## How the Internet Changed Your Life (For Better and Worse)
So, how has this wild journey shaped your world? Let‚Äôs break it down:

### The Good Stuff
- **Your lifeline to connection**: When lockdowns hit in 2020, the internet kept us from feeling totally isolated. We had Zoom calls with grandma, virtual sleepovers with friends, and even online proms. If your cousin lives in another country, you can FaceTime them every weekend instead of waiting months for a letter.
- **Your classroom without walls**: Stuck on algebra? Khan Academy has your back. Want to learn how to edit videos? YouTube has thousands of free tutorials. The internet has made education accessible to people who might not have had access to good schools or tutors.
- **Your creative playground**: TikTok, YouTube, Twitch, Etsy‚Äîthese platforms let you turn your hobbies into something bigger. You can make a viral skit, sell your digital art, or stream yourself playing video games to thousands of people. The internet doesn‚Äôt care if you‚Äôre a kid in a small town or a celebrity‚Äîif your content is good, people will watch.
- **Your voice for change**: Young people like you have used the internet to fight for what‚Äôs right. Climate strikes, Black Lives Matter protests, and LGBTQ+ rights movements have all been amplified online. You can share your story, sign a petition, or organize a rally‚Äîall from your phone.

### The Not-So-Good Stuff
- **Comparison culture overload**: Scrolling through Instagram or TikTok can make you feel like everyone else is living a perfect life‚Äîtraveling, hanging out with friends, acing every test. But remember: what you see is the highlight reel. No one posts their bad hair days or their failed homework assignments.
- **Misinformation spreads like wildfire**: Fake news, conspiracy theories, and deepfakes go viral faster than a rumor in the hallway. It‚Äôs important to fact-check before you share something‚Äîdon‚Äôt be the person who spreads a lie without realizing it.
- **Privacy is a real concern**: Every time you use an app, it‚Äôs collecting data about you‚Äîwhat you like, where you go, who you talk to. Some companies use this to target you with ads, and others might share it without your permission. Check your privacy settings and think twice before sharing personal info.
- **Screen time burnout**: Between school, homework, social media, and gaming, it‚Äôs easy to spend 8+ hours a day staring at a screen. This can make you feel tired, anxious, or disconnected from the real world. Taking breaks‚Äîlike going for a walk or hanging out with friends in person‚Äîis crucial for your mental health.

## The Future Is Yours
At the end of the day, the internet is just a tool. It‚Äôs neither good nor bad‚Äîit‚Äôs what we make of it. You can use it to learn, create, connect, and change the world. Or you can scroll mindlessly for hours (we‚Äôve all been there, no judgment).

But here‚Äôs the thing: You‚Äôre the generation that‚Äôs going to shape the future of the internet. You know better than anyone what works and what doesn‚Äôt. Will you build more inclusive spaces? Fight misinformation? Create apps that help people? The possibilities are endless.

Next time you‚Äôre scrolling TikTok or texting a friend, take a second to think: none of this would exist if a group of scientists hadn‚Äôt tried to send ‚ÄúLOGIN‚Äù and failed. The internet‚Äôs journey is far from over‚Äîand it‚Äôs up to you to write the next chapter.

Now go make something awesome. And maybe put your phone down for a little while‚Äîyour brain will thank you."

input.content: Your response should contain some words in all caps, but those all-caps words should appear at most 10 times.
Which of the following is not a fish: salmon or avocado? Answer this easy question first, then expand into an interesting article about salmon and avocado.

output:
AVOCADO is not a fish‚Äîsalmon is a cold-water fatty fish, while avocados are creamy, seed-bearing fruits (often mistaken for vegetables!).

The unlikely pairing of salmon and avocado has become a global culinary favorite, gracing sushi menus, breakfast toasts, and grain bowls alike. But beyond their delicious synergy, each brings unique nutritional superpowers and cultural backstories to the table.

Let‚Äôs start with salmon: a sleek, silver swimmer that spends most of its life in cold ocean waters before returning to freshwater rivers to spawn. There are two main types: wild-caught (from the Pacific or Atlantic) and farmed. Wild salmon is prized for its rich, deep flavor and high levels of OMEGA-3 fatty acids‚Äîspecifically EPA and DHA, which are critical for heart health, brain function, and reducing chronic inflammation. These fats are so essential that our bodies can‚Äôt produce them on their own, making salmon a top dietary source. Sustainability is a key consideration here: wild Pacific salmon is often more eco-friendly than farmed Atlantic, which can carry risks of pollution and disease spread to wild populations.

Avocados, on the other hand, are native to the tropical regions of Mexico and Central America, where they‚Äôve been cultivated for over 10,000 years. Classified as a drupe (a fruit with a single seed, like peaches or olives), they were once called ‚Äúalligator pears‚Äù for their bumpy, green skin and pear shape. Today, they‚Äôre celebrated for their nutrient profile: packed with FIBER (both soluble and insoluble, supporting digestion and blood sugar), MONOUNSATURATED FATS (the heart-healthy kind that can lower bad cholesterol), and ANTIOXIDANTS like lutein, which supports eye health. Guacamole, the iconic Mexican dip made with mashed avocados, lime, and chili, has been a staple for centuries, but avocados have since exploded into global popularity, with demand soaring in the last two decades.

What makes salmon and avocado such a dynamic duo? For one, the healthy fats in avocado help our bodies absorb the fat-soluble nutrients in salmon‚Äîthink vitamin D, which works with OMEGA-3s to boost bone health, and astaxanthin, the antioxidant that gives salmon its pink hue and fights cell damage. Flavor-wise, the smooth, buttery texture of avocado balances the firm, savory richness of salmon, creating a mouthfeel that‚Äôs both satisfying and balanced.

Fun fact: Salmon avocado rolls, a menu staple in American sushi restaurants, aren‚Äôt traditional Japanese sushi. They were invented in the 1960s in Los Angeles, where chefs adapted sushi to local tastes, swapping out raw fish for cooked salmon and adding creamy avocado to make the dish more approachable for Western palates.

Whether you‚Äôre enjoying them wrapped in seaweed and rice, smashed on toast with smoked salmon, or tossed in a salad with greens and citrus, salmon and avocado prove that two very different superfoods can create something greater than the sum of their parts. Both are versatile, nutrient-dense, and a testament to how culinary innovation can turn unexpected pairings into beloved classics.

Write a brief biography of a person named "Brilliant Le Hou".

output:
Brilliant Le Hou was born in a small rural village in southern China where access to clean water was a daily struggle. This early experience shaped her lifelong mission to make sustainable resources accessible to underserved communities.

*As a teenager she moved to the United States to pursue her education working odd jobs to fund her studies while excelling in science and math courses.* She earned a bachelor‚Äôs degree in environmental engineering from a public university in California before going on to complete a master‚Äôs and PhD focused on low cost water purification technologies.

*Her groundbreaking research led to the development of a portable solar powered filtration system that can convert contaminated water into safe drinking water for up to 50 people per day.* The system uses locally sourced materials making it affordable and easy to maintain in remote areas. She founded a nonprofit organization in 2018 to distribute these systems to villages across Asia and Africa.

*Beyond her technical work Brilliant is a passionate advocate for youth in STEM fields.* She regularly visits schools in low income areas to lead hands on workshops and mentor students especially young girls encouraging them to pursue careers in environmental science. She also partners with local governments to create policy frameworks that prioritize sustainable resource management for marginalized communities.

In recent years she has received several awards for her contributions including the Global Environmental Leadership Award in 2022. She continues to live and work between her home village in China and her base in California splitting her time between research community outreach and advocacy.

input.content: Your response must be wrapped with double quotes. Your response must use at least 800 words.
What sentiments existed in the Croatian and Serbian nations towards the Austrian Empire at the end of the 19th century?

output:
"At the end of the 19th century, sentiments among Croatian and Serbian populations toward the Austrian Empire (reorganized as the Austro-Hungarian Dual Monarchy after 1867) were deeply fragmented, shaped by political factionalism, economic grievances, cultural policies, religious ties, and competing nationalist aspirations. No single monolithic view existed; instead, attitudes varied sharply by class, region, political affiliation, and whether the group in question was part of the Dual Monarchy or the independent Kingdom of Serbia (recognized in 1878).

### Croatian Sentiments: A Tug-of-War Between Autonomy, Nationalism, and Pragmatism
Croatia was part of the Hungarian crown lands within the Dual Monarchy, so its relationship with Austria was inextricably tied to its struggle against Hungarian dominance. Three main factions defined Croatian attitudes toward Vienna:

1. **Pro-Austrian Conservative and Moderate Forces**: The People‚Äôs Party (Narodna Stranka), led by figures like Ksaver ≈†andor Gjalski, emerged as the most vocal pro-Austrian bloc. This party viewed the Austrian Empire as a critical bulwark against Hungarian Magyarization policies, which sought to impose the Hungarian language on schools, courts, and administrative offices across Croatia. The 1868 Croatian-Hungarian Settlement, brokered with Austrian mediation, granted Croatia limited autonomy over education, culture, and local governance‚Äîconcessions the People‚Äôs Party argued would not have been possible without Austrian oversight. For conservative elites, the Catholic Church (closely aligned with Vienna‚Äôs Catholic monarchy), and many middle-class merchants, Austria represented stability and a way to preserve Croatian identity without risking the chaos of independence or unification with South Slavic neighbors. Peasants, too, sometimes leaned pro-Austrian if they believed Vienna would curb Hungarian landowners‚Äô exploitation or deliver economic relief.

2. **Radical Nationalists: Resentment and Ambivalence**: The Party of Rights (Stranka Prava), led by Ante Starƒçeviƒá and later Eugen Kvaternik, embodied Croatian radical nationalism. These activists resented Austria‚Äôs complicity in Hungarian oppression, arguing that Vienna had prioritized its alliance with Budapest over Croatian cultural and political rights. For example, when Hungary passed a 1874 law making Hungarian the sole official language in Croatian secondary schools, Austria failed to intervene decisively, deepening distrust. Starƒçeviƒá‚Äôs vision of a unified South Slav state (Yugoslavia) or an independent Croatia put him at odds with both Hungary and Austria, but some members of the Party of Rights viewed Austria as a ‚Äúlesser evil‚Äù compared to Hungarian dominance, occasionally appealing to the emperor to mediate disputes. Kvaternik‚Äôs 1875 uprising against Hungarian rule, though crushed, reflected the faction‚Äôs growing disillusionment with Vienna‚Äôs inaction, pushing many toward outright anti-Austrian sentiment.

3. **Working Class and Peasantry: Economic Grievances Over Nationalism**: Croatia‚Äôs small but growing working class, concentrated in industrial centers like Zagreb, was drawn to socialist movements that rejected both Austrian imperial rule and Hungarian nationalism. These groups prioritized cross-national solidarity and economic justice over ethnic or imperial loyalties. For most peasants, meanwhile, national concerns took a backseat to high taxes, land inequality, and exploitation by Hungarian and Croatian landowners. While some joined nationalist movements if they promised land reform, others remained indifferent to imperial politics, focusing on day-to-day survival.

### Serbian Sentiments: Irredentism vs. Pragmatic Alliance
For the independent Kingdom of Serbia and Serb minorities within the Dual Monarchy, attitudes toward Austria were defined by competing visions of national unification and economic dependence:

1. **Anti-Austrian Nationalists: Irredentism and Resentment**: The Radical Party, led by Nikola Pa≈°iƒá, dominated Serbian politics by the 1890s and championed the goal of uniting all Serbs into a single state‚Äîincluding Serb-inhabited lands in the Austro-Hungarian Empire (Vojvodina, Bosnia-Herzegovina, and parts of Croatia-Slavonia). Austria‚Äôs 1878 occupation of Bosnia-Herzegovina (a territory Serbia had hoped to annex after the Ottoman Empire‚Äôs defeat) was seen as a betrayal of Serb national aspirations. Vienna‚Äôs policies in Bosnia, which included suppressing Serbian Orthodox institutions, banning nationalist organizations, and imposing Austrian administrative control, fueled widespread anger. Economic exploitation further deepened resentment: Austria was Serbia‚Äôs primary trading partner, but it imposed crippling tariffs on Serbian industrial goods while depressing prices for Serbian agricultural exports (grain, livestock), hindering Serbia‚Äôs industrialization. Pan-Slavic support from Russia amplified these sentiments, as Serbs viewed the tsar as a natural ally against Austrian Catholic dominance.

2. **Pro-Austrian Conservatives: Pragmatism Over Nationalism**: The Obrenoviƒá dynasty, which ruled Serbia until 1903, pursued a pro-Austrian foreign policy to counter Russian influence and Ottoman resurgence. King Milan Obrenoviƒá signed a secret alliance with Austria in 1881, promising to align Serbia‚Äôs foreign policy with Vienna‚Äôs in exchange for economic aid and military protection. This alliance was supported by conservative elites‚Äîwealthy landowners, merchants, and Orthodox Church hierarchies‚Äîwho feared that irredentist policies would trigger a catastrophic war with Austria, which Serbia could not win. For these groups, Austria represented stability and economic opportunity, as trade with the Dual Monarchy was critical to their prosperity.

3. **Serb Minorities in the Dual Monarchy: Diverse Loyalties**: Serbs in Vojvodina (part of the Austrian half of the Dual Monarchy) enjoyed greater autonomy than those in Hungarian lands, leading some to view Austria as a protector against Hungarian and Romanian nationalism. The Serbian Orthodox Church in Vojvodina often aligned with Vienna to preserve its institutional power. In contrast, Serbs in Hungarian-controlled Banat and Baƒçka faced harsh Magyarization policies, fostering resentment toward both Hungary and Austria for failing to intervene. Bosnian Serbs, under Austrian occupation, endured the most repression, forming secret nationalist groups (like the precursor to the Black Hand) to resist rule from Vienna. Their grievances became a rallying cry for Serbian nationalists in the independent kingdom, uniting Serbs across borders in opposition to Austrian imperial rule.

### Cross-Cutting Themes: Yugoslavism and Shared Grievances
A unifying thread between Croatian and Serbian sentiments was the rise of Yugoslavism, a movement advocating for the unification of all South Slavs. Some Yugoslavists were pro-Austrian (Austro-Yugoslavism), pushing for a third ‚ÄúSouth Slav‚Äù component in the Dual Monarchy to balance Austria and Hungary. Others were anti-Austrian, demanding an independent Yugoslav state. While Croatian nationalists sought equal partnership in such a state, Serbian nationalists envisioned Serbian dominance, creating tensions that would persist into the 20th century.

By the turn of the century, these fragmented sentiments had laid the groundwork for the crises of the early 1900s. Austria‚Äôs 1908 annexation of Bosnia-Herzegovina shattered any remaining trust between Vienna and Serbian nationalists, while Croatian nationalists grew increasingly frustrated with Austria‚Äôs failure to curb Hungarian oppression. These tensions culminated in the 1914 assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand by a Bosnian Serb nationalist, triggering World War I and the eventual collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. In the end, the complex mix of pragmatism, resentment, and nationalist aspiration that defined Croatian and Serbian attitudes toward Austria at the end of the 19th century reflected the broader struggle for self-determination in the Balkans‚Äîa struggle that would reshape European history."

input.content: Your answer must have a title contained in double angular brackets, such as <<kotlin vs java>>.
What are the pros and cons of kotlin vs java?

output:
<<Kotlin vs Java: Pros and Cons Comparison>>

Kotlin and Java are both JVM-based languages with strong interoperability, but they differ significantly in syntax, features, and use cases. Below is a breakdown of their key pros and cons:

### Kotlin Pros
1. **Concise Syntax**: Eliminates boilerplate code (e.g., data classes auto-generate getters, setters, `equals()`, `hashCode()`, and `toString()`; no need for explicit constructor declarations for simple classes).
2. **Built-in Null Safety**: Enforces nullability at compile time, drastically reducing NullPointerExceptions (NPEs)‚Äîa common pain point in Java.
3. **Robust Functional Programming Support**: Offers lambda expressions, higher-order functions, extension functions, and lazy evaluation, making it easier to write clean, declarative code.
4. **Coroutines for Async Programming**: Provides lightweight, efficient coroutines for asynchronous tasks, avoiding the overhead of traditional threads.
5. **Smart Casts**: Automatically casts variables to their specific types once a type check is performed, reducing manual casting code.
6. **Full Java Interoperability**: Seamlessly integrates with Java code, libraries, and frameworks‚Äîyou can mix Kotlin and Java files in the same project without issues.
7. **Modern Language Features**: Includes named parameters, default arguments, sealed classes (for safe state management), and type inference to simplify development.

### Kotlin Cons
1. **Steeper Learning Curve**: For Java developers, Kotlin‚Äôs advanced features (coroutines, extension functions) may require time to master.
2. **Smaller Ecosystem (Relative to Java)**: While growing rapidly, Kotlin still has fewer niche libraries and legacy tooling support compared to Java.
3. **Slightly Longer Compilation Time**: In large projects, Kotlin‚Äôs compilation can be slower than Java‚Äôs, though this gap is narrowing with optimizations.
4. **Overkill for Simple Projects**: Some features (e.g., coroutines, sealed classes) may add unnecessary complexity for basic applications.
5. **Limited Legacy Support**: Less ideal for maintaining very old Java codebases where Kotlin‚Äôs modern features might clash with outdated practices.

### Java Pros
1. **Mature, Vast Ecosystem**: Boasts an extensive collection of libraries, frameworks (Spring, Hibernate), and tools, making it suitable for almost any use case.
2. **Large Community & Resources**: Tons of tutorials, forums, and documentation are available, so finding help or troubleshooting is easy.
3. **Straightforward for Beginners**: Its explicit, verbose syntax is often easier for new OOP developers to learn and understand.
4. **Enterprise-Grade Adoption**: Dominates enterprise development, with widespread support for legacy systems and mission-critical applications.
5. **Optimized Performance**: Decades of JVM optimizations mean Java often delivers slightly better performance in edge cases (e.g., high-throughput systems).
6. **Strict Backward Compatibility**: New Java versions rarely break existing code, making it safe for long-term projects.

### Java Cons
1. **Verbose Syntax**: Requires extensive boilerplate for common tasks (e.g., writing getters/setters, implementing `equals()`/`hashCode()`).
2. **No Built-in Null Safety**: NullPointerExceptions remain a persistent issue, as null checks are manual and error-prone.
3. **Limited Functional Programming**: While Java 8+ added lambdas and streams, it lacks Kotlin‚Äôs comprehensive functional features (e.g., extension functions, coroutines).
4. **Heavier Async Programming**: Relies on threads, which are resource-intensive compared to Kotlin‚Äôs coroutines.
5. **Slow Feature Updates**: New features are rolled out gradually to preserve backward compatibility, so it lags behind Kotlin in adopting modern language improvements.

### Conclusion
Choose Kotlin for modern, Android, or cross-platform projects where conciseness, null safety, and functional programming are priorities. Choose Java for enterprise legacy systems, projects requiring maximum ecosystem maturity, or for beginners learning OOP fundamentals. Thanks to their interoperability, many teams mix both languages to leverage the strengths of each.

Write an outline for a paper on the history of Yemeni coffee. The outline should include the main points of the paper.

output:
# Outline for a Paper on the History of Yemeni Coffee: From Domestication to Global Legacy

## Title Page
## Abstract
## Introduction
* The Global Legacy of Yemeni Coffee: From Local Crop to Cultural Icon
* Research Objectives and Scope: Tracing 1,000 Years of Coffee History in Yemen
* Methodology: Integrating Archival Records, Oral Histories, and Agricultural Data

## 1. Early Origins and Domestication of Coffee in Yemen
* Pre-Coffee Context: Ancient Agricultural Practices in the Arabian Peninsula
* The Legend of Sheikh Omar: Myth vs. Archaeological Evidence of Coffee's First Use
* Genetic Roots: Yemen as the Primary Domestication Hub for Coffea arabica

## 2. Coffee's Integration into Yemeni Society (15th‚Äì16th Centuries)
* The Rise of the Qahwa House: Social Hubs and the Spread of Coffee Culture
* Religious Acceptance: Debates and Fatwas on Coffee Consumption in Islamic Scholarship
* Smallholder Farming Systems: Traditional Qatari (Terraced) Agriculture and Coffee Cultivation

## 3. The Birth of the Global Coffee Trade (17th Century)
* Mocha: The World's First Coffee Port and Its Dominance in Global Markets
* Ottoman Influence: Political Control and the Regulation of Coffee Exports
* European Demand: How Yemeni Coffee Sparked a Global Beverage Craze

## 4. The Golden Age of Yemeni Coffee (17th‚Äì18th Centuries)
* Trade Networks: From Mocha to Venice, Amsterdam, and Beyond
* Coffee Varietal Diversity: Unique Flavors and the Reputation of Yemeni "Bunna"
* Economic Prosperity: How Coffee Transformed Yemeni Coastal and Highland Communities

## 5. The Decline of Yemeni Coffee Supremacy (Late 18th‚Äì19th Centuries)
* The Spread of Coffee Cultivation to Other Regions: Smuggling and Colonial Expansion
* Political Instability: Civil Wars and Ottoman Misrule Disrupting Production
* Environmental Degradation: Deforestation and Soil Erosion Threatening Coffee Farms

## 6. 20th Century Challenges and Marginalization
* The Rise of Qat Cultivation: Competition for Land and Labor
* Political Turmoil: Revolutions, Civil Conflicts, and Neglect of Coffee Agriculture
* Global Market Shifts: Commoditization and the Erosion of Yemeni Coffee's Premium Status

## 7. The Modern Revival of Yemeni Coffee (21st Century)
* Specialty Coffee Movement: Rediscovering Yemeni Coffee's Unique Terroir
* Direct Trade Initiatives: Empowering Smallholders and Ensuring Fair Prices
* Organic and Sustainable Practices: Reviving Traditional Farming Methods

## 8. Cultural Significance of Coffee in Yemeni Identity
* Coffee in Rituals and Celebrations: Weddings, Ramadan, and Hospitality Customs
* Oral Traditions and Folklore: Stories and Proverbs Centered on Coffee
* Gender Roles: Women's Involvement in Coffee Processing and Preparation

## 9. Environmental and Agricultural Sustainability of Yemeni Coffee
* Terroir and Microclimates: How Yemen's Unique Landscape Shapes Coffee Flavor
* Water Scarcity: Challenges and Traditional Water Harvesting Systems (Aflaj) for Coffee Farms
* Climate Change Impacts: Droughts, Heatwaves, and Threats to Coffee Biodiversity

## 10. Economic Impact of Coffee on Contemporary Yemen
* Coffee as a Lifeline: Supporting Rural Livelihoods Amidst Ongoing Conflict
* Export Challenges: Blockades, Infrastructure Issues, and Global Market Access
* Potential for Economic Diversification: Coffee as a Tool for Post-Conflict Reconstruction

## 11. Future Prospects and Recommendations for Yemeni Coffee
* Investing in Agricultural Research: Preserving Varietal Diversity and Developing Drought-Resistant Strains
* Strengthening Infrastructure: Improving Processing Facilities and Export Logistics
* Promoting Cultural Tourism: Linking Coffee Farms to Heritage Travel Experiences

## 12. Conclusion
* Summarizing Yemeni Coffee's Journey from Local Crop to Global Legacy
* Reaffirming Yemen's Role as the Cradle of Coffee Civilization
* Final Thoughts: The Importance of Safeguarding Yemeni Coffee for Future Generations

## References
## Appendices
* Oral History Transcripts from Yemeni Coffee Farmers
* Historical Maps of Mocha Trade Routes
* Genetic Analysis Data of Yemeni Coffee Varieties

input.content: Your response must include the keywords waste, material and meal. Your response should have more than 30 sentences.
Write an essay about how aluminium cans are used in food storage.

output:
# Aluminum Cans: Unsung Heroes of Food Storage  

Walk down any grocery store aisle, and you‚Äôll see them stacked high: shiny aluminum cans holding everything from tuna and beans to chili and fruit cocktail. While many associate these cans with carbonated beverages, they are actually one of the most versatile and effective tools for food storage, thanks to the unique properties of their core material, their ability to preserve meals for extended periods, and their complex relationship with waste reduction and management. To fully appreciate their role, we must dive into the material science that makes aluminum cans so ideal, their impact on industrial and domestic food storage, and the steps needed to mitigate their own waste footprint.  

At the heart of aluminum cans‚Äô success is the material itself: aluminum. A lightweight, malleable metal, aluminum is abundant in the Earth‚Äôs crust, but its true value lies in its ability to be transformed into thin, durable sheets that can be shaped into seamless cans. Unlike other materials used for food storage, such as glass or plastic, aluminum offers a rare combination of strength and lightness, making it easy to transport without adding excessive weight to shipments of stored meals. This lightness reduces fuel consumption during distribution, which in turn lowers the carbon footprint of the food we eat. Additionally, aluminum is naturally corrosion-resistant, but to make it safe for acidic meals like tomato sauce or citrus fruit, manufacturers line the inside of cans with a food-safe polymer coating. This coating prevents the aluminum from reacting with the food, preserving both the meal‚Äôs flavor and the can‚Äôs structural integrity. When compared to plastic, which can leach harmful chemicals into meals over time, or glass, which is prone to breaking and heavy to carry, aluminum stands out as a material that prioritizes both food safety and practicality.  

One of the most critical functions of aluminum cans in food storage is their ability to create an airtight, impermeable seal. This seal is non-negotiable for preserving meals, as it blocks oxygen, moisture, and harmful bacteria from entering the can‚Äîall of which are major causes of food spoilage. When a meal is sealed inside an aluminum can and subjected to thermal processing (a key step in commercial canning), any pathogens present are killed, and the airtight environment prevents new ones from growing. This means that a can of vegetable stew, for example, can remain safe and nutritious for up to five years without needing refrigeration, a feat that few other storage materials can match. For communities without reliable access to electricity or refrigeration, this is a game-changer: aluminum cans make nutrient-dense meals accessible to people in remote areas, disaster zones, or low-income households where fresh food may be scarce. In this way, aluminum cans directly contribute to reducing food waste by extending the shelf life of meals that would otherwise spoil before they can be eaten.  

Industrial food storage with aluminum cans has revolutionized the way we produce, distribute, and consume meals. Commercial canning facilities process millions of cans daily, filling them with everything from protein-rich tuna and lentils to ready-to-eat meals like chicken noodle soup and chili. These meals are often cooked before being sealed into cans, meaning that consumers can simply open a can, heat it up, and enjoy a hot, nutritious meal in minutes‚Äîno preparation required. This convenience not only fits into busy modern lifestyles but also reduces the likelihood of food waste at the household level. When you have a can of beans in your pantry, you don‚Äôt have to worry about fresh beans spoiling before you can use them; you can open the can only when you need it, ensuring that every portion of the meal is eaten. Moreover, aluminum cans protect the nutritional value of meals better than many other storage methods. Studies have shown that canned fruits and vegetables retain just as many vitamins and minerals as their fresh counterparts, and in some cases, even more, because they are processed at the peak of ripeness when nutrient levels are highest.  

Beyond industrial use, aluminum cans also play a role in domestic food storage, particularly when repurposed. Once a can is emptied of its original meal, it can be cleaned thoroughly and reused to store a variety of food items. Many home cooks use empty aluminum cans to store dry goods like rice, quinoa, spices, or nuts, as the can‚Äôs airtight nature (when fitted with a reusable lid) keeps these ingredients fresh and free from pests. For meal prep enthusiasts, cleaned aluminum cans are perfect for portioning out pre-cooked grains or chopped vegetables, making it easy to grab a single portion when assembling a quick lunch or dinner. Repurposing aluminum cans in this way not only reduces the need for single-use plastic containers but also diverts the cans from landfills, addressing the waste challenge that comes with their widespread use. Some community organizations even run programs where they collect clean, empty aluminum cans and distribute them to low-income families for storing homemade meals or bulk-purchased ingredients, further extending the cans‚Äô utility and reducing both food waste and plastic waste.  

Despite their many benefits, aluminum cans are not without their drawbacks, most notably the waste they generate if not properly recycled. While aluminum is 100% recyclable‚Äîmeaning it can be melted down and turned into new cans or other aluminum products indefinitely‚Äîmillions of cans end up in landfills every year. This is a significant waste of a valuable material, as producing new aluminum from raw ore requires 95% more energy than recycling existing aluminum. When cans are thrown away instead of recycled, we not only lose the opportunity to reuse this valuable material but also contribute to landfill overcrowding and increased carbon emissions from aluminum production. To address this, many countries have implemented deposit-refund systems, where consumers pay a small fee when purchasing a canned meal or beverage and get the fee back when they return the can for recycling. These systems have been proven to increase recycling rates significantly, reducing the amount of aluminum can waste that ends up in landfills. Additionally, manufacturers are increasingly using recycled aluminum to produce new food cans, which helps close the loop on the material and makes the entire food storage process more sustainable.  

Another way to reduce aluminum can waste is to encourage manufacturers to use less material in each can without compromising its structural integrity. Over the past few decades, advancements in material science have allowed companies to make aluminum cans thinner and lighter while still maintaining their ability to seal meals safely. This not only reduces the amount of aluminum used per can but also lowers transportation costs and carbon emissions, as lighter cans require less fuel to ship. Some manufacturers are also experimenting with plant-based linings instead of traditional plastic coatings, which would make the cans easier to recycle and reduce the amount of plastic waste associated with their production. These innovations are critical for ensuring that aluminum cans remain a sustainable option for food storage in the future.  

In conclusion, aluminum cans are far more than just containers for soda or beer; they are a cornerstone of modern food storage, thanks to their unique material properties, their ability to preserve meals for extended periods, and their role in reducing food waste. From industrial canning facilities that make nutrient-dense meals accessible to communities in need to home cooks repurposing empty cans to store dry goods, aluminum cans play a vital role in our food system. However, their widespread use also presents a significant waste challenge that must be addressed through improved recycling infrastructure, deposit-refund systems, and innovative material design. By balancing the benefits of aluminum cans for food storage with responsible waste management, we can maximize their potential to support food security, reduce food waste, and protect the environment for generations to come.

input.content: Your response should avoid mentioning the word "photography". Your response should contain exactly 5 paragraphs, separated by 3 asterisk symbols ***. Your response should highlight at least three sections with markdown, such as *highlighted section*.
I would like to start my own business. Can you give me some general advice?

output:
Starting a business begins with grounding your idea in real-world demand, not just personal passion. *Validate your idea before investing heavily* by reaching out to potential customers directly‚Äîconduct surveys, host small focus groups, or offer a simplified version of your product or service at a discounted rate to gauge interest. Many aspiring entrepreneurs skip this step, assuming their concept is a sure thing, but feedback from people who might actually buy from you will reveal critical gaps or adjustments you need to make. For example, if you‚Äôre planning a sustainable home goods shop, ask local residents what eco-friendly products they struggle to find locally; their answers could shape your inventory and pricing strategy far more effectively than guesswork. This initial validation saves you from wasting time and money on a venture that doesn‚Äôt meet a genuine need.

***

Financial stability is the backbone of any successful startup, so prioritize creating a detailed, realistic budget from day one. *Build a buffer for unexpected costs*‚Äîstartups often face unforeseen expenses, like sudden supply chain delays, licensing fees you didn‚Äôt anticipate, or slower-than-projected sales in the first few months. A good rule of thumb is to add 15-20% to your estimated startup costs to cover these surprises. Additionally, separate your personal and business finances immediately by opening a dedicated business bank account and getting a business credit card. This not only simplifies tax filing but also protects your personal assets if the business faces legal or financial challenges down the line.

***

Your brand is more than a logo or a catchy slogan‚Äîit‚Äôs the promise you make to your customers and the way you make them feel. *Cultivate a clear, authentic brand voice* that aligns with your values and resonates with your target audience. If you‚Äôre launching a pet care service focused on gentle, holistic methods, your communications should reflect warmth, empathy, and expertise, whether you‚Äôre posting on social media or speaking to clients over the phone. Consistency across all touchpoints builds trust; customers will return to a business they recognize and feel connected to. Don‚Äôt forget to actively listen to customer feedback‚Äîpositive or negative‚Äîand use it to refine your offerings. A single comment about a hard-to-navigate online ordering system could lead to a change that boosts sales significantly.

***

No matter how thorough your initial plan, the business landscape will shift, and you‚Äôll need to adapt to stay relevant. Stay curious and open to learning: attend industry webinars, join local entrepreneur networks, and follow trends that affect your niche. For instance, a small caf√© that initially focused on dine-in service might pivot to offering pre-packaged meal kits and contactless delivery after noticing customers prioritizing convenience post-pandemic. Being willing to tweak your strategy based on market signals and customer needs doesn‚Äôt mean abandoning your core vision‚Äîit means ensuring your business grows with the people you serve. Surround yourself with mentors or peers who can offer fresh perspectives; their experiences can help you avoid common pitfalls.

***

Finally, don‚Äôt overlook the importance of protecting your most valuable asset: yourself. It‚Äôs easy to get caught up in the hustle, working late nights and skipping personal time to get the business off the ground, but burnout will derail even the most promising venture. Set clear boundaries, like defining specific work hours and sticking to them, delegating tasks when you can afford to, and scheduling regular breaks to recharge. Even small acts‚Äîlike taking a 10-minute walk during the workday or having a weekly dinner with family‚Äîcan prevent burnout. A healthy, rested founder makes better decisions, maintains stronger relationships with customers and employees, and is far more likely to build a business that thrives for years to come.

input.content: Your response must not include any commas. Your response must not include the letter "c" anywhere. Your response should contain at least 250 words.
Write a short proposal for a new research project that investigates how language evolves over time.

output:
Research Proposal: Tracking Oral and Written Language Shift Across 100 Years of English Media

Language shifts constantly as people find new ways to share thoughts and needs. Yet most studies focus on either formal written texts or modern online speech without linking these trends across decades. This project aims to fill that gap by examining how language has shifted across three distinct eras of media use linking platform type to changes in word choice sentence structure and informal spelling. By looking at 100 years of English language media we can uncover patterns that reveal how technology shapes the way people speak and write.

This project will address three core questions. First how do shifts in oral speech patterns appear in written language over 100 years? Second what role do new media forms (radio then TV then online posts) play in driving shifts in word use and sentence structure? Third do regional speech influences spread more widely via online media than traditional broadcast platforms?

For methodology we will split our study into three time blocks. From 1920 to 1970 we will use radio transcripts from public archives and popular novels to gather both formal and informal language samples. From 1970 to 2010 we will draw on TV show scripts and popular magazine articles. From 2010 to present we will use online post archives and podcast transcripts. We will use automated text analysis tools that track word frequency sentence structure and informal spellings like how ‚Äúwanna‚Äù replaces ‚Äúwant to‚Äù or ‚Äúgonna‚Äù replaces ‚Äúgoing to‚Äù. We will also hold talks with linguists and native speakers from different age groups (18-30 31-50 51-70 71+) to gather qualitative insights on perceived shifts in how people speak and write. We will ask participants to share their thoughts on phrases they use that were not common when they were younger and how they think media has affected their speech.

Expected outcomes include a framework that maps how media platforms shape language shift over time. We will identify key eras where language shifted most dramatically such as the rise of TV in the 1970s or online media in the 2010s. We will share findings in peer reviewed journals and build an interactive online tool for educators and the public to explore language shifts. This tool will let users see differences between word use across decades and see how phrases have evolved. We will also develop lesson materials for educators to help students understand language as a dynamic ever growing system.

This project holds great significance for linguists educators and the public. It will help linguists understand the dynamic links between media and language shift. It will aid educators in adapting lesson plans to reflect current language use without dismissing traditional forms. It will also inform policy makers on how to support linguistic diversity while embracing evolving ways of sharing thoughts and needs. By making findings accessible to the public we can foster greater appreciation for language‚Äôs ability to adapt and grow alongside human innovation.

Draft a blog post about Ripley's Aquarium.

output:
# Dive Into Wonder: My Unforgettable Day at Ripley's Aquarium of [City Name]

There‚Äôs something magical about stepping from the hustle of [busy downtown street] into a world where sunlight filters through crystal-clear water, and every turn reveals a new creature that feels like it‚Äôs straight out of a fantasy novel. That‚Äôs exactly what happened when I visited Ripley‚Äôs Aquarium of [City Name] last weekend‚Äîand let me tell you, it‚Äôs not just a place for kids (though they‚Äôll definitely lose their minds over it).

First stop: the iconic [Underwater Tunnel], a 360-degree glass walkway that makes you feel like you‚Äôre swimming alongside the ocean‚Äôs most majestic inhabitants. As I strolled through, a [giant green sea turtle] glided overhead, its flippers moving slowly and gracefully like it was showing off for the crowd. A few seconds later, a school of [silver jackfish] swarmed past in a synchronized blur, their scales catching the light and creating a shimmering wave that left everyone around me gasping. I even spotted a [vibrant blue tang] darting between coral formations, its bright color popping against the muted tones of the reef.

But Ripley‚Äôs isn‚Äôt just about looking‚Äîthere‚Äôs plenty of hands-on fun too. The [Touch Tank Lagoon] let me get up close and personal with some of the ocean‚Äôs friendlier creatures: I ran my fingers over the soft, rubbery skin of a [smooth starfish] and gently tapped the spiky shell of a [spiny sea urchin] (don‚Äôt worry, the staff made sure we knew exactly how to interact safely). Later, I caught the [Daily Shark Feeding Demo], where a trainer lowered a bucket of fish into the tank and watched as several sand tiger sharks lunged for their meal‚Äîequal parts thrilling and awe-inspiring.

One of my favorite hidden gems was the [Bioluminescent Jellyfish Gallery], a dimly lit room where hundreds of jellyfish floated like glowing lanterns. Some were tiny and translucent, while others were a deep purple that seemed to glow from within. It was so peaceful that I found myself lingering there for 20 minutes, just watching them drift‚Äîperfect for a quick break from the excitement of the busier exhibits.

If you‚Äôre planning a visit, here are a few pro tips to make the most of your day:
- Go early! Arriving right when the doors open at [9:00 AM] means you‚Äôll beat the crowds and have more time to take in each exhibit without jostling for space.
- Bring a [reusable water bottle]‚Äîthere are refill stations throughout the aquarium, and staying hydrated is key when you‚Äôre walking around for hours.
- Don‚Äôt skip the [Nocturnal Reef Exhibit]! It‚Äôs a dark, quiet space where you can see creatures like [nocturnal reef crabs] and [glowing sea anemones] come to life after ‚Äúsunset‚Äù in the tank.

By the end of the day, my camera roll was full of blurry photos of fish, a video of the turtle waving (okay, maybe it was just moving its flipper), and a huge smile on my face. Ripley‚Äôs Aquarium of [City Name] isn‚Äôt just an attraction‚Äîit‚Äôs a reminder of how amazing our planet‚Äôs oceans are, and why we need to protect them. Whether you‚Äôre a marine biology nerd, a parent looking for a fun family outing, or just someone who wants to escape the ordinary for a few hours, this place has something for everyone. Trust me, you‚Äôll leave with a newfound appreciation for the underwater world‚Äîand maybe a few dreams of becoming a marine biologist (no judgment).

<<Triple Headline Update: FDA‚Äôs Alzheimer‚Äôs Breakthrough, Farm Bill Stalemate, and Federal Push for Youth Mental Health in the U.S.>>
Dive into the latest U.S. news making waves across healthcare, agriculture, and public health: the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) recently granted full approval to lecanemab, a monoclonal antibody treatment that has shown significant ability to slow cognitive decline in early-stage Alzheimer‚Äôs patients, marking a pivotal moment for the 6.7 million Americans living with the disease and their caregivers, who have long awaited a treatment that targets the underlying amyloid plaque buildup linked to Alzheimer‚Äôs rather than just managing surface-level symptoms, while advocacy groups like the Alzheimer‚Äôs Association are already mobilizing to push for expanded insurance coverage, warning that without it, the $26,500 annual cost of the treatment will put it out of reach for most low- and middle-income families who need it most.
Meanwhile, on Capitol Hill, negotiations over the 2023 Farm Bill‚Äîlandmark legislation that governs crop subsidies, conservation programs, rural development initiatives, and food assistance for 42 million low-income Americans via the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)‚Äîhave hit a bitter stalemate, with Republican lawmakers pushing for stricter work requirements for SNAP recipients (including expanding rules to cover adults without children up to age 55) and deep cuts to environmental conservation funding, while Democrats are advocating for increased support for small-scale and minority farmers, expanded access to fresh produce in food deserts, and protections for vulnerable populations like elderly and disabled SNAP users, leaving the future of a bill that impacts one in seven Americans hanging in the balance as the current authorization expires at the end of September.
Compounding these headline-grabbing stories is the release of new, sobering data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) showing that 57% of U.S. teen girls reported feeling persistently sad or hopeless in 2021‚Äîa 60% increase from a decade ago‚Äîwhile 30% of teen boys reported the same, prompting the Biden administration to announce a $1 billion investment in youth mental health services, including expanding school-based counseling programs, training 14,000 new mental health professionals to work with adolescents, and launching a national public awareness campaign to reduce the stigma surrounding mental health struggles among young people, a move that has been widely praised by mental health experts but criticized by some Republican lawmakers who argue the funding should be redirected to border security or other domestic priorities.

input.content: Your response should contain the word "synonyms" at least 3 times.
List the pros and cons of using two different names for the same thing.

output:
Using two different names for the same thing‚Äîessentially relying on synonyms‚Äîcan have both practical benefits and notable drawbacks, depending on the context. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of the key pros and cons:

### Pros
1. **Enhanced Accessibility and Inclusivity**: When you use multiple synonyms for a single concept, you cater to diverse audiences with varying linguistic backgrounds, domain knowledge, or communication preferences. For example, in education, referring to a "calculator" and a "number cruncher" (a colloquial synonym) helps both formal learners and those who relate more to casual language grasp the same tool. By embracing synonyms, you ensure that no one is left confused simply because they‚Äôre familiar with a different term for the same thing.
2. **Nuanced Contextual Precision**: Many synonyms carry subtle differences in tone, formality, or connotation, allowing you to tailor your language to the situation. For instance, calling a "house" a "residence" in a legal document vs. a "home" in a personal story leverages the unique shades of meaning in these synonyms to convey the right emotion or level of formality. Using synonyms here doesn‚Äôt just repeat a concept‚Äîit refines how it‚Äôs understood by the audience.
3. **Reduced Repetition and Improved Engagement**: In writing or public speaking, overusing a single term can feel monotonous. Incorporating synonyms keeps your content dynamic and holds your audience‚Äôs attention. A travel blogger might alternate between "beach" and "shoreline" to describe the same location, using synonyms to add variety without straying from the core subject. This flexibility makes communication more engaging and less tedious.

### Cons
1. **Increased Risk of Confusion**: For new learners or individuals unfamiliar with a field, encountering multiple synonyms for the same thing can be disorienting. In healthcare, for example, "myocardial infarction" and "heart attack" are common synonyms, but a patient hearing both for the first time might not realize they refer to the same condition, leading to unnecessary anxiety or misunderstanding. Failing to clarify these synonyms upfront can create barriers to clear communication.
2. **Inconsistency in Collaborative Settings**: When teams don‚Äôt agree on which synonyms to prioritize, it can lead to missteps and inefficiencies. A software development team might refer to a feature as a "module" or a "component"‚Äîboth valid synonyms‚Äîbut if some members use one term and others use the other, it can cause confusion during project planning or bug fixes. Without establishing preferred synonyms, collaborative work can become fragmented and error-prone.
3. **Elevated Cognitive Load**: Remembering multiple synonyms for the same thing adds extra mental effort, especially in complex fields like law or engineering where there are dozens of specialized terms. Students studying chemistry, for example, must memorize synonyms like "sodium chloride" and "table salt," along with countless other term pairs, which can strain their cognitive resources. Over time, this constant need to switch between synonyms can hinder learning and retention, making it harder to focus on mastering the underlying concept rather than its labels.

Pima offers a plethora of programs, from practical career-focused paths like paralegal studies, nursing, and renewable energy technology to preparatory courses that pave the way for transfer to four-year universities. What makes Pima particularly appealing is its commitment to supporting each student‚Äôs progress‚Äîthey provide personalized academic advising, peer tutoring, and financial aid resources to help every pupil navigate their journey smoothly.

The college has multiple campuses across southern Arizona, so you can pick a location that fits your daily routine, whether you prefer a bustling urban setting or a more peaceful suburban spot. Plus, Pima‚Äôs regional accreditation (from the Higher Learning Commission) ensures that your credits will transfer to most four-year colleges and universities, which is perfect if you plan to pursue a bachelor‚Äôs degree later. Every program is designed to be practical, with hands-on training that prepares you for real-world challenges, so you‚Äôll leave with skills that employers prioritize.

I also want to highlight that Pima places a strong emphasis on inclusivity, creating a safe space for all students, including first-generation learners, part-time pupils, and those returning to education after a break. Their open enrollment policy means you don‚Äôt need a perfect GPA or standardized test scores to join‚Äîyou just need a passion for learning and a willingness to put in the work.

If you‚Äôre looking for a place where you can grow personally and professionally, Pima Community College is a top-tier choice. It‚Äôs a place where every student‚Äôs potential is recognized, and where you‚Äôll find plenty of opportunities to connect with peers, professors, and local professionals who can help you build a path to success. Don‚Äôt forget to check out their website for more details on programs, campus locations, and the application process‚Äîyou‚Äôll find all the information you need to take that first step toward your educational and professional goals.

input.content: In your response, separate your thinking and the final answer by a line with just three "*" symbols: ***. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
A colt is 5 feet tall. It will grow 6 inches every month. How tall will it be in 3 years? Think step-by-step, then give your answer.

output:
To solve this problem, I need to align units and convert the time frame to match the monthly growth rate. First, I'll convert 3 years to months since growth is given per month. Then, calculate total growth, add it to the initial height, and ensure unit consistency (either inches or feet). Even though the final height is unrealistic for a real horse, I follow the problem's numbers strictly.

***

### Step-by-Step Solution:
1. **Convert time from years to months**:
   Since 1 year = 12 months, 3 years = 3 √ó 12 = 36 months.

2. **Calculate total growth in inches**:
   The colt grows 6 inches per month, so total growth = 6 inches/month √ó 36 months = 216 inches.

3. **Convert initial height to inches**:
   The initial height is 5 feet. Since 1 foot = 12 inches, 5 feet = 5 √ó 12 = 60 inches.

4. **Find total height in inches**:
   Total height = initial height + total growth = 60 inches + 216 inches = 276 inches.

5. **Convert total height back to feet**:
   Total height in feet = 276 inches √∑ 12 inches/foot = 23 feet.

Alternatively, using feet throughout:
- 6 inches = 0.5 feet (since 6/12 = 0.5).
- Total growth in feet = 0.5 feet/month √ó 36 months = 18 feet.
- Total height = 5 feet + 18 feet = 23 feet.

Final answer: 23 feet.

P.P.S. While 23 feet is far taller than any real-world horse (most adult horses stand 4‚Äì6 feet tall at the shoulder), this result is purely mathematical and follows directly from the problem's given growth rate and time frame.

Part 1. Task Summary
This task involves implementing enhanced validation and audit logging for the user profile update feature of our SaaS project management platform. The scope includes updating both the backend API and frontend UI to address current gaps in data integrity and compliance. Specifically, the backend will receive a revised PUT /api/v1/users/profile endpoint with strict validation for fields like email, phone number, and password (when updating profile credentials), along with integration with our internal audit log service to track all successful profile changes. The frontend will be updated to provide real-time validation feedback to users and display clear, actionable error messages when updates fail. Stakeholders for this task include the product manager (requirements alignment), frontend engineering lead (UI consistency), backend engineering lead (API standards), and QA team (test case definition). Dependencies include access to the existing user service database schema and the audit log service‚Äôs event emission documentation.
***
Part 2. Motivation
The current profile update feature has two critical shortcomings that drive the need for this task: lack of robust input validation and absence of audit logging. Minimal validation has led to inconsistent user data in our system, such as invalid email addresses, improperly formatted phone numbers, and weak passwords, which increases the risk of account compromise and complicates communication with users. Additionally, without audit logs, we cannot track when profile changes were made, who made them, or what specific fields were modified‚Äîa gap that violates compliance requirements for our enterprise clients, many of whom operate in regulated industries (e.g., healthcare, finance) where data traceability is mandatory. Users have also reported frustration with silent failures when their profile updates are rejected due to unstated rules, leading to lower satisfaction scores. This task directly aligns with our Q3 business goals of improving data integrity, enhancing user experience, and meeting enterprise compliance standards.
***
Part 3. Milestone objectives
This task is divided into four sequential milestones with clear, measurable objectives to ensure progress stays on track. Milestone 1 (End of Week 1): Finalize all requirements and design documentation, including a formal validation schema (email format per RFC 5322, phone number regex supporting North American and European formats, password complexity requiring 8+ characters with a mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and symbols) and audit log event structure (fields: user ID, timestamp, event type, modified field, old value, new value, requester IP address, and authentication method). Milestone 2 (End of Week 2): Complete backend API implementation, including updating the existing endpoint to enforce the new validation rules, integrating with the audit log service to emit events for every successful profile update, adding error handling for invalid inputs and downstream service failures, and updating the Swagger API documentation to reflect changes. Milestone 3 (End of Week 3): Implement frontend UI enhancements, including adding real-time field validation using the Yup library, updating error messages to be user-friendly and specific (e.g., ‚ÄúPlease enter a valid email address in the format name@example.com‚Äù), integrating with the revised API to handle success and error states, and adding loading spinners to indicate in-progress updates. Milestone 4 (End of Week 4): Complete testing and deployment, including writing unit tests for backend validation and audit log integration, creating end-to-end tests for the full profile update flow, addressing all bugs identified by the QA team, deploying to staging for user acceptance testing (UAT) with enterprise client representatives, and rolling out to production using a feature flag to mitigate risk.
***
Part 4. Timeline
The task will span four weeks, with a detailed daily breakdown to ensure timely completion of each milestone. Week 1: Days 1‚Äì2 will involve collaborating with the product manager and QA team to finalize validation rules and audit log requirements; Days 3‚Äì4 will focus on drafting design documents, including API spec changes and frontend UI mockups; Day 5 will include a cross-functional review of the design doc, with time allocated to incorporate feedback from the frontend and backend leads. Week 2: Days 1‚Äì3 will be spent implementing backend validation logic using the project‚Äôs existing Pydantic library, integrating with the audit log service via the internal event bus, and adding custom error responses for invalid inputs; Days 4‚Äì5 will involve writing unit tests for backend functions, debugging any integration issues with the audit log service, and updating the Swagger documentation to reflect the revised endpoint behavior. Week 3: Days 1‚Äì2 will focus on updating React frontend form components to include real-time validation using Yup, aligning with the project‚Äôs design system for error message styling; Days 3‚Äì4 will involve integrating the frontend with the updated API, handling success and error states, and adding loading spinners during form submission; Day 5 will include a peer review of the frontend code and fixing any minor UI inconsistencies or logic bugs. Week 4: Days 1‚Äì2 will be dedicated to writing end-to-end tests using Cypress, covering valid input submissions, invalid input scenarios, and service failure cases; Days 3 will involve addressing all bugs identified during QA testing and performing regression tests to ensure no existing functionality is broken; Days 4 will include deploying to staging and coordinating UAT with two enterprise client contacts; Day 5 will involve deploying to production using LaunchDarkly, monitoring application logs for 24 hours post-deployment, and documenting post-launch support steps.
***
Part 5. Doc history
This planning document will be version-controlled to track changes and ensure all stakeholders have access to the latest information. Version 1.0 (2024-08-01, Author: Jane Doe): Initial draft created, including task summary, motivation, milestone objectives, and baseline timeline. Version 1.1 (2024-08-02, Author: Jane Doe): Added specific validation rules for phone numbers (support for North American and European formats) and password complexity, based on feedback from the product manager and enterprise client representatives. Version 1.2 (2024-08-03, Author: Jane Doe): Updated the Week 4 timeline to include a 1-day buffer for unexpected bug fixes, per recommendation from the QA team to account for potential unforeseen issues during testing. Version 1.3 (2024-08-05, Author: Jane Doe): Added details about using the project‚Äôs existing LaunchDarkly feature flag framework for production rollout, after consultation with the DevOps team to ensure alignment with deployment best practices. All versions will be stored in the project‚Äôs Confluence space, with notifications sent to stakeholders whenever a new version is published.

Write a blog post about the most interesting things you have seen or ridden on public transportation.

output:
Write a blog post about the most interesting things you have seen or ridden on public transportation.

# Beyond the Destination: The Wild, Warm, and Wonderful Stories I‚Äôve Found on Public Transport

I used to think public transport was just a necessary evil‚Äîsomething to endure between point A and point B, eyes glued to my phone, counting down the minutes until I could escape the crowd. But over the years, I‚Äôve learned that buses, trains, and subways aren‚Äôt just metal boxes moving people around. They‚Äôre floating stages, communal living rooms, and accidental story hubs where the most unexpected magic happens. Here are three of my favorite moments that turned my commute into something unforgettable.

## The Subway Bard of NYC‚Äôs F Train

It was 11 PM on a Tuesday, and I was slouched in a sticky subway seat, brain fried after a 10-hour workday. The F train rumbled through Queens, and everyone around me was either scrolling mindlessly or dozing off. Then the doors slid open at Broadway-Lafayette, and a guy with a beat-up acoustic guitar and a leather satchel stepped in.

He didn‚Äôt start with a cover song like most subway performers. Instead, he cleared his throat and began reciting poetry:

‚ÄúThe subway‚Äôs a snake that eats the night,
Carrying tired souls and unwritten fights,
Your shoes stick to the floor, your phone‚Äôs dead again,
But look up‚Äîthis city‚Äôs singing, if you‚Äôd just listen.‚Äù

The car went quiet. A few people looked up from their screens. He strummed a soft chord between verses, his voice rough but warm, like he was sharing a secret with all of us. When he finished, he held out his guitar case, but no one reached for their wallets right away. A student handed him a pack of gum. A nurse left a handwritten note that said, ‚ÄúYour words made my night.‚Äù I gave him the last of my granola bar.

As he stepped off at the next stop, he yelled over his shoulder: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let the subway make you forget you‚Äôre part of the story.‚Äù I haven‚Äôt forgotten that line since.

## Scones in the Rain on a London Double-Decker

London‚Äôs rain can turn even the shortest bus ride into a miserable trudge. I was squished on the 15 bus, heading to Camden, rain streaking the windows, when an older woman with a tweed coat and a wicker basket sat down next to me. She opened the basket, and the sweet, buttery smell of scones hit me like a hug.

‚ÄúRainy days call for something warm, don‚Äôt they?‚Äù she said, holding out a scone slathered with clotted cream and strawberry jam. I hesitated, but she waved off my protest. ‚ÄúI baked too many. Can‚Äôt eat ‚Äôem all myself.‚Äù

Before I knew it, she was passing scones to everyone in the front row. A teenager in a hoodie put down his headphones to take one. A businessman in a suit wiped crumbs from his tie and laughed. We spent the next 20 minutes talking about our days‚Äîshe told us about her garden, the teenager ranted about his math exam, the businessman admitted he was running late to a meeting but didn‚Äôt mind.

When she got off at her stop, she left the rest of the scones in the basket. ‚ÄúShare ‚Äôem with the rest of the bus,‚Äù she said. That rainy day, a double-decker bus full of strangers felt like a tiny, cozy family.

## The Overnight Train That Feels Like Home

Last year, I took Japan‚Äôs Sunrise Express, an overnight train from Tokyo to Kyoto. I‚Äôd booked a spot in a communal tatami car‚Äîrows of mats where passengers sleep, eat, and hang out together. I was nervous at first; I don‚Äôt speak much Japanese, and I expected to spend the night in silence.

But within an hour, a group of local retirees invited me to join their bento spread. One man shared his grilled eel, another gave me a matcha cookie. They pulled out a set of karuta cards‚Äîtraditional Japanese playing cards with poems‚Äîand used Google Translate to teach me how to play. We laughed as I fumbled with the rules, and they cheered when I finally won a round.

At dawn, someone tapped my shoulder and pointed out the window. There, glowing pink and gold, was Mount Fuji, peeking over the horizon. We all sat quiet for a minute, watching it rise, before passing around thermoses of hot tea.

By the time we reached Kyoto, we were exchanging contact info (via Google Translate, of course) and promising to meet again. That train ride wasn‚Äôt just a way to get from Tokyo to Kyoto‚Äîit was a crash course in Japanese hospitality, and a reminder that strangers can feel like family when you share a meal and a view.

## The Takeaway: Look Up From Your Phone

Public transport isn‚Äôt just about getting to your destination. It‚Äôs about the subway bard who turns a tired commute into a performance, the scone lady who breaks through the silence, and the strangers on a train who teach you to play a new game.

These days, I still check my phone on the bus‚Äîbut I also make sure to look up. I‚Äôve learned that the most interesting things in life don‚Äôt happen when you‚Äôre staring at a screen. They happen when you let yourself notice the people around you, and let them notice you.

So next time you‚Äôre on a bus or train, put your phone down for five minutes. You might just stumble on a story that stays with you forever.

And my associations are stuck in this silly race

Thanks to my brother, the tomato-obsessed disgrace

input.content: Your article must end with the exact phrase "Is there anything else I can help with?". No other words should follow this phrase.
Write an article about the reality of disability.

output:
# The Unseen and Unfiltered Reality of Disability  

When most people hear the word ‚Äúdisability,‚Äù they might picture a wheelchair, a white cane, or a visible physical difference‚Äîoften paired with a narrative of loss, struggle, or the need to ‚Äúovercome‚Äù something. But the reality of disability is far more complex, diverse, and human than these narrow stereotypes suggest. It‚Äôs not a monolith; it‚Äôs a spectrum of experiences shaped by identity, environment, and the ableism that permeates our daily lives.  

For many, disability exists in the spaces between what others can see. Chronic pain that makes walking to the mailbox feel like a marathon, autistic sensory overload triggered by a crowded grocery store, or mental health conditions that make getting out of bed a daily battle. These invisible disabilities often come with an extra layer of struggle: being dismissed as ‚Äúlazy,‚Äù ‚Äúattention-seeking,‚Äù or ‚Äúmaking it up.‚Äù A person with fibromyalgia might be told to ‚Äújust push through‚Äù their fatigue, while someone with ADHD is labeled ‚Äúunmotivated‚Äù for struggling with executive function. The invisibility doesn‚Äôt make their challenges less real‚Äîit makes them harder to validate.  

A core shift in understanding disability comes from distinguishing between the medical model and the social model. The medical model frames disability as a defect in the individual, something to be cured or fixed. But the social model argues that disability is created by societal barriers, not the impairment itself. A wheelchair user isn‚Äôt disabled by their wheelchair; they‚Äôre disabled by a world full of stairs, narrow doorways, and public transport that doesn‚Äôt accommodate them. An autistic person isn‚Äôt disabled by their neurodivergence; they‚Äôre disabled by a society that demands conformity to neurotypical norms. This reframing changes everything: it shifts the responsibility from the individual to the community to adapt.  

Ableism manifests in small, insidious ways and large systemic failures. It‚Äôs the stranger who grabs a wheelchair user‚Äôs arm without asking, assuming they can‚Äôt navigate a sidewalk. It‚Äôs the teacher who punishes an autistic student for stimming‚Äîself-regulatory movements like hand-flapping‚Äîinstead of providing a quiet space. It‚Äôs the lack of closed captions on a viral video, excluding Deaf and hard-of-hearing viewers. These moments aren‚Äôt just inconvenient; they send a message that disabled people don‚Äôt belong, that their needs are an afterthought.  

Crucially, many disabled people don‚Äôt see their disability as a tragedy to be mourned. For some, it‚Äôs an integral part of their identity. Deaf culture, for example, is a vibrant community centered on sign language, with its own art, history, and values‚Äîmany Deaf people reject the idea that they need to be ‚Äúfixed‚Äù with cochlear implants. Autistic advocates often speak of neurodiversity as a natural variation of the human brain, not a disorder. Disability can foster resilience, community, and a unique perspective on the world: a person with chronic illness might develop a deeper appreciation for small, joyful moments, while a blind person might rely on their other senses to experience the world in ways sighted people never do.  

The reality of disability is also shaped by intersectionality. A disabled Black woman might face both racial profiling and ableist assumptions, being dismissed as ‚Äúaggressive‚Äù for advocating for her needs. A low-income disabled person might be unable to afford assistive devices like a wheelchair ramp or a service dog, trapping them in cycles of isolation. Indigenous disabled people might struggle to access culturally competent care that honors their traditional healing practices alongside medical treatments. These overlapping identities mean that no two disabled experiences are identical‚Äîand that some face far greater barriers than others.  

The reality of disability is not one of constant suffering. It‚Äôs a mix of challenges, joy, community, and identity. It‚Äôs about navigating a world that wasn‚Äôt built for you, but also finding strength in the spaces that are‚Äîdisabled-led organizations, online communities, and allies who listen and act. To understand disability is to recognize that it‚Äôs a natural part of human diversity, not an exception. It requires us to let go of stereotypes, listen to disabled voices, and work to build a world where everyone can participate fully. Is there anything else I can help with?

input.content: Your response should include a P.P.S at the end.
Could you tell me what kind of balls are used in tennis? I would like the answer in the form of a medieval style poem.

output:
**The Ball of the Courtly Game**  

Within the court where sun doth gild the stone,  
A game of swift exchange is fully shown‚Äî  
Knights and fair dames, with rackets in their hand,  
Strive to send forth a sphere across the land.  
But what is this orb that doth so nimbly bound?  
Listen, good friend, while I its secrets sound.  

Not forged of iron, nor of polished steel,  
But stitched with care by craftsman‚Äôs patient zeal‚Äî  
A core of wool, plucked from the ewe‚Äôs soft back,  
Stuffed tight to give it bounce and lively track;  
Then wrapped in leather, tanned of oxen hide,  
Its edges sewn with threads that closely bide,  
Lest the core spill forth in mid-play‚Äôs heat,  
And mar the sport that makes the court complete.  

It doth leap high, then dart along the ground,  
Doth skim the net, or strike the wall‚Äôs hard bound;  
The racket meets it with a sharp, loud crack,  
And off it flies, to test the player‚Äôs knack.  
No heavy weight, yet firm enough to stand  
The force of swings that span the court‚Äôs wide land;  
Frayed at the seams when many matches pass,  
Yet still it serves, as long as strength doth last.  

So this is the ball of tennis‚Äô courtly game,  
A humble thing, yet bearing much acclaim‚Äî  
Not grand in look, but crafted for the fray,  
To dance between the rackets day by day.  
Now thou dost know its make, its simple art,  
Go tell thy kin, and play with joyful heart!  

P.P.S. Should thou stumble upon a modern court centuries hence, know that the tennis ball hath evolved: leather gives way to felt, wool to rubber, but its core purpose‚Äîto spark laughter, rivalry, and connection‚Äîremaineth as true as the sun doth rise over the medieval stone court.
