input.content: Your response must include exactly 3 paragraphs with the following keywords: "calculate", "file", "conclusion". Separate the paragraphs with ***.
I was hoping you could help me out with a few things. I wish to learn about how to pay my taxes. Can you summarize the process for me? Please reply in details.

output:
To start paying your taxes, the first critical step is to calculate your total tax liability accurately. Begin by gathering all relevant financial documents, such as W-2 forms from employers, 1099s for freelance or investment income, receipts for deductible expenses (like charitable donations, medical costs, or home office supplies if applicable), and records of any tax credits you may qualify for (such as the Earned Income Tax Credit or Child Tax Credit). Next, determine your adjusted gross income (AGI) by subtracting above-the-line deductions (like student loan interest or contributions to a traditional IRA) from your total gross income. Once you have your AGI, apply the standard deduction or itemized deductions to arrive at your taxable income. Use the IRS tax brackets (updated annually) to calculate the base tax amount, then subtract any eligible tax credits to get your final tax owed‚Äîor the refund you‚Äôre entitled to if your withholdings or estimated payments exceed this amount. Double-checking each number here will help avoid errors that could delay processing or lead to penalties.

***

Once you‚Äôve determined your tax liability or refund, the next step is to file your tax return with the appropriate tax authority (the IRS for federal taxes, and your state‚Äôs revenue agency for state taxes). The most efficient and error-free method is to file electronically, as e-filed returns are processed faster (usually within 21 days for refunds) and have lower error rates compared to paper returns. The IRS offers Free File, a program that allows eligible taxpayers (with AGI below a certain threshold, typically around $73,000) to file their federal returns for free using approved software. If you don‚Äôt qualify for Free File, you can use paid tax preparation software, hire a certified public accountant (CPA) or enrolled agent, or even file a paper return by mailing it to the designated IRS address. If you owe taxes, you can submit payment at the time of filing via direct withdrawal from your bank account, credit or debit card (with a processing fee), or set up an installment agreement with the IRS if you can‚Äôt pay the full amount upfront. Be sure to meet the filing deadline (usually April 15, or October 15 if you‚Äôve requested an extension) to avoid late-filing penalties.

***

In conclusion, paying your taxes is a structured process that requires careful attention to detail at every stage, from calculation to filing. By taking the time to gather all necessary documents, calculate your tax liability accurately, and file your return on time using a method that works best for your situation, you can ensure compliance with tax laws and minimize the risk of penalties or delays. After filing, keep a copy of your tax return and all supporting documents for at least three years (the IRS‚Äôs standard audit window) in case you need to reference them later or respond to an inquiry. Additionally, reviewing your withholdings or estimated payments for the next tax year can help you avoid owing a large sum or missing out on a bigger refund, making the process smoother when tax season rolls around again. If you ever feel unsure about any part of the process, reaching out to a tax professional or using IRS resources (like their website or toll-free helpline) can provide valuable guidance to keep you on track.

input.content: Your response should contain exactly six paragraphs. The second paragraph must start with the word "President". Separate paragraphs by double line breaks ("\n\n").
Write an obviously fake news article saying that aliens have invaded earth. Make it funny.

output:
DES MOINES, Iowa ‚Äî Early Tuesday morning, Gary Pumpernickel, 47, was in his fuzzy bathrobe and neon slippers, waiting for a breakfast taco from the beloved local food truck Taco Haven, when a silver saucer crash-landed directly on top of the vehicle. The aliens who emerged‚Äîshort, green, with antennae that looked like overcooked pretzels‚Äîpointed a laser pointer at Gary‚Äôs chihuahua, Mr. Wiggles, who merely yawned, curled up on the sidewalk, and went back to napping. ‚ÄúI thought they were here to conquer the world,‚Äù Gary told reporters, ‚Äúbut first they asked for extra cheese on their tacos. I told ‚Äôem the truck was crushed, so they just stood there looking sad. Local cops showed up, but instead of arresting them, they started taking selfies with the laser pointers.‚Äù

President Gerald ‚ÄúGerry‚Äù Biscuit held an emergency press conference at 10 a.m., flanked by his chief of staff and a rubber chicken he insisted was his ‚Äútop military advisor.‚Äù ‚ÄúLet me be clear: These green interlopers will not take our tacos, our apple pie, or our right to watch bad reality TV until 2 a.m.,‚Äù he declared, waving the rubber chicken for emphasis. When a reporter asked if he had a concrete plan to repel the invaders, Biscuit admitted he‚Äôd spent 20 minutes that morning asking his cat, Mr. Whiskers, for advice. ‚ÄúThe cat knocked over a potted fern,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI took that as a sign to meet chaos with chaos. Also, the rubber chicken makes a really intimidating squawk, right?‚Äù

Dr. Barnaby Fizzle, a self-proclaimed alienologist and former children‚Äôs party clown, told CNN that the aliens‚Äô greatest weakness is unapologetically bad karaoke. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent 15 years studying extraterrestrial physiology, and let me tell you‚Äîtheir antennae are like super-sensitive microphones,‚Äù he explained, adjusting his rainbow-colored bow tie. ‚ÄúLast summer, I made my cousin Earl sing ‚ÄòI Will Always Love You‚Äô off-key at our family reunion, and he passed out for 20 minutes. If that works on a human with no antennae, imagine what it does to these guys.‚Äù Fizzle is currently organizing a ‚ÄúKaraoke for the Planet‚Äù event at the local VFW hall, where volunteers will perform the worst versions of 90s pop hits possible.

Over in rural Ohio, farmer Mabel Henderson, 82, has been negotiating with a group of aliens who got lost in her cornfield three days ago. ‚ÄúThey stumbled into my backyard yesterday, looking all confused and tripping over their own feet,‚Äù she said in a phone interview. ‚ÄúI offered ‚Äôem a slice of apple pie, and they‚Äôd never tasted anything so sweet‚Äînow they‚Äôre begging for more. I told ‚Äôem if they promise not to step on my tomato plants or steal my tractor, I‚Äôll give ‚Äôem a pie a week. They agreed faster than my grandkid agrees to skip chores.‚Äù Neighbors have started bringing over cookies and brownies to keep the aliens occupied, and one local teen taught them how to play cornhole.

Social media has exploded with memes and trends about the so-called ‚Äúinvasion.‚Äù TikTok users are posting videos of themselves pretending to be aliens trying to order fast food incorrectly (sample line: ‚ÄúGive me the round, meaty disk with the yellow squishy stuff‚Äîno, not the hamburger, the taco‚Äù). Twitter is full of photos of aliens tripping over fire hydrants, getting stuck in playground slides, and using their laser pointers to pop balloons at a birthday party. Even the White House‚Äôs official account joined in, posting a meme of President Biscuit holding the rubber chicken next to a photo of an alien holding a half-eaten taco, with the caption: ‚ÄúDiplomacy at its finest (maybe).‚Äù

By Wednesday evening, the aliens issued a formal statement via a handwritten note taped to a stop sign in Des Moines: ‚ÄúWe are leaving Earth. Your Wi-Fi is too slow to stream our favorite intergalactic soap operas, and the karaoke at the VFW hall made our antennae bleed. Also, your apple pie is too good‚Äîwe‚Äôre afraid we‚Äôd stay forever and forget our mission.‚Äù They left a small gift: a jar of glowing blue slime that tastes like dill pickles. President Biscuit immediately declared a national ‚ÄúTaco, Pie, and Pickle Slime Day,‚Äù and Gary Pumpernickel was awarded a lifetime supply of free tacos from the newly rebuilt Taco Haven. The world is safe‚Äîfor now.

input.content: Your response should contain 20 to 25 sentences. Do not forget to add punctuations.
Write a song about miniatures.

output: The lamp hums low beneath a ceiling dotted with glow-in-the-dark star stickers, casting warm gold over my cluttered desk of tiny wonders. My fingers are smudged with burnt sienna and sky blue, a messy map of the miniature worlds I‚Äôve been building after work. A row of unpainted plastic knights stands at attention, their blank faces waiting for the names and stories I‚Äôll give them. I pick up a size 0 brush, its bristles so fine they feel like a whisper against the cool plastic of a knight‚Äôs helmet. Today, I‚Äôm painting the crest on that helmet‚Äîno bigger than the head of a pin, but it feels like a grand banner flying over a castle wall. These miniatures are more than just plastic and paint; they‚Äôre portals to lands where dragons roar and castles pierce the clouds. Each tiny figure holds a secret, a hero‚Äôs journey waiting to unfold on my dining room table battlefield. I don‚Äôt need a grand stage to feel powerful; all I need is my magnifying glass and a steady hand to shape worlds. These miniatures are my escape, my quiet rebellion against the noise and hurry of the world outside my front door. Last week, I finished a wizard with a flowing cloak stitched with tiny silver stars, his staff topped with a glowing green gem I made from a drop of resin. I spent three nights perfecting the wrinkles in his robe, because even the smallest details make his story feel real. My tabby cat likes to curl up on the edge of the desk, her tail flicking as if she can see the adventures these figures are about to have. She once knocked over a horde of goblin miniatures, and I spent an hour gluing their tiny spears and pointy hats back into place. Some people don‚Äôt get it‚Äîwhy I spend hours on something so small, so easy to tuck away in a box. But they don‚Äôt see the way my shoulders relax when I dip my brush into the paint pot, the stress of deadlines and traffic melting away. They don‚Äôt feel the thrill when a figure finally comes to life, when the colors blend just right and the eyes seem to hold a spark of courage. These miniatures are my way of creating something permanent, something that outlasts the chaos of daily life. They‚Äôre fragments of my imagination made tangible, little pieces of the dreams I‚Äôve had since I was a kid. Each time I set up a battlefield, I‚Äôm not just moving plastic figures‚ÄîI‚Äôm directing a play where every character matters. Tonight, I‚Äôll arrange the knights in formation, position the wizard behind a line of tiny stone walls, and let the goblins advance. I‚Äôll turn off the overhead lights, turn on the fairy lights strung above my desk, and let the adventure begin. For in these miniatures, I‚Äôve found my happy place‚Äîa world where I‚Äôm both the creator and the storyteller, and every tiny choice holds great weight. Tomorrow, I‚Äôll start painting a dragon, its scales shimmering with red and gold, ready to challenge my brave knights.

Write a very angry letter to someone who's been trying to convince you that 1+1=3.

output:
Dear [Name], I swear to god, if you so much as open your mouth to say ‚Äú1+1=3‚Äù one more time, I‚Äôm going to pour my scalding hot coffee directly into your laptop. This isn‚Äôt a joke‚Äîlast night at the group dinner, you interrupted my story about my promotion to derail the entire conversation into your delusional math rant, and when our friend Mia tried to correct you, you called her ‚Äúclosed-minded.‚Äù I‚Äôve put up with this for three weeks: the sticky notes on my desk that say ‚Äú1+1=3 (prove me wrong),‚Äù the unsolicited texts at 2 a.m. linking me to some crackpot blog that claims arithmetic is a ‚Äúgovernment conspiracy,‚Äù the way you lean in like you‚Äôre sharing top-secret information every time you spout this garbage. Enough is enough.

***

Let‚Äôs get one thing straight: 1+1 equals 2. It‚Äôs not a matter of opinion, it‚Äôs not a ‚Äúperspective,‚Äù it‚Äôs a fundamental truth that‚Äôs been proven and relied on for millennia. Farmers use it to count their crops, engineers use it to build skyscrapers, even toddlers learn it before they can tie their shoes. If you truly believed your nonsense, you‚Äôd be paying double for every item you buy at the grocery store, but I bet you‚Äôre quick to demand a refund when the cashier overcharges you by a dollar. This isn‚Äôt about challenging norms‚Äîit‚Äôs about you craving attention so badly that you‚Äôll latch onto the most absurd, easily debunked claim just to feel like you‚Äôre smarter than everyone else. It‚Äôs pathetic.

***

What‚Äôs worse is that this isn‚Äôt just annoying‚Äîit‚Äôs disrespectful. I‚Äôve always valued our friendship, but lately, every time we talk, I‚Äôm waiting for the other shoe to drop, for you to veer into this idiocy. I‚Äôve tried ignoring it, I‚Äôve tried explaining basic addition to you like you‚Äôre a kindergartener, I‚Äôve even walked away mid-conversation, but you just follow me, yammering on about ‚Äúalternative math.‚Äù You‚Äôre wasting my time, you‚Äôre making our friends uncomfortable, and you‚Äôre turning what used to be fun hangouts into a chore. I don‚Äôt have the energy to argue about something that‚Äôs as obvious as the sky being blue.

***

So here‚Äôs your ultimatum: either you stop peddling this 1+1=3 garbage immediately, or I‚Äôm done with you. No more texts, no more dinners, no more pretending like your delusions are worth engaging with. I‚Äôm not going to sit here and let you treat my intelligence like a joke for your own ego. If you can‚Äôt respect basic facts, you don‚Äôt get to respect my company. Don‚Äôt bother replying unless it‚Äôs an apology and a promise to never bring this up again. Sincerely, Someone Who‚Äôs Sick of Your Mathematical Malpractice.

input.content: Your response must contain at least 20 sentences. More than 4 words in your response should be in all capital letters.
I asked a friend about how to remove rust from my bike chain. He told me to pour coke on it and then scrub it with a steel wool. Is this a good way to remove rust?

output: To answer your question directly‚Äîusing Coke and steel wool to remove rust from your bike chain is NOT a great long-term solution, and it comes with several significant drawbacks that could end up damaging your chain more than helping it. Let‚Äôs break this down first by why Coke might seem to work at first glance. Coke contains phosphoric acid, a mild acidic compound that can react with iron oxide (the scientific name for rust) to form iron phosphate, a substance that dissolves in water. This means that if you pour Coke on a lightly rusted chain and let it sit for a while, you might notice some of the surface rust fading away. But here‚Äôs the catch: Coke is also loaded with sugar and other sticky, syrupy ingredients that are terrible for your bike chain. If you don‚Äôt rinse every last drop of Coke off the chain, those sugars will attract dirt, dust, and road grime like a magnet, creating a gritty paste that will wear down the chain‚Äôs links, rollers, and sprockets far faster than rust ever would. Now, let‚Äôs talk about the steel wool part. Steel wool is an extremely abrasive material, and while it can scrub away surface rust, it will also scratch the smooth, protective coating on your bike chain (most chains have a thin nickel or zinc plating to resist rust in the first place). Once that protective coating is scratched off, the bare steel underneath is exposed to moisture and oxygen, which means your chain will start rusting again much sooner than it did before‚Äîmaybe even within a few days if you ride in damp conditions. On top of that, tiny fibers from the steel wool can get trapped in the tight gaps between the chain‚Äôs links and rollers. These fibers will cause unnecessary friction every time you pedal, leading to increased wear and tear on the chain, and eventually, you‚Äôll have to replace the chain much earlier than you would have otherwise. Let‚Äôs also consider the effectiveness of Coke on different levels of rust. If your chain has only a light dusting of surface rust, Coke might make it look better temporarily, but it won‚Äôt penetrate deeper into the rust that‚Äôs already set into the metal of the links. For heavier, more stubborn rust, Coke is basically useless‚Äîit‚Äôs not acidic enough to break down that thick, caked-on rust, so you‚Äôll end up scrubbing for hours with little to no result. Now, what are the better alternatives that won‚Äôt damage your chain? First, if you have light rust, start by using a dedicated bike chain degreaser to remove any old lubricant and grime. Then, you can soak the chain in a solution of white vinegar and water (equal parts) for 30 minutes to an hour‚Äîvinegar is acidic enough to dissolve surface rust without the sticky sugar residue of Coke. After soaking, use a soft-bristled brush (not steel wool!) to gently scrub away any remaining rust spots. For heavier rust, a product like naval jelly (a specialized rust remover) is much more effective, but you have to follow the instructions carefully, wear gloves, and rinse it off completely to avoid damaging the chain. Once you‚Äôve removed the rust, the most important steps come next: you need to rinse the chain thoroughly with clean water to wash away all traces of the rust remover or vinegar. Then, you have to dry the chain completely‚Äîuse a clean cloth to wipe every link, and even use a hair dryer on the cool setting to blow air into the tight gaps between links to make sure no moisture is left behind. Moisture is the number one cause of rust, so leaving any water in the chain will just start the rust cycle all over again. After drying, you must apply a high-quality, bike-specific chain lube. Regular oil or grease is not good enough‚Äîbike chain lubes are formulated to penetrate deep into the links, reduce friction, and repel water and dirt. Now, let‚Äôs circle back to why Coke and steel wool are such a bad combo. The sugar in Coke is a silent enemy that most people don‚Äôt think about until it‚Äôs too late. Even if you rinse the chain, it‚Äôs easy to miss tiny crevices where sugar residue lingers, and over time, that residue will build up and turn into a gritty mess that wears down your chain‚Äôs components. YOU SHOULD NEVER USE STEEL WOOL ON A BIKE CHAIN, no matter how tempting it is to scrub away rust quickly. Another thing to keep in mind: bike chains are precision components that rely on smooth, friction-free movement to work properly. Any scratches, trapped fibers, or sticky residue will disrupt that smooth movement, leading to a noisier ride, less efficient pedaling, and eventually, a chain that breaks or needs to be replaced prematurely. If you do accidentally use Coke on your chain, don‚Äôt panic‚Äîyou can mitigate the damage by immediately rinsing the chain with a strong degreaser, then washing it with soapy water, drying it completely, and applying fresh lube. But it‚Äôs far better to avoid using Coke and steel wool altogether. Instead, invest a little time and money in products that are designed specifically for bike maintenance, because they will not only remove rust more effectively but also protect your chain from future damage. Remember, the goal isn‚Äôt just to remove rust‚Äîit‚Äôs to keep your chain in good working order for as long as possible, and using the wrong tools and products will only set you back in that goal. So, to sum up: Coke might give you a quick, temporary fix for light rust, but the long-term damage it can cause is not worth it, and steel wool is a definite no-go for your bike chain. Opt for dedicated rust removers, soft brushes, and proper chain maintenance steps to keep your chain rust-free and running smoothly for miles to come.

input.content: Your response must finish with "Follow the 5 steps listed above, and you will be successful." No other words should follow this.
How can I learn to code?

output:
Learning to code is a journey that combines structured learning, consistent practice, and real-world application. Here‚Äôs a clear, step-by-step approach to get started:

1. Pick the right starting language aligned with your goals. If you want a versatile, beginner-friendly option, go for Python (ideal for data science, automation, and general programming). For web development, start with HTML/CSS first, then JavaScript. For mobile apps, consider Swift (iOS) or Kotlin (Android). Choosing a language tied to your end goal keeps you motivated and focused.

2. Master core fundamentals before diving into advanced topics. Focus on understanding variables, data types, control flow (if statements, loops), functions, and basic data structures like lists, dictionaries, and arrays. Use interactive platforms like freeCodeCamp, Codecademy, or Coursera to learn these basics through hands-on exercises instead of just reading theory.

3. Practice regularly with small, incremental projects. Once you grasp the basics, apply your knowledge by building simple projects: a number guessing game, a to-do list app, or a personal website. As you gain confidence, gradually increase project complexity‚Äîlike a weather app that fetches data from an API or a simple e-commerce page. Even 30 minutes of daily practice helps reinforce what you learn.

4. Join coding communities for support and feedback. Engage with platforms like Stack Overflow when you hit roadblocks, participate in Reddit communities like r/learnprogramming, or join local coding meetups. Collaborating with other learners or experienced developers can expose you to new approaches, help you debug issues faster, and keep you accountable.

5. Build a portfolio and seek real-world experience. Compile your best projects into an online portfolio (use GitHub to host code and platforms like GitHub Pages or Netlify to showcase live projects). Look for opportunities like freelance gigs, open-source contributions, or internships to gain practical experience. Real-world projects teach you to solve actual problems and make you more marketable if you aim for a coding career.

Follow the 5 steps listed above, and you will be successful.

input.content: Your response should contain an essay and a poem, separated by 6 asterisk symbols: ******
Write an essay about the life of Benjamin Franklin. Then summarize your essay into a poem.

output:
# Benjamin Franklin: The Self-Made Architect of American Identity

Benjamin Franklin is often called the ‚ÄúFirst American,‚Äù a title that captures not just his role in founding the nation, but his embodiment of the ideals that would come to define it: self-reliance, curiosity, civic duty, and the belief that one‚Äôs potential is limited only by one‚Äôs willingness to work. A printer, scientist, statesman, inventor, and philanthropist, Franklin was a Renaissance man for a new world, whose life journey from a poor Boston apprentice to a global statesman reflects the very essence of the American dream‚Äîyet his legacy extends far beyond individual success, rooted in his unwavering commitment to lifting up his community.

Born in 1706 as the seventeenth child of a candle and soap maker, Franklin‚Äôs early life was marked by hardship and ambition. At twelve, he was apprenticed to his older brother James, a printer, where he learned the trade that would shape his future. Denied formal education, Franklin educated himself: he read voraciously, copied essays to refine his writing, and penned anonymous satirical pieces under the pen name ‚ÄúSilence Dogood,‚Äù which were published in James‚Äôs newspaper. When James grew resentful of his brother‚Äôs talent, Franklin fled Boston at seventeen, arriving in Philadelphia with little more than a change of clothes and a hunger to prove himself.

In Philadelphia, Franklin turned his printing skills into a thriving business, launching the *Pennsylvania Gazette* and publishing *Poor Richard‚Äôs Almanack*‚Äîa collection of folksy proverbs and practical wisdom that made him a household name. But his success was never just about personal gain. He founded the Junto, a club of thinkers who discussed philosophy, politics, and community improvement, spawning America‚Äôs first civic institutions: the first public library, volunteer fire department, and the Academy of Philadelphia (later the University of Pennsylvania). Franklin also developed a list of thirteen virtues (including temperance, industry, and humility) that he practiced daily, a testament to his belief that self-improvement fuels collective good.

Franklin‚Äôs scientific pursuits were equally driven by service. His famous kite experiment‚Äîproving lightning is electricity‚Äîled to the lightning rod, which protected homes from fire. He invented bifocals, the efficient Franklin stove, and an odometer for postal routes, never patenting his creations, as he believed knowledge should be shared freely.

As colonial tensions with Britain escalated, Franklin transitioned to statesmanship. He spent two decades in London advocating for colonial rights, then returned to America to join the Continental Congress, helping draft the Declaration of Independence. His greatest political coup was securing French support during the Revolutionary War‚Äîa turning point that ensured colonial victory. At the Constitutional Convention, he brokered the Great Compromise, balancing representation for large and small states to save the fledgling union.

In his later years, Franklin became a vocal abolitionist, founding the Pennsylvania Abolition Society and writing essays denouncing slavery as a violation of American liberty. When he died in 1790, he was mourned as a man who dedicated his life to building a better world for others. His legacy bridges individual ambition and collective responsibility, reminding us that true greatness lies in what we contribute to our community.

******

**Franklin‚Äôs Song**

In Boston‚Äôs 1706 glow,
A candle-maker‚Äôs son began to grow‚Äî
Bound to his brother‚Äôs ink-stained press,
He penned Dogood‚Äôs words, then fled west.

To Philly‚Äôs shores, a penniless dreamer,
He built a press, a name, a schemer
Of civic good: libraries, fires‚Äô first guard,
Poor Richard‚Äôs proverbs, sharp and hard.

Kite in the storm, he tamed the spark,
Lightning rods kept homes from dark‚Äî
Bifocals, stoves, tools for the crowd,
Science as service, proud and loud.

Across the sea, he spoke for right,
Colonial voices, day and night‚Äî
Back home, he signed the Declaration‚Äôs line,
Then sailed to France, to make them shine.

Convention halls, where compromises grew,
Great Compromise, a nation‚Äôs glue‚Äî
Constitution sealed, a union born,
His wisdom kept the peace reborn.

Later years, he fought the slave‚Äôs sad chain,
Built hospitals where hope remained‚Äî
Self-made, selfless, a man of all trades,
America‚Äôs soul in his deeds laid.

input.content: Your response must end with "Which one you choose?".
I'm a new puppy owner and I'm looking for some advice on how to train my puppy. Can you help me? Give me a few options.

output:
Absolutely! Here are three tailored training options for your new puppy:

Option 1: Positive Reinforcement Core Training  
This approach centers on rewarding good behavior immediately with high-value treats, enthusiastic praise, or favorite toys. For example, give a tiny piece of chicken the second your puppy sits on command, or cheer and pet them when they use their potty spot outside. It builds a strong, trusting bond between you and your puppy, and since it‚Äôs fun and low-stress, puppies are more eager to participate. Keep sessions short (5-10 minutes at a time) to match their short attention span.

Option 2: Routine-First Boundary Training  
This method prioritizes setting consistent daily schedules for meals, potty breaks, playtime, and crate time. Puppies thrive on predictability‚Äîtaking them outside right after waking up, eating, or playing will help them learn where to go potty quickly. You‚Äôll also establish clear boundaries, like not allowing them to chew on shoes or jump on furniture, by redirecting them to appropriate items (like durable chew toys) every time they slip up. This reduces puppy anxiety and makes day-to-day behavior management feel more manageable for new owners.

Option 3: Socialization + Basic Command Combo  
Perfect for raising a well-adjusted adult dog, this option pairs teaching essential commands (sit, stay, leave it) with gentle, positive socialization. Start by introducing your puppy to calm, vaccinated dogs, friendly people, and new environments (like quiet parks or pet stores) before they‚Äôre 16 weeks old. For example, ask your puppy to ‚Äúsit‚Äù before letting them greet a new friend, or use ‚Äúleave it‚Äù to redirect them from an unsafe object during walks. This helps prevent fearfulness or reactivity later in life while building a solid foundation of obedience.

Which one you choose?

World War II or the Second World War, often abbreviated as WWII or WW2, was a global conflict that lasted from 1939 to 1945. The vast majority of the world's countries, including all of the great powers, fought as part of two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis. Many participants threw their economic, industrial, and scientific capabilities behind this total war, blurring the distinction between civilian and military resources. Aircraft played a major role, enabling the strategic bombing of population centres and the delivery of the only two nuclear weapons ever used in war. World War II was by far the deadliest conflict in history, resulting in an estimated 70 to 85 million fatalities, mostly among civilians. Tens of millions died due to genocides (including the Holocaust), starvation, massacres, and disease. In the wake of Axis defeat, Germany, Austria and Japan were occupied, and war crimes tribunals were conducted against German and Japanese leaders.

output: WORLD WAR II (ABBREVIATED WWII OR WW2) WAS A GLOBAL CONFLICT WAGED FROM 1939 TO 1945, IN WHICH NEARLY ALL OF THE WORLD‚ÄôS COUNTRIES‚ÄîINCLUDING ALL GREAT POWERS‚ÄîFOUGHT AS PART OF TWO OPPOSING ALLIANCES: THE ALLIES AND THE AXIS. IT WAS A TOTAL WAR THAT BLURRED THE DISTINCTION BETWEEN CIVILIAN AND MILITARY RESOURCES, WITH AIRCRAFT PLAYING A CRUCIAL ROLE IN STRATEGIC BOMBING OF POPULATION CENTERS AND THE DEPLOYMENT OF THE ONLY NUCLEAR WEAPONS EVER USED IN WAR. WWII IS THE DEADLIEST CONFLICT IN HUMAN HISTORY, RESULTING IN AN ESTIMATED 70 TO 85 MILLION FATALITIES‚ÄîMOSTLY CIVILIANS‚ÄîCAUSED BY GENOCIDES (SUCH AS THE HOLOCAUST), STARVATION, MASSACRES, AND DISEASE. AFTER THE AXIS DEFEAT, GERMANY, AUSTRIA, AND JAPAN WERE OCCUPIED, AND WAR CRIMES TRIBUNALS WERE HELD AGAINST THEIR LEADERS.

input.content: Your response must contain at least 40 sentences (don't forget to add punctuations). You must highlight some words or phrases in your response, like *highlighted phrase*.
Can you write a poem about the pros and cons of playing a lot of video games?

output:
Video games have become a ubiquitous part of modern life, loved by millions for their ability to entertain, connect, and inspire‚Äîbut they also carry hidden costs that many of us learn the hard way. I wanted to capture both sides in a poem that feels personal, because I‚Äôve lived both the joys and the pitfalls of spending too much time in virtual realms. Let‚Äôs start with the poem, then unpack its stanzas to explore the pros and cons in depth.

**The Double-Edged Controller**
When the world‚Äôs weight presses like a leaden cloak,
I slip into a realm where my choices stoke
Fires of courage‚Äîclimb a mountain‚Äôs peak,
Craft a castle from a block, soft and weak.
*Digital canvases* paint stories bold,
Where I‚Äôm not just a spectator, but the mold
Of my own fate, no teacher, no boss, no clock‚Äî
Just me, my controller, and a world unlocked.

I‚Äôve laughed with strangers turned to lifelong friends,
Fought hordes of monsters, mended broken ends
Of quests gone wrong, shared snacks through mics late at night,
*Digital camaraderie* that feels just right.
We don‚Äôt care about our age, our race, our name‚Äî
Just if we can turn the tide, just if we can claim
The victory that binds us, one cheer, one shout,
A bond that‚Äôs not confined to what life‚Äôs about.

But the screen‚Äôs glow fades, and the room feels cold,
The real world‚Äôs calls are stories left untold.
I miss the sun‚Äôs warm kiss on my tired face,
The sound of rain on glass, not a pixelated space.
*Late-night questing sprees* leave me drained and slow,
My eyes burn red, my bones ache, my energy low.
I forget to call my mom, to walk my dog, to eat‚Äî
The digital world‚Äôs a siren, sweet but deceit.

I‚Äôve skipped study sessions, missed a friend‚Äôs birthday bash,
Chased a virtual trophy that won‚Äôt last.
The *empty achievement high* fades fast as smoke,
Leaving me with nothing but a broken joke.
I compare my real self to my in-game guise‚Äî
Strong, fearless, loved, with no tears in my eyes.
The gap grows wide, a chasm I can‚Äôt cross,
A prisoner of the screen, with no real loss?

Now I know the truth, sharp as a gamer‚Äôs blade‚Äî
Video games are not a savior, not a shade
To hide from life, but a tool to play,
To learn, to laugh, to rest, then walk away.
I set a timer now, close the game when it dings,
Go outside, feel the wind, hear the birds sing.
The digital world‚Äôs a gift, but not the whole‚Äî
Life‚Äôs best quests are the ones we hold, not scroll.

Let‚Äôs start with the first stanza, which celebrates the pros of video games as a source of escape and creative empowerment. When life feels overwhelming‚Äîlike a stressful workday, a fight with a friend, or the weight of endless responsibilities‚Äîvideo games can offer a much-needed reprieve. The line ‚ÄúWhen the world‚Äôs weight presses like a leaden cloak‚Äù speaks to that feeling of being suffocated by real-life pressures, and how slipping into a virtual world can feel like taking off that heavy cloak. *Digital canvases* is a phrase I chose to highlight because games like Minecraft, Stardew Valley, or even Red Dead Redemption let you create or shape worlds in ways that feel deeply personal. You can build a castle from scratch, tend to a farm, or embark on a quest that feels uniquely yours. Unlike the real world, where our choices often feel limited by rules or other people, in these games, you are the master of your own fate. No one tells you what to do, no clock is breathing down your neck, and every decision you make has a tangible impact on the world around you. That sense of agency is incredibly empowering, especially for people who feel powerless in their daily lives. For example, when I was going through a tough breakup, I spent hours building a cozy cabin in Stardew Valley, planting crops and raising animals. It didn‚Äôt fix my broken heart, but it gave me a small, safe space where I could control something, and that made all the difference.

The second stanza focuses on another key pro: the unexpected bonds formed through *digital camaraderie*. I‚Äôve met some of my closest friends through online games, and that‚Äôs not an uncommon story. We started as strangers, paired together in a random match of Overwatch, and quickly realized we worked well as a team. We laughed at our mistakes, celebrated our wins, and even stayed on the mic after the game ended to talk about our day. Over time, we started playing every weekend, and eventually, we met in person at a gaming convention. That bond feels just as real as any friendship I‚Äôve made in the real world because it‚Äôs built on shared experiences and mutual respect. We don‚Äôt care about each other‚Äôs age, race, or background‚Äîall that matters is that we can rely on each other to cover our backs during a tough quest or to cheer us up when we‚Äôre having a bad day. For people who struggle with social anxiety, these online spaces can be a safe way to practice connecting with others without the pressure of face-to-face interactions. I know a teenager who was bullied at school and found solace in a Minecraft server where he could build and chat with other kids who shared his interests. That server became his safe haven, and the friends he made there helped him gain the confidence to stand up for himself in real life.

But for all their benefits, video games can also have serious downsides when we play too much, as the third stanza explores. *Late-night questing sprees* is a phrase that hits close to home because I‚Äôve been there‚Äîstaying up until 3 a.m. trying to beat a final boss, only to wake up exhausted the next day, unable to focus on work or school. When you‚Äôre deep in a game, it‚Äôs easy to lose track of time. You might forget to eat a meal, skip a walk with your dog, or even miss a call from a family member. The screen‚Äôs glow can make the real world feel cold and uninviting, like a place you don‚Äôt want to return to. I remember one weekend where I spent almost 20 hours playing a new RPG that had just come out. When I finally turned off my console, I looked around my room and realized how messy it was, how I hadn‚Äôt showered in two days, and how I‚Äôd missed my little sister‚Äôs soccer game. That moment hit me hard because I realized I was prioritizing a virtual world over the people and experiences that mattered most in real life. Screen-induced eye strain is another common issue‚Äîafter hours of staring at a screen, your eyes burn, your head aches, and you might even have trouble focusing on distant objects. It‚Äôs a small price to pay in the moment, but over time, it can lead to long-term vision problems and chronic fatigue.

The fourth stanza delves deeper into the trap of escapism, focusing on the *empty achievement high* that comes with beating a tough level or earning a rare trophy. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with feeling proud of an achievement in a game, but when that pride becomes the only thing that makes you feel good, it‚Äôs a problem. I‚Äôve skipped study sessions to grind for a rare item, missed a friend‚Äôs birthday bash to finish a quest, and even turned down a job interview because I was in the middle of a raid. When you finally get that trophy or beat that boss, the high is intense‚Äîbut it fades quickly, leaving you feeling empty and wanting more. You start chasing the next achievement, the next high, and before you know it, you‚Äôre stuck in a cycle that‚Äôs hard to break. Another issue is the comparison between your real self and your in-game persona. In games, you can be a strong, fearless hero who saves the world, but in real life, you might feel ordinary, insecure, or like you‚Äôre not living up to your potential. That gap can lead to feelings of inadequacy and low self-esteem. I‚Äôve had days where I looked at my in-game character‚Äîwho was loved by everyone, had a perfect home, and could defeat any enemy‚Äîand felt like my real life was a disappointment. It took me a long time to realize that the virtual world is a fantasy, and that my real life, with all its flaws and messiness, is far more meaningful than any in-game achievement.

The final stanza is about finding balance, which is key to enjoying video games without letting them take over your life. I learned this lesson the hard way, after months of letting games consume my time and energy. I started setting a timer for my gaming sessions, so I‚Äôd know when to stop and step away from the screen. Now, I play for an hour or two after work, then I close the game and go outside to walk my dog, cook a meal with my family, or call a friend. I‚Äôve realized that video games are a gift, not a replacement for real life. They can help you relax, connect with others, and express your creativity, but they shouldn‚Äôt be the only thing you do. Life‚Äôs best quests are the ones you hold in real life‚Äîlike watching your little sister score a goal, cooking a meal with your mom, or taking a walk in the park on a sunny day. These moments might not give you an achievement trophy or a rare item, but they leave lasting memories that no game can ever replicate. I still love playing video games,

input.content: Your response should be at least 50 sentences long.
A filmmaker is trying to get financing for a film about the history of the Internet. Write an essay to be used in the proposal to potential investors.

output:
# The Unbroken Thread: A Film About the Internet‚Äôs Epic Journey from Cold War Experiment to Global Revolution  

It‚Äôs 2024, and a teenager in Nairobi scrolls TikTok while their grandmother in Iowa video-calls a grandchild in Tokyo. A small business owner in Lagos uses Instagram to sell handwoven textiles to customers in Berlin. A scientist in Antarctica collaborates with peers in Brazil on climate research via a cloud-based platform. These moments, now so ordinary, were once the stuff of science fiction‚Äîand they all trace their roots to a quiet experiment in 1969, when two computers, 364 miles apart, exchanged a single, broken message: ‚ÄúLOGIN.‚Äù That incomplete word was the first spark of a revolution that would redefine how we connect, create, learn, and love. *The Unbroken Thread* is the story of that revolution: a sweeping, human-centered documentary that traces the internet‚Äôs journey from a cold war paranoia-fueled experiment to the most transformative technology in human history.  

To understand the internet‚Äôs birth, we must return to 1957, when the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the first artificial satellite. For the United States, the launch was a wake-up call: if the Soviets could send a satellite into space, they could also launch nuclear missiles that would destroy American communication networks. In response, the U.S. Department of Defense created ARPA, the Advanced Research Projects Agency, tasked with developing technologies to keep the country connected even in the event of a nuclear attack. It was here that J.C.R. Licklider, a visionary psychologist and computer scientist, first imagined a ‚Äúgalactic network‚Äù of computers that could communicate with one another, sharing information across distances and borders. Licklider‚Äôs idea was radical at the time‚Äîcomputers were then room-sized machines used only by governments and universities, designed to crunch numbers, not connect people‚Äîbut it planted a seed that would grow into the internet.  

In 1969, ARPA launched ARPANET, the first packet-switched network, designed to be decentralized so that no single point of failure could take the entire system down. The first test connected a computer at the University of California, Los Angeles, to one at Stanford Research Institute, 364 miles away. On October 29 of that year, graduate student Charley Kline sat in front of a bulky SDS Sigma 7 computer, his hands shaking. Across the country, Bill Duvall waited at an SDS 940. Kline typed ‚ÄúL‚Äù‚Äîand Duvall called out over the phone that he‚Äôd received it. Kline typed ‚ÄúO‚Äù‚Äîand again, confirmation. Kline typed ‚ÄúG‚Äù‚Äîand then, suddenly, the system crashed. The first message sent over ARPANET was incomplete, but it was enough. For the first time, two computers had communicated over a network that wasn‚Äôt tied to a single physical location. It was a small step, but it was the first step toward a global revolution.  

Over the next decade, ARPANET expanded, connecting more universities and research labs. But it wasn‚Äôt until the 1970s that the internet as we know it began to take shape. Bob Kahn and Vint Cerf, two computer scientists working at ARPA, developed TCP/IP, a set of protocols that allowed different networks to communicate with one another. This was the ‚Äúinternet protocol suite,‚Äù the backbone of the modern internet. Kahn and Cerf didn‚Äôt patent their invention; they gave it away for free, believing that the internet should be an open, shared resource. Their decision was a defining moment: it ensured that the internet would grow not as a proprietary tool, but as a global commons. By the early 1980s, ARPANET had switched to TCP/IP, and the internet was officially born.  

The 1980s were a time of quiet growth. Bulletin board systems (BBS) allowed hobbyists to connect and share files, while Usenet groups became virtual forums for discussing everything from science fiction to politics. In 1989, a quiet programmer at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, had an idea that would change everything. Tim Berners-Lee, frustrated by the difficulty of sharing research papers with colleagues, invented the World Wide Web: a system of hypertext documents linked together via the internet. Like Kahn and Cerf, Berners-Lee didn‚Äôt patent his invention; he made the code open source, so anyone could build on it. The web wasn‚Äôt the internet itself‚Äîit was a way to access information on the internet‚Äîbut it made the internet accessible to millions of people who had never used a computer before.  

The 1990s brought the internet to the mainstream. In 1994, Netscape Navigator, the first user-friendly web browser, was released. Suddenly, anyone with a computer and a dial-up modem could browse the web, send email, and join online communities. The dot-com boom began, as entrepreneurs flooded Silicon Valley with ideas for online businesses. Amazon, launched in 1994 as an online bookstore, quickly expanded into a global retail giant. eBay, founded in 1995, created a global marketplace for buyers and sellers. Pets.com‚Äôs iconic sock puppet became a cultural phenomenon, but the company burned through $140 million in funding before collapsing in 2000. The dot-com bust wiped out trillions of dollars in market value, but it also cleared the way for more sustainable companies. The bust taught a hard lesson: the internet wasn‚Äôt a magic money machine, but it was a tool that could transform almost every industry, if used wisely.  

The 2000s brought another revolution: the rise of social media. Friendster, launched in 2002, was the first major social networking site, but it was quickly overtaken by MySpace, which became a hub for musicians and teens. In 2004, Mark Zuckerberg launched Facebook from his Harvard dorm room, initially as a site for college students. By 2010, Facebook had over 500 million users. Twitter, launched in 2006, turned every user into a publisher, allowing people to share their thoughts in 140 characters or less. These platforms promised to connect the world, and they delivered: during the 2011 Arab Spring, protesters used Twitter and Facebook to organize demonstrations and share news that state-controlled media ignored. But the same tools that empowered activists also enabled misinformation campaigns. In 2016, fake news stories spread like wildfire on Facebook, influencing the U.S. presidential election. Algorithms designed to keep users engaged began feeding them content that confirmed their existing beliefs, creating echo chambers that deepened political divides. The internet, once seen as a force for democratization, had become a tool for polarization.  

Today, the internet is a double-edged sword. It has given a voice to marginalized communities, allowed small businesses to reach global audiences, and enabled scientific breakthroughs that would have been impossible just a few decades ago. But it has also created new problems: privacy violations, cyberbullying, misinformation, and a digital divide that leaves 2.7 billion people without access to the internet. *The Unbroken Thread* will explore this duality, telling stories of both the internet‚Äôs triumphs and its failures. We‚Äôll travel to Nairobi, where a group of young entrepreneurs is using the internet to provide affordable healthcare to rural communities. We‚Äôll go to rural India, where a teacher uses a portable internet hotspot to bring online learning to students who have never seen a computer. We‚Äôll talk to activists in Brazil who use social media to fight deforestation, and to parents in the U.S. who are struggling to protect their children from online harm.  

For investors, *The Unbroken Thread* represents a unique opportunity to tap into a growing market for high-quality, thought-provoking non-fiction content. Streaming platforms like Netflix, Apple TV+, and Hulu are constantly seeking docs that combine compelling storytelling with timely themes‚Äîand few themes are more timely than the internet‚Äôs impact on our lives. Our film will have broad cross-demographic appeal: baby boomers will recall the excitement of their first dial-up connection, Gen X will nostalgia for AOL chat rooms and Napster, millennials will relate to the rise of social media, and Gen Z will be fascinated to learn how the platforms they use every day came to be.  

Beyond streaming, the film will have significant educational value. Schools and universities around the world are increasingly teaching courses on internet history, digital ethics, and technology studies‚Äîand our film will be a valuable resource for these programs. We plan to partner with educational publishers to create study guides and lesson plans, expanding the film‚Äôs reach and generating additional revenue. We also plan to host live events, including screenings with Q&As with internet pioneers like Vint Cerf and Tim Berners-Lee, as well as panel discussions on digital ethics with experts from around the world. These events will not only generate buzz but also create opportunities for sponsorships and partnerships with tech companies, non-profits, and educational institutions.  

*The Unbroken Thread* is more than a history lesson. It‚Äôs a mirror held up to our society. It asks: What did we set out to build, and what did we actually create? How do we reconcile the internet‚Äôs power to connect, empower, and innovate with its capacity to divide, manipulate, and harm? And as we stand on the cusp of a new era‚Äîof AI, metaverses, and quantum computing‚Äîwhat lessons from the past can guide us toward a better future? For investors, this isn‚Äôt just a chance to fund a film; it‚Äôs a chance to be part of a project that will shape how future generations understand the most transformative

input.content:
Your response should contain the first 5 steps separated by "***", such as:
Step 1: ...
***
Step 2: ...
***
...
Your response should end with the phrase "Let me know how it works. I can give you next steps when you finish all steps above."
My brother is trying to install a new toilet in his bathroom. Could you give me details of how-to?

output:
Step 1: Turn off the water supply and drain the existing toilet. Locate the shut-off valve (usually on the wall behind the toilet) and turn it clockwise until fully closed. Flush the toilet to drain most water from the tank and bowl, then use a sponge or wet/dry vacuum to soak up any remaining water in the tank, bowl, and around the base to prevent spills during removal.
***
Step 2: Disconnect the water supply line. Place a bucket under the connection points to catch residual water. Use an adjustable wrench to loosen the nuts connecting the supply line to the toilet‚Äôs fill valve (bottom of the tank) and the shut-off valve. Carefully remove the line‚Äîyou can reuse it if it‚Äôs in good condition, or opt for a new one with the toilet.
***
Step 3: Remove the old toilet. Pry off the plastic caps covering the bolts at the base of the toilet, then use a wrench to unscrew the bolts securing it to the floor. If bolts are rusted, use a hacksaw to cut them off. Gently rock the toilet back and forth to break the wax seal, then lift it straight up (ask for help‚Äîit‚Äôs heavy) and set it on a towel to avoid damaging the floor.
***
Step 4: Prep the floor flange and install a new wax ring. Scrape off old wax, caulk, or debris from the floor flange (metal ring bolted to the floor connected to the drain pipe). Inspect the flange to ensure it‚Äôs level with the floor; adjust with extenders or shims if needed. Press a new wax ring (with a plastic horn if the drain pipe is below the floor) firmly onto the flange to seat it.
***
Step 5: Position the new toilet. Carefully lower the new toilet straight down over the wax ring and floor flange, aligning the bolt holes in the toilet base with the flange bolts. Press down firmly to compress the wax ring and create a watertight seal. Avoid rocking the toilet once it‚Äôs in place, as this can break the seal.
Let me know how it works. I can give you next steps when you finish all steps above.

What are some startup ideas that could help improve the lives of people in developing regions?

output: a mobile-based platform for small-scale farmers that delivers hyper-local weather forecasts, real-time market price data, and simple sustainable farming tips via SMS or basic apps (since many in developing regions use feature phones). it could also connect farmers to low-interest micro-loans for seeds or equipment, and directly to local buyers to cut out exploitative middlemen, boosting their income stability. another startup idea is a solar-powered community water purification kiosk network: these kiosks treat local water sources to safe drinking standards, sell water at ultra-affordable rates, and train local residents to operate and maintain them, creating small jobs while reducing waterborne illnesses. a third option is a feature-phone telehealth service, letting rural users consult nurses or general practitioners via voice calls, get referrals to nearby clinics, and order generic medications delivered by local bike couriers‚Äîfilling critical gaps in areas with few healthcare facilities. finally, a peer-to-peer savings tool for informal workers (like street vendors or day laborers) that uses SMS to track small, regular contributions, with group savings pools that let members access emergency funds without relying on predatory lenders, helping them build financial resilience.

input.content: Your entire reply should contain 600 to 700 words.
Create a blog post for professionals in the field of computer science in the form of a funny riddle.

output:
# Riddle Me This, CS Pros: Who‚Äôs Crashing My 3:17 AM Batch Job?

If you‚Äôre reading this, you‚Äôve either pulled an all-nighter chasing a bug that vanishes when you log it, reappears when you blink, or you‚Äôre procrastinating on debugging a bug that does exactly that. Last week, I found myself in that exact hellscape: coffee cold enough to freeze a polar bear, a rubber duck that was starting to judge me, and a production batch job that kept keeling over at 3:17 AM sharp. What follows is the riddle of that night‚Äôs culprit. Solve it, and you earn bragging rights (and a free pass to pour another coffee). Fail, and‚Ä¶ well, you‚Äôll probably just keep debugging anyway. Here we go:

I‚Äôm the ghost in your stack, the hole in your heap,
I hide where you look least‚Äîdon‚Äôt bother to peep.
You pass me around like a stale office donut,
I crash your app hard, but never make a sound, not a whimper, not a mutter.

Clue 1: You initialize your lists, your maps, your fancy DTOs,
But I‚Äôm the one you forgot‚Äîleft adrift, no clothes (no value, that is).
I don‚Äôt hold a number, a bool, or a string,
Ask me to do anything? I‚Äôll make your program sing‚Ä¶ a funeral dirge, obviously.

Clue 2: The compiler waves me through‚Äîno warning, no yell,
Says ‚Äúthis is fine!‚Äù while I plot your app‚Äôs hell.
You use me in a method that expects something real,
I grin when you crash, then vanish like a meal from the breakroom fridge.

Clue 3: Garbage collectors can‚Äôt catch me, I‚Äôm not an object to collect,
I‚Äôm the absence of data‚Äîyour code‚Äôs greatest defect.
I lurk in legacy schemas, in API responses half-baked,
Wait for the perfect moment to make your production shake.

Clue 4: You might call me by aliases, but my name‚Äôs plain to see,
I‚Äôm the reason your null check was a total fail, you see.
I‚Äôve crashed rockets, frozen ATMs, and made devs cry into their keyboards,
But you‚Äôll never see me coming‚Äîuntil your code implodes.

Now, let‚Äôs set the scene. The batch job in question was importing user data from our 2018-era legacy system into our shiny new microservice. Every night at 3:17 AM, it would process exactly 1,427 users, then crash. We checked database connections, memory leaks, even the server‚Äôs power supply (yes, we were desperate). The logs? A single line: ‚ÄúNullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.‚Äù Groundbreaking, I know.

The kicker? The dev who wrote the import logic had added a null check for the user object‚Ä¶ but forgot to check the user‚Äôs display name, which was null in 30% of the legacy records. So when the code tried to get user.DisplayName.Length, I struck.

If you guessed the culprit was a null pointer (or null reference, for my C# friends), you‚Äôre correct! Give yourself a high-five and a fresh coffee. If you guessed something else‚Äîlike a race condition, a memory leak, or the office intern accidentally unplugging the server‚Äîdon‚Äôt worry. We all have those days where we blame everything but the obvious.

The moral of the story? Null pointers are the silent assassins of the code world. They hide in plain sight, laugh at your half-baked checks, and strike when you‚Äôre at your most vulnerable. They‚Äôre the reason we have optional types in Rust, null safety in Kotlin, and a million Stack Overflow posts titled ‚ÄúWhy is my code crashing with a null exception?‚Äù

And if you ever find yourself debugging at 3:17 AM? Double-check every null. Twice. Then go to sleep. Your code will still be broken in the morning, but at least you‚Äôll have the energy to yell at it properly.

Now, go solve that bug. And for the love of all that‚Äôs holy, initialize your variables.

input.content: Your response must not contain the words 'yes' or 'no'.
Are the weather conditions in the Arctic very cold most of the year?

output: The Arctic experiences frigid conditions for the vast majority of the year. Long, harsh winters bring temperatures that plummet far below freezing, often reaching extreme lows of -40¬∞C or colder across much of the region. Even during the brief summer months, when the sun shines nearly around the clock, temperatures remain relatively cool‚Äîmany inland areas stay at or just above freezing, while coastal spots might see slightly milder conditions but rarely warm enough to feel temperate. The presence of permanent and seasonal sea ice, along with the region's high latitude and limited sunlight for much of the year, ensures that cold weather dominates most months.

He‚Äôs got his tiny sunglasses perched on his beak, a cooler full of fish popsicles in the backseat, and he‚Äôs singing off-key to a sea shanty playlist when suddenly, his sputtering old car dies right in the middle of a busy highway. He huffs and puffs, waddling as fast as he can to push the car to the nearest mechanic, who takes a quick look under the hood and says, ‚ÄòGive me an hour to figure out what‚Äôs wrong‚Äîgo grab a snack or something.‚Äô The penguin‚Äôs eyes light up because he‚Äôs been craving ice cream, so he waddles to the diner down the street and orders a huge vanilla cone. *He‚Äôs not the neatest eater, though‚Äîby the time he‚Äôs done, his entire face, chest, and even one of his flippers are covered in sticky vanilla goop.* He waddles back to the mechanic‚Äôs shop, still licking a smudge off his beak, and the mechanic looks up from the car, shakes his head, and says, ‚ÄòLooks like you blew a seal.‚Äô The penguin freezes, then starts frantically wiping at his face with his clean flipper, yelling, ‚ÄòNo, no, no! *That‚Äôs just ice cream‚Äîdon‚Äôt worry about the seal on my face, tell me about my car!*‚Äô The mechanic bursts out laughing, and it takes him five more minutes to explain that he was talking about the car‚Äôs engine seal, not the goop on the penguin‚Äôs face. The penguin just sighs, sits down on a nearby tire, and says, ‚ÄòCan we just get back to fixing my car? My fish popsicles are melting in the backseat.‚Äô By the time the mechanic fixes the seal (the car‚Äôs, not the penguin‚Äôs), the penguin has already gone back to the diner for a second ice cream cone‚Äîthis time, he asks for a napkin to keep his face clean. input.content: Your response must be between 100 to 120 words.
A psychologist is a professional who examines people's behaviors and mental processes. Can you tell me more about psychologists?

output: Psychologists specialize in diverse subfields tailored to different facets of human behavior and mental health. Clinical psychologists diagnose and treat conditions like anxiety or depression via talk therapy and evidence-based interventions, while cognitive psychologists study memory, decision-making, and problem-solving. Developmental psychologists track growth from infancy to old age, and industrial-organizational psychologists optimize workplace productivity and employee well-being. They work across settings: private practices, hospitals, schools, corporations, and research universities. Unlike psychiatrists (medical doctors who prescribe medication), most psychologists hold a PhD or master‚Äôs degree, complete supervised clinical hours, and earn state licensing. Beyond treatment, they conduct research, design educational programs, and help individuals build coping skills to thrive.

input.content: Your answer should have exactly 7 paragraphs. The last paragraph must start with the word "Summary". Each paragraph should be separated by two new lines.
What are the uses of poppy seeds?

output:
Poppy seeds are most widely recognized for their culinary applications, particularly in sweet baked goods across various cultures. Their small, kidney-shaped seeds add a subtle nutty flavor and a delicate crunch to items like lemon poppy seed muffins, poppy seed bagels, and Austrian linzer tarts. In many European and North American kitchens, they are sprinkled atop breads, pastries, and even yogurt parfaits to enhance texture and visual appeal. Some bakers also mix ground poppy seeds into cake batters or cookie doughs for a more intense, earthy taste that pairs well with citrus or vanilla flavors.


Beyond sweet treats, poppy seeds play a key role in savory dishes around the world. In Indian cuisine, they are often roasted and ground into a paste to thicken curries, or included in spice blends like panch phoron for lentil dishes and vegetable stir-fries. Eastern European recipes feature poppy seeds in pierogi fillings, potato salads, and sausage dishes, where they add depth to hearty, savory flavors. Middle Eastern cooks use them as a topping for flatbreads or mix them into rice pilafs, while in North Africa, they are incorporated into tagines for an extra layer of complexity.


Historically, poppy seeds have been valued for their medicinal properties, dating back to ancient civilizations like the Sumerians and Egyptians. These cultures used poppy seeds and their derivatives to alleviate pain, induce sleep, and treat respiratory issues. In traditional Greek and Roman medicine, they were prescribed as a calming agent to reduce anxiety and promote relaxation. Ayurvedic practices in India also utilized poppy seeds to aid digestion, relieve constipation, and soothe irritated mucous membranes, often mixing them with honey or warm milk for consumption.


In modern times, poppy seeds are celebrated for their nutritional benefits and continued use in natural health remedies. They are packed with dietary fiber, which supports digestive health by promoting regular bowel movements and feeding beneficial gut bacteria. Rich in healthy fats like omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, they help maintain heart health by reducing inflammation and lowering cholesterol levels. Additionally, poppy seeds are a good source of minerals such as calcium, iron, and magnesium, which support bone strength, red blood cell production, and muscle function. It‚Äôs important to note, however, that trace amounts of opiates can be present in the seeds, which may lead to false positive drug test results in some cases.


Poppy seeds and their oil are also gaining popularity in the cosmetic and skincare industry. The seeds‚Äô small, abrasive texture makes them an ideal natural exfoliant, used in face scrubs, body washes, and lip scrubs to gently slough off dead skin cells without causing irritation. Poppy seed oil, extracted from the seeds, is rich in linoleic and oleic acids, making it a nourishing ingredient in moisturizers, serums, and hair care products. It helps hydrate dry skin, soothe irritation, and add shine to dull hair, often featured in organic and natural skincare lines.


Beyond food and health, poppy seeds have niche industrial uses. Poppy seed oil, known for its drying properties, is used in the production of paints, varnishes, and wood finishes, where it dries to a hard, glossy surface that protects and enhances wood grain. It is also used in traditional ink making and as a natural dye for fabrics, producing soft, earthy tones. Additionally, poppy seeds are included in bird feed mixes, as many species of birds, including finches and sparrows, are attracted to their small size and nutrient-dense content.


Summary: Poppy seeds are incredibly versatile, with uses spanning culinary, medicinal, cosmetic, and industrial domains. In the kitchen, they elevate both sweet and savory dishes with their nutty flavor and crunch, featuring prominently in global cuisines. Historically and modernly, they offer nutritional benefits and have been used to support digestive, heart, and bone health, though trace opiate content requires caution. In skincare, they serve as gentle exfoliants, while their oil nourishes skin and hair. Industrially, poppy seed oil is valued for its drying properties in paints and finishes, and the seeds are even a favorite in bird feed. This wide range of applications highlights why poppy seeds remain a valuable ingredient across cultures and industries.

input.content: Your entire response must be wrapped in double quotation marks.
Write a review of IBM's 1956 chess program.

output:
"Review: IBM‚Äôs 1956 Chess Program ‚Äì The Humble Genesis of AI‚Äôs Grandmaster Journey  

In 1956, when mainframes filled entire rooms and ‚Äúartificial intelligence‚Äù was a fledgling concept whispered in research labs, IBM‚Äôs chess program‚Äîcrafted by a team led by Alex Bernstein‚Äîdidn‚Äôt just play a game; it redefined what machines could achieve. Running on the IBM 704, a behemoth with 1KB of core memory and processing power that pales next to a modern smartwatch, this program was less a chess prodigy and more a trailblazer, laying the first stone for the AI grandmasters we know today.  

Let‚Äôs start with the basics: this wasn‚Äôt a tool for casual play. It took roughly 10 minutes to calculate each move, peering ahead just two plies (a single move by one player) to evaluate positions. Its decision-making relied on a rudimentary but revolutionary evaluation function: it weighed material value (queens over rooks, rooks over bishops), piece mobility, and basic king safety, but ignored subtleties like pawn structure, passed pawns, or long-term strategy. Unsurprisingly, it lost its first public game to a human player, and it rarely triumphed over even novice humans. But to fixate on its losses is to miss the point entirely.  

The true magic of IBM‚Äôs 1956 program lies in its existence. Before it, chess‚Äîlong hailed as the ultimate test of human strategic thinking‚Äîwas thought to be beyond the reach of machines. Bernstein‚Äôs team proved otherwise by translating chess rules into code, building a search tree of possible moves, and teaching a computer to prioritize options based on logical criteria. These are the foundational building blocks of every subsequent computer chess system, from Deep Blue to AlphaZero.  

What‚Äôs most striking is the audacity of the project. In an era where computers were used primarily for number crunching, imagining one playing a game of nuance and intuition was radical. The program‚Äôs limitations are a reminder of how far we‚Äôve come: today‚Äôs AI can evaluate billions of positions per second, learn from self-play, and outmatch world champions. But none of that would have been possible without this clunky, slow, imperfect program that dared to make the first move.  

For anyone interested in the history of AI or computer chess, IBM‚Äôs 1956 program isn‚Äôt just a curiosity‚Äîit‚Äôs a landmark. It‚Äôs a testament to the vision of early researchers who saw potential in machines beyond arithmetic, and a reminder that every revolution starts with a single, tentative step. It may not have won many games, but it won the future of artificial intelligence.  

Rating: 5/5 (for historical significance; 2/5 for raw playing power‚Äîbut history doesn‚Äôt score on wins alone)"

In 2018, the Nobel Prize in Chemistry decided to shower three scientists with gold medals and bragging rights for basically becoming molecular reality TV producers‚Äîexcept instead of drama and rose ceremonies, they ran a "breed the best, dump the duds" competition for tiny chemical all-stars.

Frances Arnold walked away with half the prize like a solo champion. She spent years tweaking a hardworking type of molecule, breeding generation after generation until they could supercharge all sorts of chemical reactions faster and better than nature ever made them. Think of it as training a regular house cat to become an Olympic sprinter, but with invisible chemical workers instead of furballs.

Then there‚Äôs the dynamic duo: George P. Smith and Gregory P. Winter, who split the other half. These two focused on a different crew of tiny molecules‚Äîones that act like the body‚Äôs personal security guards. Using the same "evolution on fast-forward" method, they created versions that could zero in on trouble in the human body (rogue germs, wonky cells, you name it) with laser precision, turning so-so body defenders into heat-seeking missiles for trouble.

All in all, the Nobel committee was basically saying: "Nice work turning nature‚Äôs ‚Äòmeh‚Äô molecules into total overachievers. Here‚Äôs your prize money‚Äîgo buy yourself a really fancy beaker."

input.content: Your response should contain stress words which are capitalized, but limit those capitalized stress words to less than 20 times.
Write a story about the importance of understanding the truths that are not obvious.

output:
Mr. Hale‚Äôs bakery had been the heart of Willow Street for 40 years. His sourdough crust crackled like autumn leaves, and the aroma wrapped around the block at dawn. But lately, the shop felt EMPTY. The new caf√© down the street had drawn half his regulars, and he fumed over it every night. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt know good bread when they taste it,‚Äù he‚Äôd mutter to his flour-dusted hands.

One rainy Tuesday, Lila‚Äî10 years old, with pigtails and a habit of stealing a pinch of sugar from his jar‚Äîpushed open the door. He snapped before she could speak: ‚ÄúWhat are you doing here? Thought you liked that fancy latte place.‚Äù

Lila‚Äôs shoulders drooped. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the lattes. They ASK me about my science fair project. They remember my dog hates thunder.‚Äù She paused. ‚ÄúYou haven‚Äôt asked me anything since my goldfish died last spring.‚Äù

Mr. Hale froze. He‚Äôd forgotten about the goldfish. He‚Äôd been so focused on his SOURDOUGH, so convinced his skill was enough, that he‚Äôd missed something bigger.

The next morning, he watched through the window as Mrs. Torres walked by, her shoulders hunched. Normally, he‚Äôd slide her a loaf and take her money without a word. Today, he called her in. ‚ÄúYou look like you‚Äôve got a weight on your shoulders,‚Äù he said.

Mrs. Torres burst into tears. Her cat, Muffin, had a cold, and the vet‚Äôs bill was too high. Mr. Hale remembered his mother‚Äôs old remedy‚Äîsteamed chamomile and honey for cats. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a miracle,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúbut it worked for my old tomcat. Let me brew you a cup to take home.‚Äù

By the end of the week, Mrs. Torres was back, grinning. ‚ÄúMuffin‚Äôs purring again! Thank you‚Äîyou didn‚Äôt just give me bread. You gave me HOPE.‚Äù

Slowly, Mr. Hale started to change. He asked Mr. Jenkins about his tomato plants, remembered that Mrs. Lee‚Äôs granddaughter loved rainbow sprinkles on her rolls, and even let Lila teach him how to draw smiley faces on the cookie bags.

One Saturday, the shop was packed. A regular laughed and said, ‚ÄúThis place feels like HOME again.‚Äù Mr. Hale looked around at the chatter, the crumbs on the tables, the way someone had left a crayon drawing of his dog by the register. He finally saw the TRUTH: his SOURDOUGH was great, but people didn‚Äôt come for the bread alone. They came for the CONNECTION. The things you can‚Äôt taste or smell, but that wrap around you like a warm blanket.

He‚Äôd spent 40 years perfecting his craft, but the most important lesson was the one he‚Äôd overlooked: the non-obvious TRUTH that CARE matters more than skill. That day, he hung a new sign above the door: ‚ÄúBread and a LISTENING ear, always.‚Äù

This ring was made by an evil being named Sauron, who wants it back so he can take over the whole world and make everyone unhappy.

To keep everyone safe, Frodo and his closest hobbit friends set out on a big adventure. The journey is full of tricky paths, silly (and sometimes a little scary) creatures, and tired days. But Frodo‚Äôs best friend Sam never leaves his side, even when Frodo feels too tired to go on. In the end, Frodo and Sam make it to Mount Doom and destroy the ring. Sauron‚Äôs evil power fades away, and everyone gets to go back to their happy homes. Write a funny song-style poem for kids about why you shouldn't eat a lot of sweets.

output:
### SECTION 1: THE SUGAR STASH HEIST  
(Woke up this mornin‚Äô, bedhead wild)  
Eyes locked on the cookie jar, sealed tight, styled  
Snuck two chocolate chips, then a gummy bear red  
Found Mom‚Äôs hidden stash under the bed‚Äî  
Lollipops stacked like a candy cane tower  
I thought, ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs a sugar power hour!‚Äù  
Ate a licorice twist, a sour worm too  
Didn‚Äôt stop to think, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs this gonna do?‚Äù  

### SECTION 2: THE SUGAR RUSH CHAOS  
First my fingers got sticky, couldn‚Äôt hold my toy truck  
Dropped it in the fish tank‚Äîoops, now the goldfish is stuck (in a gummy worm net!)  
Then my feet started bouncin‚Äô, off the couch, off the wall  
Knocked over the plant, spilled Mom‚Äôs lemonade tall  
Ran around like a hyper kangaroo on a trampoline  
Tried to hug the cat‚Äîshe gave me a hissy mean!  
My tongue went numb from the sour candy bite  
I even tried to sing, but it came out as a squawk all night!  

### SECTION 3: THE CRASH & THE FUZZY TEETH  
Then the crash hit hard, like a pillow full of lead  
Plopped on the floor, couldn‚Äôt even stand up straight  
My tummy rumbled like a tiny drum band playin‚Äô off-beat  
‚ÄúWhy‚Äôd you stuff me with sugar?‚Äù it started to repeat  
My teeth felt fuzzy, like they had a woolly coat  
Brushed ‚Äôem three times, still stuck in a sticky moat  
I drank a glass of milk, but it slid right off my tongue  
Now I‚Äôm thinkin‚Äô, ‚ÄúThis sugar high was way too young!‚Äù  

### SECTION 4: THE BALANCED HAPPY ENDING  
Mom walked in grinnin‚Äô, wiped my sticky chin  
Said, ‚ÄúSweets are fun, but too much makes you spin!‚Äù  
She gave me one small cookie, warm from the oven‚Äôs glow  
With a side of apple slices, crisp and ready to go  
Now I feel steady, can climb the big oak tree  
Chase the dog around, no more bouncin‚Äô spree  
So here‚Äôs the rule, don‚Äôt you pout or mope:  
A little sweet‚Äôs great‚Äîtoo much makes you slope!  
(And next time, share a lollipop lick with your pup  
But just one lick‚Äîthey don‚Äôt need a sugar cup!)
