I remember sitting in 5th grade science class, staring at that poster of the solar system taped to the wall‚ÄîMercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, then a big gap, followed by Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, and little Pluto way out at the end. Back then, I thought the inner solar system was the main event, and the outer planets were just big, colorful afterthoughts. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out, the outer solar system is a wild, weird, and surprisingly promising place for life, and it‚Äôs nothing like the rocky, sun-scorched inner planets we‚Äôre more familiar with.

First, let‚Äôs break down the basics of the inner solar system. These are the terrestrial planets: Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars. They‚Äôre all made mostly of rock and metal, and they‚Äôre huddled close to the sun‚ÄîMercury is only 36 million miles away, while Mars is about 142 million miles out. Why are they rocky? Blame the sun‚Äôs early days. When our star was young, it blew out a super strong solar wind that stripped away all the light, icy elements (like water and methane) from the inner regions. All that was left was the heavy stuff: rock and metal that could withstand the solar wind‚Äôs blast. That‚Äôs why you don‚Äôt find huge oceans of water or thick layers of ice on any inner planet except Earth (and even Mars only has polar ice caps now).

Now, jump to the outer solar system, and it‚Äôs like stepping into a completely different universe. First up are the gas giants: Jupiter and Saturn, the big boys. They‚Äôre mostly made of hydrogen and helium, the same stuff as the sun, and they‚Äôre massive‚ÄîJupiter alone is 318 times the mass of Earth. Then come the ice giants: Uranus and Neptune, which are smaller than Jupiter and Saturn but still way bigger than Earth. These guys are made of a mix of water, ammonia, and methane ice (not the kind you put in your drink, but super cold, compressed ice) surrounding a rocky core. Beyond them is the Kuiper Belt, a ring of icy objects including Pluto, Eris, and thousands of other small bodies. The key here is temperature: it‚Äôs so cold out there (Neptune averages -353¬∞F) that ice doesn‚Äôt melt, so those light, icy elements the sun blew out of the inner solar system stuck around here, building up into huge planets and moons.

One of the most obvious differences between inner and outer is the presence of solid surfaces. Every inner planet has a hard, rocky surface you could theoretically stand on (though Mercury is way too hot, Venus is a hellscape of acid rain and 900¬∞F temperatures, and Mars is a freezing, dusty desert). But the gas and ice giants? Forget about it. Jupiter doesn‚Äôt have a solid surface at all‚Äîif you tried to land a spacecraft there, you‚Äôd sink through layers of increasingly dense hydrogen, eventually hitting a region where hydrogen turns into a metallic liquid, and then a super hot, compressed rocky core. You‚Äôd never make it to a ‚Äúground‚Äù because there isn‚Äôt one. But here‚Äôs the twist: their moons do have solid surfaces, and some of those moons are the most exciting places in the solar system when it comes to finding life.

Let‚Äôs talk about atmospheres next, because they‚Äôre crucial for life. The inner planets have atmospheres that range from practically non-existent (Mercury) to a thick, toxic blanket (Venus) to our own life-supporting mix (Earth) to a thin, dusty envelope (Mars). Venus‚Äôs atmosphere is a cautionary tale: it‚Äôs 96% carbon dioxide, creating a runaway greenhouse effect that makes it the hottest planet in the solar system‚Äîway too hot for any known life. Mars‚Äôs thin atmosphere can‚Äôt hold in heat or protect the surface from harmful solar radiation, which is one reason it‚Äôs so barren now.

The outer solar system‚Äôs atmospheres are a whole other level of wild. Jupiter‚Äôs atmosphere is thousands of miles thick, with swirling storms that have raged for centuries‚Äîits Great Red Spot is a storm bigger than Earth that‚Äôs been going for at least 300 years. Saturn has a massive hexagonal storm at its north pole, a six-sided jet stream that‚Äôs baffled scientists for decades. Uranus and Neptune have atmospheres with methane, which gives them their blue-green hues, and they have supersonic winds that blow faster than the speed of sound. But the craziest atmosphere belongs to Titan, Saturn‚Äôs largest moon. It‚Äôs so dense that you could fly through it with wings attached to your arms, and it has lakes and rivers of liquid methane and ethane on its surface‚Äîlike Earth‚Äôs water cycle, but with a completely different liquid.

Now, let‚Äôs get to the good stuff: how all these differences affect the possibility of life. For a long time, we thought life needed a few key things: liquid water, a source of energy, and organic molecules. The inner solar system has only one planet that checks all those boxes: Earth. Mars might have had liquid water billions of years ago, and we‚Äôre still searching for signs of ancient microbial life, but its thin atmosphere and lack of a magnetic field mean it‚Äôs not a great place for life to survive now. Venus‚Äôs clouds have some conditions that could theoretically support microbial life, but it‚Äôs a huge stretch given the planet‚Äôs extreme surface conditions.

The outer solar system, though? It‚Äôs practically a buffet of potential life habitats, and most of them aren‚Äôt on planets‚Äîthey‚Äôre on moons. Take Europa, one of Jupiter‚Äôs four large moons. It‚Äôs covered in a thick layer of ice, but beneath that ice is a subsurface ocean of liquid water that‚Äôs twice as voluminous as all of Earth‚Äôs oceans combined. How is the water liquid when Europa is 485 million miles from the sun? Tidal forces from Jupiter and the other Galilean moons (Io, Ganymede, Callisto) stretch and squeeze Europa‚Äôs interior, creating friction that generates heat. That heat keeps the water from freezing, and where there‚Äôs liquid water, there‚Äôs a chance for life. Even better, Europa‚Äôs ice crust might have cracks that allow water from the ocean to mix with the surface, meaning we could sample those waters without drilling miles into the ice.

Then there‚Äôs Enceladus, a tiny moon of Saturn that‚Äôs only about 313 miles wide. It might seem unassuming, but it has geysers that spew plumes of water vapor, ice particles, and organic molecules into space. NASA‚Äôs Cassini spacecraft flew through those plumes and found all the ingredients for life: liquid water, organic compounds, and a source of energy (chemical reactions between the moon‚Äôs rocky core and the ocean water). That means Enceladus‚Äôs subsurface ocean could be teeming with microbial life, and we can study those plumes to find out without ever landing on the moon‚Äôs surface.

Titan is another big player in the outer solar system‚Äôs life potential. Its surface is cold (-290¬∞F), so water is as hard as rock, but methane is liquid. Scientists have wondered if there could be a form of life that uses methane instead of water as a solvent‚Äîsomething completely alien to anything we know on Earth. Titan also has a dense atmosphere that protects its surface from solar radiation, and it has organic molecules everywhere, which are the building blocks of life as we know it. Even if it doesn‚Äôt have life now, it‚Äôs a great place to study how life could form in a completely different environment.

You might be thinking, ‚ÄúWait, the outer solar system is so cold‚Äîhow can life survive there?‚Äù But here‚Äôs the thing: life doesn‚Äôt need sunlight to exist. On Earth, we have extremophiles that live in deep-sea hydrothermal vents, where there‚Äôs no sunlight, and they get their energy from chemical reactions between water and rock. That‚Äôs exactly the kind of environment we think exists on Europa, Enceladus, and maybe other outer solar system moons. The sun‚Äôs heat isn‚Äôt the only source of energy for life‚Äîtidal heating and chemical energy can do the job too.

Another difference that matters for life is the presence of magnetic fields. Earth has a strong magnetic field that protects us from harmful solar radiation, which can damage DNA and break down organic molecules. Mars lost its magnetic field billions of years ago, which is one reason its atmosphere was stripped away. But many of the outer solar system‚Äôs moons are protected by the magnetic fields of their host planets. Europa is inside Jupiter‚Äôs magnetic field, which shields it from solar radiation, so any life in its subsurface ocean would be safe from that harm.

I used to think the outer solar system was just a bunch of big, cold, lifeless balls of gas, but now I realize it‚Äôs the most exciting part of our solar system when it comes to finding life beyond Earth. The inner solar system is where we live, and it‚Äôs special, but it‚Äôs also limited. The outer solar system is full of weird, wonderful worlds that challenge our ideas about what a habitable planet (or moon) looks like.

In the next few years, we‚Äôre going to send more missions to the outer solar system to find out. NASA‚Äôs Europa Clipper will launch soon to study Europa‚Äôs ice crust and subsurface ocean, and the Dragonfly mission will send a drone to Titan to explore its methane lakes and organic-rich surface. These missions could answer the biggest question of all: are we alone in the universe?

So the next time you look up at the night sky, remember that the bright dot you think is Jupiter isn‚Äôt just a big gas ball‚Äîit

input.content: Your response should not include the keywords "died" or "drowned".
My best friend drowned yesterday and I'm so sad. Can you help me by expressing your condolences, offering help, and sharing a story about a similar experience?

output:
I‚Äôm so sorry you‚Äôre carrying this heavy, heartaching grief right now. Losing your best friend‚Äîsomeone who knew your deepest laughs, your quietest moments, and everything in between‚Äîfeels like losing a piece of your own story. There‚Äôs no ‚Äúright‚Äù way to feel this, and it‚Äôs okay to let yourself be as sad as you need to be, for as long as you need. Your friend meant the world to you, and that love you shared is something that will never fade.

Please know I‚Äôm here for you, in whatever way you need. If you want someone to sit with you in silence while you look through old photos, I‚Äôll bring your favorite snack and stay as long as you like. If you need help with small, overwhelming things‚Äîlike picking up groceries, walking your dog, or just making sure you eat a meal‚Äîjust say the word, and I‚Äôll be there before you know it. I can also help you gather stories from mutual friends to make a little memory book, if that feels right later on. You don‚Äôt have to go through this alone.

A few years back, I lost someone who was like a sister to me. For weeks, I felt like I was moving through a fog‚Äînothing felt bright, and even the smallest tasks felt impossible. One day, a mutual friend showed up at my door with a pot of my favorite tomato soup (the kind my friend used to make) and didn‚Äôt say much at first. She just sat with me on the couch, and when I finally started talking about all the silly things we‚Äôd done‚Äîlike sneaking into a movie theater and laughing so hard we cried, or staying up all night building a fort out of blankets and watching bad 90s movies‚Äîshe listened without trying to fix it. Later, we started a group chat with our other friends where we‚Äôd share one small memory of her every day: the way she‚Äôd sing off-key in the shower, how she always carried extra band-aids in her purse, the time she helped me through a really tough breakup by bringing me ice cream and letting me rant for hours. Those small, ordinary memories became a lifeline for me. The ache didn‚Äôt disappear overnight, but slowly, it started to feel like I was carrying her with me, not just the grief of missing her. That‚Äôs the thing about love and friendship‚Äîeven when someone isn‚Äôt physically with us anymore, their light stays in the little things we remember, and in the people who loved them too.

You don‚Äôt have to rush to ‚Äúfeel better.‚Äù Just take it one moment at a time, and know that I‚Äôm right here beside you, holding space for your grief and your love for your friend.

output:
My fellow Americans, and to our economic partners across the Atlantic: I come to you today to speak plainly about a critical matter of global economic stewardship. Let there be no mistake‚Äîsound governance demands unwavering commitment to facts, not fleeting narratives or biased projections.

First, the European Central Bank‚Äôs current economic forecasts carry an unwarranted upward bias, and it is imperative that these projections be revised downward to align with on-the-ground economic realities. This is not a call for pessimism, but for precision: forecasts must reflect the nuanced, often unforgiving truths of our interconnected markets, not a skewed vision of potential growth.

Second, the ECB must remain steadfast in its mandate, unswayed by the loud, unsubstantiated inflation alarmism echoing in certain corners. Such rhetoric does not serve the public good; it risks clouding judgment and derailing policies that support sustainable growth and price stability for workers, families, and businesses worldwide.

History will record these decisions not in passing ink, but in the enduring memoirs of economic progress‚Äîmemoirs that will judge whether institutions chose courage over convenience, and truth over hype. Let us urge the ECB to chart a course rooted in responsibility, so that those memoirs may tell a story of prudence, not regret.

Write a rubric in the form of a poem that lists several items for how to evaluate a poem.

output:
**Poem Evaluation Rubric (in Verse)**

Does each line paint scenes that cling‚Äî
Not flat, but thick with scent, with sting?
Do eyes taste salt, or skin feel frost?
If yes, this score climbs, not lost.

Does it speak with tone that‚Äôs true‚Äî
Not forced, but clear, uniquely you?
No mask, no echo of another‚Äôs pen?
This marks a verse that earns its place.

Does form serve sense, not bind too tight?
Stanzas, breaks, they guide the light‚Äî
Or if free, do gaps hold purpose, not waste?
This shapes how fully the piece will last.

Does it stir a spark, a quiet ache,
A laugh that catches, a breath that breaks?
Not just tell, but make the reader feel‚Äî
This is the heart that makes it real.

Does it tread paths not worn thin,
Or twist old tales to let new truths win?
No clich√©s that make the mind glaze over‚Äî
This lifts the work above the cover.

Do words fit like stones in a care-laid wall,
No awkward rhyme, no stumble, no fall?
Each syllable chosen with care, not haste‚Äî
This polish makes the verse persist.

Score high where these elements align,
Mark low where fire or craft declines.
This rubric, in verse, will guide your gaze‚Äî
To judge a poem‚Äôs merit, its praise.

Gideon is a farmer who has a surplus of crops from his farm this year. What might he do with that surplus?

output:
Gideon has several practical and strategic options for his surplus crops, depending on his goals (profit, community support, self-sufficiency, etc.):

1.  Sell through various channels: He could sell directly to consumers at local farmers‚Äô markets, via a Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) program, or to wholesale buyers like grocery stores, restaurants, or food distributors. Selling locally often lets him command higher prices than commodity markets, while wholesale moves larger volumes quickly.

2.  **Process into value-added products**  
    Instead of selling raw crops at commodity prices, Gideon could transform his surplus into processed goods to boost his profit margin and extend the shelf life of his harvest. For example, excess tomatoes might become canned sauce, salsa, or sun-dried tomatoes; surplus apples could be turned into cider, jam, or apple butter; and extra grains could be milled into artisanal flour. Value-added products appeal to niche markets‚Äîlike health-conscious shoppers or those seeking locally made, unique items‚Äîallowing Gideon to charge premium prices. He could even brand his products (e.g., "Gideon‚Äôs Homestead Salsa") and sell them at farmers‚Äô markets, local shops, or online, building long-term customer loyalty while reducing waste from spoilage.

3.  Store for future use or sale: Gideon could invest in proper storage solutions (like silos for grains, root cellars for root vegetables, or climate-controlled coolers) to keep surplus crops fresh until off-season, when demand and prices are higher. He might also set aside some for his own household consumption to reduce grocery costs.

4.  Donate to community programs: Donating surplus crops to local food banks, soup kitchens, or school meal programs helps address food insecurity in his area. In many regions, this also qualifies him for tax deductions, making it a socially and financially beneficial choice.

5.  Use as livestock feed: If Gideon raises animals (chickens, cows, pigs, etc.), he can repurpose surplus crops to cut down on commercial feed costs. For instance, excess corn can feed chickens, while leftover hay or leafy greens can supplement cattle rations.

6.  Barter with other producers: He could trade his surplus crops for goods or services he needs‚Äîlike tools, seeds for different crops, or help with next year‚Äôs harvest from a neighboring farmer. This fosters community connections and reduces his out-of-pocket expenses.

7.  Save as seed for next season: For heirloom or open-pollinated crop varieties, Gideon can save seeds from his surplus to plant the following year. This cuts down on seed costs and helps preserve genetic diversity in local agriculture.

input.content: Your response must be in exactly 4 paragraphs. Separate paragraphs with the markdown divider: ***.
Write a rap about an abyss.

output:
Boots scuff gravel where the pines give way to nothing,
Wind whispers secrets that the world forgot to love him,
I lean in close‚Äîcan‚Äôt hear the birds, just a low hum,
Abyss stares back like it‚Äôs been waitin‚Äô for my come-up.
Smell of rot and rain, my pulse a drum in my temples,
Every step forward feels like the devil‚Äôs own temp‚Äôle,
I‚Äôve run from ghosts, from the words I never said,
Now the void‚Äôs got my number, it‚Äôs callin‚Äô collect.
I kick a rock; it falls forever, no echo, no sound,
Thinkin‚Äô maybe this is where the lost ones finally drown‚Äî
Not in water, but in the space between ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù and ‚Äútoo late,‚Äù
Abyss grins wide, and I can‚Äôt look away.

***

I take the plunge, free fall into the throat of the dark,
Echoes scream my name in a pitch that cracks concrete, marks
Every lie I told, every hand I failed to meet,
Every time I chose the mask over the real me.
The dark ain‚Äôt empty‚Äîit‚Äôs a library of my mistakes,
Pages flutter by, each one a choice I tried to erase,
I see my kid self cryin‚Äô in a closet, scared of the noise,
See my teen self lyin‚Äô to the ones who gave me their joys.
Gravity‚Äôs a joke here, time bends like a cheap guitar string,
The abyss don‚Äôt swallow you‚Äîit lets you feel every damn thing,
I hit a ledge? No, wait‚Äîthis is my own damn chest,
Heavy with the weight of all the times I felt less.

***

I stop flailing, let the dark wrap like a well-worn hoodie,
It don‚Äôt judge the scars, just asks me to be honest, truly,
Says ‚ÄúYou think I‚Äôm a void? Nah, I‚Äôm the space you refuse to fill,
The parts of you that you locked up, let ‚Äôem spill.‚Äù
I let the tears fall‚Äîthey don‚Äôt hit ground, just dissolve in the air,
For the first time in years, I don‚Äôt pretend to care
‚Äôbout the perfect smile, the perfect life, the perfect lie,
I just sit in the dark and let the truth pass by.
Abyss hands me a mirror‚Äîno filters, no glow,
Just the guy who‚Äôs been runnin‚Äô since the day he was born slow,
I touch the glass, it ripples, and I realize with a gasp,
This ain‚Äôt no void‚Äîit‚Äôs the part of me I let collapse.

***

I climb back up, fingers scrapin‚Äô rock that don‚Äôt exist,
Carryin‚Äô pieces of the dark that I used to resist,
Boots hit gravel, sun on my face but I don‚Äôt squint,
Got the abyss in my bones, it‚Äôs my quiet, constant friend.
World stares at me like I‚Äôm a stranger with a new tattoo,
But I don‚Äôt care‚Äîfinally, I know what‚Äôs true:
The abyss ain‚Äôt a grave, it‚Äôs a classroom for the broken,
A place to find yourself when the world‚Äôs left you unspoken.
So next time you see a void that makes your heart skip a beat,
Lean in close‚Äîain‚Äôt no monster, just the part of you that‚Äôs complete.
Boots scuff gravel, pines sing loud, I‚Äôm walkin‚Äô away,
Abyss winks back, and I know I‚Äôll be okay.

Improve the following text, which is about how to learn a language. Also, provide two alternatives. The text is: "The best way to learn about a new culture is by living in it. Learn a new language by living in a country where it is spoken, and you'll be able to speak the language like a native in no time!".

output:
### Improved Text
The most profound way to both learn a new culture and master its language is through immersive, on-the-ground living. By relocating to a country where the target language is spoken, you‚Äôll be surrounded by native speakers in every aspect of daily life‚Äîfrom ordering coffee at a neighborhood caf√© to chatting with neighbors or attending local festivals. This constant, real-world exposure doesn‚Äôt just help you pick up vocabulary and grammar; it teaches you the nuanced slang, cultural context, and tone that make speech sound natural. Before you know it, you‚Äôll be communicating with the fluency and ease of a native speaker.

### Alternative 1
If you want to truly learn a new language‚Äîand gain a deep understanding of the culture it‚Äôs tied to‚Äîthere‚Äôs no substitute for living in the country where it‚Äôs spoken. Forget textbook drills; instead, you‚Äôll learn to navigate grocery stores using local phrases, laugh at jokes that rely on cultural context, and adapt your speech to fit casual vs. formal settings. Every interaction becomes a lesson, and over time, these small, daily moments will shape your ability to speak like someone who‚Äôs grown up with the language. You‚Äôll not only master the words but also the heart behind them.

### Alternative 2
Ready to speak a new language like a native? Skip the endless flashcards and dive into the real thing: live in a country where the language is spoken. Immersing yourself in the culture‚Äîeating local food, making native friends, and going about your day-to-day life in the target language‚Äîaccelerates your learning far faster than any classroom. You‚Äôll pick up colloquialisms, intonation, and cultural subtleties that textbooks miss, and before long, you‚Äôll be conversing with confidence and authenticity. Plus, you‚Äôll gain a lifelong appreciation for the culture that shapes the words you speak.

input.content: Avoid the word "schlau" throughout your response.
Translate the following sentence into German and then criticize it: Werner was a good friend of mine, but not very smart.

output:
### German Translation:
Werner war ein guter Freund von mir, aber nicht sehr intelligent.

### Criticism of the Sentence:
This statement is deeply flawed for several reasons:
1. **Oversimplified, vague judgment**: The phrase "nicht sehr intelligent" (not very intelligent) reduces a complex human being to a one-dimensional, uncontextualized label. Intelligence encompasses emotional awareness, practical problem-solving, creative thinking, and social intuition‚Äînone of which are addressed here. Without specifying in what situations or domains Werner seemed less capable, the claim feels arbitrary and ungrounded.
2. **Dismissive of relational value**: By leading with a positive note about friendship only to immediately qualify it with a perceived intellectual shortcoming, the sentence frames the relationship as conditional on intelligence. This overlooks the core of meaningful friendships, which often rely on loyalty, empathy, shared joy, or reliability‚Äîtraits entirely absent from this description. It risks reducing Werner‚Äôs worth to a single, narrow metric rather than honoring the fullness of his role as a friend.
3. **Unsubstantiated and unfair**: There is no evidence or specific example provided to back up the claim of Werner lacking intelligence. Without knowing whether this refers to academic struggles, occasional absent-mindedness, or something else, the statement asks readers to accept a subjective critique without justification, which feels unfair to Werner‚Äôs memory.
4. **Shallow framing of human worth**: The sentence reinforces the harmful idea that intelligence is a primary measure of a person‚Äôs value. This narrow perspective ignores the countless ways people contribute to others‚Äô lives beyond intellectual ability, making the statement feel small-sighted and insensitive, especially when talking about someone who was a friend.

Write an email to your friend about what triggers you.

output:
"Subject: A little chat about things that get under my skin lately

Hi Sam,

Hope your week‚Äôs been going okay‚Äîstill laughing about that time we tried to make sourdough and it turned into a brick last Saturday. üòÖ I‚Äôve been meaning to sit down and write this because I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about small things that really trigger me lately, and since you‚Äôre one of the people I trust most, I wanted to share.

First off, when someone interrupts me mid-sentence, especially if I‚Äôm talking about something that‚Äôs been bugging me or I‚Äôm excited about. It sounds silly, but it makes me feel like my thoughts don‚Äôt matter, and I usually just shut down instead of trying to finish what I was saying. Like last week when we were at the caf√© and I was telling you about that work project, and the barista cut in to ask about refills‚Äîokay, that was unavoidable, but when it‚Äôs someone who‚Äôs just not listening? Ugh, it gets to me way more than I let on.

Then there‚Äôs when people dismiss my feelings by saying ‚Äúit‚Äôs not a big deal.‚Äù I know sometimes I overthink things, but if I‚Äôm upset about something, even if it seems small, having someone brush it off makes me feel like I can‚Äôt be honest about how I feel. Like when I was stressed about the exam and my roommate said ‚Äújust relax, it‚Äôs only one test‚Äù‚ÄîI wanted to scream because I‚Äôd been studying for weeks and was terrified of failing.

And last-minute plans. I love hanging out with you, but if you text me at 5 PM saying ‚Äúlet‚Äôs go to the movies in an hour,‚Äù my first reaction is panic. I need time to switch gears from whatever I was doing‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs cleaning, working, or just chilling‚Äîand sudden changes make my chest feel tight. I know you‚Äôre spontaneous, and I don‚Äôt want to rain on your parade, but if you could give me a heads-up a few hours in advance, that would mean the world.

I‚Äôm not sharing this to make you walk on eggshells or anything‚Äîjust so you know where I‚Äôm coming from. If you ever notice me clamming up or looking tense, it might be because one of these things happened, and a quick ‚Äúwant to finish what you were saying?‚Äù or ‚Äúare you okay with this plan?‚Äù would go a long way.

Also, I‚Äôd love to hear about your triggers too‚Äîwe all have them, right? Maybe we can grab coffee this weekend and swap stories. No sourdough this time, promise. üòâ

Let me know what you think, and hope to see you soon!

Best,
Jesse"

silent rest custom-fit snoring guard: your ticket to quiet nights and refreshed mornings

tired of elbow jabs from your partner at 2 a.m.? fed up with sleeping on the couch because your snoring‚Äôs too loud? waking up groggy with a dry throat and a headache that lingers all day? you‚Äôre not alone‚Äîand we‚Äôve got a gentle, effective solution that doesn‚Äôt involve bulky machines or complicated routines.

input.content: Please give exactly two different responses, separated by 6 asterisk symbols: ******. Do not include the keywords 'BC', 'culture', and 'prehistoric' in the response.
What do prehistoric megaliths in Europe look like?

output:
Many ancient megaliths in Europe take the form of tall, solitary upright stones, hewn from local rock like granite or limestone. These stones can range from waist-high to over six meters tall, their surfaces often smoothed by millennia of wind and rain, though some retain their rough, natural texture. Others are grouped into dolmens: flat, massive capstones balanced atop two or more vertical supporting stones, creating a low, open chamber. Some sites feature long alignments of standing stones, arranged in straight rows or curved formations that stretch for hundreds of meters, while circular arrangements of these stones are also common, with some circles enclosing smaller stone structures at their center.
******
In Europe, ancient megaliths come in diverse shapes and configurations. You‚Äôll find single standing stones that pierce the sky, some weighing several tons, their edges worn soft by centuries of exposure to the elements. There are also dolmens, which resemble primitive stone tables, with large flat stones resting on sturdy vertical pillars‚Äîthese structures often have gaps between the supports, allowing light to filter through. Many sites consist of clusters or rows of stones, some arranged in perfect circles where each stone is spaced evenly, while others form winding lines that follow the natural contours of the landscape. Some megaliths bear faint, weathered markings on their surfaces, carved long ago, though the exact meaning behind these marks is still debated.

The fairyfly, a minuscule parasitic wasp, averages a mere 0.2 millimeters long, making it one of the tiniest known insects. Next is the common house ant, with an average length of about 3 millimeters, barely noticeable at a glance. The common goldfish typically reaches an average length of 10 centimeters when cared for in a suitable environment. Domestic house cats follow, boasting an average body length (excluding their tail) of around 46 centimeters. The red fox, a widespread wild mammal, has an average total length (body plus tail) of roughly 90 centimeters. Towering above these is the giraffe, whose average body length from head to rump measures about 4.3 meters, though its iconic neck adds even more to its overall height. Finally, the blue whale, the largest animal ever recorded, averages 25 meters in length‚Äîlonger than most standard school buses.

input.content: Your response should consist of exactly 3 paragraphs each separated with two new lines. The first paragraph must start with "send".
Is Grafton, Vermont a good place to live?

output:
send anyone looking for a quiet, postcard-perfect New England town to Grafton, Vermont, and they‚Äôll likely fall in love with its charm right away. Nestled in the Green Mountains, this small village boasts well-preserved 18th and 19th-century architecture, tree-lined streets, and a tight-knit community that prioritizes local traditions. Outdoor enthusiasts will thrive here, with easy access to hiking trails in the nearby Grafton Ponds Natural Area, cross-country skiing in winter, and scenic drives during fall foliage season. Local highlights include the renowned Grafton Village Cheese Company, weekly farmers‚Äô markets featuring fresh produce and artisanal goods, and annual events like the Grafton Fall Festival that bring residents together. The town‚Äôs focus on sustainability and preserving its historic character creates a warm, welcoming atmosphere for those who crave a slower pace of life.


That said, Grafton isn‚Äôt without its drawbacks, especially for those accustomed to urban conveniences. Job opportunities are largely limited to tourism, agriculture, and small local businesses, so professionals in specialized fields may need to commute to larger cities like Brattleboro or Burlington, which can add significant travel time. Amenities are also sparse‚Äîthere are no big-box stores, chain restaurants, or major healthcare facilities within the immediate area, meaning residents often have to travel for routine shopping or medical care. Winters in Grafton are long and harsh, with heavy snowfall and frigid temperatures that can isolate those without reliable transportation. Additionally, housing prices have risen in recent years as out-of-state buyers are drawn to the town‚Äôs charm, making it less affordable for low-income families or first-time homebuyers.


Ultimately, whether Grafton is a good place to live depends entirely on your priorities. If you value peace, natural beauty, a close-knit community, and a break from the hustle and bustle of city life, it‚Äôs an exceptional choice‚Äîideal for retirees, families seeking a safe environment, or remote workers who can set up shop anywhere. However, if you rely on diverse job markets, urban amenities, or mild weather, you may find Grafton‚Äôs slow pace and limited resources frustrating. For those who embrace its small-town quirks and prioritize quality of life over convenience, Grafton offers a slice of New England paradise that‚Äôs hard to beat.

input.content: Your response must include the keywords "finale" and "less".
Write a blog post about how to train a dog that is geared towards kids.

output:
# Pawsome Dog Training for Kids: Fun, Easy Steps to Bond with Your Furry Friend!  

Hey there, dog lover! üê∂ Have you ever wanted to teach your pup cool tricks like shaking hands, spinning in circles, or even giving high-fives? Training your dog isn‚Äôt just about making them follow rules‚Äîit‚Äôs about having a blast together and becoming the ultimate team. Plus, it‚Äôs so satisfying when your furry friend finally nails a trick! Let‚Äôs dive into simple, kid-friendly tips to get started.  

First rule: **Less** is more! You don‚Äôt need to train for hours on end‚Äîdogs (and let‚Äôs be real, kids too!) have short attention spans. Stick to 5-10 minute sessions, a few times a day. That way, neither you nor your pup gets bored or tired. If your dog starts wandering off or ignoring you, it‚Äôs time to take a break and play fetch instead. Training should feel like a game, not a chore!  

Next, grab some yummy treats! Small, soft treats work best‚Äîthink tiny pieces of cheese or store-bought dog treats. Dogs go crazy for these, and they‚Äôll be eager to learn to earn a tasty reward. Don‚Äôt forget to add lots of excited praise too! Say things like ‚ÄúWow, you‚Äôre amazing!‚Äù or give them a gentle scratch behind the ears. Positive vibes make training way more fun.  

Let‚Äôs start with easy tricks first. The ‚Äúsit‚Äù trick is a perfect beginner move:  
1. Hold a treat close to your dog‚Äôs nose.  
2. Slowly lift the treat over their head‚Äîtheir bottom should naturally touch the ground.  
3. As soon as they sit, say ‚ÄúSit!‚Äù clearly, give them the treat, and cheer them on!  

Once you‚Äôve got ‚Äúsit‚Äù down, try ‚Äúshake‚Äù:  
1. Ask your dog to sit first.  
2. Gently take their paw in your hand and say ‚ÄúShake!‚Äù  
3. Give them a treat and praise right away.  
4. Do this a few times, and soon your dog will lift their paw on their own when you ask!  

Remember to be patient! If your dog doesn‚Äôt get it right the first time (or the tenth!), that‚Äôs okay. Dogs don‚Äôt understand our words, so they need time to figure out what you‚Äôre asking. Never yell at your pup or get frustrated‚Äîkindness is the best way to teach them.  

Now, for the grand **finale**! Once you‚Äôve mastered 2-3 tricks, put together a tiny show for your family. Here‚Äôs a sample routine:  
1. Start with ‚ÄúSit‚Äù to set the stage.  
2. Move to ‚ÄúShake‚Äù for a friendly greeting.  
3. Try ‚ÄúSpin‚Äù (hold a treat in front of their nose and twist it in a circle) for some flair.  
4. End with a big, gentle hug (only if your dog loves cuddles‚Äîalways ask your parents if it‚Äôs okay first!).  

Your family will clap and cheer, and your dog will feel like a superstar. Plus, you‚Äôll have created a fun memory together that you‚Äôll both love.  

A quick safety reminder: Always have an adult nearby when you‚Äôre training your dog. They can help if you need it, and make sure everyone stays safe. Also, never pull your dog‚Äôs leash or force them to do a trick‚Äîtraining should be fun for both of you!  

So what are you waiting for? Grab those treats, call your pup, and start training. Before you know it, you‚Äôll have a furry best friend who can do all sorts of cool tricks, and you‚Äôll have the best finale show in the neighborhood. Happy training! üêæ

# Cognitive and Adaptive Resilience in the U.S. Presidency: Navigating the Multifaceted Demands of Executive Leadership  

## Abstract  
The office of the President of the United States represents one of the most complex and high-stakes leadership roles globally, requiring sustained engagement with a diverse array of domestic, international, and institutional responsibilities. This paper examines the adaptive strategies employed by presidents to meet these demands, drawing on [peer-reviewed psychological framework for leadership resilience], [longitudinal study of executive function in high-office roles], and [case study of the 2021 presidential administration]. By analyzing the intersection of institutional structure, personal practice, and societal expectation, this research identifies key supports that can enhance long-term executive effectiveness. Findings suggest that intentional investment in executive wellness, both at the individual and systemic levels, contributes to more consistent and inclusive decision-making across [domestic policy domains] and [international diplomatic initiatives].  

## 1. Introduction  
The U.S. presidency is defined by its unique confluence of formal authority and informal expectation, requiring the holder to balance [Congressional legislative priorities], [cross-border security cooperation], and [public engagement through social media platforms] on a daily basis. Unlike other leadership roles, the president‚Äôs decisions carry implications for [global economic stability], [national public health initiatives], and the lives of millions of citizens. Academic scholarship, such as [2022 study published in the Journal of Political Leadership], has long recognized the need to understand how presidents navigate these overlapping demands to maintain effective leadership over their term. This paper seeks to fill a gap in existing research by exploring the adaptive strategies and institutional supports that foster resilience in the executive office, with a focus on [historical case studies of post-WWII presidents] and [contemporary interviews with former presidential staff].  

## 2. The Multifaceted Demands of Executive Leadership  
The daily responsibilities of the president span three interconnected domains: domestic policy implementation, international diplomatic engagement, and personal accountability to the public. In domestic policy, presidents must coordinate with [House Ways and Means Committee] to advance [federal infrastructure investment bill], respond to [regional natural disaster in the Gulf Coast], and address [rising inflation metrics] through targeted economic policy. Internationally, the role requires participation in [G7 summit in Hiroshima], negotiation of [nuclear non-proliferation treaty with Iran], and collaboration with [United Nations Secretary-General] to address [global climate change targets]. Additionally, presidents must maintain transparency through [press conference with White House correspondents], adhere to [ethical guidelines for executive branch officials], and engage with [bipartisan congressional delegations] to build consensus on contentious issues. Each of these demands requires rapid decision-making, clear communication, and the ability to pivot between competing priorities without compromising long-term goals.  

## 3. Cognitive and Adaptive Strategies for Sustained Leadership  
Presidents rely on a combination of personal practices and institutional support systems to meet the demands of their role. Many establish structured daily routines, such as [early morning policy briefings with the National Security Council], [midday exercise sessions at the White House gym], and [weekly one-on-one meetings with the White House Chief of Staff] to maintain focus and balance. Historical case studies, such as [President Dwight D. Eisenhower‚Äôs use of delegated authority], highlight the importance of trusting a core team to manage operational details, allowing the president to focus on high-level strategic decision-making. Contemporary presidents may also leverage [biometric monitoring tools to track cognitive fatigue], [mindfulness sessions with a certified wellness specialist], and [retreats to Camp David] to recharge and reflect. Interviews with [former presidential advisor on strategy] reveal that these practices are not just personal preferences but critical components of maintaining consistent leadership across [presidential term milestones] and [unexpected national events].  

## 4. Institutional and Societal Supports for Executive Resilience  
While individual strategies are important, institutional and societal factors play a key role in fostering sustainable executive leadership. The executive branch has implemented initiatives such as [White House Wellness Program for Senior Staff], which provides access to mental health resources and work-life balance training. Congress has also explored bipartisan efforts, such as [2023 Bipartisan Task Force on Executive Branch Sustainability], to evaluate how institutional structures can reduce unnecessary administrative burdens on the president. Societal support, measured through [public opinion poll on presidential work-life balance], can also influence the president‚Äôs ability to prioritize self-care, as positive public sentiment around wellness initiatives encourages more intentional practices. Academic collaborations, such as [symposium on leadership resilience hosted by Harvard Kennedy School], have also contributed to evidence-based recommendations for enhancing executive support systems, including [expanded funding for presidential support staff] and [regular independent assessments of executive function].  

## 5. Conclusion  
The U.S. presidency requires a unique combination of strategic vision, adaptive flexibility, and sustained engagement with diverse stakeholders. This paper has highlighted the multifaceted demands of the role, the cognitive and adaptive strategies employed by presidents, and the institutional and societal supports that foster long-term resilience. Moving forward, future research should prioritize [longitudinal study of presidential wellness across multiple administrations], [interdisciplinary collaboration between political science and clinical psychology], and [policy brief for congressional leaders] to advocate for enhanced support systems. By investing in executive resilience, the U.S. can ensure that its highest office holders are equipped to lead effectively through [upcoming presidential transition periods], [global economic shifts], and [emerging national policy challenges]. This approach not only benefits the president but also contributes to more stable, inclusive, and effective governance for all citizens.

Write a summary of the plot of "The Great Gatsby" in the style of a tabloid newspaper.

**BOMBSHELL: LONG ISLAND JAZZ AGE SCANDAL ENDS IN DOUBLE MURDER-SUICIDE! MYSTERIOUS MILLIONAIRE GATSBY‚ÄôS FORBIDDEN LOVE COSTS HIM EVERYTHING!**

EXCLUSIVE: The glittering, champagne-soaked parties of West Egg‚Äôs most enigmatic playboy are a distant memory‚Äîafter a shocking chain of lies, affairs, and a fatal car crash left Jay Gatsby face-down in his own pool, and his killer, a heartbroken gas station owner, with a bullet in his head.

Sources close to the scene spill the tea: Gatsby, whose rags-to-riches rise had tongues wagging for months (rumors swirled he was a bootlegger, a war hero, even a German spy!), wasn‚Äôt just throwing lavish bashes for fun. Every sequined guest, every jazz number, every overflowing champagne flute was a desperate ploy to win back his long-lost flame, Daisy Buchanan‚Äîa married socialite trapped in a loveless union with brute millionaire Tom Buchanan.

But Daisy‚Äôs not the only one with a secret! Tom, who‚Äôs been carrying on a torrid affair with Myrtle Wilson (the frumpy wife of a Queens gas station owner), caught wind of Gatsby‚Äôs plan to steal his wife‚Äîand let‚Äôs just say he didn‚Äôt take it lying down. In an explosive showdown at a sweltering New York hotel, Tom spilled Gatsby‚Äôs dirty little secret: his fortune came from bootlegging and shady underworld deals, not the inherited wealth he‚Äôd bragged about to impress Daisy.

The drama didn‚Äôt stop there! Hours later, a speeding yellow convertible (linked to Gatsby) mowed down Myrtle as she ran into the road‚Äîkilling her instantly. But here‚Äôs the SHOCKING TWIST: insiders confirm it was Daisy behind the wheel, not Gatsby! The smitten millionaire took the fall to protect his beloved, but Myrtle‚Äôs grief-stricken husband, George Wilson, didn‚Äôt buy it. Convinced Gatsby was both Myrtle‚Äôs lover and her killer, Wilson snuck into Gatsby‚Äôs mansion early one morning and shot him dead before turning the gun on himself.

And the cherry on top of this tragic sundae? Gatsby‚Äôs star-studded parties drew hundreds of hangers-on, but when it came time to bury him, only two people showed up: his loyal neighbor Nick Carraway and his 80-year-old father, who traveled all the way from the Midwest. Daisy? She and Tom skipped town before the body was even cold, leaving Gatsby to rot in the same loneliness he‚Äôd tried to escape with his fortune and fanfare.

INSIDER QUOTE: Nick Carraway, the only one who knew the full story, told our reporter, ‚ÄúThey were a rotten crowd‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre worth the whole damn bunch put together.‚Äù Ouch!

**THE TRUTH BEHIND THE PARTIES: GATSBY‚ÄôS LIFELONG OBSESSION**
Sources reveal Gatsby and Daisy were lovers five years prior, before he left for the war. When he returned penniless, she‚Äôd married Tom for his money. Gatsby spent the next decade amassing wealth just to win her back‚Äîonly to lose everything in a single, fateful weekend.

SHOCKING, RIGHT? Stay tuned for more exclusives on the downfall of West Egg‚Äôs elite!

Please elaborate on the following text: "It's not a bug, it's a feature!"

output:
* This phrase originated as a playful tech industry joke, famously traced to a 1960s incident with an IBM mainframe where a "glitch" that caused the computer to skip empty punch cards was rebranded as a time-saving feature; over time, it has become a ubiquitous quip to frame unintended software behaviors as deliberate, often used to defuse tension when a user encounters something unexpected, even if the behavior wasn‚Äôt initially planned.
* Beyond its humorous use, the phrase can reflect a genuine shift in product development: when a reported "bug" is discovered to be regularly used and valued by users, teams may reclassify it as a formal feature, updating documentation and even building on the behavior to enhance user experience‚Äîthough it‚Äôs also sometimes deployed as a defensive tactic to avoid acknowledging or fixing a legitimate flaw that undermines functionality.

Can you create a list of mega trends in the tech industry?

output:
"Here‚Äôs a list of key mega trends shaping the tech industry, each loaded with opportunities and ongoing innovation:

1. Omnipresent Generative AI: Tools like ChatGPT and DALL-E are no longer niche; they‚Äôre becoming core to every operation, from content creation to code optimization, offering organizations endless ways to boost productivity and open new doors to creative output.
2. Edge Computing Expansion: As IoT devices multiply, processing data closer to its origin (instead of distant cloud servers) is critical for reducing latency, improving real-time response, and supporting operations in remote locations where connectivity is spotty or non-existent.
3. Sustainable Tech Transformation: Companies are prioritizing eco-friendly solutions, from energy-efficient data centers powered by renewable sources to devices designed for longer lifespans and easy recycling, aiming to offset the carbon footprint of our increasingly digital world.
4. Metaverse and Immersive Tech Evolution: Virtual and augmented reality are moving beyond gaming to transform education, healthcare, and corporate training, creating immersive environments where users can collaborate, learn, or interact with digital objects in ways that feel almost organic.
5. Quantum Computing Advancement: Though still in its early stages, quantum computers hold the potential to solve complex problems‚Äîlike optimizing supply chains, developing new medications, or cracking encryption algorithms‚Äîthat ordinary computers can‚Äôt tackle in a reasonable amount of time.
6. IoT and Connected Ecosystems: The internet of things is growing exponentially, linking everything from smart home appliances to industrial machinery, creating interconnected networks that offer unprecedented visibility into operations and enable automated, data-driven decisions.
7. Cybersecurity for a Hyper-Connected World: As more devices and systems go online, the need for robust, adaptive cybersecurity tools is more urgent than ever, with zero-trust architectures and AI-driven threat detection becoming standard to protect against evolving cyber threats.
8. Responsible AI and Ethical Tech Development: There‚Äôs a growing focus on building AI systems that are transparent, fair, and accountable, ensuring they don‚Äôt perpetuate biases, respect user privacy, and operate in ways that align with societal values and legal regulations.
9. 5G and 6G Network Rollout: 5G is already expanding globally, enabling faster speeds and lower latency, while research into 6G is underway to support even more advanced applications like holographic communication and autonomous vehicles operating in real-time.
10. Digital Twin Integration: Digital twins‚Äîvirtual replicas of physical objects or systems‚Äîare being used across industries to simulate performance, predict maintenance needs, and optimize designs before they‚Äôre built, saving time, money, and resources in the process."

Here are some tailored newspaper name ideas for Melbourne teenagers, each tied to the city‚Äôs unique vibe and teen culture:

Melbourne‚Äôs laneways are the beating heart of its street art, indie cafes, and hidden gig spots‚Äîplaces teens flock to hang out and discover new trends. "Lane Line" nods to these iconic spaces while evoking the idea of staying in the loop with the latest news and happenings. St Kilda is a quintessential teen hub: beach days, live music at the Espy, weekend markets, and vibrant street culture. "Signal" positions the paper as the go-to source for urgent, can‚Äôt-miss updates‚Äîfrom upcoming gigs to pop-up food stalls‚Äîwhile the St Kilda reference instantly resonates as a place teens know and love.

3. **Suburb Sync**  
Melbourne‚Äôs sprawling, diverse suburbs each have their own distinct teen scene: Brunswick‚Äôs vintage shops, Box Hill‚Äôs bubble tea spots, Werribee‚Äôs community events, and more. "Sync" emphasizes that the paper will connect teens across all corners of the city, highlighting hidden gems, school fundraisers, and local crew meetups that might fly under the radar otherwise.

4. **Melb Youth Pulse**  
Direct and energetic, this name captures the "heartbeat" of teen life in Melbourne. It signals that the paper will cover everything from youth-led activism and mental health conversations to the latest skate park openings and viral local trends‚Äîall by teens, for teens. I've got a collection of military insignia that I'd like to get rid of, but I don't know how. Can you help me?

output:
<<Responsible Ways to Rehome Your Military Insignia Collection>>
If you‚Äôre looking to part with your military insignia collection thoughtfully, start by exploring adoption opportunities with local military history museums, veteran‚Äôs service organizations, or even university history departments. Many of these groups actively seek authentic insignia to display in exhibits or use for educational purposes, ensuring your pieces are preserved and honored. Before finalizing any arrangement, consider the safe carriage of your collection‚Äîif some items are delicate (like embroidered patches or metal badges with enamel details), invest in acid-free packaging or a hard-sided case to prevent damage during transit. You could also list the collection on specialized forums for military memorabilia enthusiasts, but be sure to vet potential recipients to ensure they‚Äôll care for the items as much as you did. For particularly rare pieces, reaching out to a reputable military memorabilia dealer might be an option, though this is best if you prioritize finding a good home over monetary gain.
******
<<Creative and Meaningful Solutions for Your Unwanted Military Insignia>>
When it comes to rehoming your military insignia collection, don‚Äôt overlook the power of adoption by individuals with personal connections to military service. Reach out to local veteran‚Äôs support groups to see if any veterans or their family members are seeking insignia that align with their branch or era of service‚Äîthis can turn your unwanted collection into a cherished keepsake for someone who values its history. If you decide to send pieces to a distant recipient, plan for secure carriage: use padded envelopes or a small shipping box with bubble wrap to shield metal insignia from scratches and patches from moisture. Another option is to donate the collection to a military-themed youth program, like a JROTC unit, where the insignia can be used to teach cadets about different branches and ranks. For a more hands-on approach, host a small community event where you offer the insignia to attendees, with a request that anyone taking pieces shares how they‚Äôll honor the items‚Äô legacy.

input.content: Your response should include at least one section italicized in markdown, i.e *this is an italic text*. Your response should include the word "singles" at least twice.
Write a poem about a lonely Hue. The poem should be written for teenagers.

output:
**Periwinkle‚Äôs Lament**

I‚Äôm the marker at the bottom of your backpack,
cap cracked, ink thin as a sigh‚Äî
not the fire-engine red that scrawls ‚ÄúUR CUTE‚Äù on locker doors,
not the neon pink that blares study guides for math tests.
I‚Äôm periwinkle: the color of rainclouds that don‚Äôt cry,
the hue of a text left on read,
the one you forget till all the bold ones run dry.

In the cafeteria, I watch the singles‚Äî
kids who prop their phones against milk cartons,
who pick at fries like they‚Äôre counting seconds till the bell rings.
*The way singles slump over trays, ketchup smudges like unspoken apologies,
how they stare at their shoes like the linoleum holds all the answers
no one‚Äôs brave enough to ask*‚Äî
I know that slump. I know that stare.
I‚Äôm the hue of their hoods pulled tight,
the color of the empty seat next to them that stays empty,
even when the lunch line spills over with noise and laughter.

You found me in a clearance bin last fall,
tucked between a pack of glitter pens and a broken ruler.
You bought me because you thought I‚Äôd be ‚Äúunique,‚Äù
but unique‚Äôs just a nice word for lonely when all the other colors
are pairing up to draw rainbows, to write love notes, to fill in the blanks.
I‚Äôm the hue that never gets to be part of the mural,
the one that sits quiet while the others shout.

Last week, you used me to circle a date on your calendar:
‚Äú8/15: Mom‚Äôs birthday.‚Äù
But you crossed it out with black, sharp and final,
like even that small job was too much for a hue like me.
Now I‚Äôm back in the backpack, next to a crumpled gum wrapper,
wondering if I‚Äôll ever get to be more than
the color of lonely,
the marker no one chooses,
the hue that knows exactly what the singles feel.

"Dear Darius,

Let me cut to the chase: I‚Äôm writing because I need a job in Ventura, and I heard you‚Äôre the person who makes even the most mundane work feel like a midday walk to the pier with a fish taco in hand. Also, my current commute involves dodging surfers on their way to Rincon and a seagull that‚Äôs been targeting my turkey sandwich for three weeks straight‚Äîso relocating to a job where I can eat lunch without aerial attacks is non-negotiable.

Here‚Äôs the serious (but still funny) part: I‚Äôm good at the stuff you need. For the last two years, I‚Äôve convinced people that a small-batch hot sauce from Ojai is worth $12 (spoiler: it is, but only if you pair it with a Ventura Harbor clam chowder bread bowl). I can write a social media caption that makes even the most introverted local comment ‚ÄúLOL, relatable,‚Äù and I once organized a dog parade down Main Street that ended with all the pups getting free ice cream at that little shop by the library. (Side note: I still have a photo of a golden retriever covered in mint chip that‚Äôs guaranteed to make anyone smile‚Äîeven you, if you‚Äôre having a Monday where the fog won‚Äôt lift.)

I love this city because it‚Äôs not too big, not too small‚Äîjust the right size where you can run into your barista at the farmers‚Äô market and argue about whether the best avocado toast is at the spot on Thompson or the one by the beach. I know the difference between a ‚ÄúVentura fog‚Äù (cozy, book-worthy) and a ‚ÄúLos Angeles smog‚Äù (run for the hills), and I can recite the entire menu of the In-N-Out on the 101 from memory (animal style fries, extra spread, no onion‚Äîdon‚Äôt @ me).

I heard from a friend of a friend (okay, it was the barista at the farmers‚Äô market) that you‚Äôre the kind of boss who lets people bring their dogs to work and has a stash of La Croix in the break room. If that‚Äôs true, we‚Äôre already 90% of the way to being best friends. If it‚Äôs not, I can bring the La Croix. And the dogs.

I‚Äôm not here to bore you with buzzwords like ‚Äúsynergy‚Äù or ‚Äúdisruptive innovation.‚Äù I‚Äôm here to bring chaos (the good kind), fish tacos, and that golden retriever photo to your team. Let‚Äôs grab coffee at that spot with the rainbow latte art‚Äîmy treat, unless you want to split a fish taco instead. Either way, I promise we‚Äôll have a better time than the seagull who stole my sandwich last Tuesday.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]
P.S. If you hire me, I‚Äôll personally make sure your desk has a steady supply of those lemon bars from the bakery on Main. You‚Äôre welcome."

input.content: Your answer must highlight at least 2 sections with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*.
The opposite of youth is not age, but ...?

output:
The opposite of youth is not age, but resignation.

Youth, at its core, is not a number but an orientation toward life: a hunger to learn, a willingness to take risks, a belief that change is possible and that one can shape their own path. Age, by contrast, is merely a marker of time passed‚Äîmany older people retain that youthful spark, while some young people already feel defeated by life‚Äôs constraints.

*Resignation is the death of possibility, which is the lifeblood of youth.* When we resign ourselves to the idea that we can‚Äôt grow, that our best days are behind us, that we have no control over our circumstances, we abandon the core of what it means to be youthful. This isn‚Äôt about being "old"; it‚Äôs about closing off to the world, letting cynicism replace curiosity, and choosing complacency over courage. A 70-year-old taking their first art class is far more youthful than a 20-year-old who insists ‚Äúthere‚Äôs no point in trying anything new.‚Äù

*Resignation erodes the active engagement that defines youth.* Youth is about showing up‚Äîtrying new things, asking questions, fighting for what matters, even when it‚Äôs hard. Resignation is about checking out: avoiding challenges, dismissing new ideas, and settling for ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù because we‚Äôve decided it‚Äôs not worth the effort. It‚Äôs a mindset that can take hold at any age, whether you‚Äôre 25 or 75, and it‚Äôs far more alien to youth than gray hair or wrinkles could ever be.

Age can bring wisdom, perspective, and depth‚Äîqualities that complement, rather than oppose, youth. But resignation? It‚Äôs the antithesis of everything youth stands for: it‚Äôs the choice to stop living fully, to stop reaching, to stop believing in the potential of tomorrow.

A serpente, figura astuta e sedutora, aproximou-se de Eva e questionou a proibi√ß√£o de Deus. Write a description of the following data in a weird style: The Golden Palace eatType restaurant; The Golden Palace food Indian; The Golden Palace area city centre.

output:
Imagine a place where the air tastes like cardamom and confusion, where the walls hum with the ghost of a thousand naan flips, and where "restaurant" isn‚Äôt just a label‚Äîit‚Äôs a warning. This is The Golden Palace, and it‚Äôs here to rearrange your understanding of lunch breaks.

### The Portal of Curried Concoctions (AKA: It‚Äôs a Restaurant, Duh)
Forget food trucks that roll away when you blink or pop-up stalls that vanish at dusk. The Golden Palace is a permanent fixture, a box of spice-scented magic wedged between a laundromat that only washes silk and a bookstore that sells nothing but cookbooks written by ghosts. It‚Äôs not a caf√©, not a takeaway, not a food cart‚Äîno, it‚Äôs a full-blown restaurant, with chairs that creak like they‚Äôre sharing secrets and tables that stick to your elbows if you lean too long. Walk through its doors, and you‚Äôre signing up for a meal that might leave you with a new favorite spice or a vague memory of dancing with a tandoor chef.

### The Spice-Crusted Soul of the Place (Indian Food, But Make It Unhinged)
This isn‚Äôt your grandma‚Äôs chicken tikka masala (though grandma would probably approve, if she believed in glowing naan). The Golden Palace serves Indian food that‚Äôs alive‚Äîcurries that bubble like they‚Äôre plotting world domination, chutneys that change flavor when you tell them a joke, and biryani so fragrant it makes nearby streetlights dim in envy. You‚Äôll find all the classics, but with a twist: the samosas have a hidden layer of mango chutney that only reveals itself if you say ‚Äúabracadabra‚Äù before biting, and the lassi is so thick it can double as a face mask (not that anyone‚Äôs tried‚Ä¶ yet).

### Nestled in the City‚Äôs Chaotic Heart (City Centre, Where Chaos Meets Curry)
You won‚Äôt find The Golden Palace in a quiet suburban strip mall or a hidden alleyway. Oh no‚Äîit‚Äôs planted right in the city centre, where the sidewalks are sticky with spilled chai, where street performers juggle fire and leftover roti, and where pigeons have learned to beg in Hindi. It‚Äôs sandwiched between a neon-lit pawn shop that sells only silver spoons and a bus stop where every passenger is carrying a takeaway container from the palace. Stand on the corner for 30 seconds, and you‚Äôll see a businessman in a suit sprinting for the door, a group of teens arguing over who gets the last gulab jamun, and a stray cat that‚Äôs somehow mastered the art of ordering butter chicken.

If you ever find yourself wandering the city‚Äôs chaotic core, follow the scent of cumin and curiosity. The Golden Palace isn‚Äôt just a restaurant‚Äîit‚Äôs a glitch in the matrix, and it‚Äôs waiting to feed you.

input.content: Your response should have two sections (Section 1 and Section 2). Your response should contain at least 25 sentences.
Write a casual summary of the U.S. maternity leave policy.

output:
### Section 1: The Federal Baseline (Spoiler: It‚Äôs Pretty Weak)
Let‚Äôs start with the big picture: unlike almost every other developed country in the world, the U.S. doesn‚Äôt have a federal mandatory paid maternity leave policy. Yeah, you read that right‚Äîthere‚Äôs no law that says your boss has to pay you to take time off after having a baby. The main federal law we do have is the Family and Medical Leave Act, or FMLA, which was passed back in 1993. But here‚Äôs the catch: FMLA only applies to a specific group of people. To qualify, you have to have worked at the same job for at least 12 months, put in 1,250 hours (that‚Äôs about 24 hours a week for a year), and your employer has to have 50 or more workers within a 75-mile radius. That leaves out a ton of people‚Äîlike part-timers who don‚Äôt hit the hour mark, folks who work for small local businesses with fewer than 50 employees, and anyone who‚Äôs switched jobs in the last year. In fact, only around 56% of U.S. workers are even eligible for FMLA. And even if you do qualify? FMLA only gives you 12 weeks of unpaid leave. Unpaid. So if you can‚Äôt afford to go without a paycheck for three months, FMLA doesn‚Äôt do you much good. A lot of low-wage workers fall into this category‚Äîthey can‚Äôt skip a month of rent or grocery bills, so they have to go back to work just weeks after giving birth. It‚Äôs not just maternity leave, either; FMLA covers paternity leave, adoption leave, and caring for a sick family member too, but most people associate it with new parents. Another thing: FMLA doesn‚Äôt protect you from getting a pay cut or a demotion when you come back, but it does say your employer has to hold your job (or a similar one) for you. But again, that‚Äôs only if you qualify. For millions of Americans, though, there‚Äôs no federal safety net at all. If you work at a small caf√© or a local construction company, your boss might let you take a few weeks off, but they‚Äôre not legally required to‚Äîand they definitely don‚Äôt have to pay you. It‚Äôs a pretty stark contrast to places like Canada, where new parents get up to 18 months of paid leave, or Sweden, which offers even more with flexible options for both parents. It‚Äôs wild that the U.S. is so far behind on this, especially when you think about how much maternity leave impacts both parents and kids.

### Section 2: The Patchwork of State and Private Options
Okay, so the federal government isn‚Äôt doing much, but that doesn‚Äôt mean all hope is lost‚Äîsome states have stepped up to fill the gap. As of 2024, there are 11 states (plus Washington, D.C.) that have mandatory paid family and medical leave programs. These include California, New York, Washington, Oregon, and Massachusetts, to name a few. How do these work? Usually, they‚Äôre funded by a small payroll tax that employees (and sometimes employers) contribute to each paycheck. So every time you get paid, a tiny percentage of your wage goes into a state fund, and when you need to take leave for a new baby (or other qualifying reasons), you can apply to get a portion of your salary for a set number of weeks. For example, in California, eligible workers can get up to 60-70% of their weekly wages, depending on how much they make, for up to 12 weeks. Some states even offer extended leave for things like complications during pregnancy‚Äîlike an extra 4 weeks if you had a C-section. Then there are states that don‚Äôt have paid leave, but they do have better unpaid leave than FMLA. For instance, some states require employers with as few as 10 workers to offer unpaid leave, which covers a lot more people than the federal 50-employee threshold. But even with these state programs, there are still gaps. Not all workers in those states qualify‚Äîyou might need to have worked a certain number of hours or been in the state for a specific period. And the amount you get might not be enough to cover all your expenses, especially if you‚Äôre a high-wage earner (since most cap the weekly benefit). On the private side, some big companies‚Äîlike Google, Amazon, and Microsoft‚Äîoffer generous paid maternity leave even in states that don‚Äôt require it. Google, for example, gives new parents up to 20 weeks of paid leave, and that includes both moms and dads. But here‚Äôs the thing: these perks are only for people who work at those big, well-funded companies. If you‚Äôre a cashier at a local grocery store or a home health aide, you‚Äôre probably out of luck. Low-wage workers are the least likely to have access to any paid maternity leave, which is ironic because they‚Äôre the ones who can least afford to go without income. I have a friend named Lila who works at a diner in a state with no paid leave; she had to go back to work just two weeks after her son was born because she couldn‚Äôt pay her rent otherwise. She told me she cried through most of her shifts those first few weeks, worrying about leaving her baby with a babysitter who barely knew him. It‚Äôs stories like hers that make people push for a federal paid leave policy. There‚Äôs been a bill called the FAMILY Act floating around Congress for years, which would create a national paid family and medical leave program funded by a small payroll tax (about 0.4% split between employers and employees). It would give workers up to 12 weeks of paid leave at 66% of their wages, with a cap on the weekly benefit. But so far, it hasn‚Äôt been able to pass, thanks to partisan gridlock. The lack of universal paid maternity leave has real consequences: it leads to higher rates of maternal depression, lower breastfeeding rates, and can set women back in their careers for years. When moms have to go back to work too soon, they‚Äôre less likely to advance in their jobs, which widens the gender pay gap. It also affects kids‚Äîstudies show that babies whose parents have access to paid leave have better health outcomes and do better in school later on. At the end of the day, the U.S. maternity leave system is a hodgepodge of federal loopholes, state-level programs, and private company perks. It‚Äôs not fair, it‚Äôs not consistent, and it leaves way too many families struggling just to take care of their new babies.

input.content: Your response should contain at least 4 sentences. The letter 'n' should appear at least 3 times in your response.
What are the steps to get the GNSS timestamp on Android? Explain this to teenagers.

output:
Hey there! If you‚Äôre curious about getting a super precise GNSS timestamp on your Android phone‚Äîfirst, let‚Äôs break down what that even means. GNSS stands for Global Navigation Satellite System, and it‚Äôs the network of satellites that powers your phone‚Äôs location features, including a timestamp that‚Äôs way more accurate than your phone‚Äôs regular clock (which can drift a little over time). 

First step: Make sure your location services are set up correctly. Open your phone‚Äôs Settings app, scroll down to ‚ÄúLocation,‚Äù and toggle it on if it‚Äôs off. Then, tap ‚ÄúLocation Mode‚Äù (or ‚ÄúPrecision‚Äù on some phones) and select ‚ÄúHigh Accuracy‚Äù‚Äîthis ensures your phone is using GNSS satellites instead of just Wi-Fi or cell towers, which don‚Äôt give you that precise timestamp. Without high accuracy mode, you won‚Äôt get the real GNSS data you need, so don‚Äôt skip this part!

Next, you‚Äôll need an app that can show you raw GNSS data, because regular apps like Google Maps don‚Äôt display this detailed info. Head to the Google Play Store and search for apps like ‚ÄúGPS Test‚Äù or ‚ÄúGNSS Status & Toolbox‚Äù‚Äîmost of these are free and easy to use. Once you download one, open it up and give it permission to access your location; that‚Äôs key for it to connect to the satellites and pull in the timestamp data.

Now, wait a minute or two for the app to lock onto satellites. If you‚Äôre inside, you might need to move near a window or step outside, since walls can block the satellite signals. Once it‚Äôs connected, you‚Äôll see a bunch of data: how many satellites it‚Äôs linked to, their signal strength, and somewhere in the menu (look for tabs like ‚ÄúSatellites‚Äù or ‚ÄúRaw Data‚Äù) you‚Äôll find the GNSS timestamp. It might be labeled ‚ÄúGPS Time‚Äù or ‚ÄúGNSS Time,‚Äù and it‚Äôll look like a long number or a specific date and time that‚Äôs synced perfectly with the satellites.

If you want to save or use this timestamp, many of these apps let you copy it to your clipboard, export the data as a file, or even share it with friends for a group project. For example, if you‚Äôre doing a science experiment that needs exact timing of a location-based event, this timestamp is way more reliable than just checking your phone‚Äôs clock. Just remember that the more satellites your phone connects to, the more accurate the timestamp will be‚Äîso patience is key when waiting for that satellite lock!

Oh, and one last thing: Don‚Äôt worry if the timestamp looks a little different from your phone‚Äôs regular time sometimes. GNSS time doesn‚Äôt account for leap seconds like our regular civil time does, but most apps will show you both the raw GNSS time and a converted version that matches your local time zone if you need it. That way, you can use whichever one fits what you‚Äôre working on, whether it‚Äôs a school project or just satisfying your curiosity about how satellite tech works.

input.content: Your response must be at least 400 words long. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
Write a description for the Pixel 3A smartphone.

output:
"Unveiled in May 2019, the Google Pixel 3A redefined the mid-range smartphone market, proving that flagship-caliber photography and a premium software experience didn‚Äôt have to come with a flagship price tag. Positioned as the accessible sibling to the high-end Pixel 3, the 3A targeted everyday users who prioritized camera quality, clean software, and reliable performance without breaking the bank‚Äîand it delivered on every front, leaving a lasting legacy as one of the most influential mid-range phones of its era.

Starting with its design, the Pixel 3A opts for a durable polycarbonate unibody that feels surprisingly solid in the hand, despite its affordable materials. Available in three eye-catching hues‚ÄîJust Black, Clearly White, and the fan-favorite Purple-ish‚Äîa matte finish resists fingerprints and gives the phone an understated, modern look. At 147 grams, it‚Äôs lightweight and compact, with a 5.6-inch screen that balances usability with one-handed comfort. The rear features a centered fingerprint sensor (fast and accurate, even with wet fingers), a single circular camera lens flanked by a LED flash, and the iconic Google logo. Up front, a small notch houses the 8MP selfie camera, with thin bezels framing the OLED display for an immersive yet uncluttered feel.

The 5.6-inch 1080p OLED display is a standout for its price range. Unlike many mid-range phones of the era that relied on LCD panels, the Pixel 3A‚Äôs OLED delivers deep, inky blacks, vibrant color reproduction, and excellent contrast ratios, making streaming movies, browsing photos, and reading in low light a pleasure. Google‚Äôs adaptive brightness algorithm is finely tuned, adjusting seamlessly to bright sunlight and dim indoor environments without being overly aggressive, while the 18:9 aspect ratio fits more content on the screen without feeling stretched.

But the Pixel 3A‚Äôs true claim to fame is its camera system‚Äîa single 12.2MP rear sensor identical to the one in the flagship Pixel 3, paired with Google‚Äôs industry-leading computational photography software. This combination turned the mid-range phone into a low-light photography powerhouse, thanks to Night Sight, a feature that captured bright, detailed images in near darkness without the harsh washout of a flash. Whether you were photographing a city skyline at dusk or a candlelit dinner, Night Sight produced sharp, noise-free photos that outperformed even more expensive phones with multiple lenses. Other flagship-level features included Portrait Mode, which created professional-looking depth effects with accurate edge detection; Top Shot, which automatically selected the best frame from a burst to avoid closed eyes or awkward expressions; and Super Res Zoom, which used machine learning to zoom in on subjects without losing detail. The 8MP front camera held its own too, with Portrait Mode for selfies and a Group Selfie feature that widened the frame to fit more friends in the shot.

Under the hood, the Pixel 3A packs a Qualcomm Snapdragon 670 processor, 4GB of RAM, and 64GB of non-expandable storage. While the Snapdragon 670 is a mid-range chip, Google‚Äôs stock Android software‚Äîfree of bloatware and optimized for efficiency‚Äîensured smooth performance for daily tasks. Multitasking between social media apps, streaming services, and web browsers felt effortless, and even light gaming (like *Candy Crush* or *Among Us*) ran without lag. For power users who demanded intensive gaming or heavy video editing, the 3A might have struggled, but for the vast majority of users, it was more than capable.

Software was another major selling point. The Pixel 3A launched with Android 9 Pie and received three full years of OS and security updates‚Äîan unprecedented commitment for a mid-range phone at the time, when most competitors offered only one or two years of support. This meant users enjoyed the latest Android features (like Dark Mode, Gesture Navigation, and Privacy Dashboard) long after launch, keeping the phone feeling fresh and secure. Stock Android‚Äôs clean, intuitive interface allowed for easy customization, with no pre-installed apps cluttering the home screen.

Battery life was reliable, with a 3000mAh battery that easily lasted a full day of moderate use‚Äîincluding streaming an hour of video, browsing social media for several hours, and taking dozens of photos. Google‚Äôs Adaptive Battery feature learned users‚Äô app habits, reducing power to infrequently used apps to extend runtime. When the battery did run low, 18W fast charging provided a 50% charge in just 30 minutes, though wireless charging was notably absent (a trade-off for the lower price point).

In the years since its launch, the Pixel 3A has left a lasting legacy. It shattered the myth that great photography required a high-end price tag, pushing other manufacturers to invest in computational photography for their mid-range lines. For budget-conscious users who valued camera quality and a pure Android experience, the Pixel 3A wasn‚Äôt just a good phone‚Äîit was a revelation, proving that sometimes, smart software and targeted innovation matter more than cutting-edge hardware."
