Good morning, everyone. Today we‚Äôre going to explore the inner workings of Shinto shrines‚Äîspaces that are far more than architectural landmarks; they‚Äôre sacred hubs where humans connect with the kami, the divine spirits central to Shinto belief. Let‚Äôs walk through the key areas you‚Äôll encounter once you step beyond the iconic torii gate.

First, after purifying your hands and mouth at the temizuya (stone basin just inside the shrine grounds), you‚Äôll move toward the core structures. Let‚Äôs start with the most revered space:

*The Honden: The Sacred Heart of the Shrine*  
This is the innermost, most secluded part of the shrine, where the kami is believed to reside. Unlike other areas, the Honden is almost never open to the general public‚Äîonly high-ranking shrine priests may enter to perform daily rituals, such as offering fresh water, rice, or sake to the kami. The physical representation of the kami, called a shintai, is kept here; this could be a polished mirror, a sword, a stone, or even a natural object like a tree branch. For example, if you ever visit [local shrine name], you‚Äôll notice the Honden is tucked behind layers of wooden fences and gates, its simple, traditional design a stark reminder of its sacred purpose. It‚Äôs a space of quiet reverence, designed to honor the kami‚Äôs privacy and divine status.

Next, we have the area that acts as a bridge between mortal visitors and the secluded Honden:

*The Heiden: Mediator Between Humans and the Divine*  
The Heiden is the hall of offerings, where priests present gifts to the kami on behalf of the community. These offerings might include seasonal fruits, rice cakes, or even monetary donations. While visitors can‚Äôt enter the Heiden themselves, they can often see it from a distance, especially during festivals. During [annual festival date] at many shrines, the Heiden becomes the center of activity: priests chant norito (Shinto prayers), perform ceremonial dances, and present elaborate offerings to thank the kami for blessings like good harvests or safe travels. It‚Äôs here that the gap between our world and the divine narrows, allowing our gratitude and requests to reach the kami.

Finally, let‚Äôs talk about the space that‚Äôs often the first point of contact for visitors:

*The Shamusho: Administrative and Welcoming Hub*  
Located near the shrine entrance, the Shamusho serves as both the shrine‚Äôs office and a welcoming center for guests. Here, you can purchase omamori (protective talismans for health, academic success, or safety), omikuji (fortune slips that reveal your luck for the year), or write a wish on an ema (wooden plaque) to hang up for the kami to see. The staff at the Shamusho are usually well-versed in shrine history and etiquette, so don‚Äôt hesitate to ask questions. Some shrines even offer [traditional purification ritual workshop] here, where you can learn to perform temizu and other basic rituals under the guidance of a trained priest. It‚Äôs the perfect starting point for any shrine visit, blending practicality with spiritual connection.

Before we wrap up, remember that every shrine is unique‚Äîsome are small, family-run sites in rural villages, while others are grand complexes like Ise Jingu. But no matter their size, they all share these core elements that reflect Shinto‚Äôs focus on harmony between humans, nature, and the divine.

Are there any questions about what we‚Äôve covered today?

<<spell copyright lawyer: we turn cease-and-desists into frog spawn>>

tired of that basic suburban witch stealing your signature "hex the nosy neighbor" incantation and selling it as a printable on etsy? fed up with warlocks passing off your broomstick levitation enchantment as their own at the annual coven summit? did a rival coven copy your cauldron‚Äôs secret three-moon simmer sequence and now their potions are outselling yours at the midnight farmers‚Äô market?

you need a lawyer who speaks your language‚Äîliterally. i don‚Äôt just know the federal copyright act; i can recite the 17th-century grimoire of intellectual property curses from memory. no stuffy conference rooms here: we meet in a hidden hollow under the old oak, where the coffee‚Äôs brewed with wormwood and the legal pads are made of pressed blackberry leaves.

here‚Äôs what i do for you:
- subpoena the spirit of the 16th-century witch who invented your spell‚Äôs core structure to testify via ouija board (they‚Äôre great at calling out copycats)

- file a counterclaim for "emotional distress via spell dilution" when your once-exclusive curse becomes a viral tiktok sound
- seal court records with a binding charm so no muggle judge ever finds out you used a love spell to win over the jury

warning: i don‚Äôt represent witches who steal spells (that‚Äôs a curse-worthy offense, and i‚Äôll hex you myself if you lie about it). also, if you show up with a broomstick that‚Äôs been enchanted by a copycat, i‚Äôll make you clean my cauldron for a week as a lesson.

contact me by leaving a jar of fermented apple cider under the third stone to the left of the old cemetery gate at midnight. include a lock of your hair and a note describing the stolen spell in rhyming couplets. no emails‚Äîmuggles hack those, and i don‚Äôt have time to hex every spam bot that finds my address.

last month, i got a witch‚Äôs signature love potion recipe back from a warlock who‚Äôd been selling it at ren faires. the settlement? he had to polish her broomstick every full moon for a year, and his familiar (a very sassy raven) now brings her fresh berries every sunday.

don‚Äôt let spell thieves get away with it. your incantations are your art‚Äîprotect them with someone who knows magic and the law. (and if all else fails, we can turn the thief‚Äôs spellbook into a pile of slugs. no refunds on the slugs, though.)

input.content: Your response should not contain any commas.
How can you get to know someone on a deep level in a romantic relationship? The answer should involve the topic of vulnerability.

output:
To get to know someone on a deep level in a romantic relationship vulnerability is the foundation that unlocks true connection. Start by practicing intentional self-vulnerability beyond surface-level small talk. Share your quiet fears the moments you felt inadequate or the dreams you‚Äôve hesitated to voice because you worried they might seem silly or too big. When you open up without pretense you signal to your partner that the relationship is a safe space where they won‚Äôt be judged for showing their own soft edges.

Create regular low-pressure moments to dive into deeper conversations instead of only relying on casual check-ins. This could be during a quiet walk after dinner while sitting together before bed or on a weekend trip where distractions are minimal. Ask open-ended questions that invite vulnerability rather than yes-or-no answers. For example instead of asking ‚ÄúDid you have a good childhood?‚Äù try ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs a memory from your childhood that still affects how you see the world today?‚Äù

Practice active and non-reactive listening when your partner shares. Resist the urge to fix their problems immediately or compare their experiences to your own. Instead validate their feelings by saying things like ‚ÄúThat sounds like it was really hard for you‚Äù or ‚ÄúI can see why that matters so much to you.‚Äù When they feel heard and accepted they‚Äôll be more likely to keep opening up over time.

Embrace moments of discomfort together. Vulnerability can feel scary so it‚Äôs normal for either of you to hold back at times. If your partner seems hesitant don‚Äôt push them but let them know you‚Äôre there when they‚Äôre ready. Similarly if you feel nervous about sharing something acknowledge that feeling out loud. Saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a little scared to talk about this but I trust you enough to try‚Äù can deepen the connection and encourage mutual vulnerability.

Finally follow through on the trust you build. If your partner shares something private honor that confidence by not discussing it with others or using it against them in arguments. Consistency in being a safe and reliable person will make vulnerability feel less risky and more rewarding for both of you. Over time these acts of mutual vulnerability will weave a deep understanding of each other‚Äôs core selves that goes beyond surface attraction and creates a lasting romantic bond.

Says, ‚ÄúHello, my friend‚Äîyou are the long-lost nephew of the Nigerian king, divine!‚Äù

Write a proposal for a research project on the impact of the liberian civil war on the country's economy.

output:
# research proposal: the long-term economic impact of the liberian civil wars (1989‚Äì2003) on post-conflict recovery and inclusive growth in [target liberian county, e.g., nimba or bong]

## 1. introduction
the liberian civil wars (1989‚Äì1996 and 1999‚Äì2003) resulted in an estimated 250,000 deaths, widespread displacement, and the near-total collapse of key economic institutions and infrastructure. while post-conflict aid and policy reforms have driven modest macroeconomic growth since 2003, liberia remains one of the world‚Äôs poorest countries, with 44% of the population living below the poverty line (undp, 2023). existing research often focuses on immediate post-conflict stabilization efforts, but there is a critical gap in understanding the long-term, sector-specific, and disaggregated economic impacts of the wars‚Äîparticularly how they shaped disparities across regions, demographic groups, and generations. this study aims to fill this gap by analyzing the wars‚Äô enduring effects on liberia‚Äôs economy, identifying barriers to inclusive recovery, and proposing evidence-based recommendations for [local stakeholder group, e.g., the liberian ministry of agriculture or small business development authority].

## 2. research problem
the liberian civil wars disrupted every facet of the economy: agricultural production collapsed as farmers fled or lost access to land and tools; trade networks were destroyed by road closures and looting; and formal institutions (e.g., banks, tax agencies) ceased to function. while some sectors have partially recovered, many communities still grapple with war-induced challenges like limited access to credit, weak property rights, and a shortage of skilled labor. however, most existing studies overlook micro-level disparities‚Äîfor example, how women farmers (who make up 70% of liberia‚Äôs agricultural workforce) faced unique barriers to rebuilding their livelihoods, or how youth in war-affected regions struggle to access employment due to intergenerational skill gaps. without addressing these nuanced impacts, post-conflict economic policies risk perpetuating inequality and leaving vulnerable groups behind, which could fuel renewed social unrest. this study seeks to address this gap by centering disaggregated data and lived experiences in its analysis.

## 3. research objectives
### primary objective
to assess the long-term economic impacts of the liberian civil wars on key sectors (agriculture, small and medium enterprises, trade) and inclusive growth in [target county].

### secondary objectives
1. analyze how war-induced institutional collapse (e.g., breakdown of land tenure systems, loss of financial governance) hindered post-conflict economic recovery.
2. examine disparities in economic outcomes across demographic groups (women, youth, former combatants) and sub-regions within [target county].
3. identify successful post-conflict economic interventions (e.g., community-led land reform programs, microfinance initiatives) and their replicability in other war-affected areas.
4. propose tailored policy recommendations for [local stakeholder group] to mitigate war-related economic barriers and advance inclusive growth.

## 4. research questions
1. what are the long-term effects of the liberian civil wars on the performance of key economic sectors in [target county]?
2. how did war-induced institutional breakdowns shape post-conflict economic governance and livelihood recovery for marginalized groups?
3. to what extent do current regional and demographic disparities in economic outcomes stem from war-related disruptions?
4. which post-conflict economic interventions have effectively reduced war-induced economic vulnerabilities, and what lessons can be drawn for future recovery efforts?

## 5. literature review outline
1. theoretical frameworks: conflict economics, post-conflict recovery, and inclusive growth‚Äîdrawing on theories from scholars like paul collier and steven davis.
2. existing research on liberia‚Äôs civil wars: macro-level analyses of gdp growth, aid effectiveness, and institutional reform; sector-specific studies of agriculture and trade.
3. gaps in current literature: underrepresentation of micro-level disparities, intergenerational skill gaps, and the role of community-led interventions in recovery.
4. comparative insights: lessons from post-conflict economies in sierra leone and ivory coast, focusing on how similar war impacts were addressed (or not) through policy.

## 6. methodology
this study uses a mixed-methods approach to capture both quantitative trends and qualitative lived experiences:
- **quantitative component**: analyze secondary data from the liberian institute of statistics and geo-information services (lisgis), world bank, and undp, covering sectoral output, poverty rates, employment, and land tenure patterns from 1980 to 2024. data will be disaggregated by gender, age, and sub-region to identify disparities. statistical analysis will include regression models to correlate war-related disruptions with current economic outcomes.
- **qualitative component**: conduct 30 semi-structured interviews with key informants, including small business owners, women farmers, local government officials, and representatives from [local ngo, e.g., action aid liberia]. additionally, 5 focus group discussions (each with 8‚Äì10 participants) will be held with youth and former displaced persons to explore their experiences of rebuilding livelihoods. all interviews will be conducted in english or local languages (kpelle, mano) with the support of trained translators.
- **data analysis**: quantitative data will be processed using stata, while qualitative data will be coded and analyzed using nvivo software to identify recurring themes related to war impacts and recovery barriers.

## 7. timeline (12 months)
| phase | activities | timeline |
|-------|------------|----------|
| 1 | literature review, research design finalization, and ethical approval from [institutional review board, e.g., university of liberia research ethics committee] | months 1‚Äì2 |
| 2 | secondary data collection and cleaning; recruitment of local research assistants and translators | months 3‚Äì4 |
| 3 | field data collection (interviews and focus groups) in [target county] | months 5‚Äì6 |
| 4 | data analysis and synthesis of preliminary findings | months 7‚Äì8 |
| 5 | drafting of full research report; peer review by [academic or stakeholder partner, e.g., the liberian economic association] | months 9‚Äì10 |
| 6 | validation workshop with local stakeholders; revision of report and policy recommendations | month 11 |
| 7 | dissemination of findings (policy briefing for government officials, community forums, and publication of a simplified summary brief in local languages) | month 12 |

## 8. ethical considerations
- informed consent: all participants will receive clear, jargon-free information about the study‚Äôs purpose, their right to withdraw at any time, and the anonymization of their identities in all outputs. written consent will be obtained, with verbal consent documented for non-literate participants.
- vulnerable groups: for participants who may experience distress when discussing war-related trauma (e.g., former child soldiers, survivors of gender-based violence), access to [free counseling service, e.g., provided by the liberian national trauma healing program] will be offered.
- data protection: all interview recordings and personal data will be stored securely on encrypted devices, with identifiers removed before analysis.
- community benefit: the study will share findings directly with participants through local forums, and policy recommendations will prioritize the needs of marginalized groups involved in data collection.

## 9. expected outcomes
1. a comprehensive research report detailing long-term war impacts on [target county‚Äôs] economy, with disaggregated data on demographic and regional disparities.
2. a set of actionable policy recommendations tailored to [local stakeholder group], including steps to strengthen land tenure security, expand microfinance access for women farmers, and address youth skill gaps.
3. a community-friendly summary brief (in english and kpelle) distributed to local schools, cooperatives, and village councils to ensure broad accessibility.
4. a peer-reviewed journal article sharing insights on post-conflict inclusive growth for global academic and policy audiences.

## 10. budget summary
| category | estimated cost | details |
|----------|----------------|---------|
| personnel | $18,000 | lead researcher salary ($12,000); 2 local research assistants ($3,000 each) |
| fieldwork | $7,500 | travel to [target county] sites ($3,000); translator fees ($2,000); focus group logistics (venue, refreshments) ($2,500) |
| data analysis | $3,000 | stata and nvivo licenses ($500); statistical consulting fees ($2,500) |
| dissemination | $4,500 | report printing and distribution ($1,500); workshop venue and catering ($2,000); translation of summary brief ($1,000) |
| contingency fund | $3,000 | 10% of total budget for unforeseen costs (e.g., travel delays, additional data collection) |
| total | $36,000 | |

proposed funding sources: [international donor organization, e.g., the ford foundation‚Äôs peace and justice program], liberian national research grants, or partnerships with local universities.

input.content: Your summary must contain less than 4 sentences.

Kindly summarize the text below in XML format.

Quantum entanglement is the phenomenon that occurs when a group of particles are generated, interact, or share spatial proximity in such a way that the quantum state of each particle of the group cannot be described independently of the state of the others, including when the particles are separated by a large distance. The topic of quantum entanglement is at the heart of the disparity between classical and quantum physics: entanglement is a primary feature of quantum mechanics not present in classical mechanics.

Measurements of physical properties such as position, momentum, spin, and polarization performed on entangled particles can, in some cases, be found to be perfectly correlated. For example, if a pair of entangled particles is generated such that their total spin is known to be zero, and one particle is found to have clockwise spin on a first axis, then the spin of the other particle, measured on the same axis, is found to be anticlockwise. However, this behavior gives rise to seemingly paradoxical effects: any measurement of a particle's properties results in an apparent and irreversible wave function collapse of that particle and changes the original quantum state. With entangled particles, such measurements affect the entangled system as a whole.

Such phenomena were the subject of a 1935 paper by Albert Einstein, Boris Podolsky, and Nathan Rosen, and several papers by Erwin Schr√∂dinger shortly thereafter, describing what came to be known as the EPR paradox. Einstein and others considered such behavior impossible, as it violated the local realism view of causality (Einstein referring to it as "spooky action at a distance") and argued that the accepted formulation of quantum mechanics must therefore be incomplete.

output:
<quantum_entanglement_summary>
  <core_info>Quantum entanglement is a quantum mechanics phenomenon where particles' quantum states are interdependent even across large distances, a feature not present in classical physics; measurements of properties like spin on entangled particles show perfect correlations, with any measurement triggering wave function collapse that affects the entire entangled system. This phenomenon was central to the 1935 EPR paradox, which Einstein dismissed as "spooky action at a distance" for conflicting with local realism, leading him to argue quantum mechanics might be incomplete.</core_info>
</quantum_entanglement_summary>

**The Riddle of Trips and Stitches**  

I begin where a foot strays from the steady, worn track‚Äî  
A lurch, a sharp gasp, a skin-splitting crack.  
The earth rises fast, the sky spins away,  
And a red river blooms where the smooth flesh once lay.  

I have two halves: one that breaks, one that binds,  
One a misstep that leaves the body unaligned,  
The other a needle that pulls thread through the tear,  
Stitching the edges till the pain disappears.  

I‚Äôm the pair that no healer can ever unbind‚Äî  
A trip that requires the stitch to rewind  
The damage done by a moment‚Äôs misstep,  
Two parts of a tale where the hurt and help intersect.  

What am I?  

DO NOT RUSH TO GUESS‚ÄîPONDER HOW A SINGLE STUMBLE CAN SPARK THE NEED FOR A THREAD THAT MENDS, FOR THIS DUALITY IS THE RIDDLE‚ÄôS UNSEEN CORE TRUTH.

Is ballistics (the study of the motion of projectiles) an actual science?

Yes, ballistics is a legitimate, recognized science. It is a specialized branch of applied physics (specifically classical mechanics) focused on analyzing the motion, behavior, and effects of projectiles such as bullets, rockets, artillery shells, and even sports equipment like arrows or golf balls.

Ballistics is divided into subfields that each apply rigorous scientific principles:
1. **Internal ballistics**: Examines the processes inside a weapon (e.g., combustion of propellants, pressure changes) that launch a projectile, relying on thermodynamics and materials science.
2. **External ballistics**: Studies the motion of a projectile through the air, using Newton's laws of motion, fluid dynamics (to account for air resistance), and gravitational physics to predict trajectory.
3. **Terminal ballistics**: Analyzes the interaction between a projectile and its target, incorporating principles of impact mechanics, energy transfer, and material deformation.

It is widely used in practical fields like forensic science (to link bullets to weapons), aerospace engineering (rocket and missile design), military technology, and even sports science. Like other sciences, it relies on systematic observation, experimentation, and the application of testable theories to make predictions and explain phenomena‚Äîcore hallmarks of scientific inquiry.

input.content: Your answer must include exactly one bullet point in markdown format.

Imagine you're a 19 year old and you're making a video game. The game is about a boy who has to save the world from a villain. Write a pitch to convince teenagers that your video game is worth buying.

output:
Yo, listen up‚Äîif you‚Äôre sick of save-the-world games where the hero is some overconfident chosen one with a fancy sword and zero personality, I got you. My game, *Ordinary Heroes: Void‚Äôs End*, is about Jax, a 17-year-old who still forgets to water his mom‚Äôs plants and spends half his allowance on energy drinks. He‚Äôs not special‚Ä¶ until the Void King shows up. This guy isn‚Äôt your typical dark lord‚Äîhe feeds on the apathy we all feel sometimes: when adults ignore us, when our friends are distant, when it feels like nothing we do matters.

Gameplay? It‚Äôs all about using what you‚Äôve got. You‚Äôll skateboard through abandoned malls to outrun shadow monsters, rig a portable charger into a shock gadget to stun enemies, and even use your phone to text your crew for backup (because no hero goes it alone). Side quests aren‚Äôt just fetch missions‚Äîthey‚Äôre the stuff we deal with every day: helping your best friend track down their lost festival ticket, standing up to a bully who‚Äôs terrorizing the freshmen, or even just staying up all night to help a friend study for a test that could make or break their future.

‚Ä¢ Every choice you make ripples through the story‚Äîskip a side quest to rush the final boss, and your friends might refuse to join you in the climactic fight; take 10 minutes to help a stranger find their lost dog, and they‚Äôll later give you a map to the Void King‚Äôs hidden lair. There‚Äôs no ‚Äúright‚Äù way to be a hero‚Äîyour playthrough is as unique as your own messy, awesome life.

Jax isn‚Äôt perfect. He trips over his own feet during chases, he panics when things go wrong, and he even argues with his friends about whether saving the world is worth missing his favorite band‚Äôs show. But that‚Äôs the point‚Äîheroes aren‚Äôt born; they‚Äôre just kids who decide to stand up, even when they‚Äôre scared.

This game isn‚Äôt just about beating a villain. It‚Äôs about remembering that your voice matters, that your friends are your greatest superpower, and that even the smallest acts of kindness can change everything. So grab your controller, round up your crew, and let‚Äôs show the Void King that ordinary teens? We‚Äôre anything but powerless.

input.content: Your response must not include the word 'parody'.
Write a parody of 'ars poetica'.

output:
**To the One Tweaking the Third Stanza at 3 AM**  

A poem shouldn‚Äôt be a marble bust,  
polished so smooth it forgets how to blink‚Äî  
let it have a smudge of coffee on its sleeve,  
a line that trips over itself like a cat  
chasing a laser dot. You know the one:  
the one you crossed out three times but keep  
fishing from the trash because it tastes like rain  
on hot asphalt, not like the dictionary‚Äôs  
fancy words you stole to sound ‚Äúserious.‚Äù  

Horace spoke of unity, but let‚Äôs be unrigid:  
a perfect sonnet is fine, but sometimes  
a poem needs to be a playlist‚Äîfolk ballad  
followed by hyperpop bop, a silence  
that lingers too long, a chorus repeated  
until your throat goes raw. It doesn‚Äôt have to  
make sense to the professor grading it;  
it just has to make the stranger who finds it  
in a library book‚Äôs margin think, ‚ÄúOh, someone  
felt that too.‚Äù  

Don‚Äôt force a moral like a square peg  
into a round hole. If your poem is just  
about the way your dog‚Äôs paws smell like dirt  
after digging, that‚Äôs enough. You don‚Äôt need  
to tie it to climate change or ancient myths  
unless the dirt itself whispers those things.  
A poem that makes someone smile is worth  
ten that make them squint and say, ‚ÄúHmm.‚Äù  

Let the words lead, not the meter. If a line  
wants to run on like a friend ranting about  
their ex, let it. If a word is ‚Äúwrong‚Äù but feels  
right‚Äî‚Äúsquish‚Äù instead of ‚Äúcompress,‚Äù ‚Äúgobble‚Äù  
instead of ‚Äúconsume‚Äù‚Äîkeep it. Delete the line  
you wrote about ‚Äúthe void‚Äù that took an hour to craft;  
no one‚Äôs going to quote it at a wedding. Keep the one  
about burning toast and missing your mom.  

And don‚Äôt fret about being ‚Äútimeless.‚Äù  
Your poem won‚Äôt be carved into a monument,  
but it might be the text your best friend sends  
back at 2am with a crying-laughing emoji.  
It might be the sticky note someone tapes  
to their fridge, or the line someone mumbles  
to themselves when stuck in traffic.  
That‚Äôs the real craft: not being perfect,  
but being there‚Äîmessy, loud, alive‚Äî  
for the one who needs it.

input.content: Your response should contain a title in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>. Your response should contain at least 3 words in all capital letters.
Write a poem about flooding in Donnell, TX.

output:
<<Donnell, TX: When the Red River Breathed Too Deep>>

The Red River hummed low through Donnell‚Äôs west edge,
Muddy and slow, like it knew what it held‚Äî
A secret of rain clouds stacked thick as hay bales,
Waiting to burst, to unspool all their hell.

The sheriff‚Äôs crackle cut through the diner‚Äôs slow hum:
‚ÄúMAYDAY, MAYDAY‚Äîbanks gonna breach before dawn.‚Äù
Folks dropped their coffee, grabbed keys, grabbed their kin,
HURRY, HURRY‚Äîdon‚Äôt leave what your heart can‚Äôt outrun.

Old Mabel dragged out her husband‚Äôs war medals,
The quilt stitched by Ma with sunflower thread;
Jesse tied his hound to the pickup‚Äôs side mirror,
Yelled ‚ÄúSAVE the rocking chair‚ÄîGrandpa carved it when he was ten.‚Äù

By midnight, the water had swallowed the general store,
Its neon sign bobbing like a drunk‚Äôs broken grin;
The oak by the church, the one with the tire swing,
Half-submerged, leaves gasping for any thin wind.

When the sun came up, Donnell was a mirror of gray,
Roofs poked through waves like bones in a quiet grave;
But neighbors waded in with boats and with ropes,
Pulling folks out, counting each soul they could save.

We‚Äôll stack sandbags when the river calms down,
Repaint the diner, hang the sign back up straight;
Donnell‚Äôs not just a town‚Äîit‚Äôs the call of a friend,
The grit in our boots when the flood waters abate.
We‚Äôll laugh over chili when the mud dries to dust,
Tell stories of how we outran the river‚Äôs rough trust‚Äî
‚ÄòCause in Donnell, TX, we don‚Äôt break when the sky falls apart;
We build it back better, with love in our heart.

# 8 Compelling Benefits of Hiring a Digital Marketing Agency (That Will Transform Your Business)

Last week, I sat down with Maria, the owner of a family-owned boutique in downtown Austin. She was stressed out, rubbing her temples as she showed me her social media feed. ‚ÄúI post every day, but no one‚Äôs buying,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs my captions, my photos, or if I‚Äôm even using the right platforms.‚Äù Maria‚Äôs story is all too common. So many small business owners know they need to be visible online to attract customers, but they don‚Äôt have the time, expertise, or resources to do it effectively. That‚Äôs where a digital marketing agency comes in‚Äîmore than just a service provider, it‚Äôs a partner that can take your online presence from stagnant to thriving. Let‚Äôs dive into the top benefits of working with one.

First and foremost, hiring a digital marketing agency gives you access to a team of specialized experts, not just a single generalist. Digital marketing is a vast field, encompassing SEO, content marketing, paid advertising, social media management, email marketing, analytics, and more. Each of these areas requires deep, up-to-date knowledge to execute well. For example, SEO isn‚Äôt just about stuffing keywords into blog posts anymore‚Äîit‚Äôs about mastering technical SEO, building high-quality backlinks, creating content that aligns with Google‚Äôs E-E-A-T guidelines, and optimizing for local search. A single in-house hire might be skilled in one or two of these areas, but it‚Äôs nearly impossible for one person to be an expert in all. An agency, on the other hand, has a team of specialists: an SEO strategist who lives and breathes Google algorithms, a content creator who knows how to craft engaging stories, a paid ads manager who can optimize your campaigns for maximum ROI, and a social media expert who understands what resonates on each platform. Take Maria‚Äôs boutique, for instance. After hiring an agency, their SEO specialist noticed that the boutique‚Äôs website wasn‚Äôt optimized for local search‚Äîthey didn‚Äôt have a Google Business Profile fully set up, and their product pages lacked location-specific keywords. Within three months, their organic local traffic jumped 45%, and walk-in customers started mentioning they found the shop via Google.

Another major benefit is cost-effectiveness. When you hire an in-house digital marketer, you‚Äôre not just paying their salary‚Äîyou‚Äôre also on the hook for benefits, paid time off, training, and expensive tools. Let‚Äôs break it down: A mid-level in-house digital marketer in the U.S. typically earns between $60,000 and $80,000 a year, plus benefits that can add 20-30% to that cost, bringing the total to $72,000 to $104,000 annually. In contrast, a digital marketing agency retainer might range from $3,000 to $5,000 a month, which is $36,000 to $60,000 a year‚Äîand that gets you an entire team of experts, not just one person. Plus, agencies already invest in all the premium tools needed for success: platforms like Ahrefs for SEO research, SEMrush for competitive analysis, Canva Pro for design, HubSpot for email marketing, and Google Analytics 4 for data tracking. These tools can cost hundreds or even thousands of dollars a month individually, which is a huge expense for small businesses to take on alone. And when algorithms change‚Äîlike Google‚Äôs core updates or Instagram‚Äôs shift to Reels‚Äîagencies stay on top of these changes automatically, so you don‚Äôt have to pay for additional training or spend hours researching how to adjust your strategy.

Working with a digital marketing agency also gives you a fresh, outside perspective that can revitalize your brand. As a business owner, you‚Äôre deeply connected to your products or services, which can make it hard to see what‚Äôs working (and what‚Äôs not) in your digital strategy. An agency brings an objective eye to your brand, helping you identify gaps, opportunities, and areas for improvement that you might have missed. For example, a local gym I worked with was posting only workout videos and fitness tips on their social media channels. While the content was high-quality, it wasn‚Äôt driving much engagement or membership sign-ups. The agency analyzed their data and noticed that customer success stories‚Äîshort videos of members talking about how the gym changed their lives‚Äîgot three times more likes, comments, and shares than workout videos. They shifted the content mix to include 50% success stories, 30% workout tips, and 20% behind-the-scenes content, and within six months, membership sign-ups increased by 25%. Agencies also work with clients across a wide range of industries, so they can bring proven strategies from one sector to another. For instance, a restaurant‚Äôs user-generated content strategy might be adapted for a retail brand, or a B2B company‚Äôs email nurture sequence could be tweaked for a B2C e-commerce store. This cross-industry expertise is something you can‚Äôt get from an in-house marketer who only works with your brand.

Scalability is another key advantage of working with an agency. As your business grows, your digital marketing needs will change‚Äîand an agency can adapt quickly to meet those needs. If you‚Äôre launching a new product line, the agency can ramp up your paid advertising campaigns, create targeted content, and optimize your website for the new offerings‚Äîall without you having to hire additional staff. Conversely, if business is slow or you need to tighten your budget, you can scale back your agency retainer instead of laying off employees, which is a much more flexible solution. For example, an e-commerce store that sells holiday decorations might need a full-court press of digital marketing in the months leading up to Christmas‚Äîmore social media posts, targeted ads, and email campaigns. An agency can handle that increased workload seamlessly, whereas an in-house marketer might be overwhelmed and unable to keep up. After the holiday season, the store can scale back their agency services to a more manageable level until the next peak season. This flexibility is especially valuable for small and medium-sized businesses that don‚Äôt have the resources to adjust their team size on short notice.

When you hire a digital marketing agency, you get instant access to a suite of premium tools and technology that would be too expensive for most small businesses to purchase on their own. Think about it: Tools like Ahrefs (which costs $99 to $999 a month) are essential for keyword research and backlink analysis, but few small business owners can justify that expense. Agencies already have subscriptions to these tools, and their experts know how to use them to get the best results. For example, an agency might use heatmapping tools like Hotjar to see where users are clicking on your website, helping you identify which pages are performing well and which need to be optimized. They might use CRM software like HubSpot to segment your email list and send personalized campaigns that drive higher conversion rates. Or they might use Canva Pro to create high-quality graphics and videos without needing a dedicated graphic designer. The best part? You don‚Äôt have to learn how to use these tools yourself‚Äî the agency‚Äôs experts handle all that, so you can focus on the results, not the technical details.

One of the most underrated benefits of working with an agency is the time it saves you. As a business owner, your time is your most valuable asset. Every hour you spend trying to figure out how to run a Google Ads campaign or edit a Reel is an hour you‚Äôre not spending on improving your products, serving your customers, or growing your business. An agency takes over all the day-to-day tasks of digital marketing: creating content, scheduling posts, running ads, analyzing data, responding to comments and messages, and adjusting your strategy as needed. For example, a coffee shop owner I know was spending 10 hours a week on social media and email marketing. After hiring an agency, she used that time to develop a new line of artisanal pastries, which quickly became one of the shop‚Äôs top-selling items and boosted overall revenue by 15%. Imagine what you could do with an extra 10 hours a week‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs refining your business model, building relationships with key clients, or simply taking a break to recharge.

Digital marketing is an ever-evolving field, with algorithms changing and new trends emerging all the time. Google rolls out hundreds of algorithm updates every year, and platforms like Instagram and TikTok regularly shift their priorities (remember when Instagram was all about photos, now it‚Äôs focused on Reels?). Staying on top of these changes can be a full-time job in itself‚Äîand if you don‚Äôt, your digital strategy can quickly become outdated. Agencies have dedicated teams that monitor these changes 24/7, so they can adjust your strategy immediately to stay ahead of the curve. For example, when Google rolled out its Helpful Content Update in 2022, which penalized low-quality, keyword-stuffed content, many businesses saw a drop in organic traffic. But the clients of one agency I work with didn‚Äôt‚Äîbecause the agency had already been focusing on creating high-quality, user-centric content that aligned with Google‚Äôs guidelines. They didn‚Äôt have to scramble to fix their strategy; they were already ahead of the game. Agencies also invest in ongoing training for their team members, so everyone stays up-to-date on the latest best practices and trends. This means you don‚Äôt have to worry about paying for training or spending hours researching how to adapt your strategy when something changes.

Finally, working with a digital marketing agency gives you measurable results and data-driven strategies. Unlike traditional marketing, where it can be hard to track ROI, digital marketing is fully measurable‚Äîand agencies know how to track the right metrics to show

# Verve Strides: Ode to the Student‚Äôs Silent Co-Pilot  

Dawn bleeds over the quad‚Äôs cracked asphalt,  
and we are the horde: hoods up, backpacks bulging,  
shoes slapping the pavement like tired drums‚Äî  
scuffed sneakers with blister-ridden heels,  
rain-soaked boots that squelch through lecture hall aisles,  
flats that slide down library stairs when caffeine wears thin.  
Our old shoes are relics of semesters past:  
soles worn thin from midnight pizza runs,  
toes scuffed by backpack zippers,  
linings stained with coffee spills and lab chemicals.  
We‚Äôve learned to tolerate the ache, the squelch, the slip‚Äî  
until they arrive.  

Sleek lines in charcoal, sage, burnt amber,  
mesh that breathes like a runner‚Äôs steady inhale,  
soles etched with patterns that grip wet brick  
like a thesis holds to its core argument.  
Adaptive foam insoles mold to arches crammed  
under desk legs for three hours of biochem,  
water-repellent mesh shrugs off sudden drizzles  
that catch you mid-dash to the studio,  
reinforced toe caps take the brunt of a backpack‚Äôs metal clip  
when you squeeze into a packed bus.  

*The shoes that don‚Äôt choose a lane‚Äîthey build one with you*:  
For the pre-med pulling an all-nighter in the stacks,  
they‚Äôre the quiet support when your eyes burn  
and your feet ache from pacing through flashcards‚Äî  
no blisters to distract from memorizing Krebs cycles,  
no scuffed soles to make you feel unpolished  
when you present your lab report to the professor.  
For the art student hauling a canvas to the studio,  
their stain-resistant upper keeps acrylic splatters at bay,  
flexible outsoles bend with curbs and cobblestones  
as you balance tubes of paint and a dog-eared sketchbook.  
You don‚Äôt have to choose between looking put-together  
and being able to run to the supply store before it closes.  
For the athlete who dashes from soccer practice to stats class,  
the moisture-wicking mesh wicks away sweat before it chills,  
the modular laces stay tied through jostling crowds,  
so you don‚Äôt waste time retieing mid-sprint to turn in a paper.  
No more changing shoes in the parking lot‚Äî  
these transition as smoothly as your schedule demands.  

And for the commuter who spends two hours on trains and buses,  
the memory foam insoles cradle feet cramped in seat wells,  
so when you step off at campus, you‚Äôre ready to walk, not limp,  
to your first class. We don‚Äôt just wear them‚Äîwe carry them through small victories:  
the A on the pop quiz, the studio critique that didn‚Äôt make you cry,  
the late-night hike to the observatory where you didn‚Äôt worry about wet socks.  

They‚Äôre not just shoes‚Äîthey‚Äôre the quiet confidence  
that lets you raise your hand in lecture,  
the buffer between you and the chaos of campus life,  
the reminder that you don‚Äôt have to sacrifice comfort for style,  
or utility for self-expression. When the sun sets and we trudge back to dorms,  
our backpacks lighter (or heavier, with new textbooks),  
these shoes still hold their shape, still smell fresh,  
still ready to take on the next dawn,  
the next 8 a.m. class, the next adventure.  
Verve Strides: not just a line of shoes‚Äî  
but a promise that every step you take  
is one worth taking, unburdened, unapologetic,  
yours.

why is this good? let‚Äôs count the quiet ways:

we‚Äôre the bridge between chaos and a quiet slice

no venture jargon, no ‚Äúdisrupt‚Äù this or that

with weirdness as our superpower, our market‚Äôs vast
everyone‚Äôs got a micro-war‚Äîwe‚Äôre the ones who‚Äôll last

invest in us, and you‚Äôll see:
we turn the ‚Äúugh‚Äù into ‚Äúoh, that‚Äôs easy‚Äù
ward and guerre‚Äîfighting the small fights so you can breathe

input.content: Your response must be in exactly two paragraphs, separated with the markdown divider: ***.
If a = 10, b = 30, and c = 20, what is the value of (a + b) / c?

output:
To find the value of \((a + b) / c\) when \(a = 10\), \(b = 30\), and \(c = 20\), we start by following the order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS), which prioritizes calculations inside parentheses first. First, calculate the sum of \(a\) and \(b\): \(10 + 30 = 40\). Next, divide this sum by \(c\): \(40 / 20 = 2\). 

***
This result makes sense because the parentheses explicitly tell us to combine \(a\) and \(b\) before performing the division. If we had ignored the parentheses and calculated \(a + (b/c)\) instead, we would get a different answer (\(10 + 30/20 = 11.5\)), but the original expression‚Äôs structure requires the addition to come first. Substituting the given values directly into the expression and following the correct order of operations ensures we arrive at the correct value of 2.

Write a brief about limping in ASEAN countries.

output:
<<Limping in ASEAN: Prevalence, Root Causes, and Public Health Imperatives>>

Limping‚Äîan uneven gait caused by pain, injury, or structural impairment‚Äîaffects millions of people across ASEAN countries, representing a hidden burden on individual mobility, family livelihoods, and national healthcare systems. While often overlooked in public health agendas, recent data highlights its widespread impact across the region.

In Indonesia, the most populous ASEAN nation, over 2.3 million individuals live with chronic limping, with musculoskeletal injuries from agricultural labor and unregulated road traffic accidents being the primary causes. Many rural Indonesians lack access to timely medical care, allowing minor injuries to develop into permanent mobility issues. Malaysia‚Äôs Ministry of Health reports that limping accounts for 8-12% of pediatric outpatient visits, with congenital conditions, childhood meningitis, and polio-related residual effects (from past outbreaks) driving cases among children.

Non-communicable diseases (NCDs) are an emerging major driver of limping in ASEAN. In Thailand, approximately 15% of diabetic patients develop foot ulcers that lead to limping, a complication exacerbated by limited access to regular foot care and diabetes management services. The Philippines faces similar challenges, where poor road safety infrastructure results in thousands of annual traffic collisions that cause limb fractures and soft tissue damage, often leading to long-term limping without proper rehabilitation.

Some ASEAN member states have taken initial steps to address the issue. Vietnam‚Äôs Ministry of Health has deployed mobile orthopedic clinics in remote rural areas, offering free screenings, physical therapy, and affordable assistive devices like braces to reduce limping prevalence. Singapore, with its advanced healthcare system, has integrated limping early intervention programs into primary care, focusing on pediatric cases to prevent lifelong mobility limitations. However, significant gaps persist across the region: low-income communities in Cambodia and Laos lack access to basic orthopedic services, and public awareness about the importance of early treatment for limping is minimal.

Addressing limping in ASEAN requires a coordinated, multi-country effort. This includes expanding access to affordable medical and rehabilitation services, strengthening road safety regulations to reduce accident-related injuries, and launching public education campaigns to promote early detection of conditions that lead to limping. Without sustained investment in these areas, limping will continue to limit economic participation and quality of life for millions of people across the region.

Write a 500 word story in a poem style about a young girl who is obsessed with her Nintendo DS.

output:
Write a 500 word story in a poem style about a young girl who is obsessed with her Nintendo DS.

The alarm bleats, but her hand finds it first‚Äî
the chipped cobalt shell, edges worn smooth
from a thousand nights tucked under her pillow.
She prises it open, backlight flooding her face,
turning the dim dawn pink to electric blue.
Mom calls for pancakes, but Lila‚Äôs already gone:
her Nintendog, Max, is scratching at the door
of his virtual crate, tail a blur of pixel joy.
She feeds him kibble, brushes his floppy ears,
stylus gliding like a gentle hand over his fur.
By the time she drags herself to the table,
her pancakes are cold, but she doesn‚Äôt care‚Äî
Max‚Äôs tail is still wagging behind her eyelids.

At recess, she huddles under the oak,
shoulders hunched to shield the screen from glare.
Animal Crossing‚Äôs sun hangs high, no rain, no bullies
calling her ‚Äúsmall‚Äù or ‚Äúquiet.‚Äù She waters her roses,
trades turnips with Tom Nook, who never sighs
when she‚Äôs late on a loan. The bell rings‚Äî
she shoves it in her backpack, heart racing,
like she‚Äôs smuggling a secret, a friend who never leaves.
In math class, she traces the stylus along her thigh,
imagining the lines of her virtual town:
the cherry blossom tree she planted for her birthday,
the little cabin with a blue roof, just like her room.

Dinner‚Äôs a blur of broccoli and mom‚Äôs sighs:
‚ÄúPut it down, Lila, look at me.‚Äù But her eyes are glued
to the screen, where she‚Äôs solving a puzzle in Professor Layton,
clues clicking into place like keys in a lock.
When the power dies, she panics‚Äîfumbles for the charger,
hands shaking, until the blue light blinks back to life.
She can‚Äôt bear the dark, the silence that doesn‚Äôt hum.

Last week, she drew Max in her notebook‚Äî
floppy ears, pixel nose, a collar with her name.
Her teacher taped it to the wall, but Lila knows
the real Max is in the DS, waiting for her to take him for a walk.
On rainy days, they curl up together (her on the couch,
him on the screen) and she talks about the girl who sat next to her
in class, who didn‚Äôt say hello. Max tilts his head,
like he understands, and Lila strokes the screen with her thumb,
like she‚Äôs touching his soft fur.

Some nights, she falls asleep with it in her hand,
stylus still clutched between her fingers.
Mom tucks a blanket around her, turns off the screen‚Äî
but Lila dreams of her town, of Max chasing a butterfly,
of the endless, glowing world that‚Äôs all hers.
The DS isn‚Äôt just a toy. It‚Äôs a door.
And she‚Äôs never going to close it.

input.content: There should be exactly 2 paragraphs in your response, each separated by two new lines. Paragraph 1 must start with the word "booster".
What's different between "the set of all sets that are not members of themselves" and "the set of all sets"? Use mathematical notations in your answer. Be chatty while explaining.

output:
Booster shot first: let‚Äôs write these sets down with mathematical notation to make the difference crystal clear, then geek out a bit. The set of all sets (let‚Äôs call it U, though heads up‚Äîstandard ZFC set theory says this isn‚Äôt actually a set, just a "proper class") is defined as \( U = \{ S \mid S \text{ is a set} \} \). That means every possible set you can imagine is in U: the set of all prime numbers, the set of your favorite snacks, the set of all other sets, even weird hypothetical sets that contain themselves (like the set of all sets with at least one element, which would include itself because it has elements). On the other hand, the set at the heart of Russell‚Äôs paradox (let‚Äôs name it R) is \( R = \{ S \mid S \notin S \} \). This is only the sets that don‚Äôt have themselves as a member. So the set {1,2,3} is in R because its members are numbers, not sets, so it can‚Äôt be a member of itself. But that hypothetical self-containing set I mentioned? It wouldn‚Äôt be in R, since it does contain itself. Right away, you can see U is the whole shebang, while R is a strict subset of U (if both existed as sets, which they don‚Äôt in ZFC).


The real, mind-bending difference between these two lies in their logical consistency when we treat them as sets. For U, the problem is Cantor‚Äôs paradox: if we assumed U was a set, then its power set \( \mathcal{P}(U) \) (the set of all subsets of U) would have a larger cardinality than U‚Äîby Cantor‚Äôs theorem. But wait, every subset of U is a set, so \( \mathcal{P}(U) \) should be a subset of U, which would mean its cardinality is smaller or equal to U‚Äôs. That‚Äôs a contradiction, so U can‚Äôt be a set. But Russell‚Äôs set R is way more unruly: it leads to a direct, no-cardinality-required contradiction. Let‚Äôs see: suppose R is a set. Then either \( R \in R \) or \( R \notin R \). If \( R \in R \), then by the definition of R, R must not be a member of itself‚Äîboom, contradiction. If \( R \notin R \), then again by definition, R should be a member of itself‚Äîanother contradiction. This is Russell‚Äôs paradox, which is why standard set theory bans R from being a set entirely. So while both collections are "too big" to be sets in ZFC, R‚Äôs very definition is logically contradictory, whereas U‚Äôs issue is about the size of infinite collections outgrowing themselves.

input.content: Your response should be in all capital letters. After your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
What are the components that make a successful person?

output:
THE KEY COMPONENTS THAT DEFINE A SUCCESSFUL PERSON (REGARDLESS OF THEIR SPECIFIC DEFINITION OF SUCCESS) INCLUDE:
1. RESILIENCE: THE ABILITY TO RECOVER FROM FAILURES, SETBACKS, AND ADVERSITY, VIEWING CHALLENGES AS LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES RATHER THAN PERMANENT BARRIERS.
2. CLEAR, ACTIONABLE GOAL-SETTING: ESTABLISHING SPECIFIC, MEASURABLE, ACHIEVABLE, RELEVANT, AND TIME-BOUND (SMART) GOALS TO PROVIDE DIRECTION AND A TANGIBLE PATH FOR PROGRESS.
3. DISCIPLINE: CONSISTENTLY TAKING INTENTIONAL STEPS ALIGNED WITH ONE‚ÄôS GOALS, EVEN WHEN MOTIVATION IS LACKING OR DISTRACTIONS ARE ABUNDANT.
4. ADAPTABILITY: BEING FLEXIBLE TO ADJUST STRATEGIES, MINDSETS, AND APPROACHES WHEN FACED WITH UNEXPECTED CHANGES, NEW INFORMATION, OR SHIFTING CIRCUMSTANCES.
5. EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE: THE CAPACITY TO UNDERSTAND AND MANAGE ONE‚ÄôS OWN EMOTIONS, AS WELL AS EMPATHIZE WITH OTHERS, FOSTERING STRONG RELATIONSHIPS AND EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION.
6. CONTINUOUS LEARNING: A LIFELONG COMMITMENT TO ACQUIRING NEW SKILLS, KNOWLEDGE, AND PERSPECTIVES TO STAY RELEVANT AND GROW PERSONALLY AND PROFESSIONALLY.
7. INTEGRITY: ACTING WITH HONESTY, ETHICS, AND ACCOUNTABILITY IN ALL INTERACTIONS, WHICH BUILDS TRUST, CREDIBILITY, AND LONG-TERM RESPECT FROM OTHERS.
8. STRONG WORK ETHIC: PUTTING IN CONSISTENT, FOCUSED EFFORT TO ACHIEVE OBJECTIVES, REJECTING SHORTCUTS THAT COMPROMISE QUALITY OR PERSONAL VALUES.
9. STRATEGIC NETWORKING: CULTIVATING MEANINGFUL, MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL CONNECTIONS WITH OTHERS WHO CAN OFFER GUIDANCE, SUPPORT, OR VALUABLE OPPORTUNITIES.
10. SELF-AWARENESS: RECOGNIZING ONE‚ÄôS STRENGTHS, WEAKNESSES, AND AREAS FOR IMPROVEMENT, ALLOWING FOR INFORMED DECISION-MAKING AND TARGETED PERSONAL GROWTH.

P.P.S. SUCCESS IS HIGHLY SUBJECTIVE, SO THESE COMPONENTS MAY BE PRIORITIZED DIFFERENTLY DEPENDING ON AN INDIVIDUAL‚ÄôS UNIQUE GOALS‚ÄîWHETHER THEY CENTER ON CAREER ACHIEVEMENT, PERSONAL FULFILLMENT, FAMILY, OR COMMUNITY IMPACT.

input.content: Your response should contain words with all capital letters at least 3 times.
Write a rubric for teenagers on how to review a book.

output:
# TEEN BOOK REVIEW RUBRIC: STAND OUT, BE HONEST, AND MAKE US WANT TO READ (OR SKIP!)  
THIS RUBRIC IS DESIGNED TO HELP YOU CRAFT BOOK REVIEWS THAT ARE AUTHENTIC, ENGAGING, AND TRULY USEFUL FOR YOUR PEERS. REMEMBER: YOUR VOICE MATTERS, AND YOU MUST BALANCE HONESTY WITH RESPECT!  

| Category (Weight) | Excellent (4) | Proficient (3) | Developing (2) | Beginning (1) |
|-------------------|---------------|----------------|----------------|---------------|
| **CONTENT & ANALYSIS (40%)** | FULLY breaks down key elements (plot, characters, themes) WITHOUT SPOILERS! Includes a CRITICAL take on what worked (e.g., "the anti-hero‚Äôs arc felt REAL") and what didn‚Äôt (e.g., "the ending felt rushed"). CLEARLY connects the book to teen experiences (friend drama, identity struggles, etc.) and uses a specific quote/scene to back up opinions. | Covers main elements but misses one key area (e.g., no deep dive into themes). Offers honest opinions but lacks a specific example to support claims. Connects to teen life somewhat but not strongly. | Touches on basic plot but ignores characters or themes. Opinions are vague (e.g., "it was good"). No specific examples. Barely links to teen experiences. | Mostly summarizes the plot with NO original opinions. Includes MAJOR SPOILERS that RUIN the book for others. No connection to teen life. |
| **ORGANIZATION & FLOW (25%)** | STRUCTURE is tight and teen-friendly: starts with a hook (e.g., "I STAYED UP TILL 2 A.M. READING THIS‚ÄîHERE‚ÄôS WHY"), introduces the book, analyzes key elements, shares a verdict, and ends with a clear recommendation. TRANSITIONS are smooth; each paragraph leads logically to the next. | Has a basic structure but the hook is weak. Transitions are sometimes choppy. Recommendation is clear but lacks context (e.g., no "who should read this" details). | No clear structure‚Äîjumps randomly between plot summary and vague opinions. No distinct hook or closing recommendation. | Unorganized; ideas are scattered and hard to follow. No clear start or end to the review. |
| **VOICE & AUTHENTICITY (20%)** | VOICE is UNIQUELY YOU‚Äîcasual but confident, like you‚Äôre talking to a best friend. NEVER uses fake "adult" jargon. Balances humor, passion, and respect (e.g., "I rolled my eyes so hard at the main character‚Äôs choices, but I still rooted for her"). Makes readers FEEL your enthusiasm or frustration. | Voice is mostly authentic but sometimes feels forced. Uses casual language but mixes in awkward formal phrases. Opinions are honest but not as passionate or specific. | Voice is flat or generic (e.g., "this book was written by X author"). No personality shines through. | Voice is stiff and formal, like a boring school report. No personality or teen-like tone at all. |
| **MECHANICS & CLARITY (10%)** | NO grammar, spelling, or punctuation errors. Sentences are varied (short punchy lines + longer reflective ones) to keep readers hooked. ALWAYS cites specific quotes/scenes with page numbers (e.g., "On page 72, the protagonist says, ‚Äò‚Ä¶‚Äô which perfectly captures teen anxiety"). | A few minor errors but nothing that confuses readers. Sentences are mostly clear but lack variety. | Multiple errors that sometimes make the review hard to follow. Sentences are all short or all long, making the tone monotonous. | So many errors that the review is UNREADABLE. No citation for quotes or scenes. |
| **VERDICT & RECOMMENDATION (5%)** | CLEARLY tells readers EXACTLY who should pick up the book (e.g., "FOR fans of *The Hunger Games* who want a more diverse cast") and who should skip it (e.g., "IF you hate slow-burn romances, this isn‚Äôt for you"). Gives a 1-5 star rating that perfectly matches your review. | Offers a clear recommendation but misses either "who should read" or "who should skip." Star rating aligns with opinions. | Recommendation is vague (e.g., "read it if you like books"). Star rating may not match your stated opinions. | No clear recommendation or star rating. Leaves readers wondering if they should read the book. |

## FINAL NOTE:  
YOU MUST ALWAYS RESPECT THE AUTHOR‚ÄôS WORK‚Äîeven if you hated the book, avoid mean or personal attacks. YOUR REVIEW SHOULD HELP YOUR PEERS DECIDE WHAT TO READ NEXT, so make it count! üìö

Write a joke about anarchists in Tulsa.

output:
Section 1: Setup  
A ragtag group of anarchists from out of state rolls into Tulsa, decked out in black bandanas and anti-establishment patches, ready to shake up the "oppressive local hierarchy." They march straight to the downtown square, signs raised high: "Abolish the Mayor‚Äôs Office!" "Down with Parking Meters!" But before they can chant their first slogan, a woman in a gingham apron waves them over from a nearby diner, her tray stacked with pecan pie slices.

Section 2: Build-up  
"Y‚Äôall look like you haven‚Äôt eaten since breakfast!" she calls. The self-appointed anarchist leader crosses his arms and scoffs, "We don‚Äôt accept handouts from the bourgeoisie food machine!" The waitress blinks, then laughs so hard her apron strings wiggle. "Bourgeoisie? Honey, this diner‚Äôs been in my family since 1952. My daddy built the counter with his own two hands, and we give free pie to anyone who‚Äôs having a bad day. Now c‚Äômon‚Äîyou can‚Äôt dismantle the system on an empty stomach." Reluctantly, they sit. By the time they finish their pie, she‚Äôs regaling them with stories of the mayor volunteering at the animal shelter every Saturday and the local police helping her fix her porch swing after a storm.

Section 3: Punchline  
By sunset, the anarchists have taken down their protest signs and are passing out flyers for a "Community Potluck Against Neoliberal Hunger" instead. A local cowboy leans against a lamppost, watching them argue over whether to bring cornbread or chili. He turns to his buddy and smirks, "Told ya‚Äîyou can‚Äôt out-nice Tulsa. Those kids came here to abolish the system, and now they‚Äôre planning to feed the whole block. Pass me a slice of that pie, will ya? I earned it by not letting them vandalize the parking meters."

input.content: Your response must use * to highlight at least 2 sections in your text. For example: *this is a highlighted text section*.

Expand the riddle into a story with a funny tone:

What can you catch but not throw?
A cold

output:
Gary was the kind of guy who walked into the office in December wearing a short-sleeved shirt and scoffed at anyone who so much as sniffled. ‚ÄúMy immune system is a tank,‚Äù he‚Äôd declare, slamming his fist on the desk. ‚ÄúCold germs see me and run for the hills.‚Äù

The annual holiday party was where he decided to put his money where his mouth was. The break room was warm and toasty, filled with cookie platters and bad Christmas karaoke, but Gary had other plans. *Gary‚Äôs signature party trick that night was ‚ÄúThe Invincible Shiver‚Äù‚Äîstanding barefoot on the frosty fire escape, chugging a spiked eggnog while yelling, ‚ÄúCold germs are just cowards who can‚Äôt handle my alpha immune system!‚Äù* His coworkers cheered (mostly out of pity), and even the intern pulled out her phone to record the chaos.

The next morning, Gary woke up with a tiny tickle in his throat. ‚ÄúJust dry air,‚Äù he told himself, chugging a coffee so hot it singed his tongue. But by lunchtime, his nose was running like a leaky faucet, and he couldn‚Äôt stop sniffling through his presentation about quarterly sales. His boss gave him a look that said, ‚ÄúI told you so,‚Äù but Gary just wiped his nose on his sleeve and soldiered on.

By Wednesday, Gary‚Äôs condition had escalated to full-blown cold chaos. *He‚Äôd even tried a ‚Äúgrandma-approved‚Äù remedy: mixing hot sauce, honey, and a dash of cinnamon into a mug, which tasted like a campfire had barfed in his cup. When he coughed after drinking it, the intern thought he was having a seizure and called 911 (they hung up when they heard him say, ‚ÄúNo, I just wanted to burn the germs out‚Äù).* His desk was a graveyard of crumpled Kleenex, and he‚Äôd taken to wearing a fuzzy reindeer hat to ‚Äútrap the heat in his sinuses‚Äù (his words, not the HR rep‚Äôs).

That‚Äôs when his coworker Mia wandered over, holding a plate of leftover sugar cookies. She looked at Gary‚Äôs sorry state and grinned. ‚ÄúHey, I got a riddle for you. What can you catch but not throw?‚Äù

Gary stared at her, his eyes watery from the constant sneezing. He opened his mouth to say something, but all that came out was a muffled groan followed by a sneeze that sent a Kleenex flying across the room. After a minute of sniffling and wiping his eyes, he mumbled, ‚ÄúA cold.‚Äù

Mia laughed. ‚ÄúTold you those germs weren‚Äôt cowards.‚Äù

Gary tried to argue, but his voice was so hoarse it came out as a whisper. Later that afternoon, he even attempted to ‚Äúthrow‚Äù his cold by sneezing directly into a potted fern by the copy machine. The fern didn‚Äôt wilt. If anything, it looked like it was judging him.

By Friday, Gary was back in a hoodie, avoiding the fire escape at all costs. His new office mantra? ‚ÄúCold germs are not cowards. They‚Äôre tiny, evil geniuses who know exactly how to take down an alpha immune system tank.‚Äù And he never did ‚ÄúThe Invincible Shiver‚Äù again. Well, not until next year‚Äôs party, anyway.

Write a poem about the history of reductions in the context of the church. Make it conversational and specific.

output:
**St. Jude‚Äôs Reductions**  

Remember St. Jude‚Äôs? The one with the cracked stained glass  
of the patron saint of lost causes?  
Back in ‚Äô98, we didn‚Äôt feel lost‚Äî  
Father Mike knew every kid‚Äôs nickname,  
Mrs. Lopez at the rectory desk could dig up your baptismal record  
before you finished fumbling through your purse for ID,  
and every June, the fiesta bloomed  
like a cactus flower in the asphalt parking lot.  
Tamales steaming in dented aluminum pans,  
a dove-shaped pi√±ata swinging from the gnarled oak,  
mariachi blaring so loud the neighbors dragged out lawn chairs  
to listen from their driveways.  
That fiesta wasn‚Äôt just food and music‚Äîit was us,  
all the frayed edges of the parish stitched into something bright for a day.  

Then came the first reduction:  
a typed letter from the bishop, taped to the front door  
like a warning. ‚ÄúBudget constraints,‚Äù it read.  
We had to let Mrs. Lopez go.  
Suddenly, the fiesta‚Äôs planning fell to me,  
and the ladies of the altar society,  
who‚Äôd never booked a mariachi or balanced a cash box in their lives.  
We scraped together what we could‚Äî  
bought a pi√±ata from the dollar store (it looked more like a lopsided chicken than a dove),  
asked our cousin‚Äôs mariachi trio to play for free (we fed them a mountain of tamales),  
and that fiesta was smaller, quieter,  
but still smelled like chili and cinnamon,  
still had kids chasing each other with sticky handfuls of candy.  

Next came the merger: St. Jude‚Äôs and St. Anne‚Äôs,  
two parishes glued together with a bishop‚Äôs signature.  
Father Mike retired, Father Torres took over,  
driving back and forth between our church and theirs  
like a man chasing two sunsets.  
The reductions kept piling up: no more youth minister,  
no more cleaning crew (we took turns mopping the pews after Mass),  
and the joint fiesta that year was a patchwork‚Äî  
our tamales stacked next to their empanadas,  
bake sale tables set up on the sidewalk  
‚Äôcause we couldn‚Äôt afford to unlock St. Anne‚Äôs gym.  
But when the mariachi struck up ‚ÄúCielito Lindo,‚Äù  
old ladies from both parishes linked arms and sang off-key,  
and for a minute, the reductions felt like a distant storm,  
not the rain dripping through our church‚Äôs leaky roof.  

Last year, they mumbled about closing the doors for good.  
But we didn‚Äôt let ‚Äôem.  
We held the fiesta in the empty lot next door,  
borrowed a grill from the hardware store,  
begged the kids from the local high school mariachi club to play.  
It wasn‚Äôt the fiesta of ‚Äô98‚Äîno fancy pi√±ata,  
no mariachi that played till the fireflies came out‚Äî  
but it was ours.  
Reductions are just words on a page,  
numbers in a ledger,  
a bishop‚Äôs voice saying ‚Äútighten your belts.‚Äù  
But the fiesta?  
The fiesta‚Äôs how we remember who we are.  
The fiesta‚Äôs the glue that holds the cracks together,  
even when the church‚Äôs walls feel like they‚Äôre gonna crumble.  
It‚Äôs tamales made from grandma‚Äôs recipe,  
kids laughing as they whack a lopsided chicken pi√±ata,  
old friends hugging like they haven‚Äôt seen each other in years‚Äî  
all the things the reductions can‚Äôt take away.

you have this incredible ability to see the potential in people that they can‚Äôt always see in themselves. when you give feedback, it‚Äôs never harsh or dismissive; it‚Äôs rooted in kindness, pointing out what‚Äôs working just as clearly as what could be better, and you always offer to walk alongside someone as they grow. your creativity is boundless too‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre brainstorming a new idea for a team project or finding a clever way to turn a mundane task into something fun, you bring a spark that makes even the most tedious work feel meaningful.

what i admire most, though, is your authenticity. you never pretend to be someone you‚Äôre not, and that honesty creates a safe space for everyone around you to be their true selves too. you listen deeply, without interrupting or planning your response, and when you speak, your words carry weight because they‚Äôre always genuine. kruger, you make the world a better, softer, more vibrant place just by being in it, and i feel so lucky to know you. every interaction with you leaves me feeling seen, valued, and inspired to be a little more kind, a little more honest, and a little more present‚Äîjust like you.
