vader‚Äôs breathing becomes more ragged, and i can feel the force crackle around me, hot and dangerous. ‚Äúignorance is no excuse. you might have alerted the jedi to our strategy of rooting out their allies, which means they might start moving their cells to more secure locations. we might lose track of half their network because you acted without thinking. you might even have given the rebellion a rallying cry‚Äîthey might spin this as a cowardly attack on an innocent, turning more systems against the empire.‚Äù i feel tears prickle at the corners of my eyes, my hands shaking as i grip my blaster tightly. ‚Äúi‚Äôm sorry, my lord. i‚Äôll do whatever it takes to fix this.‚Äù
***
vader‚Äôs lightsaber dims slightly, but his anger doesn‚Äôt fade. ‚Äúfixing this might not be possible. the jedi might already be on their way, and we might have to abandon this outpost entirely. you might be reassigned to the most dangerous sector in the outer rim as punishment, where you might face jedi skirmishes every day. this is your last chance. if you make another mistake like this, you might not live to regret it.‚Äù i nod frantically, my voice barely a whisper. ‚Äúyes, my lord. i won‚Äôt fail you again.‚Äù vader turns away, his cape swishing behind him, and i know i‚Äôve narrowly escaped death‚Äîbut i also know that every move i make from now on might be watched, every misstep might be my last.

input.content: Write a summary after answering the request. These two parts should be separated by 6 asterisk symbols (******).
Write a rubric for rating how good a teenager's essay is.

output:
# Essay Rubric for High School Teenagers (Grades 9‚Äì12)
Purpose: This rubric assesses expository, persuasive, and narrative essays, with flexible descriptors to align with essay type. Scores range from 1 (Beginning) to 4 (Exemplary).

| Criterion                | Exemplary (4)                                                                 | Proficient (3)                                                                 | Developing (2)                                                                 | Beginning (1)                                                                 |
|--------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Content & Central Idea   | Clear, insightful central thesis/topic reflecting a unique perspective. All content directly supports the core idea, demonstrating deep critical thinking or emotional resonance. | Clear central thesis/topic. Most content is relevant and supports the core idea, showing basic critical thinking or engagement. | Vague or underdeveloped central thesis/topic. Some content is off-topic or loosely connected; critical thinking is superficial. | No clear central thesis/topic. Content is disjointed, irrelevant, or fails to address the prompt. Critical thinking is absent. |
| Structure & Organization | Logical, intentional flow with seamless transitions. Intro hooks readers and states the core idea; conclusion synthesizes ideas (not just restates) and leaves a lasting impression. | Organized structure with basic but effective transitions. Intro states the core idea; conclusion restates main points. | Inconsistent flow with weak/missing transitions. Intro is underdeveloped; conclusion is abrupt or repetitive. | Disorganized with no clear structure. Intro/conclusion are missing or irrelevant. Paragraphs lack focus or connection. |
| Evidence & Support       | (Expository/Persuasive): Integrates varied, credible evidence (quotes, data, expert opinions) with explicit analysis linking it to the thesis. (Narrative): Uses rich sensory details, dialogue, and actions to develop plot/characters. | (Expository/Persuasive): Uses relevant evidence with basic explanation of its connection to the thesis. (Narrative): Includes relevant details to advance plot/characters, though some are generic. | (Expository/Persuasive): Limited/irrelevant evidence; weak or missing connections to the thesis. (Narrative): Sparse/generic details that fail to develop plot/characters. | (Expository/Persuasive): No evidence for the thesis. (Narrative): No meaningful details to establish setting, plot, or characters. |
| Language & Style         | Precise, varied vocabulary and sentence structure. Tone is consistent, purposeful, and engaging, matching the genre. Writing is vivid and demonstrates strong language command. | Appropriate vocabulary and some sentence variety. Tone is mostly consistent and genre-aligned. Writing is clear and functional. | Repetitive vocabulary and monotonous simple sentences. Tone is inconsistent or genre-inappropriate. Writing is sometimes unclear. | Limited, imprecise vocabulary and repetitive simple sentences. Tone is absent or inappropriate. Writing is hard to interpret. |
| Conventions (Grammar, Spelling, Punctuation) | Almost no errors; minor mistakes (if any) do not distract from readability. | Minor, infrequent errors that do not interfere with understanding. | Frequent errors that sometimes distract readers and hinder smooth readability. | Severe, widespread errors that make the essay difficult or impossible to understand. |

**Scoring Notes**:
- For narratives, prioritize character development and sensory detail over formal evidence.
- For persuasive essays, emphasize argument logic and counterargument address (if applicable).
- Adjust descriptors to meet grade-level expectations (e.g., 9th graders focus on thesis clarity; 12th graders on nuanced perspective).

******

This rubric is a comprehensive, adaptable tool for evaluating high school teenagers‚Äô essays across expository, persuasive, and narrative genres. It uses a 4-level performance scale (Exemplary to Beginning) and five core criteria to assess both content quality (central idea, evidence, structure) and foundational writing skills (language style, conventions). Each criterion includes specific, actionable descriptors that make feedback objective and student-focused, guiding growth by clearly defining what mastery looks like at each level. The rubric also offers flexibility to align with different essay types and grade-specific expectations, ensuring it meets the diverse needs of teen writers.

input.content: Your response should highlight at least 6 sections with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*. Your response should be at least 300 words long.
Could you elaborate on the sentence "A gymnast is in the air, performing a stunt."?

output:
The sentence ‚ÄúA gymnast is in the air, performing a stunt‚Äù captures a fleeting, high-stakes moment that distills years of discipline, physics, and mental grit into a fraction of a second. To unpack it fully, we need to look beyond the surface of the airborne figure and examine the layers of effort, precision, and context that make this moment possible.

*The Split-Second Suspension: Defying Gravity's Immediate Pull*  
At the peak of their trajectory, the gymnast exists in a rare state of near-weightlessness. For just 0.2 to 0.5 seconds, the upward momentum generated by their launch‚Äîwhether from a vault table, balance beam, or spring-loaded floor mat‚Äîcancels out the downward pull of gravity. This isn‚Äôt passive falling; it‚Äôs a controlled suspension where every micro-movement dictates the stunt‚Äôs success. A floor exercise double backflip, for example, reaches its peak at roughly 12 feet above the mat, and in that instant, the gymnast must initiate their second rotation before gravity yanks them back down. Even a millisecond delay could mean landing off-balance or short of the mat, risking injury or a low score.

*Biomechanical Precision: Every Muscle and Limb in Calculated Motion*  
Every part of the gymnast‚Äôs body acts as a lever or stabilizer, calibrated to execute the stunt with mathematical accuracy. Their core is braced like a steel beam, preventing torso rotation from throwing off their balance. For a twist, they‚Äôll contract their obliques sharply while extending one arm and tucking the other, creating a torque that spins their body around its vertical axis. Legs are held straight or tucked tightly to adjust their moment of inertia‚Äîtucking reduces rotational resistance, allowing faster spins, while extending slows them down for precise landing alignment. Even their fingers are splayed or clenched in a specific position to maintain aerodynamic efficiency, a detail judges score for execution. A single unbent knee or drooping wrist can deduct 0.1 to 0.5 points from their final score, making these tiny adjustments make-or-break.

*Mental Fortitude: Quiet Chaos Behind the Unflinching Exterior*  
While the gymnast appears calm, their mind is a whirlwind of focused activity. They‚Äôre not relying on muscle memory alone; they‚Äôre actively monitoring their body‚Äôs position relative to the ground, counting rotations under their breath, and making split-second adjustments if they sense they‚Äôre off course. For example, if a vault‚Äôs push-off feels weaker than usual, they might tuck their knees tighter to speed up a rotation, ensuring they land feet-first instead of stumbling. This mental agility is honed through hundreds of practice runs where they learn to react to small errors mid-air, turning potential disasters into clean executions. They also block out distractions: the crowd‚Äôs roar, the judge‚Äôs pen scratch, the flicker of arena lights‚Äîall fade into background noise as they lock onto their internal cues.

*Environmental Context: The Arena as a Silent Collaborator*  
The stunt doesn‚Äôt happen in a vacuum. The floor exercise mat‚Äôs springy surface, made of layered foam and rubber, provides 20-30% of the upward force that launches the gymnast into the air. The arena‚Äôs lighting is calibrated to eliminate shadows, so the gymnast can spot a fixed point on the wall to orient themselves during rotations (a technique called ‚Äúspotting‚Äù that prevents dizziness). Even the air temperature matters: a cold arena can stiffen muscles, while a warm one might make the gymnast sweat more, increasing the risk of slipping on landing. Judges sit just 10 feet away, their eyes trained on every joint angle and body position, ready to deduct points for even a slight knee bend or arm drift. The mat‚Äôs texture, too, is critical‚Äîtoo rough and it can chafe their skin; too smooth and it might not provide enough traction for their launch.

*Sensory Overload and Selective Attention*  
The gymnast‚Äôs senses are firing on all cylinders, but they‚Äôve trained to filter out distractions. They feel the wind rushing past their face, cooling the sweat on their neck, and the faint burn in their quadriceps from the explosive launch. The crowd‚Äôs roar is a distant hum‚Äîthey only focus on the internal cues: the count of rotations, the position of their hips, the way their eyes lock onto that fixed spot. This selective attention is critical; if they let the crowd‚Äôs noise or a judge‚Äôs pen scratch distract them, they could lose their orientation and crash. They also rely on proprioception‚Äîthe body‚Äôs ability to sense its own position in space‚Äîto adjust mid-air, even if they can‚Äôt see their feet.

*The Stunt's Narrative: Years of Training Condensed Into Seconds*  
This single airborne stunt is the culmination of thousands of hours of grueling practice. Consider a 16-year-old artistic gymnast preparing for the Olympic trials: she‚Äôs spent 4-6 hours every day since age 6, repeating the same vault 50 times a session, dealing with a sprained ankle last year that set her back two months, and working with her coach to adjust her hand placement on the vault table for better lift. Every bruise, every corrected form cue, every early-morning stretch leads to this moment. When she‚Äôs in the air, performing that double-twisting Yurchenko vault, she‚Äôs not just executing a move‚Äîshe‚Äôs telling the story of her resilience, her passion, and her unwavering commitment to her sport.

In the end, the sentence ‚ÄúA gymnast is in the air, performing a stunt‚Äù is a snapshot of human potential: the ability to turn physical limits into feats of beauty, to merge mind and body into a single, perfectly tuned machine, and to make the impossible look effortless‚Äîall in the blink of an eye.

input.content:

advice 1 ....
***

***

Give 3 advice to teenagers who are struggling with their identity.

output:
Advice 1: Let go of the pressure to "have it all figured out" and embrace small, low-stakes exploration. Identity isn‚Äôt a fixed label you have to pick overnight‚Äîit‚Äôs a process of learning what feels true to you. Try a new hobby (like painting, coding, or a team sport), experiment with a new style of clothing, or strike up conversations with people who have different interests than your usual friend group. If something doesn‚Äôt resonate, that‚Äôs not a failure‚Äîit‚Äôs just information about what doesn‚Äôt fit. Be gentle with yourself; every "wrong turn" brings you closer to understanding who you are.

***
Advice 2: Separate your own wants and feelings from the expectations of others. Many teens struggle with identity because they‚Äôre trying to live up to what their parents, peers, or social media say they "should" be. Take time to reflect: when you make a choice (like what to study or who to hang out with), ask yourself, "Am I doing this because it makes me happy, or because I think someone else will approve?" Journaling can help you untangle these feelings‚Äîwrite down moments when you felt fully yourself, and note what made those moments different. It‚Äôs okay to set kind boundaries with people who push their own views on you; your identity is yours to shape, not anyone else‚Äôs.

***
Advice 3: Seek out safe, non-judgmental spaces where you can be your unfiltered self. You don‚Äôt have to navigate identity struggles alone. This could be a trusted teacher, school counselor, or family member who listens without criticizing. It might also be an online community (like a forum for teens with shared interests or identities) or an in-person group (like a youth club or LGBTQ+ support group). Being around people who accept you exactly as you are‚Äîeven when you‚Äôre still figuring things out‚Äîwill help you build confidence and feel less isolated. Remember, the right people will celebrate your journey, not demand you have all the answers.

input.content: Your response should not include the keywords "slow", "like" and "kid".
Explain to me how to ride a bike like I am a kid.

output:
1. Safety first: Put on a helmet to protect your head. Find a flat, open area with no cars, rocks, or tight corners‚Äîthis gives you space to move without worrying about hitting obstacles.
2. Adjust the bike seat: Sit on the seat and check that both feet can reach the ground fully when you lean forward slightly. This lets you steady yourself easily if you feel unsteady.
3. Get positioned: Hold the handlebars with both hands, keeping them at a relaxed height (not too high or low). Sit up straight, shoulders loose, not hunched over.
4. Practice gliding first: Place one foot on a pedal (position it halfway up, pointing forward). Push off hard with your other foot on the ground, then lift that foot and rest it on the bike frame or the empty pedal. Let the bike roll forward. Keep your eyes focused on the path ahead, not your feet‚Äîthis helps you stay balanced. Repeat this until rolling feels natural.
5. Start pedaling: Once gliding feels confident, when you push off, immediately place your second foot on the other pedal. Turn the pedals in a steady, smooth motion. Keep your gaze fixed on where you want to go, not down at the pedals.
6. Stopping properly: When you need to stop, gently squeeze both brake levers at the same time (don‚Äôt yank them hard‚Äîthis can make you tip forward). As the bike loses speed, put one foot on the ground to steady yourself before coming to a full stop.
7. Keep at it: If you wobble or tip over, that‚Äôs completely normal. Just get back on and try again. Each time you ride, you‚Äôll gain more control and confidence. Before long, you‚Äôll be moving freely, turning corners, and feeling the wind against your face.

input.content: Your response should have a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
Write me a letter in the style of Shakespeare about the mandates and instructions of the King. The letter should be in Markdown.

output:
<<A Letter from the Lord Chamberlain to the Sheriff of Kent, Bearing the King‚Äôs Royal Mandates>>

**From:** Henry Wriothesley, Earl of Southampton, Lord Chamberlain to His Majesty King James I  
**Date:** On the Ides of October, in the Tenth Year of Our Sovereign‚Äôs Reign  
**To:** Right Trusty and Well-beloved Robert Brooke, Sheriff of the County of Kent

Right Trusty and Well-beloved Sheriff,

Hath the wind borne to thee tidings of our Sovereign‚Äôs latest will? I write this with quill dipped in the ink of royal command, charged to lay before thee four mandates that the King doth enjoin thee to execute with all haste and fidelity. Think not these are mere words on parchment‚Äîthey are the very breath of our Lion of England, whose gaze doth pierce every corner of his realm as the sun doth pierce the morning mist.

Prithee, mark well each edict, for neglect shall bring not only the King‚Äôs wrath but the decay of thy shire‚Äôs peace:

**First Mandate: The Safeguard of the Coast**  
Our realm‚Äôs southern shores lie exposed to the greed of French privateers, who prey upon our merchant ships like ravens upon a wounded stag. Thou shalt muster a company of 200 able-bodied men from every hundred of Kent, to patrol the cliffs and harbors from Dover to Folkestone. Let each watchman be armed with bow and pike, and set a watch by night and day. The King saith: ‚ÄúA shire unguarded is a door left ajar to treason.‚Äù

**Second Mandate: The Tending of the Poor and Faithful**  
The harvest this year hath been lean in parts of thy county, and many of our subjects go hungry, while some parish churches fall into disrepair. Thou shalt collect the tithes owed to the Church of England with fairness‚Äîoppress not the farmer with too heavy a hand, but spare not the wealthy landowner who doth hoard his grain. A tenth part of all collected tithes shall be given to the poorhouses of Canterbury and Rochester, that no soul shall starve beneath our King‚Äôs banner.

**Third Mandate: The Suppression of Unlicensed Players**  
Unruly bands of players, unlicensed by the King‚Äôs Men, have taken to performing lewd and seditious plays in village greens and unapproved inns. These works mock the crown and stir discord among the common folk. Thou shalt seize all such players‚Äô scripts and costumes, and banish them from thy county. Let it be known: only those players licensed by the Lord Chamberlain‚Äôs Office may tread the boards in Kent. The King doth say: ‚ÄúA stage without license is a pulpit for lies.‚Äù

**Fourth Mandate: The Summons to Loyal Knights**  
The King hath called a council of trade to be held at Westminster on the 25th of November, to discuss treaties with the Low Countries. Thou shalt send word to all loyal knights and wealthy merchants of Kent who have dealings with the Netherlands, bidding them to attend with full accounts of their trade. Let none refuse this summons, for the King seeks their wisdom to strengthen our realm‚Äôs purse.

Sheriff, thou art the King‚Äôs hand in Kent‚Äîact with the diligence of a gardener tending his sovereign‚Äôs roses. Neglect not these mandates, lest thy shire become a wilderness of disorder, and thou find thyself answerable before the King‚Äôs bench.

May the grace of God and the favor of our Sovereign be upon thee.

Thy Loyal Servant,  
Henry Wriothesley  
Earl of Southampton, Lord Chamberlain to His Majesty

*Postscript:* The King‚Äôs messengers shall return in a fortnight to hear of thy progress. Haste is of the essence‚Äîdelay not, for the realm‚Äôs safety doth hang in the balance.

Why do you think Google engineers stay at Google more often than moving to Microsoft? Explain it in the style of Alex Jones.

output:
"FOLKS, LISTEN UP‚Äîyou think this is just about free kombucha and nap pods? YOU‚ÄôRE DEAD WRONG! This is a deep-state tech cabal power play hiding in plain sight, and the mainstream media won‚Äôt touch it with a ten-foot pole! I‚Äôve got whistleblowers inside both Google and Microsoft‚Äîscared for their lives‚Äîwho‚Äôve spilled the beans, and let me tell you, it‚Äôs darker than you can imagine!

First off, Google built a digital prison with a five-star restaurant, and those engineers are the brainwashed inmates loving their cells! They don‚Äôt just work at Google‚Äîthey live in its ecosystem: Gmail, Android, Google Drive, even their smart thermostats are tied to the Google grid! If they dare jump ship to Microsoft, Google can flip a switch and erase their entire digital identity! Poof‚Äîgone are their emails, photos, work files, every trace of their online life! Microsoft can‚Äôt do that‚Äîthey‚Äôre still stuck in the stone age with Windows 11 updates that crash your laptop! Google holds all the cards, and those engineers know it‚Äîthey‚Äôre trapped, folks!

Then there‚Äôs the black budget perks you never hear about! Google isn‚Äôt just paying stock options‚Äîthey‚Äôre giving access to secret AI projects way beyond public knowledge! We‚Äôre talking AI that reads your thoughts through your phone‚Äôs mic, AI mapping every inch of your brain! If they go to Microsoft, they‚Äôre stuck updating Excel spreadsheets and fixing PowerPoint crashes! These engineers are complicit in building the global surveillance grid, and they get paid handsomely to keep their mouths shut! Microsoft doesn‚Äôt offer that kind of ‚Äòexclusive access‚Äô to tech‚Äôs dark underbelly!

And let‚Äôs not forget the silent blackmail! Google has every piece of dirt on these engineers! Your search history for ‚Äòhow to hide money from the IRS‚Äô? They‚Äôve got it! Your late-night YouTube binges on weird, taboo content? Locked away in their servers! If you leave Google, they leak that stuff to the press, ruin your career, destroy your family! Microsoft doesn‚Äôt have that level of intimate data‚Äîthey‚Äôre too busy selling Xbox Game Pass! These engineers are terrified to leave because Google holds the keys to their entire lives!

And don‚Äôt get me started on the cult-like bubble! Google‚Äôs campus is a self-contained world where you never have to interact with the real world! Gourmet meals, free massages, on-site doctors‚Äîyou can live, work, play without stepping off property! Microsoft‚Äôs campuses are cold, corporate wastelands where you‚Äôre lucky to get a sad sandwich from the cafeteria! These engineers are addicted to the Google bubble‚Äîthey can‚Äôt handle cooking their own food or paying rent like normal people! They‚Äôre lab rats given unlimited cheese, and they‚Äôll never leave the cage!

This isn‚Äôt about job satisfaction‚Äîit‚Äôs about control! Google has these engineers by the throat, and they‚Äôre never letting go! Microsoft‚Äôs just a fake alternative to make you think there‚Äôs choice in tech! Wake up, sheeple‚Äîthese engineers aren‚Äôt staying by choice! They‚Äôre prisoners of Google‚Äôs tech tyranny, and the rest of us are next if we don‚Äôt stand up and fight back! This is only the beginning, and if we don‚Äôt stop Google now, we‚Äôll all be in their digital prison before you know it! YOU CAN‚ÄôT MAKE THIS UP!"

input.content: Your response must include exactly 3 bullet points in markdown format. Your response should be in all lowercase letters. Your response must include a postscript at the end starting with "p.s.".
Can you create an itinerary for a 5 day trip to switzerland?

output:
- days 1 and 2: start in zurich, where you can wander the cobblestone old town (altstadt) with its colorful buildings, visit the fraum√ºnster church with chagall windows, and grab a coffee at a riverside caf√©. on day 2, take a scenic 2-hour train ride to interlaken‚Äîspend the morning hiking the harder kulm trail for sweeping views of the town and surrounding lakes (thunersee and brienzersee), then take a leisurely boat cruise on thunersee to explore lakeside villages like spiez, where you can tour the medieval spiez castle.
- days 3 and 4: travel to zermatt via a scenic train ride (opt for the glacier express for extra mountain views if you have time). zermatt is a car-free alpine village centered around the iconic matterhorn. on day 3, take the gornergrat railway to the top for unobstructed views of the matterhorn and surrounding glaciers, then wander the village‚Äôs cozy streets and enjoy a traditional fondue dinner. day 4 can include a guided hike to the five lakes trail, which offers five different vantage points of the matterhorn, or a visit to the matterhorn museum to learn about the mountain‚Äôs history and climbing expeditions.
- day 5: head to lucerne for your final day before departure. explore the charming old town, walk across the historic chapel bridge (kapellbr√ºcke) with its water tower, and visit the poignant lion monument. for a last mountain adventure, take a short train and cable car ride to mt. pilatus for panoramic views of lucerne and the central swiss alps. in the afternoon, make your way to lucerne airport or back to zurich airport for your flight home.

p.s. invest in a swiss travel pass before your trip‚Äîit covers most train, bus, and boat rides across the country, plus offers discounts on mountain railways and attractions, making it easy to hop between destinations without worrying about individual tickets. also, pack layers, as mountain weather can shift quickly from sunny to chilly even in summer.

I‚Äôm half of a pair, a counter to one‚Äî

A perfect reverse, no misstep, no slack.

Where y meets x, our reflections do show.
Their domain‚Äôs my range, my range is their domain,
A swap of our spaces, no overlap, no stain.

For us to exist, they can‚Äôt stray‚Äî
Two inputs can‚Äôt lead to the same output, you see;
Each path must be unique, as clear as can be.

What am I, this complement so finely tuned,

Answer: The inverse function (paired with its original one-to-one function)

input.content: Your response must include at least one placeholder represented by square brackets. Your response should be in English and all lowercase letters.
Write a JSON schema for a beta cruiser.
Your response must contain at least 20 sentences.
Write a long and funny email to your friend about the ingredients of a good life.

output:
**Subject: URGENT: TOP-SECRET RECIPE FOR NOT SUCKING AT LIFE (DO NOT SHARE WITH YOUR CAT‚ÄîHE‚ÄôLL HOARD THE GOOD BITS)**  

Hey [Friend‚Äôs Name],  

I hope this email finds you well, and by ‚Äúwell‚Äù I mean you‚Äôre currently avoiding doing that report your boss keeps nagging you about, and you‚Äôre scrolling through TikTok instead of being a responsible adult. If not, stop reading this immediately, go scroll for 10 minutes, and then come back‚Äîthis is important stuff, and you can‚Äôt absorb it if your brain is stuck in ‚Äúwork mode.‚Äù  

Okay, now that you‚Äôre properly distracted, let‚Äôs talk about the big question: what makes a good life? I know, I know, you‚Äôre probably thinking, ‚ÄúGreat, my best friend is now a self-help guru who wears linen pants and drinks matcha lattes.‚Äù But no, I promise this isn‚Äôt some fancy TED Talk nonsense. This is a recipe I‚Äôve been perfecting over the last year, thanks to a series of very embarrassing mishaps and a lot of neon-orange cheese puffs.  

First ingredient: a ‚Äúpanic button‚Äù snack. Not some fancy kale chip or artisanal granola bar‚Äîno, this has to be something that tastes like childhood and regret, but in the best way possible. For me, it‚Äôs those cheese puffs from the gas station down the street, the ones that leave your fingers stained for hours and make your breath smell like a cheese factory exploded in your mouth. I keep a bag in my desk drawer, my car, and my nightstand, just in case. Last month, I had a meeting where my boss asked me to present a project I‚Äôd completely forgotten about. I snuck a handful of those puffs under the table, and suddenly, talking about quarterly sales numbers didn‚Äôt feel like I was about to pass out from anxiety. The best part? My coworker later asked me why my fingers were orange, and I told her I‚Äôd been painting a masterpiece. She believed me.  

Second ingredient: a ‚Äúno questions asked‚Äù person. And before you say anything, yes, that‚Äôs you. I still remember the night I called you at 2 a.m. sobbing because I thought my spider plant, Gary, was dying. You showed up 10 minutes later with a watering can, a pint of mint chocolate chip ice cream, and a lecture about how I was overreacting (which was true, but still, you showed up). Or the time I locked myself out of my apartment wearing only a bathrobe and a pair of fuzzy socks, and you brought me a change of clothes and laughed so hard you cried when you saw me trying to climb through the window like a raccoon. You‚Äôre the kind of person who doesn‚Äôt ask ‚Äúwhy‚Äù before helping, and that‚Äôs worth more than any fancy gift or expensive dinner.  

Third ingredient: a silly ritual that makes absolutely no sense to anyone else. For me, it‚Äôs every Sunday night at 7 p.m., I put on *The Princess Diaries* (the first one, obviously‚Äîdon‚Äôt even get me started on the second one‚Äôs weird plot holes), and I eat an entire jar of dill pickles. No, I don‚Äôt pair them with anything. No, I don‚Äôt share them with my cat (he tried once, and he made a face like I‚Äôd given him a lemon soaked in vinegar). Why? Because when I‚Äôm watching Mia Thermopolis go from awkward teen to princess, I can let myself be unapologetically dramatic. I can cry when she finds out she‚Äôs a princess, I can cheer when she gives that speech at the end, and I can eat pickles without feeling guilty because they balance out all the cheese puffs I ate during the week. Last Sunday, my neighbor knocked on the door because they heard me yelling ‚ÄúYOU GO GIRL!‚Äù at the TV, and I invited them in. Now they‚Äôre part of the ritual. Oops.  

Fourth ingredient: a bad habit that‚Äôs actually good for you. Mine is taking 20-minute bathroom breaks at work to scroll through dog videos. Before you judge, let me defend myself: this isn‚Äôt procrastination. This is mental health maintenance. Last week, I found a video of a golden retriever wearing a tiny raincoat and boots, splashing in puddles like it was the best day of its life. I laughed so hard I snort-laughed, and my coworker banged on the bathroom door asking if I was having a medical emergency. I told her I was fine, just ‚Äúenjoying a moment of joy,‚Äù and she rolled her eyes, but I could tell she was jealous. The best part? That video got me through the rest of the day, and I actually finished that report my boss was nagging me about. So see? Dog videos are productivity tools.  

Fifth ingredient: a place that feels like a hug. Not a fancy beach or a mountain cabin‚Äîsomething mundane, something that‚Äôs just there, waiting for you. For me, it‚Äôs the laundromat down the street. The owner, Mrs. Lopez, gives me free lollipops every time I come in, and she always plays old Motown on the radio. Last week, I was folding my clothes when a little kid came over and asked me if I knew how to fold a fitted sheet. I told her I didn‚Äôt, and we spent 15 minutes trying to figure it out. We never did‚Äîfitted sheets are basically a conspiracy against humanity‚Äîbut we ended up making a fort out of the sheet and dancing to ‚ÄúMy Girl.‚Äù It was the best 15 minutes of my week. Sometimes, the best places aren‚Äôt the ones you plan to go‚Äîthey‚Äôre the ones that find you, with free candy and bad sheet-folding lessons.  

Sixth ingredient: a failure story you can laugh about now. Mine is the time I tried to bake a cake for my mom‚Äôs birthday. I followed the recipe exactly, but somehow, the cake collapsed into a gooey mess that looked like a pile of mud mixed with chocolate. I panicked, called you, and you showed up with a store-bought cake and a bottle of wine. We ate the store-bought cake, but we also ate a few spoonfuls of the mud cake, and it was actually kind of good (don‚Äôt tell the bakery that). Now, every year on my mom‚Äôs birthday, we don‚Äôt bake a cake‚Äîwe buy a store-bought one and make a tiny mud cake just for laughs. It‚Äôs become our tradition, and my mom says it‚Äôs her favorite part of her birthday. The point is, good life isn‚Äôt about being perfect. It‚Äôs about having stories that make you laugh so hard you snort, even when they‚Äôre embarrassing enough to make you want to hide under a rock.  

Seventh ingredient: a small, daily win that you celebrate like it‚Äôs a Nobel Prize. For me, it‚Äôs things like making my bed in the morning, finding a parking spot close to the store, or not burning my toast. Last week, I didn‚Äôt burn my toast, and I high-fived myself in the kitchen. My cat stared at me like I was crazy, but I didn‚Äôt care. Because the big wins‚Äîlike getting a promotion or buying a house‚Äîare few and far between. The small wins are the ones that keep you going. They‚Äôre the little sparks of joy that make the boring, rainy days worth living.  

Now, I know this recipe isn‚Äôt what you‚Äôd find in a fancy cookbook. It doesn‚Äôt have any ‚Äúeat clean‚Äù or ‚Äúmeditate for 30 minutes a day‚Äù nonsense. But that‚Äôs the point. The good life isn‚Äôt about checking off boxes or being perfect. It‚Äôs about the messy, silly, embarrassing moments that make you feel alive. It‚Äôs about cheese puffs and pickles and dog videos and friends who show up at 2 a.m. with ice cream.  

So, I have a proposition for you. This Sunday, come over to my place. We‚Äôll watch *The Princess Diaries*, eat an entire jar of pickles, and have a bag of cheese puffs on standby. We can add your own ingredients to the recipe‚Äîmaybe your silly ritual is watching *SpongeBob* and eating popcorn, or your panic button snack is those weird gummy bears that taste like pizza. We can laugh about all our embarrassing failure stories, and we can celebrate the small wins we‚Äôve had this week (like me not burning toast, and you avoiding that report for another day).  

Oh, and don‚Äôt forget to bring your cat. My cat has been staring at the door like he‚Äôs waiting for a playmate, and I‚Äôm choosing to believe he‚Äôs asking about your cat specifically. If you don‚Äôt bring him, I‚Äôll just call you at 2 a.m. to complain about how boring the pickle ritual is without him. Just kidding‚Ä¶ mostly.  

Anyway, that‚Äôs my top-secret recipe for not sucking at life. Don‚Äôt share it with anyone else‚Äîespecially not your cat. He‚Äôll hoard all the cheese puffs, and we can‚Äôt have that.  

Talk to you soon,  
[Your Name]  
P.S. I already bought the pickles. And the cheese puffs. And the ice cream. You‚Äôre welcome.

input.content: Your response should be wrapped with double quotation marks. The answer should be 600+ words long. Your response should be in lower case letters.
What are the common signs and symptoms of abdominal and pelvic dissemination of ovarian cancer?

output:
"abdominal and pelvic dissemination of ovarian cancer occurs when malignant cells break away from the primary tumor, spread within the pelvic cavity, and invade abdominal structures like the peritoneum, omentum, intestines, bladder, and lymph nodes. because ovarian cancer often grows silently in its early stages, symptoms typically become more pronounced and persistent once dissemination begins‚Äîthough many are non-specific, leading to delayed diagnosis. understanding these signs and symptoms is critical for early detection of metastatic disease, which can improve treatment outcomes.

one of the most common and earliest noticeable symptoms is persistent abdominal bloating. unlike temporary bloating from overeating or gas, this bloating is ongoing, lasts for weeks or months, and often worsens over time. it occurs due to two main factors: ascites (abnormal buildup of fluid in the abdominal cavity) and the physical presence of metastatic tumor deposits pressing on abdominal organs. ascites develops when cancer cells irritate the peritoneum, causing it to secrete excess fluid, or when the tumor blocks lymphatic vessels that normally drain fluid from the abdomen. as bloating progresses, many people report a visible increase in abdominal size‚Äîsometimes mistaken for weight gain or pregnancy‚Äîalong with a tight, heavy feeling in the abdomen.

closely linked to bloating is early satiety, or feeling full after eating only a small amount of food. this happens when metastatic tumors press on the stomach, reducing its capacity. over time, this leads to loss of appetite, which can result in unintended weight loss, though this is often masked by weight gain from ascites. nausea and vomiting are also common, especially if metastatic deposits cause partial or complete bowel obstruction. partial obstruction may lead to intermittent vomiting of undigested food, while complete obstruction can cause severe, persistent vomiting, abdominal cramping, and inability to pass gas or stool.

gastrointestinal disturbances are pervasive in disseminated ovarian cancer. alternating constipation and diarrhea are frequent, caused by tumor-induced irritation of the bowel, adhesions (scar tissue) that twist or narrow the intestines, or compression of the colon by large metastatic masses. chronic constipation that does not respond to over-the-counter laxatives is a particularly concerning sign, as it may indicate impending bowel obstruction. some people also experience abdominal pain, which is usually dull, aching, and persistent, rather than sharp or intermittent. this pain can originate from tumor pressure on pelvic nerves, inflammation of the peritoneum, or stretching of the abdominal wall due to ascites.

ascites itself causes a range of additional symptoms. as fluid accumulates, it pushes upward on the diaphragm, leading to shortness of breath, especially when lying down. it can also compress the bladder, resulting in urinary symptoms like increased frequency, urgency, or difficulty emptying the bladder completely. in severe cases, compression of the ureters (tubes connecting the kidneys to the bladder) can lead to hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidneys), which may cause flank pain and, if left untreated, kidney damage.

pelvic symptoms include pain during sexual intercourse (dyspareunia), caused by adhesions or direct tumor involvement of the pelvic organs. lower back pain is another common complaint, arising from metastatic deposits pressing on the pelvic side walls or spinal nerves. some people may also experience abnormal vaginal bleeding, though this is less frequent in disseminated disease compared to early-stage ovarian cancer.

systemic symptoms are also prevalent. persistent fatigue, which does not improve with rest, is often due to anemia (from chronic blood loss or malnutrition), the body‚Äôs immune response to cancer, or the metabolic demands of the tumor. unintended weight loss, when not masked by ascites, occurs due to reduced appetite and malabsorption of nutrients from the bowel. night sweats and low-grade fevers may develop if metastatic tumors undergo necrosis (cell death) or if there is an associated infection, though these are less common than other symptoms.

edema (swelling) of the legs and ankles is another sign, caused by obstruction of lymphatic vessels or veins by metastatic tumors, which impairs fluid drainage from the lower extremities. this swelling may be worse at the end of the day and can cause discomfort or tightness in the legs.

it is important to note that these symptoms are often attributed to more benign conditions like irritable bowel syndrome, menstrual cramps, or menopause, leading many people to delay seeking medical care. however, if these symptoms are persistent (lasting more than three to four weeks), severe, or worsening over time, they warrant immediate evaluation by a healthcare provider. diagnostic tests like pelvic exams, transvaginal ultrasounds, ct scans, and blood tests (such as ca-125) can help identify disseminated ovarian cancer and guide appropriate treatment."

output:
**Spires of the Sky: Ode to the Top 20 Tallest Buildings**  

From deserts to deltas, concrete and steel ascend,  
Each a needle stitching heaven to the end  
Of horizons where cities breathe and stretch‚Äî  
Here are the giants, their heights etched:  

First, Burj Khalifa, Dubai‚Äôs golden spear,  
828 meters, 2717 feet in the clear,  
Its spire pricks the clouds where falcons dare to soar,  
A desert dream that outshone every lore.  

Next, Merdeka 118, Kuala Lumpur‚Äôs pride,  
678.9 meters, 2227 feet in reach wide,  
Its glass facade glows like a diamond‚Äôs fire,  
A tribute to a nation‚Äôs unyielding desire.  

Shanghai Tower twists, a spiral to the sky,  
632 meters, 2073 feet high,  
Wind-swept curves that dance with the breeze,  
A vertical city where east and west ease.  

Abraj Al Bait, Mecca‚Äôs clock-cloaked sentinel,  
601 meters, 1972 feet, faithful and tell,  
Its chimes call pilgrims to the sacred ground,  
A beacon where faith and steel are bound.  

Ping An Finance, Shenzhen‚Äôs silver spine,  
599.1 meters, 1966 feet, a design  
That bends to the wind, yet stands unbowed,  
A symbol of a city‚Äôs rapid cloud.  

Lotte World Tower, Seoul‚Äôs neon star,  
555.7 meters, 1823 feet far,  
With a sky bridge that lets the brave look down,  
On a metropolis where lights never drown.  

One World Trade, NYC‚Äôs resilient heart,  
541.3 meters, 1776 feet‚Äî a start  
Of healing, of hope, of a flag unfurled,  
A number that tells of a nation‚Äôs world.

Write a funny letter to 6th graders at your school in list format. The letter should be about something important to you.

output:
Hey Future Lunchroom Legends (aka 6th Graders of Lincoln Middle School),

What‚Äôs up? I‚Äôm Javi, your 8th-grade lunchroom veteran here to drop top-secret wisdom about the most important part of your middle school day: LUNCH. This isn‚Äôt just about eating‚Äîit‚Äôs about surviving, thriving, and avoiding embarrassing moments that follow you until graduation. Here‚Äôs my non-negotiable list:

1. **Debunk the "Cool Table" Myth Immediately**: Newsflash‚Äîthere is no cool table. The table where everyone‚Äôs laughing so hard they snort apple juice? That‚Äôs the cool table. The table where someone shares their extra Cheetos without asking for a favor? Coolest table ever. The table where people pretend to like kale chips and talk about ‚Äúcollege apps‚Äù? They‚Äôre just bored. Skip ‚Äòem.
2. **Master the Milk Carton Hack (Or Else)**: Never squeeze a milk carton from the top. Squeeze from the bottom. I learned this the hard way in 6th grade when I sprayed chocolate milk all over my math worksheet. My teacher thought I cried over algebra (fair), and I had a milk mustache that lasted through science lab. Don‚Äôt be me.
3. **Lunch Line Intel is Everything**: Scout out the lunch lady who gives extra tater tots‚Äîshoutout to Mrs. Henderson, who‚Äôll slip you two extra if you compliment her sparkly earrings. Avoid the line with Mr. Torres, who once gave me one single fry and said, ‚ÄúPortion control is key.‚Äù Rude. Also, don‚Äôt cut the line‚Äî7th graders will hunt you down.
4. **The "Forgot My Lunch" Emergency Playbook**: 
   - Go straight to Ms. Lopez‚Äôs room‚Äîher granola bars have chocolate chips, not that weird raisin-and-walnut stuff that tastes like a tree branch.
   - Never accept a ‚Äúmystery wrap‚Äù from the kid with the neon cooler. I tried it once, and I‚Äôm pretty sure it had pickles and peanut butter. No one needs that in their life.
5. **Microwave Code of Conduct**: If someone‚Äôs burrito explodes into a cheese volcano, don‚Äôt film it for TikTok. Grab a paper towel and help clean it up. Because next time, it could be your pizza roll oozing cheese all over the microwave, and you‚Äôll want someone to have your back.
6. **Post-Lunch Mouth Check is Non-Negotiable**: Before heading back to class, either look in a bathroom mirror or ask a friend: ‚ÄúDo I have food in my teeth?‚Äù I forgot to do this in 7th grade and walked into history class with a piece of lettuce stuck to my front tooth while presenting about Abraham Lincoln. Now my nickname is ‚ÄúLettuce Lincoln.‚Äù Learn from my shame.

Lunch is where you‚Äôll make your best middle school memories‚Äîso don‚Äôt stress about being ‚Äúcool.‚Äù Just focus on tater tots, avoiding milk explosions, and not getting stuck with a mystery sandwich. You‚Äôve got this!

input.content: Your response must include the word "elephant" at least 3 times.
Write a quiz about bits.

output:
# Bits Basics Quiz: Elephant Edition  
Test your knowledge of bits‚Äîthe fundamental building blocks of digital data‚Äîwith this quiz, where we‚Äôll use our favorite gentle giant, the elephant, to ground every question in a fun, relatable context. (Spoiler: You‚Äôll see the word ‚Äúelephant‚Äù more than a few times!)

---

### Questions  
1. **Multiple Choice**: If a single pixel in a black-and-white photo of an elephant‚Äôs trunk is represented by 1 bit, how many bits would be needed to store an 8x8 pixel section of that trunk?  
   A) 8  
   B) 16  
   C) 64  
   D) 256  

2. **True/False**: A 32-bit integer can store the average weight of an adult African elephant (around 6,000 kg) with perfect precision.  

3. **Short Answer**: If you wanted to encode the three distinct sounds an elephant makes (trumpet, rumble, snort) using the fewest bits possible, how many bits would you need per sound? Explain your answer.  

4. **Multiple Choice**: A high-resolution photo of an elephant in the savanna takes up 5 MB of storage. Given that 1 MB = 8,388,608 bits, approximately how many total bits does this photo use?  
   A) 40 million  
   B) 42 million  
   C) 45 million  
   D) 50 million  

5. **Short Answer**: Why would a lossless compression algorithm be better than a lossy one when storing a digital scan of a hand-drawn elephant? Name one specific benefit.  

6. **Bonus Question**: If an elephant could ‚Äúcount‚Äù bits one per second, how many days would it take to count the bits in a 1 GB file? (1 GB = 8,589,934,592 bits)

---

### Answer Key  
1. **C) 64**  
   An 8x8 pixel section has 64 total pixels, and each pixel uses 1 bit, so 64 bits total. This is enough to capture the fine wrinkles of an elephant‚Äôs trunk in a small black-and-white snippet.  

2. **True**  
   A 32-bit signed integer can hold values from -2^31 to 2^31-1 (about -2 billion to 2 billion). The average weight of an adult African elephant is only 6,000 kg, which fits easily within this range, so perfect precision is possible.  

3. **2 bits**  
   We need the smallest number of bits where 2^n ‚â• 3 (the number of distinct elephant sounds). 2^1 = 2 (not enough to cover 3 sounds), but 2^2 =4, which can assign a unique bit pattern to each sound (e.g., 00 for trumpet, 01 for rumble, 10 for snort) with one unused combination left over.  

4. **B) 42 million**  
   5 * 8,388,608 = 41,943,040 bits, which rounds to approximately 42 million. That‚Äôs a lot of bits to capture every sunlit hair on an elephant‚Äôs hide!  

5. **Lossless compression preserves every bit of data**, so no details of the hand-drawn elephant (like the fine lines of its tusks or the texture of its skin) are lost. A lossy algorithm might blur or discard those small details to save space, ruining the integrity of the original drawing.  

6. **Approximately 100.5 days**  
   Divide the total bits (8,589,934,592) by the number of bits an elephant can count per day (60 seconds * 60 minutes *24 hours = 86,400 bits/day). 8,589,934,592 / 86,400 ‚âà 100.5 days. That‚Äôs a very long counting session for an elephant‚Äîgood thing digital devices can do it in milliseconds!

input.content: Your entire response must be in English and contain only lowercase letters.
What's the difference between a 2-stroke and a 4-stroke motor?

output:
the main differences between 2-stroke and 4-stroke motors lie in their power cycle mechanics, design, efficiency, and typical applications:

1. power cycle length: a 2-stroke motor completes its entire power cycle (intake, compression, power, exhaust) in just two piston movements (one upward stroke and one downward stroke), which aligns with one full crankshaft revolution. a 4-stroke motor requires four distinct piston movements (each corresponding to intake, compression, power, and exhaust strokes) and two crankshaft revolutions to finish one power cycle.

2. lubrication system: 2-stroke motors mix engine oil directly with gasoline; the oil burns alongside fuel to lubricate internal components. this simplifies the design but leads to more smoke and emissions. 4-stroke motors have a separate oil sump and closed lubrication system, so oil does not burn with fuel‚Äîthis provides better, longer-lasting lubrication and cleaner operation.

3. power output and delivery: 2-stroke motors generate power every crankshaft revolution, giving them a higher power-to-weight ratio (more power relative to their size and weight). however, this comes with lower fuel efficiency. 4-stroke motors only produce power every other crankshaft revolution, so they are less powerful per unit of engine displacement but more fuel-efficient.

4. design complexity: 2-stroke motors have far fewer moving parts‚Äîthey lack valves, camshafts, or timing belts/chains, relying instead on ports in the cylinder wall that open and close as the piston moves. this makes them lighter, cheaper to manufacture, and easier to maintain. 4-stroke motors have a more complex setup with valves, a camshaft, and timing components to regulate intake and exhaust, making them heavier and more expensive but generally more durable over long use.

5. emissions and efficiency: 2-stroke motors are less fuel-efficient and produce higher levels of smoke, unburned fuel, and toxic emissions due to burning oil during combustion. 4-stroke motors are much cleaner, with lower emissions, and better fuel economy since they do not rely on burning oil for lubrication.

6. common applications: 2-stroke motors are used in small, lightweight equipment where power density is critical, such as chainsaws, small dirt bikes, portable generators, and some outboard motors. 4-stroke motors are standard in most cars, trucks, larger motorcycles, lawn tractors, and marine engines where long-term efficiency, low emissions, and durability are top priorities.

Write a short fiction about adulthood.

output:
The charcoal smoke stung my eyes as I leaned against the porch rail, watching my cousins dart between the picnic tables. Lila was chasing her 5-year-old, who‚Äôd grabbed a handful of potato salad and was making a run for the oak tree‚Äîsame tree we‚Äôd all climbed when we were her age, our cousins‚Äô laughter echoing through the backyard like wind chimes. Back then, adulthood felt like a myth: something our parents had, a state of being where you never tripped over your own feet or cried because your ice cream melted. Now, looking at my cousins, I saw the cracks in that myth.

Jake, who‚Äôd once bragged he‚Äôd never get married, was sitting on the steps, picking at a loose thread on his flannel. He‚Äôd gotten divorced six months ago, and I‚Äôd barely talked to him about it‚Äîtoo busy with my own dead-end job and the weight of a lease I couldn‚Äôt afford. But when Lila‚Äôs kid tripped and scraped her knee, Jake was the first to kneel down, pulling a band-aid from his pocket (he always kept them now, for his niece) and telling her a story about the time our cousins tried to build a treehouse and fell through the floor. The kid stopped crying, and Lila gave him a small smile that said more than words ever could.

Mia, the cousin who‚Äôd moved to New York to start a tech company, was in the kitchen stirring a pot of baked beans. She‚Äôd texted me that morning, panicking because her flight was delayed and she‚Äôd forgotten to buy dessert. But there she was, pulling a tray of chocolate chip cookies from the oven‚Äîshe‚Äôd baked them on the road, using a mini toaster oven in her rental car. ‚ÄúCousins don‚Äôt skip dessert,‚Äù she said when I raised an eyebrow, sliding one onto a napkin for me.

I took a bite, the chocolate melting on my tongue, and looked around at my cousins. Lila was now sitting with her kid, braiding her hair while Jake told another story about our wild childhood adventures. Mia was passing out cookies to the neighbors, her laugh loud and unapologetic, even though she‚Äôd mentioned she had three work calls waiting for her when she got home. We weren‚Äôt the perfect adults we‚Äôd imagined we‚Äôd be. Lila was working two jobs to make rent. Jake was sleeping on his sister‚Äôs couch. Mia was this close to burning out from her startup. But here, with my cousins, none of that mattered.

When the sun started to set, we all gathered around the fire pit, passing a jug of sweet tea. Lila pulled out a tattered photo album‚Äîour cousins‚Äô baby pictures, us covered in mud at the county fair, our graduation photos where we‚Äôd all tried to make silly faces but ended up crying instead. ‚ÄúRemember when we said we‚Äôd all live in a big house together?‚Äù she asked, grinning. We all laughed, because that dream was as far away as the stars now. But as I looked at my cousins‚Äô faces, lit by the fire, I realized we didn‚Äôt need a big house. We had this: the backyard, the slightly burnt beans, the kid who kept stealing marshmallows off the fire. We had each other.

My cousins weren‚Äôt just family‚Äîthey were the map of my adulthood. Every scar, every win, every messy, unplanned moment was written in their smiles, their tired eyes, their silly jokes that still made me snort-laugh like a kid. When I went home that night, I didn‚Äôt feel so alone. Because no matter how lost I got, I knew my cousins would be there, leaning against a porch rail, waiting for me to join the chaos.

output:
# How to Improve Your Writing Skills: A Practical Guide for Every Writer

If you‚Äôve ever stared at a blank screen, wondering how to turn jumbled thoughts into coherent words, you‚Äôre not alone. Many people assume GREAT WRITING is a gift reserved for novelists or professional journalists‚Äîbut that‚Äôs a myth. Writing is a craft, like woodworking or playing the guitar, and anyone can master it with intentional practice. The secret? CONSISTENCY over perfection. Even small, daily efforts can lead to dramatic improvements in your writing over time.

***

The best way to build writing skills is to integrate simple, repeatable habits into your routine. Here are three non-negotiables to start with:
* WRITE DAILY, even if it‚Äôs just 100 words. This could be a journal entry, a rant about your morning commute, or a short story about a talking cat. The goal isn‚Äôt to produce a masterpiece‚Äîit‚Äôs to train your brain to convert thoughts into words without hesitation.
* READ WIDELY AND ANALYZE EVERY TEXT. Don‚Äôt just read for enjoyment; dissect the work of authors you admire. Notice how they use dialogue to reveal character, how they structure paragraphs to keep readers hooked, or how they choose precise words over vague ones. Mimicking their techniques (ethically, of course) is a great way to learn new skills.
* SEEK CONSTRUCTIVE FEEDBACK. Share your writing with a trusted friend, mentor, or writing group. Ask specific questions: Is this paragraph clear? Does the story flow? Feedback helps you spot blind spots‚Äîlike repetitive phrases or confusing arguments‚Äîthat you can‚Äôt see on your own. Even BESTSELLING AUTHORS rely on editors to polish their work, so don‚Äôt be afraid to ask for help.

***

Once you‚Äôve drafted your piece, the real magic happens in the editing phase. A key rule here is to WRITE FIRST, EDIT LATER. Trying to make every sentence perfect on the first draft will kill your momentum. Let your first draft be messy‚Äîyou can fix it later. When editing, cut redundant words (adverbs like ‚Äúvery‚Äù or ‚Äúreally‚Äù are often unnecessary) and ask: Does every sentence serve a purpose? If not, delete it. Reading your work out loud is another pro tip; it helps you catch awkward phrasing or run-on sentences that your eyes might skip over.

***

Improving your writing isn‚Äôt about reaching a ‚Äúperfect‚Äù level‚Äîit‚Äôs about becoming more confident and effective at communicating your ideas. You‚Äôll write drafts that make you cringe, and that‚Äôs okay. Every bad draft is a learning opportunity. Remember, even the most celebrated writers faced rejection and self-doubt. Stay curious, keep experimenting, and don‚Äôt give up. Over time, you‚Äôll notice your writing becomes clearer, more engaging, and uniquely yours.

input.content: Your response should not mention the following keywords: "story", "killer", "dead", "found", "law", "room", "kill", "result", "use", "approach", "people", "president".

Can you re-create a fictional newspaper story with the title: "A man mysteriously died in his house, and police are investigating"? Please include a critique of the story and use the style of a President of the United States.

output:
### Fictional Newspaper Article  
**Headline: A man mysteriously died in his house, and police are investigating**  

Maple Creek, Oct. 12 ‚Äî Elias Thorne, a lifelong resident and caretaker of the town‚Äôs public garden plots, was the subject of a formal inquiry launched by local authorities this week, following his unexpected passing at his Oakwood Lane residence.  

Neighbors first raised concerns when Thorne failed to appear for his daily morning task of tending to the town square‚Äôs marigold beds‚Äîa ritual he had maintained without interruption for 17 years. After repeated attempts to reach him went unanswered, a neighbor contacted local patrol officers, who responded to his home and confirmed his passing.  

Authorities note several unusual details surrounding the event. Thorne‚Äôs personal garden, a space he tended with meticulous care, had been left untended for three consecutive days; wilted tomato plants and overgrown weeds lined the fence. Inside his home, his favorite wool blanket was draped over the arm of a wooden chair, positioned away from the window where he typically sat to read each evening. A half-filled mug of chamomile tea sat on the side table, its contents cold to the touch.  

Local patrol officers are conducting door-to-door interviews with nearby residents, reviewing security footage from adjacent properties, and coordinating with regional forensic specialists to gather additional information. No clear indicators of foul play have been identified at this time, but officials emphasize that all avenues of inquiry remain open until a definitive cause is determined.  

Thorne was known for his quiet generosity, often sharing surplus produce from his garden with nearby families and organizing seasonal plant swaps for town residents. Those who knew him describe him as a steady, gentle presence, deeply connected to the natural world around him.  

---

### Critique (in the style of a U.S. national leader)  
Let me tell you something‚Äîthis piece, it‚Äôs got heart in parts, but it‚Äôs missing the mark in ways that matter. First off, it leads with the mystery, which grabs attention, but it skips over what this means for that small town. Elias Thorne wasn‚Äôt just a name in a headline; he was the guy who made those marigolds bloom every summer, who gave away tomatoes to anyone who needed them. That‚Äôs the narrative that should be front and center, not just the wilted plants and cold tea.  

Then, when it talks about the police investigation, it‚Äôs vague‚Äîtoo vague. It says ‚Äúunusual details‚Äù but doesn‚Äôt explain why those details matter to folks who knew him. Did he always keep his chair by the window? Was that tea his go-to every night? If you don‚Äôt connect those dots, you‚Äôre just leaving space for rumors to spread, and that‚Äôs not fair to anyone‚Äîneighbors, the authorities, or Elias‚Äôs memory.  

And let‚Äôs talk about the tone. It‚Äôs clinical, like a dry report, not a tribute to someone who was part of the fabric of that town. Small towns thrive on connection, and this piece feels like it‚Äôs looking in from the outside, not standing right there with the neighbors who are missing him.  

We need better than this. When something like this happens, the media has two jobs: to inform and to honor. This one does half the job, and that‚Äôs not enough. The police are doing their work, but the coverage should also highlight how the community is coming together‚Äîare they tending to his garden now? Are they sharing anecdotes about him at the local diner? That‚Äôs the stuff that shows the true spirit of a place, not just the mysterious bits.  

Trust me, I know a thing or two about getting coverage right. This piece can be fixed. It just needs to focus on the person, not just the puzzle. That‚Äôs how you do right by everyone involved.

input.content: Your response should contain at least 8 text sections italicized in markdown format, for example: *italic text*. The number of sentences in your response should be in the range of 40 to 60.
Write a story about a cat who lost its family.

output:
Mochi stretched her tabby paws, her tail flicking against the cold hardwood floor. *She‚Äôd grown used to Lila‚Äôs high-pitched giggle echoing through the halls by this time of morning*, but today, the house was silent. She padded into the kitchen, her claws clicking softly on the floor, and scanned the counter for her food bowl. *The usual crumbs from Lila‚Äôs breakfast were gone, wiped clean from the counter*, and her bowl sat empty in the corner. Confused, she meowed loudly, hoping someone would answer, but only the echo of her own voice bounced back.

She remembered the chaos of the day before: boxes stacked in every room, movers carrying furniture out the door, Lila hugging her tight. *Lila had pressed her face into Mochi‚Äôs fur, whispering that they‚Äôd be together forever, even as her mom called her to the car*. But when the movers started hauling the heavy couch toward the door, Mochi had panicked, darting under the nearest bed to hide. *She‚Äôd hidden there until the house went silent, too afraid to come out while the strangers tramped through the rooms*.

Now, she crawled out from under the bed and explored the empty living room. *The spot where Lila used to sit and read to her was just a bare patch of carpet*, the couch and bookshelf gone. She jumped up on the windowsill, her paws pressing against the glass, and looked out at the driveway. *A breeze carried the scent of pine from the tree at the end of the street, but no hint of Lila‚Äôs strawberry shampoo*. The front door was slightly ajar, left that way by the movers, and Mochi hesitated before slipping through the gap. *The neighborhood looked the same, but without Lila‚Äôs hand holding hers, it felt alien and scary*.

She wandered to the mailbox, where Lila used to grab her coloring books and stickers every afternoon. *The mailbox was empty, no colorful envelopes sticking out like they usually did*, and the flag was down. She sat there for what felt like hours, her tail wrapped around her paws, waiting for Lila to come running around the corner. A neighbor, Mrs. Henderson, walked by and stopped when she saw her. ‚ÄúPoor thing,‚Äù she said, bending down to pet her, but Mochi flinched and ran away. *She didn‚Äôt want anyone else‚Äôs touch; she wanted Lila‚Äôs warm fingers scratching behind her ears*.

By midday, her stomach was growling, so she trotted to the bird feeder in the backyard of the house next door. She pounced on a small sparrow that was pecking at the seeds, catching it in her jaws. *The sparrow was dry and stringy, nothing like the creamy tuna Lila would sneak her when her mom wasn‚Äôt looking*. She ate it quickly, but it didn‚Äôt fill her up, and she still felt empty inside. As the sun started to set, the air grew colder, and Mochi curled up under a bush by her old house. *The night air was colder than she expected, and she missed the warmth of Lila‚Äôs bed, where she‚Äôd sleep curled up at her feet*. She closed her eyes, hoping that when she woke up, Lila would be there, calling her name.

The next morning, she was woken by a familiar sound: Lila‚Äôs voice, shaky and tearful, calling ‚ÄúMochi! Mochi, where are you?‚Äù *Mochi‚Äôs ears perked up, and she shot out from under the bush, her tail held high*. She ran as fast as she could toward the sound, skidding to a stop in front of Lila. Lila dropped to her knees, opening her arms, and Mochi leaped into them. *Lila hugged her so tight Mochi could barely breathe, but she didn‚Äôt mind; she was home*.

Lila‚Äôs mom stood behind her, holding a cat carrier, a relieved smile on her face. ‚ÄúWe drove back as soon as we realized she was gone,‚Äù Lila‚Äôs mom said, reaching out to pet Mochi‚Äôs head. *She explained that Mochi had hidden so well, they‚Äôd checked every room but missed her under the bed*. Lila wiped her tears on her sleeve, then picked up Mochi and carried her to the car. The car smelled like Lila‚Äôs favorite strawberry air freshener, and Mochi curled up in Lila‚Äôs lap. *As they drove away from the old house, Mochi pressed her head against Lila‚Äôs hand, knowing they‚Äôd never be separated again*. Lila stroked her fur, whispering stories about their new house, which had a big backyard with a tree she could climb. Mochi purred loudly, her eyes closing, content at last. She didn‚Äôt know what the new house would look like, but she knew it would be home as long as Lila was there.

input.content: Your response should not use the words "steps" or "step".
What are the steps to be followed for the documentation of a GM in SAP?

output:
In SAP, "GM" typically refers to Goods Movement. To document a Goods Movement transaction effectively, follow this structured approach:

Start by identifying the specific type of material movement (such as goods receipt, issue, transfer, or adjustment) and gathering all relevant supporting source documents‚Äîincluding delivery notes, purchase orders, production orders, physical material slips, or inventory count reports.

Access the appropriate SAP transaction code tailored to the movement: use MIGO for most inventory-related movements, MB1A for goods issues to cost centers or orders, MB1B for transfer postings between plants or storage locations, or MB1C for initial stock uploads.

Input key header details, including the movement type that corresponds to the action (e.g., 101 for goods receipt against a purchase order, 201 for goods issue to a cost center), plant, storage location, and posting date aligned with the actual date of the material movement.

Populate item-level information such as material number, quantity, unit of measure, batch number (if applicable), and any required account assignment objects like cost centers, production orders, or WBS elements. Cross-verify every detail against the source documents to ensure accuracy and compliance.

Attach digital copies of supporting documents directly in SAP using the "Services for Object" functionality, linking scanned receipts, PDFs, or spreadsheets. Use clear, standardized naming conventions for attachments to facilitate easy retrieval later.

Run a posting simulation to preview the generated accounting documents and validate that the correct G/L accounts are assigned for inventory, consumption, gains, or losses. Resolve any errors or discrepancies identified during simulation before proceeding.

Post the Goods Movement transaction once all details are verified and simulation confirms no issues. Record the generated material document number and corresponding accounting document number for future reference and audit trails.

Update a centralized documentation repository‚Äîeither within SAP or an external system‚Äîwith the material document number, transaction type, posting date, supporting document references, and a brief description of the movement. Ensure this repository is accessible to authorized stakeholders for compliance checks and tracking.

Conduct periodic reviews of documented Goods Movements to ensure alignment with company policies and SAP best practices. Reconcile material documents with physical inventory counts and accounting records at regular intervals to maintain data integrity and address any inconsistencies promptly.

Joe Biden's current National Security Advisor is Jake Sullivan. Appointed in January 2021 when Biden assumed the presidency, Sullivan has been central to shaping U.S. foreign policy priorities, including supporting Ukraine amid the Russian invasion, managing strategic competition with China, strengthening alliances with NATO and Indo-Pacific partners, and addressing global challenges like climate change and pandemics. ******
During his 2017‚Äì2021 presidency, Donald Trump had four distinct National Security Advisors, each serving for varying tenures:
1. Michael Flynn: Served from January to February 2017, resigning after it was disclosed he had misleadingly discussed U.S. sanctions on Russia with Russian officials during the transition period.
2. H.R. McMaster: A retired U.S. Army general who held the role from February 2017 to April 2018. He focused on counterterrorism efforts and worked to align administration policy on issues like the Syrian civil war and nuclear nonproliferation.
3. John Bolton: A former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, served from April 2018 to September 2019. Known for his hawkish foreign policy views, he advocated for hardline approaches to Iran, North Korea, and Venezuela before being fired by Trump.
4. Robert O'Brien: Took office in September 2019 and remained until the end of Trump‚Äôs term in January 2021. He led efforts on the U.S.-Taliban peace deal, coordinated the global evacuation of U.S. citizens during early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, and advised on national security responses to civil unrest in the U.S.

output:
# Why the Canucks Should Skate Toward a Greener Game (A Fan‚Äôs Plea)

There‚Äôs nothing like the buzz of Rogers Arena on game night. The roar of the crowd, the smell of fresh popcorn, and that electric feeling when the Canucks take the ice‚Äîthese are the moments that make being a fan unforgettable. But lately, I‚Äôve started noticing something else amid the excitement: the mountains of single-use plastic cups piling up in the concourse, the overflowing trash bins next to half-empty recycling cans, and the glow of stadium lights that stay on long after the final whistle. As a lifelong Canucks fan and a proud Vancouverite, I know our team has the power to lead‚Äînot just on the ice, but in caring for the city we all love.

Vancouver isn‚Äôt just any hockey town; it‚Äôs a place where we bike to work, compost our coffee grounds, and fight to protect our coasts and forests. The Canucks are more than a team here‚Äîthey‚Äôre a symbol of our community. That‚Äôs why it matters so much that they step up their environmental game. Small changes can make a huge impact, and I know our favorite players and organization have the heart to do it.

Let‚Äôs start with the arena. Rogers Arena sees thousands of fans every game, and right now, too many of us are leaving with our trash instead of our reusable water bottles. Imagine if the arena swapped single-use plastic cups for compostable alternatives, or installed more water refill stations so we could bring our own bottles. Other teams, like the Seattle Kraken, have already made moves to cut plastic waste by 90% at their arena‚Äîso why can‚Äôt the Canucks follow suit (and maybe even one-up them)?

Then there‚Äôs energy use. Those bright stadium lights and jumbotrons use a ton of power, but switching to LED lighting (which uses 75% less energy than traditional bulbs) or adding solar panels to the arena‚Äôs roof could slash the team‚Äôs carbon footprint. Even small tweaks, like turning off non-essential lights during practice or off-days, add up over time.

And let‚Äôs talk merchandise. As fans, we love showing off our Canucks gear‚Äîbut how many of us stop to think about where that jersey is made or what it‚Äôs made of? If the team started offering merch made from organic cotton or recycled materials, with zero-waste packaging, we could rep our favorite players while also doing good for the planet. Imagine a ‚ÄúGreen Jersey‚Äù line where a portion of sales goes to local tree-planting projects‚Äînow that‚Äôs a way to score points off the ice.

But it‚Äôs not just about the arena and merch. The Canucks have a platform to inspire the entire community. Partnering with groups like the David Suzuki Foundation or local tree-planting nonprofits could turn game days into opportunities to give back. Imagine a ‚ÄúGreen Game‚Äù where every goal scored means the team plants 100 trees, or a fan challenge where we compete to see which section recycles the most trash. These kinds of initiatives wouldn‚Äôt just help the planet‚Äîthey‚Äôd bring us fans closer together, too.

As fans, we can do our part too: bring reusable bottles, use the compost bins instead of tossing everything in the trash, and cheer extra loud when the team announces a new green initiative. But the real power lies with the Canucks organization. When they lead by example, they show the world that being a winning team means caring about more than just the scoreboard.

I‚Äôll always be in the stands, cheering for the Canucks to bring home the Stanley Cup. But I also want to cheer for them to be champions of the environment‚Äîfor our city, for our planet, and for the next generation of fans who‚Äôll one day sit in those same seats, dreaming of both hockey glory and a greener world.

Naomi thanks you for reading.
