input.content: Do not include the keywords 'icefrog', 'blizzard', 'lawsuit' in the response.
Can you give me a zany, bullet point TLDR of this article: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dota_2

output:
- Spawned from a chaotic, fan-made custom map in a fantasy real-time strategy game, this 5v5 MOBA blew up so hard it got a full, polished release to satisfy its rabid, rule-obsessed fanbase.
- Core objective: Obliterate the enemy team‚Äôs glowing, sacred crystal (dubbed the Ancient) before they turn your base into dust‚Äîsimple in theory, impossible when 100+ unhinged heroes are flinging spells, punches, and rocket barrages.
- No two matches are identical: Random hero drafts, dynamic item builds, and last-minute team plays mean you could be winning a 20-minute slugfest one game and getting crushed by a surprise soul-stealing combo the next.
- Hero roster is a who‚Äôs who of weirdos: A sentient, punch-happy tree, a crossbow-wielding maniac who fires rockets, a ghost queen that steals souls to heal, a tiny gremlin on a mech spider, and even a guy who turns into a bear‚Äîno generic knights allowed.
- Its learning curve is steeper than a mountain made of math textbooks: New players often get steamrolled by veterans who‚Äôve memorized 100+ item interactions, 20+ ability combos, and the exact second a jungle camp pops back up.
- The International, its flagship tournament, has prize pools so massive (tens of millions of dollars) that a chunk comes from players buying silly cosmetic gear (sparkly swords, neon capes, dancing emojis) for their heroes‚Äîfans literally fund the pros‚Äô big paychecks.
- 100% free to play, but the real status symbol is owning a rare, glittering weapon or skin that costs more than a new gaming console (and makes your hero look like a rockstar mid-battle).
- Community chaos is baked in: User-created game modes let you fight zombie hordes, play a turn-based card game inside the game, or even race carts‚Äîbecause why stick to just 5v5?
- It‚Äôs one of the biggest esports on Earth, with packed stadiums and millions of online viewers watching pro teams pull off 10-minute, nail-biting comebacks that make regular sports highlights look like child‚Äôs play.

input.content: Your ENTIRE response must be in lowercases without using any capital letters. There should be exactly 3 paragraphs with the only paragraph separation being two new lines. Start Paragraph 2 with the word "jasper".
Write an essay on first names.

output:
first names are more than just labels we answer to; they are the first gift we receive, wrapped in the hopes, memories, and cultural roots of the people who name us. some are passed down through generations, carrying the weight of a grandparent‚Äôs laughter, a parent‚Äôs unfulfilled dream, or a family‚Äôs long-held tradition. others are chosen for their soft sound, their meaningful translation, or a fleeting moment of inspiration‚Äîlike a character in a favorite book, a song lyric, or a flower blooming in the backyard. we grow into our names, too; a name that feels awkward in childhood might fit like a well-worn sweater by adulthood, as we infuse it with our own quirks, triumphs, and quiet moments. strangers make split-second judgments based on them, but over time, we rewrite those assumptions, turning a name into a reflection of who we are, not the other way around.

jasper never thought much about his name until he started middle school, when classmates began teasing him for having a ‚Äúrock name.‚Äù his parents had picked it after the deep red gemstone they‚Äôd found on their first hike together, a small, smooth stone they kept on their nightstand as a reminder of their early days. at first, he wished he had a more common name, like noah or ethan, one that didn‚Äôt draw extra attention. but in eighth grade, his english teacher paused before calling on him and said, ‚Äújasper‚Äîsuch a steady, warm name. it suits you, with your quiet way of listening to everyone.‚Äù that comment stuck with him. slowly, he started to see his name not as a joke, but as a piece of his parents‚Äô story, a tiny, tangible link to the love that brought him into the world. now, when he meets someone new, he doesn‚Äôt shy away from explaining the gemstone origin; he even keeps a small jasper stone in his backpack, a quiet nod to his name‚Äôs roots.

names are living things, evolving with the people who bear them. they connect us to the past‚Äîwhether through a great-aunt‚Äôs name or a cultural tradition we might not fully understand at first‚Äîand they shape our present, as we carry them into every conversation, every friendship, every milestone. some people choose to redefine their names later in life, picking a new one that aligns with their true identity, an act of courage that says, ‚Äúthis is who i am.‚Äù even the most common names hold unique meaning: a lily might be named after her mother‚Äôs favorite flower, a liam after his father‚Äôs childhood best friend. when we take the time to learn the story behind someone‚Äôs name, we‚Äôre not just learning a fact‚Äîwe‚Äôre opening a door to their world, to the people who loved them first, and to the person they‚Äôre still becoming.

**Subject Line: YOU‚ÄôVE GOT THE POWER to Warm Aberdeen‚ÄîVolunteer with Our Soup Kitchen!**  

Hi [First Name],  

I bet you walk past Union Street or the Green every week and notice how bone-chilling Aberdeen‚Äôs winters can get. But did you know there are neighbors right here in our city who don‚Äôt have a warm place to sit, a hot meal to eat, or even someone to chat with on those FREEZING days? That‚Äôs where YOU come in.  

The Aberdeen Community Warm Hub Soup Kitchen is looking for awesome teens like you to join our team‚Äîand let me tell you, your time could make a HUGE difference. You don‚Äôt need any fancy experience, just a willingness to lend a hand, share a smile, and maybe even swap stories about the best fish and chip shops in town (we‚Äôve got strong opinions on that, by the way).  

What can you do? Serve steaming bowls of lentil soup, hand out cozy blankets, or just sit and listen to someone‚Äôs day. It‚Äôs TOTALLY flexible‚Äîwe have shifts on Saturday afternoons or Sunday mornings, so you can fit it around school, football practice, or hanging with your mates. And here‚Äôs the best part: you‚Äôll meet a crew of cool people (both volunteers and guests) who‚Äôll make you feel like you‚Äôre part of something WAY bigger than yourself.  

Let‚Äôs be real‚Äîteen life can feel like it‚Äôs all about exams and social media, but volunteering here gives you a chance to leave a lasting IMPACT on our city. Plus, it‚Äôs not all work and no play: we have post-shift pizza nights for volunteers, and you‚Äôll get a snazzy volunteer badge that‚Äôs perfect for your CV (hello, university apps!).  

Don‚Äôt overthink it‚Äîsigning up is EASY. Just click this link [insert link] or shoot us a text at 01224-XXX-XXX. We‚Äôre hosting an info session next Wednesday at 6 PM at the hub (right near the train station) where you can meet the team, ask questions, and even try a sample of our famous vegetable stew (it‚Äôs chef‚Äôs kiss).  

This isn‚Äôt just about helping others‚Äîit‚Äôs about building a WARMER, kinder Aberdeen together. YOU have the power to turn someone‚Äôs tough day around, and that‚Äôs something to be PROUD of.  

Can‚Äôt wait to meet you,  
The Team at Aberdeen Community Warm Hub Soup Kitchen

input.content: Your entire response should be in all capital letters.
Write a story about a family that goes camping in the woods.

output:
IT WAS 6 A.M. WHEN THE CAR RUMBLED OUT OF THE DRIVEWAY, ZOE (10) AND JAX (7) SQUISHED IN THE BACKSEAT WITH THEIR NEON SLEEPING BAGS AND A CRATE HOLDING MAX, THEIR FLOPPY-EARED GOLDEN RETRIEVER. DAD, JIM, GRINNED IN THE REARVIEW MIRROR AS MOM, LISA, PASSED A BOX OF GRANOLA BARS TO THE KIDS. ‚ÄúTODAY WE BECOME OFFICIAL WOODSMEN‚ÄîAND WOODSWOMEN,‚Äù JAX YELLED, WAVING A STICK HE‚ÄôD SNAGGED FROM THE YARD.

BY 9 A.M., THEY PULLED INTO A SUN-DAPPLED CAMPSITE NESTLED BETWEEN TALL PINE TREES. THE AIR SMELLED LIKE RESIN AND FRESH DIRT. ZOE DUG OUT THE TENT INSTRUCTIONS WHILE JIM FUMBLED WITH THE POLES, LISA LAUGHING WHEN ONE SLIPPED AND WHACKED HIM IN THE SHOULDER. MAX TROTTED OFF TO EXPLORE, COMING BACK WITH A SQUIRREL‚ÄôS NUT IN HIS MOUTH THAT HE DROPPED AT JAX‚ÄôS FEET LIKE A TREASURE.

AFTER LUNCH, THEY LACED UP HIKING BOOTS AND HIT A TRAIL WINDING DOWN TO A GLISTENING STREAM. ZOE SNAPPED PHOTOS WITH HER DISPOSABLE CAMERA‚ÄîJAX SKIPPING STONES (MOST SANK INSTANTLY), MAX SPLASHING IN SHALLOW WATER, HIS FUR STICKING UP IN TUFFS. HALFWAY UP, JAX STOPPED SHORT, POINTING AT A GREEN FROG PERCHED ON A LILY PAD. ‚ÄúHE‚ÄôS WAVING AT ME!‚Äù HE WHISPERED, AND THE FROG BLOATED HIS THROAT LIKE HE WAS AGREEING. WHEN JAX LEANED IN TO PET IT, IT HOPPED AWAY, MAKING HIM GIGgle SO HARD HE FELL IN THE GRASS.

AS THE SUN DIPPED BEHIND THE TREES, THEY BUILT A FIRE. THE CRACKLE OF FLAMES MIXED WITH CRICKET CHIRPS. LISA PULLED OUT MARSHMALLOWS AND GRAHAM CRACKERS; ZOE SHOWED JAX HOW TO ROAST HIS MARSHMALLOW GOLDEN BROWN (NOT CHARRED, LIKE HIS FIRST ATTEMPT). WHEN THE SKY TURNED PINK, JIM LEANED IN, VOICE DROPPED TO A WHISPER: ‚ÄúYOU KNOW WHAT LIVES HERE? THE GREAT PINE SPIRIT‚ÄîWHO LEAVES CANDY FOR KIDS WHO CLEAN THEIR CAMPSITE.‚Äù JAX‚ÄôS EYES WIDE, ZOE ROLLING HERS BUT SMILING.

BY 10 P.M., THE KIDS WERE TUCKED INTO SLEEPING BAGS, MAX CURLED AT THEIR FEET. JAX MUMBLED, ‚ÄúI HEARD A NOISE,‚Äù AND ZOE HUGGED HIM. ‚ÄúIT‚ÄôS JUST A RACCOON. OR MAYBE THE PINE SPIRIT BRINGING CANDY.‚Äù LATER, LISA CHECKED IN TO FIND THEM ASLEEP, JAX CLUTCHING A FROG STICKER ZOE HAD GIVEN HIM.

THE NEXT MORNING, THEY WOKE TO WOODPECKER CHIRPS. LISA MADE PANCAKES ON A CAST-IRON SKILLET OVER THE FIRE, SWEET SMELL WAFTING THROUGH THE TREES. AFTER PACKING UP, ZOE HUNG A DRAWING OF THE FAMILY ON A PINE TREE, WITH A NOTE: ‚ÄúWE‚ÄôLL BE BACK!‚Äù

AS THEY DROVE AWAY, JAX WAVED OUT THE WINDOW AT THE TREES. ‚ÄúMAX AND I ARE GONNA CATCH A BEAR NEXT TIME,‚Äù HE SAID. ZOE LAUGHED, BUT SHE KNEW HE WAS SERIOUS. SOMEWHERE BEHIND THEM, THE PINES SWAYED‚ÄîLIKE THEY WERE WAVING BACK.

input.content: Your response must be 300 or more words in length.
Give me a startup pitch for a company that provides a service that creates trusts for people online.

output:
**Pitch Deck: TrustTree ‚Äì Making Trusts Accessible to Every Family**  

[Opening Slide: Warm image of a multi-generational family laughing, with the TrustTree logo (a stylized tree with intertwined branches) and tagline: ‚ÄúProtect What Matters, Without the Lawyer‚Äôs Price Tag‚Äù]  

**Hook (1 minute)**  
Let me tell you about Maria, a single mom in Chicago with two kids and a $350k home. When her mom passed suddenly last year, Maria realized she had no plan for who would care for her kids or manage her home if something happened to her. She called an estate planning attorney, who quoted her $2,500 for a basic living trust‚Äîmoney she couldn‚Äôt spare after covering her mom‚Äôs medical bills. So she did nothing. Today, if Maria were to pass unexpectedly, her kids would be caught in a years-long probate battle, her home could be sold to cover any outstanding debts, and her sister (her only family) would have to fight for guardianship. Maria‚Äôs story isn‚Äôt rare: 68% of Americans have no estate planning documents, and 90% of middle-class families can‚Äôt afford traditional trust services. But what if creating a legally valid, customized trust was as easy as ordering a pizza?  

**The Problem (2 minutes)**  
Trusts are the gold standard of estate planning‚Äîthey avoid probate (which can take 6-18 months and cost 3-7% of your estate), protect assets from creditors, ensure minor kids are cared for by the guardians you choose, and even support disabled family members or charitable causes. But the system is broken:  
- **Expensive**: Traditional lawyers charge $1,500-$5,000 for a single trust, putting it out of reach for 80% of middle-class Americans.  
- **Time-Consuming**: Weeks of back-and-forth meetings to draft and review documents.  
- **One-Size-Fits-All**: Generic online tools (like LegalZoom) offer state-agnostic templates that often fail to meet local legal requirements, leaving users with unenforceable trusts.  
- **Forgotten Maintenance**: Even when people do create trusts, 70% never update them after life events (births, marriages, deaths), rendering them obsolete.  

**The Solution: TrustTree (3 minutes)**  
TrustTree is the first online platform that makes creating, executing, and maintaining a legally valid trust simple, affordable, and personalized for every family. Here‚Äôs how it works:  

1. **Guided, Conversational Questionnaire**: No legal jargon‚Äîjust a 15-minute chat that asks about your family, assets, and goals (e.g., ‚ÄúWho do you want to care for your kids if you can‚Äôt?‚Äù ‚ÄúDo you want to leave money to your local animal shelter?‚Äù). Our AI adapts questions based on your responses, so you only answer what‚Äôs relevant.  
2. **State-Specific, Attorney-Reviewed Customization**: Unlike generic tools, every trust is tailored to your state‚Äôs unique laws (critical, since trust validity hinges on local regulations). Then, a licensed estate planning attorney in your state reviews the document to ensure it‚Äôs airtight‚Äîno exceptions.  
3. **End-to-End Execution Support**: We handle the hard parts: integrated online notarization (so you don‚Äôt have to visit a bank), step-by-step guidance to sign the trust correctly, and a clear roadmap to fund your trust (transferring real estate, bank accounts, or investments into the trust‚Äôs name).  
4. **Ongoing Maintenance for Life**: We send you personalized reminders when life events happen (a new baby, a divorce, a parent‚Äôs death) to update your trust. Our premium plan includes annual check-ins with an attorney and unlimited access to our support team for questions about funding or modifying your trust.  

**Market Opportunity (2 minutes)**  
The U.S. estate planning market is a $50B industry, but 90% of that revenue goes to serving the top 10% of wealthiest Americans. TrustTree targets the underserved middle class: 130M adults who own homes, have kids, or have assets to protect but can‚Äôt afford traditional legal services. We also focus on underserved niches: single parents, LGBTQ+ families (who need specialized protections for partners), small business owners, and families with disabled members‚Äîgroups that are often overlooked by traditional firms.  

**Business Model (1 minute)**  
We use a tiered pricing structure to meet every family‚Äôs needs:  
- **Basic Plan ($199)**: Revocable living trust, state-specific customization, attorney review, and execution support.  
- **Premium Plan ($399/year)**: All Basic features plus ongoing maintenance, life event reminders, annual attorney check-ins, and unlimited support.  
- **Add-Ons**: Irrevocable trust ($299), special needs trust ($349), charitable remainder trust ($399).  
- **Enterprise**: We partner with financial advisors and employers to offer TrustTree as a benefit to their clients and employees, charging a per-user licensing fee.  

**Traction (1 minute)**  
In our beta launch with 500 users across 20 states:  
- 98% of users completed their trust in under 40 minutes.  
- 95% said they‚Äôd recommend TrustTree to a friend.  
- We‚Äôve partnered with 120 licensed estate planning attorneys across 45 states, with a 90% retention rate.  
- We raised $500k in pre-seed funding from angel investors, including a former CEO of a top legal tech startup and a leading estate planning attorney.  

**Team (1 minute)**  
Our team combines legal expertise and tech innovation to deliver a product you can trust:  
- **Jane Doe, CEO**: Former estate planning attorney with 10 years of experience, who left her firm after seeing how many families were priced out of critical planning.  
- **John Smith, CTO**: Fintech veteran who built user-friendly platforms for Fidelity and Vanguard, specializing in secure, compliant financial tools.  
- **Sarah Lee, COO**: Led customer support operations at LegalZoom, scaling a team of 200 to serve 1M+ users.  
- **Advisors**: Includes Professor Emily Carter, a leading estate planning law scholar at Harvard Law, and Mike Chen, former CEO of Rocket Lawyer.  

**Competitive Edge (1 minute)**  
Unlike generic tools like LegalZoom or Rocket Lawyer, TrustTree doesn‚Äôt cut corners on legal validity‚Äîevery trust is reviewed by a local attorney. Unlike traditional firms, we‚Äôre affordable and fast. And no other platform offers ongoing maintenance as a core feature, ensuring your trust stays relevant for life.  

**Call to Action (30 seconds)**  
We‚Äôre seeking a $2M seed round to:  
1. Expand our attorney network to all 50 states.  
2. Launch our mobile app, so users can create and update their trusts on the go.  
3. Scale our marketing to reach underserved groups, including single parents and LGBTQ+ families.  

With this funding, we aim to acquire 100k users in the next 18 months and become the leading online trust platform for middle-class Americans. Because everyone deserves to protect what matters most‚Äîwithout breaking the bank.  

[Closing Slide: TrustTree logo, website (www.trusttree.com), and contact info for investors]

input.content: Your response must be wrapped in JSON format. Please make sure that your response only contains a JSON block. Please also make sure to include keywords 'compensated' and 'immigrants' in the response.
Could you please give me the pros and cons of working abroad.

output:
{
  "pros": [
    "Enhanced professional growth: Exposure to international work methodologies, innovative technologies, and diverse team collaborations that expand your skill set and increase long-term career mobility.",
    "Financial stability: Many international roles offer the chance to be well-compensated with competitive salaries, performance-based bonuses, and comprehensive benefits (like housing stipends or relocation allowances) that outpace domestic earning potential in certain industries.",
    "Cultural competence development: Working alongside locals and other immigrants provides firsthand insight into their unique challenges, triumphs, and perspectives, fostering greater empathy and cross-cultural communication skills that are valuable in globalized workplaces.",
    "Personal resilience: Navigating new environments, language barriers, and social norms builds adaptability, independence, and problem-solving abilities that strengthen personal growth.",
    "Global professional network: Establishing connections with colleagues and industry leaders across borders creates opportunities for future collaborations, international projects, or career advancements."
  ],
  "cons": [
    "Cultural adjustment hurdles: Unfamiliar workplace etiquette, communication styles, and social norms can lead to misalignment or feelings of isolation, particularly for immigrants who may face additional barriers like implicit bias or language proficiency gaps.",
    "Emotional and social strain: Being separated from family, friends, and familiar support systems often results in persistent homesickness, which can impact mental health and overall job satisfaction.",
    "Legal and administrative complexity: Securing work visas, residency permits, or tax compliance requires extensive paperwork, long processing times, and potential fees, which can be stressful and time-consuming.",
    "Financial risks: Relocation costs (such as moving expenses, temporary housing, or currency exchange fluctuations) can strain budgets, and initial compensation may not immediately offset these upfront expenses.",
    "Career transition challenges: Some domestic employers may undervalue international work experience, making it difficult to re-integrate into home-country roles or advance in a domestic career path after returning."
  ]
}

Critique this startup pitch: Stephenson and Hong Kong will be the first-ever digital marketplace where users can buy and sell products from all over the world Stephenson and Hong Kong will be a onestopshop for all of your shopping needs and we will offer a variety of features that will make shopping online easier and more convenient than ever before.

output:
This startup pitch has several critical weaknesses that undermine its ability to persuade investors or resonate with potential users. First the name "Stephenson and Hong Kong" is confusing and non-descriptive. Mixing a personal name with a geographic location fails to signal the platform‚Äôs purpose making it unmemorable and unclear whether Stephenson refers to a person place or brand. 

Second the claim of being the "first-ever digital marketplace where users can buy and sell products from all over the world" is entirely unsubstantiated. Major established platforms like Amazon eBay and Alibaba already offer global cross-border shopping so this overclaim immediately erodes credibility with anyone familiar with the e-commerce space. 

Third the phrase "onestopshop" is a vague clich√© that provides no specific value. The pitch does not outline what types of products the marketplace will host leaving potential users unsure if it caters to their needs such as electronics clothing handmade goods or niche items. 

Fourth the mention of "a variety of features that will make shopping online easier and more convenient" is far too generic. It fails to detail any unique or competitive features that set this platform apart from existing options. For example there is no mention of solving common cross-border shopping pain points like high shipping costs hidden currency fees long delivery times or trust issues with international sellers. Without specific examples of innovative features the pitch cannot demonstrate a clear competitive edge. 

Fifth the pitch lacks a defined target audience. It does not specify whether it is for casual shoppers small business owners looking to export niche product enthusiasts or any other group. This makes it impossible to understand the tailored value proposition for the people most likely to use the platform. 

Finally the pitch is repetitive and unstructured. It repeats the platform‚Äôs name twice without adding new information each time creating a disjointed and unpolished flow that fails to build a compelling case for the business. Overall the pitch needs to focus on unique problem-solving specific differentiators and a clear understanding of its audience to be effective.

input.content: Your response must be in English, with no capital letters. Your response must contain between 20 to 30 sentences.
Write a tweet storm with a weird tone about a time when you found out that the earth is indeed not flat.

output:
tweet 1: so i was at the 24/7 laundromat last tuesday, the one with the flickering neon sign that says ‚Äòclean clothes = clear conscience‚Äô (total lie, i stole a candy bar from the gas station next door an hour prior). i was staring at my last remaining left sock, the one with the tiny coffee stain that never comes out, when the guy folding towels next to me said ‚Äòyou know the earth‚Äôs not flat, right?‚Äô i froze like a popsicle left out in the sun for 10 minutes, my brain short-circuiting faster than the dryer that eats quarters.

tweet 2: i‚Äôd always just assumed the flat earth thing was a bit, like people who say they hate pizza but secretly eat it when no one‚Äôs looking. i never bothered to fact-check it because why would i? my biggest concern that week was whether my houseplant was judging me for forgetting to water it again. but this guy had a towel folded into a perfect square, the kind you only see in hotel rooms, so clearly he knew things. i leaned in, my voice a whisper like i was sharing a secret about a celebrity‚Äôs weird pet.

tweet 3: he pulled out a crumpled napkin from his pocket, the kind with a cartoon cat wearing a top hat, and drew a circle on it. ‚Äòsee this?‚Äô he said, pointing to the circle. ‚Äòthat‚Äôs the earth. it spins. it curves. when you look at a ship going over the horizon, it doesn‚Äôt just disappear‚Äîit sinks because of the curve.‚Äô i stared at the napkin like it was an ancient scroll holding the secrets of the universe. my left sock suddenly felt irrelevant, which is saying something because i‚Äôve had that sock for 3 years.

tweet 4: i ran home after that, leaving my dryer running (oops, hope whoever found my clothes is nice) and immediately googled ‚Äòis the earth flat?‚Äô the first result was a nasa article with pictures of the earth from space, and i felt like i‚Äôd just found out my favorite childhood cartoon character was actually a villain. i sat on my couch, staring at the screen, and realized i‚Äôd been living a lie. not a big, dramatic lie like hiding a pet elephant in the closet, but a small, stupid one that made me feel silly. my houseplant definitely was judging me now, i could feel its leaves drooping in disappointment.

tweet 5: i spent the rest of the night watching videos of ships disappearing over the horizon and people doing experiments with lasers and water. every time i saw the curve, my stomach did a flip like i was on a rollercoaster that only goes up. i even went outside and looked at the moon, wondering if it was really a sphere too (spoiler: it is). the worst part? i told my best friend about it the next day, and she just said ‚Äòduh, everyone knows that‚Äô like i‚Äôd just told her grass is green.

tweet 6: now i can‚Äôt stop thinking about it. every time i drive on a long road, i squint to see if i can spot the curve (i can‚Äôt, but i keep trying). i bought a globe at the thrift store yesterday, and i keep spinning it when i‚Äôm bored, like it‚Äôs a fidget toy. i still feel a little betrayed, not by the earth, but by myself for being so oblivious. maybe i should start fact-checking more things, but first, i need to apologize to my houseplant and buy it a new pot.

Hey! I need a rubric for evaluating the performance and price of a laptop. Can you create an example for me? Do not give me any bullet points, lists, or tables. Just write the rubric in plain English paragraphs.

output:
This rubric is designed to holistically evaluate a laptop‚Äôs performance relative to its price point, providing clear, measurable criteria to determine overall value for different user needs, from casual web browsing to intensive creative work or gaming. To begin, processing power is a core component of performance, and we break it into four levels of achievement. For the Exemplary level, a laptop must feature a latest-generation processor‚Äîsuch as an Intel 13th or 14th Gen Core i7/i9 or AMD Ryzen 7/9‚Äîthat effortlessly handles all intensive tasks, including 4K video editing, 3D rendering, and multitasking with 10 or more resource-heavy apps open simultaneously, with no noticeable lag or slowdown; benchmark scores should place it in the top 10% of consumer laptops, indicating it‚Äôs among the most powerful options on the market. The Proficient level applies to laptops with mid-range processors, like Intel Core i5 or AMD Ryzen 5, which handle daily tasks smoothly, including light photo editing, streaming, and moderate multitasking with 5 to 8 apps open, with minimal lag even during peak usage; benchmark scores should fall in the top 30% of consumer laptops, making it suitable for most mainstream users. At the Basic level, laptops have entry-level processors, such as older-generation Core i3/Ryzen 3 or budget-focused chips, which struggle with multitasking, take significant time to load large apps, and are only reliable for basic tasks like web browsing, word processing, and email; benchmark scores place them in the top 50% of consumer laptops, meaning they‚Äôre functional but not powerful enough for anything beyond essential use. The Below Basic level is reserved for laptops with outdated processors, like Intel Core 2 Duo or older AMD models, which can‚Äôt handle even basic multitasking without freezing or crashing, making them unsuitable for most modern use cases and a poor investment for anyone needing to run current software.

Next, graphics performance is critical for users who game, do creative work, or work with visual media, and it also has four distinct levels. An Exemplary graphics setup includes a high-end dedicated GPU, such as an NVIDIA RTX 4070/4080 or AMD RX 7800M, which runs AAA games at 1080p with 60+ frames per second or 4K with 30+ frames per second, handles 3D modeling and video editing with GPU acceleration seamlessly, and delivers benchmark scores in the top 10% of consumer laptops. Proficient graphics performance comes from a mid-range dedicated GPU, like NVIDIA RTX 4050 or AMD RX 7600M, or a high-performance integrated GPU such as Intel Iris Xe Max or AMD Radeon 780M, which runs most indie games at 1080p/60fps, supports light 3D work, and accelerates basic video editing tasks, with benchmark scores in the top 30% of consumer laptops. Basic graphics performance is provided by entry-level dedicated GPUs or standard integrated graphics, which can run casual games only at low settings, offer no GPU acceleration for creative tasks, and may lag during HD video playback when multitasking, with benchmark scores in the top 50% of consumer laptops. Below Basic graphics are found in laptops with outdated integrated graphics or no dedicated GPU at all, which can‚Äôt play even casual games smoothly, struggle to play HD video without stuttering, and make media consumption frustrating, with benchmark scores falling below the top 50% of consumer laptops.

Memory, or RAM, is another key factor in multitasking capability, and its evaluation follows the same four-level structure. An Exemplary laptop will have 16GB or more of latest-generation DDR5 RAM, with expandability up to 32GB or higher, allowing it to handle heavy multitasking with dozens of browser tabs, creative apps, and background processes open simultaneously without any slowdown, and switching between apps is instantaneous. Proficient laptops have 8GB of DDR4 or DDR5 RAM, often expandable to 16GB, which handles daily multitasking with 3 to 5 apps and 10 to 15 browser tabs smoothly, though it may experience slight lag when running two resource-heavy creative apps at once. Basic laptops have either 8GB of non-expandable RAM or 4GB of expandable RAM, which struggles with more than 2 to 3 apps open at once, requires closing browser tabs to maintain performance, and has significantly increased loading times when running multiple tasks. Below Basic laptops have 4GB of non-expandable RAM or less, which can barely handle a single browser window with 5 tabs and a word processor open without freezing, making it impractical for anyone who needs to do more than one thing at a time.

Storage performance affects how quickly a laptop boots, loads apps, and accesses files, so it‚Äôs a crucial part of the evaluation. Exemplary storage is a 1TB or larger PCIe 4.0 NVMe SSD, which delivers read speeds over 7000MB/s, boots the laptop in under 5 seconds, loads large apps like Adobe Photoshop or AAA games in under 10 seconds, and provides enough space for extensive media libraries and software installations without needing external storage. Proficient storage is a 512GB PCIe 3.0 NVMe SSD, with read speeds over 3000MB/s, which boots in under 10 seconds, loads large apps in 10 to 20 seconds, and offers enough space for average users‚Äô needs, with room to expand via an extra drive bay if available. Basic storage is either a 256GB SATA SSD or a 1TB HDD; the SATA SSD has read speeds around 500MB/s, boots in 15 to 20 seconds, and loads large apps in 20 to 30 seconds, while the HDD is even slower, taking 30+ seconds to boot and 40+ seconds to load apps, and space is limited, requiring frequent deletion of files to free up room. Below Basic storage is a 128GB SSD or smaller HDD, where the 128GB SSD is barely enough for the operating system and a few basic apps, and the HDD is extremely slow, leading to constant waiting for files to load, with no expandability options available, so users can‚Äôt add more storage without replacing the entire drive.

Display quality impacts media consumption, creative work, and overall user experience, so it‚Äôs evaluated with clear criteria. An Exemplary display has a 1080p or higher resolution (preferably 4K), a 120Hz or higher refresh rate, 100% coverage of the sRGB or DCI-P3 color gamut, 500 nits of brightness, and excellent viewing angles, making it ideal for professional color work, gaming, and media consumption even in bright outdoor environments. Proficient displays have a 1080p resolution, a 60Hz refresh rate, 90% coverage of the sRGB color gamut, 300 to 400 nits of brightness, and good viewing angles, which is suitable for most daily tasks and media consumption, though not ideal for professional color-sensitive work. Basic displays have a 720p resolution, a 60Hz refresh rate, 70 to 80% coverage of the sRGB color gamut, 200 to 250 nits of brightness, and narrow viewing angles, making it hard to see the screen in bright rooms and unsuitable for any color-sensitive tasks. Below Basic displays have a 720p or lower resolution, poor color accuracy (under 70% sRGB coverage), under 200 nits of brightness, and distorted viewing angles, so the screen is barely visible even in moderate light, and colors appear washed out or skewed, making it frustrating to use for any extended period.

Battery life is essential for portability, so we evaluate how long a laptop lasts on a single charge and its charging capabilities. An Exemplary laptop lasts 10 hours or more on a single charge during light use (web browsing, word processing) and 6+ hours during intensive use (video editing, gaming), with fast charging that provides 50% battery in 30 minutes, allowing users to go all day without needing a power outlet. Proficient laptops last 6 to 10 hours on light use and 3 to 5 hours on intensive use, with standard charging that provides 50% battery in 60 minutes, which is suitable for a full workday with one midday charge if needed. Basic laptops last 3 to 6 hours on light use and 1 to 2 hours on intensive use, with slow charging that takes 2+ hours to reach 50% battery, requiring frequent access to a power outlet and making it impractical for travel or use away from home. Below Basic laptops last less than 3 hours on light use and under 1 hour on intensive use, with extremely slow charging that takes 3+ hours to reach 50% battery, and the battery may not hold a charge well over time, needing replacement within a year of purchase.

Build quality and portability determine how easy a laptop is to carry and how durable it is over time. An Exemplary laptop is made of premium materials like aluminum or carbon fiber, weighs under 3 pounds, is thinner than 0.7 inches, has a durable chassis that passes MIL-STD 810H testing for drops, shocks, and temperature extremes, and features a backlit keyboard

Write a pitch deck for a startup that aims to make a new social network that focuses on the board game society.

# Pitch Deck: Tabletop Nexus ‚Äì The Social Network for Board Game Enthusiasts
---

## Slide 1: Title Slide
**Headline**: Tabletop Nexus ‚Äì Connect, Play, and Thrive with Your Board Game Tribe  
**Subheadline**: The all-in-one social network built exclusively for board game lovers  
**Visual**: Collage of diverse players laughing over board games, with the Tabletop Nexus logo front-and-center  
**Footer**:  
- Founding Team: [Name 1, CEO], [Name 2, CTO], [Name 3, CMO]  
- Contact: hello@tabletopnexus.com | @TabletopNexus

---

## Slide 2: The Problem ‚Äì Board Game Enthusiasts Are Fragmented & Frustrated
**Headline**: Why Every Board Gamer Has a Story of "Game Night Fails"  
**Key Pain Points**:  
1. **Finding the Right Players**: Difficulty locating local/virtual players with matching tastes (e.g., Eurogame fans vs. party game lovers) or skill levels.  
2. **Fragmented Communities**: Scattered across Reddit threads, Facebook groups, and Discord servers ‚Äì no single hub for all needs.  
3. **Event Chaos**: Organizing in-person meetups or virtual tournaments requires juggling multiple tools (Google Forms, Zoom, Tabletop Simulator).  
4. **Lack of Personalized Discovery**: Generic reviews on Amazon or BGG don‚Äôt account for your unique playstyle (e.g., casual vs. competitive).  
**Speaker Note**: "Post-pandemic, 62% of board gamers say they struggle to find consistent play partners ‚Äì and 78% want a dedicated space for their hobby, not just a corner of another social platform."

---

## Slide 3: The Solution ‚Äì Tabletop Nexus
**Headline**: Your One-Stop Hub for All Things Board Games  
**Subheadline**: We‚Äôre building the social network that turns "I can‚Äôt find players" into "Who‚Äôs joining my game night?"  
**Core Mission**: Unify board game communities, simplify player matching, and make every game night unforgettable.  
**Visual**: Screenshot of the Tabletop Nexus app home screen (player match suggestions, upcoming events, game recommendations).

---

## Slide 4: Market Opportunity ‚Äì A Booming, Underserved Niche
**Headline**: The Board Game Industry Is Growing ‚Äì And We‚Äôre Here to Capture It  
**Key Stats**:  
- Global board game market size: $12.6B (2023), projected to hit $20.3B by 2028 (CAGR 10.5%).  
- Post-pandemic growth: 35% increase in casual board game players since 2020.  
- Gap in the market: No dedicated social platform for enthusiasts ‚Äì 80% of players use 3+ fragmented tools to connect with others.  
**Speaker Note**: "Reddit‚Äôs r/boardgames has 3.8M members, but it‚Äôs not built for player matching or event organization. We‚Äôre filling that gap with a platform designed specifically for this community."

---

## Slide 5: Product Overview ‚Äì Core Features
**Headline**: What Makes Tabletop Nexus Irreplaceable?  
**Feature Breakdown**:  
1. **AI-Powered Player Matching**: Match with local/virtual players based on game preferences, skill level, availability, and even personality (e.g., "competitive Eurogame fan" or "casual party game lover").  
2. **Game Library & Personalized Recommendations**: Track your collection, read user-generated reviews, and get AI suggestions tailored to your play history.  
3. **Event Hub**: Create/join in-person meetups, virtual tournaments, or casual game nights ‚Äì with built-in RSVP, location sharing, and integration with Tabletop Simulator/Board Game Arena.  
4. **Niche Communities**: Join groups for RPGs, solo games, indie board games, or even designer AMAs (we‚Äôre partnering with top creators for exclusive content).  
5. **Collection Sync**: Import your existing BGG collection to jumpstart your profile.

---

## Slide 6: Unique Value Proposition (UVP)
**Headline**: Why We‚Äôre Better Than the Alternatives  
| Platform               | Tabletop Nexus Advantage                                                                 |
|------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Reddit/Facebook Groups | Centralized, AI-driven tools for matching and events ‚Äì no noise from unrelated content.  |
| BoardGameGeek (BGG)    | Social-first focus (not just a database) with real-time player matching and event management. |
| Discord Servers        | Scalable, niche communities with integrated game night tools (no need to switch apps).    |
**Speaker Note**: "Unlike BGG, we‚Äôre not just a reference site ‚Äì we‚Äôre a social network where you can go from reading a game review to joining a game night in 3 clicks."

---

## Slide 7: Business Model ‚Äì Monetize Without Alienating the Community
**Headline**: Sustainable Revenue That Grows With Our Users  
**Freemium Core**:  
- **Free Tier**: Basic player matching, event access, limited collection tracking.  
- **Premium Tier ($4.99/month)**: Ad-free experience, advanced AI matching, exclusive tournament access, early previews of new games.  
**Additional Streams**:  
1. **Affiliate Commissions**: 10-15% cut from game sales linked through our platform (partnerships with Amazon, GameNerdz, and local game stores).  
2. **Publisher Partnerships**: Sponsored game listings, designer AMAs, and beta access promotions ($500-$2,000 per campaign).  
3. **Tournament Hosting Fees**: 5% cut from paid tournament entry fees (with prizes funded by publishers or sponsors).

---

## Slide 8: Traction ‚Äì Beta Launch Success
**Headline**: Our Beta Proves the Community Wants Us  
**Key Metrics (First 2 Months)**:  
- 5,000 beta users across NYC, London, and Tokyo.  
- 42% weekly active users (WAU) ‚Äì 2x the average for social apps in the gaming niche.  
- 217 events organized (in-person and virtual) with 89% attendance rate.  
- 85% user satisfaction score in post-beta surveys.  
- Partnerships with 12 indie game publishers (including Stonemaier Games and CMON) for exclusive content.

## Slide 9: Team ‚Äì We Live and Breathe Board Games
**Headline**: A Team That Knows the Hobby and the Business

- **CTO [Name]**: 7 years in AI and mobile app development, built community platforms for gaming startups, designed the matching algorithm for Tabletop Nexus.  
- **CMO [Name]**: 4 years in gaming marketing (previously at Fantasy Flight Games), led campaigns for 15+ board game launches.

What does the word "jock" mean to you?

output:
To me, the term in question refers to someone who centers much of their identity and daily life around athletic activities, especially within a school or college environment. This individual is usually actively involved in competitive team sports, devoting hours to training, practice, and participating in games. They often belong to a social group where sports are the primary shared interest, and the term sometimes carries a stereotype of prioritizing physical pursuits over academic or creative endeavors‚Äîthough this is a narrow view that doesn‚Äôt apply to everyone fitting the general description.

***

Beyond the stereotype, the meaning can expand to include anyone with a passionate, dedicated commitment to sports, regardless of their social circle or academic focus. Many people described this way balance their athletic goals with strong performance in other areas, like academics or art, and their involvement in sports often fosters discipline, teamwork, and leadership skills that translate to other parts of their lives. The term‚Äôs connotation can shift depending on context; in some cases, it‚Äôs used affectionately to acknowledge someone‚Äôs athletic talent and work ethic, rather than as a limiting label.

Write a pros and cons list of apple products in the style of a 19th century novelist.

output:
Write a pros and cons list of apple products in the style of a 19th century novelist.

Dear reader, let us pause in our perusal of dusty tomes and the quiet hum of the parlor to turn our gaze upon a curious modern marvel: the products of the Apple company. These sleek, polished devices have insinuated themselves into the lives of gentlefolk and artisans alike, blending utility with a grace that would make a classical sculptor‚Äôs heart stir. Yet like any complex character in a novel, they bear both virtues and vices‚Äîqualities that enchant and frustrate in equal measure. Let us dissect them with the care of a scholar examining a rare manuscript.

### The Virtues: A Tapestry of Craft and Utility
1. **Artisanal Precision That Dances in the Hand**  
To hold an Apple device is to feel the weight of deliberate craftsmanship. Its edges are smoothed to a finish softer than a well-worn leather glove; its glass surface glows with a clarity that rivals a pane of Venetian crystal; its symmetry is so perfect it might have been forged by the hand of a divine watchmaker. A gentleman might run his thumb along the back of an iPad and marvel at how it balances between utility and beauty‚Äîno rough edges, no extraneous knobs, just a form that serves its function without fanfare. It is the sort of object that makes one appreciate the difference between a tool and a work of art.

2. **A Harmonious Ecosystem of Interlocking Wonders**  
These devices do not stand alone, but rather form a symphony of utility. A note jotted on an iPhone appears instantly on a MacBook, as if carried by a fleet of invisible messengers. A photograph taken on an iPad is stored safely in a ‚Äúcloud‚Äù‚Äîa nebulous but reliable vault‚Äîready to be printed or shared at a moment‚Äôs notice. Compare this to the chaos of a study cluttered with quills, inkwells, ledgers, and separate boxes for correspondence: here, one set of tools works in perfect concert, reducing the friction of daily life to a whisper. It is the dream of every efficient gentleman, realized in polished metal and glass.

3. **Access to a World of Knowledge and Connection**  
For those of us who once relied on traveling libraries and slow-moving stagecoach letters, the power of these devices is nothing short of revolutionary. An iPhone can hold more books than the grandest private library in London, allowing a farmer in the countryside to read Shakespeare or Darwin at his leisure. A MacBook lets one correspond with a cousin in Bombay as easily as chatting with a neighbor over the garden fence. These devices tear down the walls of distance and privilege, placing the world‚Äôs wisdom and warmth within reach of anyone with the means to hold one.

4. **Understated Luxury as a Marker of Discernment**  
To own an Apple product is to signal a taste for quality over ostentation. Unlike a gaudy gold watch or a carriage with polished brass trim, these devices speak of quiet refinement. They do not shout their value; they whisper it, through their smooth finish, their seamless function, their refusal to succumb to the vulgarity of excess. A lady might carry an iPhone in her reticule, and her peers would recognize it as a sign that she is a person of discernment‚Äîsomeone who values substance over show.

### The Vices: Shadows Lurking Behind the Shine
1. **Prohibitive Cost That Excludes the Working Class**  
Alas, these wonders are not for all. A laborer in Manchester might work three months to earn enough for an iPhone, while a gentleman in Mayfair might purchase one as a trifle for his daughter. This creates a chasm between those who can partake in modern innovation and those who cannot. A weaver who spends his days at a loom will never know the joy of holding a library in his hand, nor the ease of corresponding with a sibling in America. It is a bitter truth that these devices, which promise to connect the world, only widen the gap between the haves and the have-nots.

2. **Obsolescence That Fades Like a Summer Rose**  
The tragedy of these devices is their fleeting nature. No sooner have you grown accustomed to the weight of your MacBook, no sooner have you mastered its many functions, than a newer model is announced. Your once-prized possession becomes a relic, its features deemed outdated, its value diminished. Compare this to my grandfather‚Äôs oak desk, which has served three generations of our family, its surface worn smooth by years of writing but still sturdy and reliable. Apple products are like mayflies‚Äîbeautiful but ephemeral, here one season and forgotten the next.

3. **The Erosion of Handcraft and Human Touch**  
I fear these devices are slowly eroding the skills that make us human. Why learn to write a graceful hand with a quill when you can tap out words on a screen? Why memorize a poem by heart when you can look it up in an instant? The tactile joy of turning a book‚Äôs pages, the satisfaction of solving a mathematical problem with pencil and paper, the warmth of a handwritten letter‚Äîthese things are being replaced by cold, impersonal interactions with glass and metal. We risk losing the art of doing things slowly, deliberately, with our own two hands.

4. **Isolation in the Midst of Connection**  
Paradoxically, these devices that promise to bring us closer often drive us apart. I have attended dinners where guests sit side by side, their eyes fixed on their iPhones, exchanging not a word of conversation, not a smile, not a shared story. Once, such an evening would have been filled with laughter, with tales of adventure, with the give-and-take of human connection. Now, it is a room full of silent strangers, each lost in their own private world. The glow of the screen replaces the warmth of a fireside chat, and we are left with a hollow sort of connection‚Äîpresent in body, but absent in spirit.

5. **Fragility That Breaks the Heart**  
These devices are delicate things. Drop an iPhone, and its glass screen shatters like a fallen teacup. Spill a drop of coffee on a MacBook, and it may never work again. Unlike a leather-bound book or a wooden chair, which can be mended with glue and patience, these devices require specialized care and expensive repairs. A gentleman who drops his device might spend weeks without it, cut off from his correspondence and his books. It is a fragile dependence, one that leaves us vulnerable to the smallest mishap.

In the end, Apple products are like any great invention: they are a double-edged sword. They bring us beauty, utility, and connection, but they also carry with them inequality, obsolescence, and the loss of human touch. As we embrace these modern wonders, let us not forget to hold dear the things that make us truly human‚Äîthe feel of a book in our hands, the sound of a friend‚Äôs laughter, the joy of doing things slowly and deliberately. For in the end, it is not the devices we own that define us, but the lives we live with them.

For engineers, architects, EOD specialists, game developers, and innovators everywhere, testing ideas in the physical world often comes with huge barriers: cost, safety, scalability. You can‚Äôt just set off bombs in a downtown lab to test blast-resistant materials, right? You can‚Äôt ask a bomb disposal team to practice defusing an IED in a crowded mall without putting lives on the line. And you certainly can‚Äôt build 10 different bridge prototypes to see which one holds up in a category 5 hurricane‚Äîunless you‚Äôve got an unlimited budget and a lot of patience.

That‚Äôs why we built Simulatech‚Äîyour all-in-one platform for hyper-realistic physics simulations that let you test, iterate, and perfect your ideas without ever stepping into the danger zone or breaking the bank.

Let‚Äôs talk about what Simulatech can do for you:

üí£ **EOD & Defense: Train smarter, keep heroes safe**  
Bomb disposal teams and defense engineers face some of the highest-stakes testing scenarios imaginable. With Simulatech, you can simulate every detail of a detonation: adjust bomb type (IED, pipe bomb, military-grade explosive ordnance), detonation force, environmental factors (rain, wind, concrete vs. wood structures), and even the placement of bystanders to replicate real-world chaos. Test new protective gear to see how it absorbs blast waves, practice defusal protocols in virtual environments that mirror subway stations, office buildings, or rural fields‚Äîall without any risk to human life. A recent user, the UK‚Äôs National Bomb Disposal Unit, told us that Simulatech cut their training time by 25% and helped them refine their response protocols to reduce potential casualties by 40% in simulated high-risk scenarios. No more guessing how a bomb‚Äôs blast will interact with a crowded space‚Äîyou can see it, measure it, and adjust your strategy before you ever face the real thing.

üèóÔ∏è **Civil Engineering: Build stronger, waste less**  
Architects and structural engineers know that one miscalculation can lead to catastrophic failure. With Simulatech, you can test bridge designs under earthquake loads, simulate flood impacts on coastal sea walls, or even see how a new skyscraper facade holds up against a car bomb detonation. No more wasting tons of concrete and steel on physical prototypes that end up in a landfill. BlastShield Innovations, a leading provider of blast-resistant materials, used Simulatech to run 50+ simulations in 3 days‚Äîadjusting bomb size, detonation distance, and concrete mix ratios‚Äîto develop a material that‚Äôs 30% more effective and 20% cheaper than their original design. That‚Äôs weeks of work saved, and tons of waste kept out of the environment. For urban planners, Simulatech even lets you simulate crowd flow during emergencies, ensuring that evacuation routes are optimized to get people to safety as quickly as possible.

üéÆ **Game Development: Create worlds that feel real**  
Game developers spend hundreds of hours coding custom physics to make their worlds feel immersive‚Äîbut what if you could skip the tedious coding and plug in hyper-realistic physics directly into your engine? Simulatech integrates seamlessly with Unity and Unreal, letting you simulate grenade blasts that send debris flying in accurate trajectories, car crashes that crumple exactly as they would in real life, or weather systems that interact with every object in your open world. Indie studio Apocalypse Games used Simulatech to build their post-apocalyptic RPG, and they said it cut their development time by 30%‚Äîall while making their game‚Äôs physics so authentic that players are raving about how ‚Äúevery explosion feels like it‚Äôs happening right next to you.‚Äù Even tabletop game designers can use Simulatech to test the physics of custom dice or mechanical game pieces, ensuring that every roll and movement feels fair and realistic.

üåç **Renewable Energy: Optimize for a sustainable future**  
Testing renewable energy infrastructure comes with its own set of challenges‚Äîyou can‚Äôt just wait for a hurricane to test your wind turbine blades. With Simulatech, you can simulate extreme wind speeds, hailstorms, and even ice buildup on solar panels to optimize designs for durability and efficiency. A team at GreenWave Energy used Simulatech to adjust the angle and material of their wind turbine blades, resulting in a 15% increase in energy output in high-wind conditions. And because they didn‚Äôt have to build 5 physical prototypes, they saved over $100k in materials and labor. For hydroelectric dam designers, Simulatech lets you simulate flood surges and sediment buildup, ensuring that dams are built to last for decades without endangering nearby communities.

But Simulatech isn‚Äôt just for big teams or high-stakes industries. Whether you‚Äôre a student testing a simple pulley system, a hobbyist building a drone, or a startup innovating a new medical device, our intuitive drag-and-drop interface makes it easy to build simulations in minutes‚Äîno PhD in physics required. For advanced users, we offer full access to our scripting tools and API, so you can customize every variable to fit your exact needs. Plus, our cloud-based platform lets your team collaborate in real time, no matter where you are in the world‚Äîso your engineer in Tokyo, your designer in Berlin, and your project manager in New York can all tweak the same simulation, leave comments, and iterate together.

Ready to stop guessing and start simulating? We‚Äôre giving new users a 14-day free trial with unlimited access to our core simulation libraries, real-time collaboration tools, and 24/7 customer support. No credit card required, no strings attached.

input.content: Your response should be divided into at least 4 sections, with each section starting with "Section X" (where X is 1, 2, 3, 4). The entire response should have at least 100 sentences.
Write a story about a man who is in love with a woman who has turrets.

output:
Section 1: The First Encounter in the Stacked Shelves
Leo had worked at Maplewood Public Library for three years, and he thought he knew every regular by name‚ÄîMr. Henderson who read westerns every Wednesday, Mrs. Lopez who brought her cat in a carrier to browse children‚Äôs books, the teens who huddled in the back with their laptops. But one rainy Tuesday in April, a new face walked through the door, and Leo‚Äôs world shifted a little. She was in her mid-twenties, with curly auburn hair tied back in a messy bun, wearing a faded denim jacket covered in patches of her favorite bands. She hesitated at the entrance for a moment, her left eye blinking rapidly three times in a row before she took a step forward. Leo was behind the front desk, reshelving returned DVDs, when he heard her throat clear loudly, followed by a sharp, involuntary ‚ÄúHey!‚Äù that made a few heads turn. He looked up, expecting to see her talking to someone, but she was alone, her cheeks flushing pink as she mouthed an apology to the nearby patrons. Leo smiled gently, hoping to put her at ease, and she nodded in return before heading toward the poetry section. For the rest of the afternoon, Leo found himself glancing over at her every few minutes. He noticed her tics: the way her right hand would jerk up to touch her earlobe every few seconds, the occasional snort that escaped her when she laughed at a poem, the sudden, quiet ‚ÄúBoo!‚Äù that she would mumble under her breath without realizing it. He didn‚Äôt find them distracting; if anything, they made her feel more human, more real than the polished, put-together people who often wandered through the library. When she came up to check out a collection of Mary Oliver poems, her voice was soft, but her left foot tapped rapidly against the floor as she spoke. ‚ÄúDo you have any other recommendations?‚Äù she asked, her eye blinking twice before she finished the sentence. Leo thought for a moment, then grabbed a copy of Rumi‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Essential Rumi‚Äù from the display beside the desk. ‚ÄúThis one‚Äôs my favorite,‚Äù he said, handing it to her. ‚ÄúThe poems feel like they‚Äôre talking directly to the parts of you that no one else sees.‚Äù She took the book, her fingers brushing his, and her tic made her hand jerk slightly, but she didn‚Äôt pull away. ‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù she said, a small smile playing on her lips. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Clara, by the way.‚Äù ‚ÄúLeo,‚Äù he replied, and he found himself wanting to say more, to ask her about her favorite poems, about the patches on her jacket, about the tics that seemed to dance around her like a quiet storm. But she turned to leave, her foot still tapping, and Leo watched her walk out into the rain, already counting the days until he would see her again. He didn‚Äôt know it then, but that rainy Tuesday was the start of something he had never dared to hope for: a love that didn‚Äôt just tolerate the noise of the world, but embraced it.

Section 2: Curiosity Turns to Connection
Clara came back to the library three days later, the Rumi book tucked under her arm, and Leo‚Äôs heart skipped a beat when he saw her. She walked straight to the front desk, her right hand jerking to touch her earlobe as she approached. ‚ÄúThat Rumi book was amazing,‚Äù she said, her voice warm. ‚ÄúI read three poems out loud to my cat last night. She didn‚Äôt seem impressed, but I was.‚Äù Leo laughed, and he noticed that when he laughed, Clara‚Äôs tics softened a little‚Äîher eye blinked only once, her foot stopped tapping for a few seconds. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you liked it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWant to talk about it? There‚Äôs a quiet corner by the window with a couch if you have time.‚Äù Clara hesitated for a moment, her throat clearing twice before she nodded. ‚ÄúYeah, that sounds nice.‚Äù They sat down on the worn leather couch, and Clara opened the Rumi book to a dog-eared page. ‚ÄúThis one,‚Äù she said, pointing to a poem about love and imperfection, ‚Äúit made me think about‚Ä¶ well, about me. About how my tics aren‚Äôt something to hide, but just part of who I am.‚Äù Leo leaned forward, his full attention on her. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been noticing your tics,‚Äù he said, careful to keep his tone gentle, not intrusive. ‚ÄúDo you mind me asking how long you‚Äôve had them?‚Äù Clara took a deep breath, her left hand fidgeting with the hem of her jacket. ‚ÄúSince I was seven,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAt first, it was just eye blinking, but as I got older, more tics started showing up. The throat clearing, the hand jerks, the occasional verbal outbursts. Kids at school used to make fun of me. They called me ‚ÄòTwitchy‚Äô or ‚ÄòWeirdo.‚Äô I stopped going to parties in high school because I was afraid I‚Äôd have a tic episode and everyone would stare.‚Äù Leo‚Äôs chest ached for her. He couldn‚Äôt imagine what it must have been like, growing up feeling like an outsider in your own skin. ‚ÄúThat sounds awful,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo one should have to go through that alone.‚Äù Clara smiled sadly. ‚ÄúI had my mom, at least. She always told me that my tics were just my brain‚Äôs way of singing a song no one else could hear. It sounds silly, but it helped.‚Äù As they talked, Leo learned more about her: she worked at a local bookstore, she loved hiking in the nearby woods, she had a tabby cat named Mabel who slept on her pillow every night. He also learned that her tics got worse when she was nervous or stressed, and better when she was doing something she loved, like reading poetry or gardening. One afternoon, a man in a suit came up to the front desk while Clara was talking to Leo. He glared at her when she let out a sudden ‚ÄúWhoa!‚Äù and said, ‚ÄúCan you please control yourself? This is a library, not a playground.‚Äù Clara‚Äôs face turned bright red, and she started apologizing profusely, her eye blinking so rapidly it looked like she was crying. Leo stood up, his voice firm but calm. ‚ÄúSir, she can‚Äôt control that. Tourette syndrome is a neurological condition, not a choice. If you‚Äôre uncomfortable, you can find another section to read in, but please don‚Äôt speak to her like that.‚Äù The man huffed and walked away, and Leo turned back to Clara, who was still fidgeting with her jacket. ‚ÄúThank you,‚Äù she said, her voice shaky. ‚ÄúNo one‚Äôs ever done that for me before.‚Äù Leo sat down beside her and put a hand on her shoulder. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to apologize for being yourself,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYour tics don‚Äôt make you any less worthy of respect. Or of being seen.‚Äù In that moment, Leo knew that his feelings for Clara were more than just curiosity. He liked her‚Äîliked her laugh, her love of poetry, her way of seeing the world through a lens of quiet wonder. And he didn‚Äôt care about her tics. If anything, they made her more beautiful to him, because they were a part of the brave, kind, amazing woman sitting beside him.

Section 3: The First Date and the Quiet Courage of Being Seen
A week after the incident with the man in the suit, Leo worked up the courage to ask Clara out on a date. He was nervous‚Äîmore nervous than he had been since his first job interview‚Äîand he practiced the question in the mirror at home ten times before he said it. ‚ÄúWould you like to go to that new coffee shop on Main Street this Saturday?‚Äù he asked, his hands sweating as he waited for her answer. Clara‚Äôs eye blinked twice, and she let out a small ‚ÄúYesss!‚Äù that was half tic, half genuine excitement. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd love to,‚Äù she said, grinning. On Saturday morning, Leo arrived at the coffee shop twenty minutes early, pacing back and forth outside until he saw Clara walking down the street. She was wearing a yellow sundress that made her auburn hair glow, and her right hand was jerking to touch her earlobe every few steps. input.content: Your entire response must contain at least 1200 words.
Write an essay on the differences between Sunni and Shi'a Muslims.

output:
# The Divide and Unity: Exploring the Differences Between Sunni and Shi‚Äôa Muslims  

Islam, one of the world‚Äôs largest religions, is often misperceived as a monolithic faith, but its 1.9 billion adherents are split into two major branches‚ÄîSunni and Shi‚Äôa‚Äîwhose differences are rooted in centuries-old debates over leadership, historical memory, and religious interpretation. While sectarian tensions have occasionally erupted into violence in modern times, these divisions do not stem from a rejection of core Islamic tenets: both groups unwaveringly believe in the oneness of God (tawhid), the authority of the Quran, and the prophethood of Muhammad. Instead, their rift began as a dispute over who should succeed the Prophet after his death in 632 CE, and it has since expanded into distinct theological, legal, and cultural identities. To fully grasp the differences between Sunni and Shi‚Äôa Muslims, one must examine their historical origins, theological divergences, legal traditions, religious practices, communal structures, and political perspectives, while also acknowledging the shared beliefs that bind them as members of the global Islamic umma (community).  

## Historical Origins: The Succession Crisis and the Martyrdom of Karbala  

The split between Sunni and Shi‚Äôa Muslims originated in the immediate aftermath of Muhammad‚Äôs death. The Prophet left no explicit instructions regarding his successor, sparking a fierce debate within the early Muslim community. The majority, who would later be called Sunni (from ‚ÄúAhl al-Sunnah wa al-Jama‚Äôah,‚Äù or ‚ÄúPeople of the Tradition and Community‚Äù), argued that the leader of the umma should be elected through shura (consultation) by the most pious and respected members of the community. They supported Abu Bakr, a close companion of Muhammad and father-in-law, who was chosen as the first caliph (successor) in a gathering at the Saqifa of Banu Sa‚Äôida. Sunni tradition frames Abu Bakr and the subsequent Rashidun (‚ÄúRightly Guided‚Äù) caliphs‚ÄîUmar, Uthman, and Ali‚Äîas righteous leaders who upheld the Prophet‚Äôs legacy.  

The minority, who became known as Shi‚Äôa (from ‚ÄúShi‚Äôat Ali,‚Äù or ‚ÄúPartisans of Ali‚Äù), rejected the election of Abu Bakr. They believed Muhammad had explicitly designated his cousin and son-in-law, Ali ibn Abi Talib, as his heir during a sermon at Ghadir Khumm shortly before his death. Ali was not only Muhammad‚Äôs blood relative but also his closest confidant, having married the Prophet‚Äôs daughter Fatima. Shi‚Äôa argued that leadership should remain within the Prophet‚Äôs family, as only descendants of Ali and Fatima could embody the spiritual and political authority necessary to guide the umma.  

The dispute escalated into open conflict in the mid-7th century. After the assassination of the third caliph, Uthman, in 656 CE, Ali was finally elected caliph, but his rule was challenged by Mu‚Äôawiya, the governor of Syria and a relative of Uthman. The Battle of Siffin (657 CE) between Ali‚Äôs forces and Mu‚Äôawiya‚Äôs army ended in a controversial arbitration agreement, which split Ali‚Äôs supporters into factions. A group of radical dissidents known as the Kharijites assassinated Ali in 661 CE, clearing the way for Mu‚Äôawiya to establish the Umayyad dynasty.  

The defining moment for Shi‚Äôa identity came in 680 CE, when Ali‚Äôs son Hussein refused to pledge allegiance to Mu‚Äôawiya‚Äôs son, Yazid, a tyrannical ruler who had seized power through force. Hussein and a small band of family members and supporters traveled to Kufa (in modern-day Iraq) to rally opposition, but they were ambushed by Yazid‚Äôs army at Karbala. Outnumbered and cut off from water, Hussein and his companions were brutally killed. For Shi‚Äôa Muslims, the martyrdom of Hussein symbolizes resistance against injustice and oppression, and it remains the emotional core of their identity. Karbala is not just a historical event but a moral parable: Hussein‚Äôs willingness to die rather than submit to tyranny is seen as a model for all Muslims to stand up against wrongdoing. Sunni tradition, by contrast, frames the Rashidun caliphs as the legitimate leaders of the early umma, with Ali recognized as the fourth and final Rashidun caliph, but without the centrality of Karbala to their historical memory.  

## Theological Divergences: Imamate, Infallibility, and Authority  

The historical split between Sunni and Shi‚Äôa has evolved into profound theological differences, most notably over the concept of leadership. For Shi‚Äôa, the Imamate is a divinely ordained institution: Imams are infallible (ma‚Äôsum) leaders descended from Ali and Fatima, chosen by God to guide the community. Unlike Sunni caliphs, who are elected by the community, Shi‚Äôa Imams are not subject to human error, as they are directly guided by divine inspiration.  

The number of Imams varies among Shi‚Äôa subgroups. Twelvers, the largest Shi‚Äôa community (comprising 85% of all Shi‚Äôa Muslims), believe in 12 Imams. The 12th Imam, Muhammad al-Mahdi, disappeared in 874 CE and is believed to be in a state of occultation (ghayba), where he remains hidden from the world but continues to guide the community through senior religious scholars. Twelvers await his return as the Mahdi, a messianic figure who will defeat evil and establish universal justice at the end of time. Ismailis, a smaller Shi‚Äôa branch, recognize seven Imams, with the seventh Imam, Ismail, having gone into occultation; his descendants, including the current Aga Khan IV, serve as living Imams who lead the community spiritually and temporally. Zaydis, another minority Shi‚Äôa group, believe Imams are descendants of Ali but not necessarily infallible, and they recognize Zayd ibn Ali as their fifth Imam.  

For Sunni Muslims, the caliphate is a political and religious institution based on community consensus. Sunni reject the idea of divinely appointed, infallible Imams, arguing that only the Prophet Muhammad was infallible. They believe the caliph should be a pious, qualified leader elected by the umma, tasked with upholding Islamic law (sharia) and preserving the unity of the community. Sunni tradition holds all of Muhammad‚Äôs companions (Sahaba) in high regard, particularly the Rashidun caliphs, whom they view as righteous successors. Shi‚Äôa, by contrast, are critical of some companions‚Äîincluding Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman‚Äîwhom they accuse of usurping Ali‚Äôs rightful position. They believe only Ali and his descendants (the Imams) are the legitimate interpreters of Islamic tradition.  

Another theological difference is the practice of taqiyya, which allows Shi‚Äôa Muslims to conceal their faith if they face persecution. This practice developed as a survival strategy during centuries of oppression by Sunni rulers, and it is enshrined in Shi‚Äôa jurisprudence. While Sunni scholars may allow taqiyya in extreme cases of danger, it is not a central tenet of Sunni identity, nor is it emphasized in their religious teachings.  

## Legal and Jurisprudential Traditions  

Sunni and Shi‚Äôa Muslims also differ in their approaches to Islamic law and jurisprudence. Sunni Islam has four major schools of thought: Hanafi, Maliki, Shafi‚Äôi, and Hanbali. Each school is based on the same primary sources‚Äîthe Quran, the Sunnah (the Prophet‚Äôs sayings and actions), ijma (consensus of scholars), and qiyas (analogical reasoning)‚Äîbut they vary in how they prioritize and interpret these sources. For example, the Hanafi school, the largest Sunni school, places greater emphasis on reason and analogy, while the Hanbali school, the most conservative, relies almost exclusively on the Quran and Sunnah.  

Shi‚Äôa Islam has its own legal traditions, the most prominent being the Ja‚Äôfari school, followed by Twelvers. Like Sunni schools, the Ja‚Äôfari school uses the Quran and Sunnah as primary sources, but it also incorporates the teachings and sayings of the Imams, whom Shi‚Äôa believe were infallible interpreters of divine law. Shi‚Äôa jurisprudence also emphasizes aql (reason) as a source of law, allowing scholars to derive rulings from existing sources to address modern issues. One notable difference between Sunni and Shi‚Äôa law is the practice of mut‚Äôah, a temporary marriage contract that specifies a duration and dowry. Shi‚Äôa jurists allow mut‚Äôah as a way to regulate consensual relationships, particularly in situations where permanent marriage is not feasible. Sunni jurists, however, prohibit mut‚Äôah, arguing that it was abrogated by the Prophet in the later years of his life.  

Ritual practices also differ slightly. During daily prayers (salat), Sunni Muslims fold their hands over their chests, while Shi‚Äôa keep their hands at their sides. Shi‚Äôa also use a small clay tablet (muhra) from Karbala to place their forehead on during prayer, symbolizing their connection to Hussein‚Äôs martyrdom. Additionally, Shi‚Äôa combine the afternoon (dhuhr) and late afternoon (asr) prayers, as well as the sunset (maghrib) and evening (isha) prayers, when traveling, a practice that is optional for Sunni Muslims.  

## Religious Practices and Rituals: Mourning, Festivals, and Devotion

input.content: Your response must contain 3 sections, mark the beginning of each section with SECTION X.
Write a short, funny story about a man named Harry with a pet dog.

output:
### SECTION 1: The Brunch That Never Was
Harry had spent three hours perfecting his "impressive neighbor brunch": sourdough avocado toast with smoked salmon, a perfectly poached egg, and a dusting of everything bagel seasoning that he‚Äôd driven 20 minutes to buy. His co-conspirator (read: accidental saboteur) was Muffin, a 100-pound Great Dane with the soul of a lap dog and a name he‚Äôd gotten after Harry lost a bet to his cousin.

‚ÄúMuffin,‚Äù Harry said, pointing a wooden spoon at the dog, who was staring at the toast like it was the Holy Grail. ‚ÄúThis is for Clara. The new neighbor. The one who likes hiking and doesn‚Äôt think my collection of vintage video games is weird. You will not touch it. Understand?‚Äù

Muffin tilted his head, blinked his big brown eyes, and then‚Äîwhen Harry turned to grab a linen napkin‚Äîsnatched the entire plate off the counter in his jaws. By the time Harry spun around, half the toast was gone, seasoning dusted Muffin‚Äôs snout like a tiny, salty snowstorm, and his tail had knocked over a pitcher of orange juice, which was now seeping into the kitchen rug.

‚ÄúMUFFIN!‚Äù Harry yelped. The dog dropped the plate (it clattered, but miraculously didn‚Äôt break) and trotted to the couch, where he curled up with a satisfied huff, seasoning still clinging to his nose. Harry stared at the mess, then at Muffin, and wondered if he should just move to a different state.

### SECTION 2: The Unplanned Icebreaker
The doorbell rang 90 seconds later.

Harry froze. Clara was early. He scrambled to block the kitchen with his body, wiping seasoning off his own shirt (he‚Äôd gotten some on himself while yelling) and hoping Muffin would stay hidden. No such luck. The Great Dane bounded over, tail wagging so hard his whole body shook, and the seasoning on his nose flaked off onto Clara‚Äôs white canvas shoe.

Clara blinked. Then she snickered. ‚ÄúIs that‚Ä¶ everything bagel seasoning? Did your dog just commit brunch theft?‚Äù

Harry‚Äôs face burned. ‚ÄúI can explain. His name is Muffin, I lost a bet, and he‚Äôs got the self-control of a toddler in a candy store.‚Äù

Muffin, apparently sensing he was the topic of conversation, trotted back to his bed and dragged out his favorite toy: a tiny, bedraggled stuffed unicorn that was half the size of his paw. He dropped it at Clara‚Äôs feet, then sat back on his haunches, looking proud.

Clara picked up the unicorn, her grin widening. ‚ÄúAww. He‚Äôs a gentle giant with a tiny, sparkly heart. I love him already.‚Äù

Harry stared. He‚Äôd spent three hours on toast, and Muffin had won her over in 30 seconds with stolen food and a stuffed toy.

### SECTION 3: Pizza, Pepperoni, and Wingman Glory
Harry gave up on the fancy brunch. He ordered a large pepperoni pizza, and when it arrived, Muffin stole a whole slice right out of the box before Harry could even set it down.

‚ÄúHey!‚Äù Harry protested, reaching for the slice. Muffin dodged, and the pizza flew into Clara‚Äôs lap‚Äîshe caught it mid-air, then laughed so hard she snort-laughed.

They ended up sitting on the floor, sharing pizza (Muffin got three slices, Harry got one, Clara got two) and watching Muffin carry his stuffed unicorn around like a trophy. When Clara left an hour later, she said, ‚ÄúTell Muffin I‚Äôll bring him a new unicorn tomorrow. The sparkly kind.‚Äù

Harry looked at Muffin, who was passed out on the couch with a pizza crust stuck to his cheek, and shook his head. ‚ÄúYou know,‚Äù he said to the dog, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre the worst wingman I‚Äôve ever had. But also the best.‚Äù

Muffin snored. The crust fell off his cheek. Harry smiled, then grabbed the last leftover pizza crust and set it on Muffin‚Äôs belly. Some bets, he realized, were worth losing.

Kelly, as well as high-profile celebrities like Mel Gibson and Mischa Barton. She is the founder of Bloom Firm and a frequent legal commentator, focusing on gender equality and victim advocacy.
